description: The Service Operation intermediate module focuses on the principles, processes, operational activities and functions that enable organizations and individuals to successfully manage how their products and services perform. The SO module focuses on the coordination and execution of activities that enable the ongoing management and operation of the products or services developed or implemented during the service strategy, design and transition phases of the IT Service Lifecycle as well as any technology and support resources that are used to deliver them.

episodes.title: Introduction to ITIL Intermediate
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:06.635
[NOISE] Hi, and welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:06.635 --> 00:00:08.139
My name is Jo Peacock and

3
00:00:08.139 --> 00:00:13.190
I'm going to be taking you through
an introduction to your ITIL Intermediate.

4
00:00:14.320 --> 00:00:18.250
So let's take a look then at
our first slide here coming up.

5
00:00:18.250 --> 00:00:22.250
And we have our introduction
to our intermediate class and

6
00:00:22.250 --> 00:00:27.730
exactly what content is going to be found
in this upcoming intermediate class.

7
00:00:27.730 --> 00:00:32.340
You will see what we will cover
is an introduction to the class,

8
00:00:32.340 --> 00:00:37.100
followed by the principles and
the processes of the life cycle phase.

9
00:00:37.100 --> 00:00:40.550
Then we'll take a look at organizing for
that life cycle phase.

10
00:00:40.550 --> 00:00:43.255
And also the technology considerations,

11
00:00:43.255 --> 00:00:47.998
especially those that we need when
we're implementing the phase itself.

12
00:00:47.998 --> 00:00:52.421
Then we'll take a look at the challenges
and critical success factors and

13
00:00:52.421 --> 00:00:56.999
all of the risks that are associated
with that particular life cycle phase.

14
00:00:56.999 --> 00:01:00.778
And most importantly, of course for
you, is that preparation for

15
00:01:00.778 --> 00:01:04.980
the exam that's going to be coming up
when you have completed your class.

16
00:01:05.980 --> 00:01:10.497
So let me take a look now then at how
we're going to approach this particular

17
00:01:10.497 --> 00:01:11.869
intermediate class.

18
00:01:13.981 --> 00:01:17.230
We're going to be doing
some presentation work.

19
00:01:17.230 --> 00:01:22.280
Obviously, you're going to be watching us
on screen both myself and my colleagues.

20
00:01:22.280 --> 00:01:27.110
And we're going to be taking you through
the course materials for the class.

21
00:01:27.110 --> 00:01:31.300
And then there are going to be some
discussions and some exercises.

22
00:01:31.300 --> 00:01:35.720
That are going to be based
primarily in our chat rooms, and

23
00:01:35.720 --> 00:01:38.140
also in our forums as well.

24
00:01:38.140 --> 00:01:42.214
And we're also available if you want
undertake any of the assessments,

25
00:01:42.214 --> 00:01:45.568
then please feel free to come
back to us through the forums.

26
00:01:45.568 --> 00:01:49.270
And we will be able to help
you out in any way we can.

27
00:01:49.270 --> 00:01:51.950
Also provided in the course
material which is available for

28
00:01:51.950 --> 00:01:57.390
you to download are mock tests or
exams, if you prefer to use that word.

29
00:01:57.390 --> 00:02:02.720
And we will be conducting a run
through of that mock exam for you.

30
00:02:04.530 --> 00:02:08.540
So where are we then at
ITIL intermediate level.

31
00:02:08.540 --> 00:02:15.090
Well you'll see in using Blooms Taxonomy
that we are actually at level 4 analyzing.

32
00:02:15.090 --> 00:02:19.390
In other words, we've done foundation
level, we've done the remembering and

33
00:02:19.390 --> 00:02:23.470
understanding of those
concepts within ITIL.

34
00:02:23.470 --> 00:02:28.198
And we're actually moving through applying
those concepts to analyzing those

35
00:02:28.198 --> 00:02:28.911
concepts.

36
00:02:28.911 --> 00:02:33.325
And being able to apply
the ITIL processes and

37
00:02:33.325 --> 00:02:39.957
also the concepts at a real world level,
in a real world situation.

38
00:02:39.957 --> 00:02:42.590
Okay, so where does ITIL come from then?

39
00:02:42.590 --> 00:02:45.080
Well let me give you a little
bit of a background.

40
00:02:45.080 --> 00:02:48.330
It's actually owned by
a company called Axelos.

41
00:02:48.330 --> 00:02:54.110
And it was first published in
the mid 1980s by the UK government.

42
00:02:54.110 --> 00:03:01.020
And the office of government commerce
owned ITL for a very, very long time.

43
00:03:01.020 --> 00:03:04.509
And we developed ITIL right
the way back from the 1980s.

44
00:03:05.630 --> 00:03:14.147
Through its version 2 in the mid 1990s
to version 3 which was released in 2007.

45
00:03:14.147 --> 00:03:19.006
And then there was an update
to version 3 in 2011 which is

46
00:03:19.006 --> 00:03:22.450
exactly where we are right now.

47
00:03:22.450 --> 00:03:26.660
It is copyright, it is trademark
protected, it's a framework for

48
00:03:26.660 --> 00:03:28.670
managing services.

49
00:03:28.670 --> 00:03:30.960
And as such it is a flexible framework,

50
00:03:30.960 --> 00:03:36.730
a framework that we would expect any
organization to adopt as a framework.

51
00:03:36.730 --> 00:03:41.126
But they're to adapt it
to suit your needs, okay?

52
00:03:41.126 --> 00:03:44.898
ITIL was born right
away back in the 1990s,

53
00:03:44.898 --> 00:03:49.519
out of a desire to be able to
demonstrate value for money and

54
00:03:49.519 --> 00:03:54.068
efficiency for
the use of taxpayers money within the UK.

55
00:03:54.068 --> 00:03:58.650
Way back in the 1980s these things
started appearing on desks.

56
00:03:58.650 --> 00:04:04.002
And quite frankly we didn't know
how to manage these in an unbiased,

57
00:04:04.002 --> 00:04:10.109
in an impartial, and in an efficient and
effective way and thus ITIL was born.

58
00:04:10.109 --> 00:04:14.661
And ITIL was born from a group of
industry experts that went out into

59
00:04:14.661 --> 00:04:19.297
the big wide world and analyzed
various organizations from various

60
00:04:19.297 --> 00:04:22.971
different industry sectors,
not just government.

61
00:04:22.971 --> 00:04:27.633
But we're talking finance,
we're talking retail, etc, and

62
00:04:27.633 --> 00:04:31.230
they came back with
a set of best practices.

63
00:04:31.230 --> 00:04:36.176
Best practices that they
observed in the real world for

64
00:04:36.176 --> 00:04:40.488
managing our IT services and
thus we have ITIL.

65
00:04:40.488 --> 00:04:43.207
As I've already said we have
had subsequent revisions.

66
00:04:43.207 --> 00:04:46.787
And now we are up to version 3, 2011.

67
00:04:46.787 --> 00:04:51.363
So we welcome the understanding that

68
00:04:51.363 --> 00:04:56.240
we have a life to every single service.

69
00:04:57.500 --> 00:05:00.298
And we start off with
a concept in Service Strategy.

70
00:05:00.298 --> 00:05:05.080
And there we take that concept and
we design it.

71
00:05:05.080 --> 00:05:09.890
And then we develop it, and
we deploy it as a service into

72
00:05:09.890 --> 00:05:14.520
a live environment, which is where
we operate and where we maintain it.

73
00:05:14.520 --> 00:05:19.360
And we continually seek to
ensure that we are aligned with

74
00:05:19.360 --> 00:05:22.230
the needs of the organization in CSI.

75
00:05:24.960 --> 00:05:29.040
So you're attending this class
because you probably want

76
00:05:29.040 --> 00:05:33.040
to achieve an ITIL
intermediate qualification.

77
00:05:34.180 --> 00:05:38.509
So you can see that if we were to
start off right at the very, very top,

78
00:05:38.509 --> 00:05:40.011
you'll see where I am.

79
00:05:40.011 --> 00:05:46.560
I am an accredited ITIL trainer working
with an accredited training organization.

80
00:05:46.560 --> 00:05:50.491
I'm also an accredited examiner and
and the proctor or

81
00:05:50.491 --> 00:05:52.720
invigilator for these exams.

82
00:05:52.720 --> 00:05:58.320
And work very, very closely with
the official ITIL accreditor and

83
00:05:58.320 --> 00:06:01.829
also AXELOS who owns the ITIL copyright.

84
00:06:01.829 --> 00:06:06.492
Now in terms of ITIL, where can you
go with your qualification level?

85
00:06:06.492 --> 00:06:10.045
Well we start off with ITIL Foundation,
and

86
00:06:10.045 --> 00:06:15.040
ITIL Foundation would traditionally
be a three day classroom

87
00:06:15.040 --> 00:06:20.050
experience where we learn
the foundations of ITIL.

88
00:06:20.050 --> 00:06:23.809
We learn all the terminology and all
of the definitions to that terminology.

89
00:06:23.809 --> 00:06:28.900
There's roughly around about 75 that we
learn within the ITIL Foundation class.

90
00:06:28.900 --> 00:06:33.820
And then as we move through, we can
either take an ITIL practitioner class,

91
00:06:33.820 --> 00:06:36.710
which can be taken at any point in time

92
00:06:36.710 --> 00:06:40.820
throughout the progression
of your career within ITIL.

93
00:06:40.820 --> 00:06:45.330
Because ITIL practitioner focuses
on the implementation of ITIL.

94
00:06:45.330 --> 00:06:50.474
Okay, whereas if we take a look
at a more advanced intermediate

95
00:06:50.474 --> 00:06:54.851
classes you are at this
moment In a Lifecycle module.

96
00:06:54.851 --> 00:06:59.529
And there is a Lifecycle modules consist
of service strategy, service design,

97
00:06:59.529 --> 00:07:04.157
service transition, service operation and
continual service improvement.

98
00:07:04.157 --> 00:07:05.550
And that's where we focus,

99
00:07:05.550 --> 00:07:09.330
on those Lifecycles that we've
just looked at previously.

100
00:07:09.330 --> 00:07:14.308
Okay, and on the right hand side
then we have our capability modules.

101
00:07:14.308 --> 00:07:19.515
And these capability modules
really focus on specific

102
00:07:19.515 --> 00:07:27.450
areas within ITIL such as off RCV which
focuses on release control and validation.

103
00:07:27.450 --> 00:07:32.115
And these classes, you will notice that
every single one of these classes has

104
00:07:32.115 --> 00:07:34.430
got a score right beside each one.

105
00:07:34.430 --> 00:07:39.592
So we've got a number two for
ITIL Foundation, and we've got a three for

106
00:07:39.592 --> 00:07:44.510
Lifecycle modules and we've got a four for
our capability modules.

107
00:07:44.510 --> 00:07:49.585
Now what we need to do is
ensure that we have achieved

108
00:07:49.585 --> 00:07:54.779
a minimum of 15 credits at
both either life cycle,

109
00:07:54.779 --> 00:07:57.744
or capability module level.

110
00:07:57.744 --> 00:08:03.043
In order to be able to qualify to sit
the managing across the Lifecycle class,

111
00:08:03.043 --> 00:08:08.665
and therefore, subsequently,
the test that goes along with that class.

112
00:08:08.665 --> 00:08:12.797
So we need to take two from the ITIL
Foundation, that's a prerequisite.

113
00:08:12.797 --> 00:08:17.823
We have to do the foundation, and
then we need to add in another 15 scores

114
00:08:17.823 --> 00:08:22.379
from either as I've said the Lifecycle or
the capability stream.

115
00:08:22.379 --> 00:08:25.484
Now you can interchange,
you can mix and match,

116
00:08:25.484 --> 00:08:29.100
you do not have to stick to one stream or
the other.

117
00:08:29.100 --> 00:08:33.215
Once you've got that 17 in total scores

118
00:08:33.215 --> 00:08:37.165
that are needed to be able to sit
managing across the lifecycle.

119
00:08:37.165 --> 00:08:41.345
You're perfectly able to sit
that Lifecycle class and

120
00:08:41.345 --> 00:08:43.845
to be able to take that test afterwards.

121
00:08:43.845 --> 00:08:48.145
And as soon as you've taken that test
you will be awarded those five credits

122
00:08:48.145 --> 00:08:52.535
which will mean that you
have achieved ITIL expert.

123
00:08:52.535 --> 00:08:57.240
Now ITIL expert is allocated
as soon as you have passed

124
00:08:57.240 --> 00:09:02.510
the managing across the Lifecycle test and
have achieved 22 credits.

125
00:09:02.510 --> 00:09:06.160
Both of those must have happened for
you to achieve ITIL expert.

126
00:09:07.380 --> 00:09:10.741
Now, we have the ITIL
master qualification and

127
00:09:10.741 --> 00:09:14.279
the ITIL master is
a completely different beast.

128
00:09:14.279 --> 00:09:18.910
The ITIL master is a two
year qualification.

129
00:09:18.910 --> 00:09:24.579
And during that two years,
you will be expected to submit various

130
00:09:24.579 --> 00:09:31.190
white papers on specific topics,
within the ITIL qualifications scheme.

131
00:09:31.190 --> 00:09:35.870
So these could be topics
on activities within ITIL.

132
00:09:35.870 --> 00:09:38.830
These could be topics of
processes within ITIL.

133
00:09:38.830 --> 00:09:43.810
These could be topics on implementation
of various aspects of ITIL.

134
00:09:43.810 --> 00:09:46.860
But you will be required to sit
a number of white papers, or

135
00:09:46.860 --> 00:09:51.410
submit a number of white papers
over the period of two years.

136
00:09:51.410 --> 00:09:56.535
At the end of those two years,
once you have submitted the prerequisite

137
00:09:56.535 --> 00:10:01.260
white papers, then you will be
asked to attend a panel interview.

138
00:10:01.260 --> 00:10:06.427
And during that panel interview, you
will be assessed not only on your white

139
00:10:06.427 --> 00:10:11.611
papers but also on your experience
within the IT service management arena.

140
00:10:11.611 --> 00:10:15.514
And at the end of that panel
interview then if successful,

141
00:10:15.514 --> 00:10:18.630
you will be awarded
the status of ITIL master.

142
00:10:20.060 --> 00:10:21.816
So the qualification scheme,

143
00:10:21.816 --> 00:10:25.067
I'm going to take this back
now to blooms taxonomy then.

144
00:10:25.067 --> 00:10:28.877
And just very, very quickly look at
the fact that an ITIL Foundation and

145
00:10:28.877 --> 00:10:32.069
I know that I've already covered
this in a previous slide.

146
00:10:32.069 --> 00:10:36.679
That we just looked at understanding,
understanding the terminology and

147
00:10:36.679 --> 00:10:39.150
the concepts of ITIL Foundation.

148
00:10:39.150 --> 00:10:41.169
And then in the life cycle modules,

149
00:10:41.169 --> 00:10:45.358
we're looking at implementing those
processes contained within ITIL.

150
00:10:45.358 --> 00:10:50.617
And in capability, we're looking
at actually those processes and

151
00:10:50.617 --> 00:10:52.838
managing those processes.

152
00:10:52.838 --> 00:10:57.658
Whereas managing across the life cycle,
this is for senior management.

153
00:10:57.658 --> 00:11:02.406
This is at CIO level and
at senior management level, and

154
00:11:02.406 --> 00:11:05.437
MALC as we like to abbreviate it to,

155
00:11:05.437 --> 00:11:10.475
your concern with leading
IT service management.

156
00:11:10.475 --> 00:11:14.875
So I mentioned, right at the very
beginning of all of this,

157
00:11:14.875 --> 00:11:20.507
that we had a test to go along with every
single life cycle phase and there is.

158
00:11:20.507 --> 00:11:25.621
And we will be conducting a session to
go all over this particular test or

159
00:11:25.621 --> 00:11:30.310
at least a sample of this test just
to give you some preparation for

160
00:11:30.310 --> 00:11:32.960
the actual test itself.

161
00:11:32.960 --> 00:11:38.892
So your test is conducted online,
it's conducted virtually.

162
00:11:38.892 --> 00:11:43.810
It is an eight multiple
choice question test.

163
00:11:43.810 --> 00:11:46.390
It's complex multiple choice.

164
00:11:46.390 --> 00:11:49.440
You get an hour and a half for
this particular test, and

165
00:11:49.440 --> 00:11:51.500
with every single question.

166
00:11:51.500 --> 00:11:58.270
You will be given a scenario, and then
you will be given four possible options,

167
00:11:58.270 --> 00:12:04.680
four possible answers for the question
that is posed along with that scenario.

168
00:12:04.680 --> 00:12:07.805
Get five points for the best fit answer.

169
00:12:07.805 --> 00:12:10.140
Now it mentions up there the most correct.

170
00:12:10.140 --> 00:12:14.287
I always call it the best fit,
because every single question asks,

171
00:12:14.287 --> 00:12:19.300
what is the best answer given
the scenario, and given the question.

172
00:12:19.300 --> 00:12:23.350
Don't be alarmed if you don't see
an answer that you think is 100% correct,

173
00:12:24.870 --> 00:12:29.380
because the question is asking you for
the best fit.

174
00:12:29.380 --> 00:12:32.990
And for that best fit,
you're gonna get 5 points.

175
00:12:32.990 --> 00:12:36.000
For the next best fit,
you're going to get 3.

176
00:12:36.000 --> 00:12:42.674
For the next one, which we consider to be
the least correct, you're gonna get 1.

177
00:12:42.674 --> 00:12:44.940
And for the next one,
you're gonna get a 0.

178
00:12:44.940 --> 00:12:50.712
Now, it mentions up on that slide there
the next one is 0 marks for incorrect.

179
00:12:50.712 --> 00:12:56.490
We like to call that in the industry, us
in the know, we call that the distractor.

180
00:12:56.490 --> 00:13:00.600
And we call that the distractor for
a reason, cuz it distracts.

181
00:13:00.600 --> 00:13:04.103
And quite often what you will
find is with your distractor.

182
00:13:04.103 --> 00:13:09.287
A lot of the words in the terminology that
are taken straight out of the ITIL book,

183
00:13:09.287 --> 00:13:14.168
straight out of the publication and
are input into that zero pointer because

184
00:13:14.168 --> 00:13:17.081
it's there to distract and
it sounds great.

185
00:13:17.081 --> 00:13:22.111
But more often than not,
that distractor has absolutely

186
00:13:22.111 --> 00:13:26.600
no relevance to the scenario or
to the question.

187
00:13:26.600 --> 00:13:29.390
So you have to be incredibly
careful with that.

188
00:13:29.390 --> 00:13:34.322
It's so easy to be distracted,
you have to get 28

189
00:13:34.322 --> 00:13:39.138
out of a possible 40 in
order to be able to pass and

190
00:13:39.138 --> 00:13:44.432
achieve accreditation at
any Lifecycle test, okay?

191
00:13:44.432 --> 00:13:48.339
If English is not your first language
you are allowed a paper dictionary.

192
00:13:48.339 --> 00:13:53.315
But you will be asked to show that
to the proctor at the time that

193
00:13:53.315 --> 00:13:55.650
you take your test.

194
00:13:55.650 --> 00:13:59.844
And as I've already said, you have to have

195
00:13:59.844 --> 00:14:05.439
an ITIL Foundation in version 3 or
version 3 2011 or

196
00:14:05.439 --> 00:14:10.579
an ITIL version 2 Foundation
bridge to version 3.

197
00:14:10.579 --> 00:14:12.628
I will be very, very honest with you.

198
00:14:12.628 --> 00:14:17.546
There are not that many people that
have attained the version 2 to version

199
00:14:17.546 --> 00:14:18.348
3 bridge.

200
00:14:18.348 --> 00:14:22.278
And most people will have the version 3 or

201
00:14:22.278 --> 00:14:27.230
2011, sorry, ITIL Foundation certificate.

202
00:14:27.230 --> 00:14:32.385
You will be required to upload
that certificate to the examining

203
00:14:32.385 --> 00:14:38.430
board prior to sitting your Lifecycle
test, so be prepared with that.

204
00:14:38.430 --> 00:14:42.590
You will need to have it to hand and
saved as a PDF as well.

205
00:14:44.250 --> 00:14:51.760
So when we come to the end of every single
life cycle class, we will be going over,

206
00:14:51.760 --> 00:14:56.410
and this one's no exception,
we'll be going over a sample test for you.

207
00:14:56.410 --> 00:15:00.535
And during that sample test,
I'll be giving you lots of hints and

208
00:15:00.535 --> 00:15:03.841
tips on how to select that
best fit possible answer.

209
00:15:03.841 --> 00:15:08.090
And also how to ensure that you read
the full question, how to relax.

210
00:15:08.090 --> 00:15:12.737
And to make sure that you
approach it with an open mind,

211
00:15:12.737 --> 00:15:17.200
but you consider relevance
in every single answer.

212
00:15:17.200 --> 00:15:21.680
Ultimately we want to get you past
the test just as much as you want to

213
00:15:21.680 --> 00:15:23.760
achieve that accreditation.

214
00:15:24.970 --> 00:15:29.993
So just to sum up,
what we will be doing over the next few

215
00:15:29.993 --> 00:15:37.108
shows is encouraging you to take your
ITIL Lifecycle intermediate classes.

216
00:15:37.108 --> 00:15:42.718
And feel free to join us in the forums for
any questions that you may have.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo introduce the ITIL Service Operation lifecycle.  Jo reminds us the key concepts that carries through from ITIL foundations.  In service operation, the goal is to deliver value through the daily business by providing consistent value through carrying out and coordinating services, managing services and optimizes services during regular business.  This sets the stage for the service operations that the series will dive into!
episodes.title: Introduction to Service Operation

1

service operation, what are we

Service operation being our

as we go through the life

25
00:01:09.850 --> 00:01:13.340
From the foundation material where
we looked at the purpose of every

lifecycle phase.

27

So in this particular section here,

28

We're not learning any new technology,
new terminology, I'm sorry.

29

[LAUGH] We're not covering

30

>> But we're not

32

What we're going to be doing

35

>> All right, it sounds great.

36

37

38

40

41
00:01:56.950 --> 00:01:59.510
So, you have the course

42

And the first thing that I want you to, or

43

want to draw your attention to is

44

Now, I'm not gonna read
through these slides for you,

45

you're perfectly capable of doing that.

46
00:02:11.750 --> 00:02:15.970
What I'm gonna do is add some context to
this and what you can see straight away

47
00:02:15.970 --> 00:02:20.970
when you look at this in the blue box in
front of you, what you can see immediately

48
00:02:20.970 --> 00:02:25.190
is that we're talking about business
as usual, nothing more than that.

49
00:02:25.190 --> 00:02:27.900
This is about carrying out
all of the activities and

50
00:02:27.900 --> 00:02:32.040
those on dependent processes that
are required to simply deliver and

51
00:02:32.040 --> 00:02:35.270
manage the services at agreed levels.

52
00:02:35.270 --> 00:02:37.560
Agreed levels, where are these agreed?

53
00:02:37.560 --> 00:02:42.670
Well, they're in the service level
agreement documents, of course.

54
00:02:42.670 --> 00:02:47.730
So we're delivering these services
to provide value to our business and

55
00:02:47.730 --> 00:02:48.729
to our organization.

56
00:02:50.260 --> 00:02:53.750
So what we have to do then if we're
talking about providing value to our

57
00:02:53.750 --> 00:02:57.040
business and
we have to keep them happy obviously and

58
00:02:57.040 --> 00:03:00.720
in fact what we really have to do
is maintain business satisfactions.

59
00:03:00.720 --> 00:03:05.070
We've got to ensure that w are delivering
value to the organization,

60
00:03:05.070 --> 00:03:07.642
that value being perceived.

61
00:03:07.642 --> 00:03:12.620
And so, if you think about this logically,
we all have a different concept of value.

62
00:03:12.620 --> 00:03:13.700
What you value,

63
00:03:13.700 --> 00:03:17.690
what you value is completely
different to what I might value.

64
00:03:17.690 --> 00:03:19.960
So that's a challenge in itself.

65
00:03:19.960 --> 00:03:23.670
So we're talking about
keeping the business running.

66
00:03:23.670 --> 00:03:26.730
We're talking about minimizing
the impact of any outages.

67
00:03:26.730 --> 00:03:31.915
And we're also referring to ensuring
that everybody does have access

68
00:03:31.915 --> 00:03:37.175
to our services that should have access
to our services and at the same time

69
00:03:37.175 --> 00:03:43.195
stopping those that shouldn't have access
to our services from having that access.

70
00:03:43.195 --> 00:03:44.945
So that's what service operation is about.

71
00:03:44.945 --> 00:03:49.785
And the service operation class,
that we're going to be looking at over

72
00:03:49.785 --> 00:03:55.640
the next few modules,
this focuses on all of the processes,

73
00:03:55.640 --> 00:04:00.005
all of the functional areas and
the tools that under paying

74
00:04:00.005 --> 00:04:04.950
this ability to deliver up
services at agreed levels.

75
00:04:04.950 --> 00:04:09.220
So we have some explanations here
underneath in bullet points.

76
00:04:09.220 --> 00:04:11.340
You'll see that we have services, and

77
00:04:11.340 --> 00:04:14.460
a service is,
if you remember from foundation.

78
00:04:14.460 --> 00:04:18.950
A means of delivering value by
facilitating the outcomes that customers

79
00:04:18.950 --> 00:04:23.570
want to achieve without the ownership
of specific costs and risks.

80
00:04:23.570 --> 00:04:24.740
Risks.
Let me put that into plain and

81
00:04:24.740 --> 00:04:25.792
simple English for you.

82
00:04:25.792 --> 00:04:26.440
>> [LAUGH] better.

83
00:04:26.440 --> 00:04:31.210
>> What that actually means is that
what we will be doing is we will

84
00:04:31.210 --> 00:04:33.085
be providing an ability.

85
00:04:33.085 --> 00:04:33.860
>> Okay.

86
00:04:33.860 --> 00:04:38.790
>> We're going to give you the ability
to send and receive email, for instance.

87
00:04:38.790 --> 00:04:42.050
We are not going to send and
receive that email for you.

88
00:04:42.050 --> 00:04:44.930
After all, you know what you want
to type when you send an email.

89
00:04:44.930 --> 00:04:47.660
I don't know what you want to
type when you send and email.

90
00:04:47.660 --> 00:04:52.650
So, I'm gonna give you the ability to
send and receive any emails, but I'm not

91
00:04:52.650 --> 00:04:56.780
going to actually do it for you, which is
why we talk about facilitating outcomes.

92
00:04:56.780 --> 00:05:02.960
Now, in order for me to do that, I have
to be organized in a way that I work and

93
00:05:02.960 --> 00:05:06.510
this is where our service management
processes come into this.

94
00:05:06.510 --> 00:05:11.700
Because we have to make sure that we're
organized in delivering that ability.

95
00:05:11.700 --> 00:05:16.245
If we're not organized, then we
can't deliver an ability very well.

96
00:05:16.245 --> 00:05:20.595
And certainly, if you think about the two
tenets of ITIL, which are efficiency and

97
00:05:20.595 --> 00:05:24.245
effectiveness, I need to be able
to deliver these services is

98
00:05:24.245 --> 00:05:28.685
a business-as-usual environment
efficiently and effectively,

99
00:05:28.685 --> 00:05:31.665
with minimal disruption to service.

100
00:05:31.665 --> 00:05:35.325
So I need to have some processes
that underpin these services,

101
00:05:35.325 --> 00:05:37.790
to enable me to do that.

102
00:05:37.790 --> 00:05:39.610
Of course there's technology involved.

103
00:05:39.610 --> 00:05:43.030
There has to be technology involved,
because let's face it,

104
00:05:43.030 --> 00:05:44.850
we're delivering IT services.

105
00:05:44.850 --> 00:05:47.920
But we also have to have tools
that underpin these services too.

106
00:05:47.920 --> 00:05:51.050
And then, lets not forget the people.

107
00:05:51.050 --> 00:05:54.520
The most important element
of service delivery.

108
00:05:54.520 --> 00:05:58.150
Without the people, without the skills,
and without their ability to manage those

109
00:05:58.150 --> 00:06:00.992
services we simply would
not have a service.

110
00:06:00.992 --> 00:06:04.285
So I have already talked about value.

111
00:06:04.285 --> 00:06:09.750
I've already talked about
the fact that value is perceived.

112
00:06:09.750 --> 00:06:14.456
And so, we have to ensure that we can
deliver value to the business and

113
00:06:14.456 --> 00:06:18.990
in an ever changing world,
a very fastly changing world.

114
00:06:18.990 --> 00:06:20.327
Is that a word, fastly?

115
00:06:20.327 --> 00:06:21.527
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Anyway,

116
00:06:21.527 --> 00:06:24.220
in rapidly changing world,
that sounds better.

117
00:06:24.220 --> 00:06:27.690
I can't speak English, it's the.

118
00:06:27.690 --> 00:06:33.000
In this rapidly changing world we
have to be able to deliver value,

119
00:06:33.000 --> 00:06:36.540
in a continual way because value changes.

120
00:06:36.540 --> 00:06:40.480
Think about that cellphone that
you bought last year for instance.

121
00:06:40.480 --> 00:06:45.200
That cellphone you bought last year, you
bought it because it was the latest thing.

122
00:06:45.200 --> 00:06:47.660
It had all the functionality
that you needed and

123
00:06:47.660 --> 00:06:51.620
it did everything that you wanted to do
and I bet you even thought it would make

124
00:06:51.620 --> 00:06:53.780
you a cup of coffee on a morning
when you got out of bed.

125
00:06:55.280 --> 00:06:57.390
Yeah, but unfortunately it doesn't.

126
00:06:57.390 --> 00:07:00.010
And since you bought that cell phone,

127
00:07:00.010 --> 00:07:03.670
somebody else has brought out another one
that actually does a little bit more.

128
00:07:03.670 --> 00:07:07.490
So your valued perception of that
cell phone has now diminished,

129
00:07:07.490 --> 00:07:08.930
over a very short period of time.

130
00:07:09.990 --> 00:07:12.120
And you know what?
It hasn't changed.

131
00:07:12.120 --> 00:07:15.170
It still delivers that say,
ability to make and

132
00:07:15.170 --> 00:07:19.390
receive that phone call but,
you don't value it as much.

133
00:07:19.390 --> 00:07:23.100
So, what we have to do is we have to
ensure that we can deliver value in

134
00:07:23.100 --> 00:07:25.050
an ongoing way.

135
00:07:25.050 --> 00:07:29.450
So we talked about meeting the goals and
objectives of an organization in relation

136
00:07:29.450 --> 00:07:33.820
to security,
in relation to facilitating that outcome.

137
00:07:34.880 --> 00:07:40.180
We talked about providing access to those
services in a way that delivers value and

138
00:07:40.180 --> 00:07:45.700
that doesn't hinder because let's face it,
sometimes we don't always get the access

139
00:07:45.700 --> 00:07:49.330
that we need or the functionality that
we need the minute that we want it.

140
00:07:50.810 --> 00:07:53.618
We like to talk about
automated operations and

141
00:07:53.618 --> 00:07:56.931
we like to do things as
efficiently as we possibly can.

142
00:07:56.931 --> 00:08:03.963
But we have to consider that automation,
wherever we utilize automation has to be.

143
00:08:03.963 --> 00:08:05.856
Where appropriate.

144
00:08:05.856 --> 00:08:09.548
You don't just automate something
because it seems like a good idea.

145
00:08:09.548 --> 00:08:13.329
After all, you're only going
to get to that result quicker.

146
00:08:13.329 --> 00:08:16.726
And if that result is a bad result
because you've actually scoped

147
00:08:16.726 --> 00:08:21.256
out the process inefficiently yourself,
then you're just gonna get there quicker.

148
00:08:21.256 --> 00:08:22.880
It's still gonna be a bad result.

149
00:08:25.260 --> 00:08:30.250
So what we have to do is assure
that we deliver that value.

150
00:08:30.250 --> 00:08:33.380
And that first bullet point that you
see on the slides in front of you that

151
00:08:33.380 --> 00:08:37.830
talks about difficulty in maintaining
that expected return on investment.

152
00:08:37.830 --> 00:08:39.010
When we talk about return,

153
00:08:39.010 --> 00:08:44.490
we don't just talk about financial return,
we talk about value return.

154
00:08:44.490 --> 00:08:50.140
So things that aren't necessarily
demonstrable in a financial sense.

155
00:08:50.140 --> 00:08:52.050
Think about that cell phone again.

156
00:08:52.050 --> 00:08:54.080
Really once you've spent
the money on that,

157
00:08:54.080 --> 00:08:58.460
you don't care about how much that's
actually physically cost you at the time.

158
00:08:58.460 --> 00:09:00.210
The money's been spent.

159
00:09:00.210 --> 00:09:02.950
What you want to be able
to do is to send and

160
00:09:02.950 --> 00:09:07.680
receive emails and to send and
receive texts and to make phone calls.

161
00:09:07.680 --> 00:09:11.850
And if that phone let's you down, or if
you find a phone that can do it a little

162
00:09:11.850 --> 00:09:15.320
bit better,
then your value perception has changed.

163
00:09:15.320 --> 00:09:21.470
So you're no longer maintaining a value on
an investment on that particular phone.

164
00:09:22.950 --> 00:09:26.770
It's that value perception and
the diminishment of that value perception,

165
00:09:26.770 --> 00:09:30.390
that actually makes it hard to
maintain funding for changes.

166
00:09:30.390 --> 00:09:33.630
Because nowadays,
we're all familiar with technology.

167
00:09:33.630 --> 00:09:37.520
There's nobody in this world that's
not familiar with technology.

168
00:09:37.520 --> 00:09:39.910
And so, we all know better.

169
00:09:39.910 --> 00:09:42.550
We all know what's available
in the market space.

170
00:09:42.550 --> 00:09:45.860
And how many times has our
organization come to us and said, but

171
00:09:45.860 --> 00:09:47.500
why can't we do it like this?

172
00:09:47.500 --> 00:09:50.680
Because I've seen this commercial
on TV and that's available.

173
00:09:50.680 --> 00:09:52.110
Why can't I do it like this?

174
00:09:53.400 --> 00:09:56.622
And so, our organization
perceives value in one way.

175
00:09:56.622 --> 00:09:59.399
We perceive value delivery in another way.

176
00:09:59.399 --> 00:10:04.333
And it's that inability to articulate
what value really means that can make it

177
00:10:04.333 --> 00:10:06.960
very difficult for us to obtain funding.

178
00:10:08.150 --> 00:10:12.640
And that means funding not just for the
services themselves, but also funding for

179
00:10:12.640 --> 00:10:16.460
the tools that we use in IT to
support those services, too.

180
00:10:18.480 --> 00:10:25.000
So what we're looking for over a period of
time, as we are delivering these services,

181
00:10:25.000 --> 00:10:31.350
is that we are looking for incremental,
iterative, step by step, improvement.

182
00:10:31.350 --> 00:10:35.130
Because as we've already said,
value diminishes over time.

183
00:10:35.130 --> 00:10:37.666
And value diminishes very, very, quickly.

184
00:10:37.666 --> 00:10:41.865
So we're going to be,
on an ongoing iterative basis,

185
00:10:41.865 --> 00:10:46.540
checking the performance of
these services that we supply.

186
00:10:46.540 --> 00:10:50.729
We're going to be ensuring that the
services are not only working as per those

187
00:10:50.729 --> 00:10:52.276
service level agreements,

188
00:10:52.276 --> 00:10:55.253
that we mentioned right away
back on that first slide.

189
00:10:55.253 --> 00:10:59.485
But we're also going to be making
sure that those services continue

190
00:10:59.485 --> 00:11:03.740
to deliver value,
understanding the value changes.

191
00:11:03.740 --> 00:11:05.540
So when we talk about improvements,

192
00:11:05.540 --> 00:11:09.610
we could be talking about
improvement to service availability.

193
00:11:09.610 --> 00:11:14.950
We could be talking about improvements
to the uptime of a service, but we also

194
00:11:14.950 --> 00:11:20.060
could be talking about improvements by
adding in new functionality to a service.

195
00:11:21.650 --> 00:11:25.370
And that's what we would call a long
term incremental improvement,

196
00:11:25.370 --> 00:11:27.810
something that's looking to the future.

197
00:11:27.810 --> 00:11:32.690
We also have short term improvements
that we can make on a regular basis,

198
00:11:32.690 --> 00:11:37.010
which could be something as simple
as maybe changing the hours of

199
00:11:37.010 --> 00:11:38.616
the service desk work.

200
00:11:38.616 --> 00:11:41.858
We get a peak on Monday mornings at 9 AM,
and

201
00:11:41.858 --> 00:11:47.400
the service desk staff don't start
until 9:30 AM on Monday morning.

202
00:11:47.400 --> 00:11:49.061
Well, in that case then,

203
00:11:49.061 --> 00:11:54.357
we made need to change those hours because
we need to deliver value to the business.

204
00:11:54.357 --> 00:11:57.928
So short term improvements,
they're not just one off.

205
00:11:57.928 --> 00:12:01.139
It's not something that we do,
it's something that we do and

206
00:12:01.139 --> 00:12:05.603
then we check that it's worked, and then
we'll look to do something else, as well.

207
00:12:05.603 --> 00:12:08.930
We're looking to maintain momentum.

208
00:12:08.930 --> 00:12:12.320
Initially, we have to build it,
but we have to maintain that.

209
00:12:12.320 --> 00:12:15.650
We don't want to change
the fundamental nature of any service,

210
00:12:15.650 --> 00:12:18.630
we don't want to change who we are, but

211
00:12:18.630 --> 00:12:22.400
let's face it, we all know when we're
being a little bit disorganized.

212
00:12:22.400 --> 00:12:25.395
We all know when we're putting
off that one task that we really,

213
00:12:25.395 --> 00:12:26.619
really don't want to do.

214
00:12:26.619 --> 00:12:31.494
And so, that's the idea of
the short term ongoing intuitive

215
00:12:31.494 --> 00:12:35.040
improvements is the ongoing improvement.

216
00:12:35.040 --> 00:12:39.557
Those small things that we
know it is that we can do.

217
00:12:39.557 --> 00:12:42.004
So what we're going to be looking at,

218
00:12:42.004 --> 00:12:46.216
the first five bullet points over
the service operation course.

219
00:12:46.216 --> 00:12:52.272
The first five bullet points are the five
processes within service operation.

220
00:12:52.272 --> 00:12:55.169
And we're going to be looking
at event management, and

221
00:12:55.169 --> 00:12:58.692
we're also going to covering
monitoring as part of that, as well.

222
00:12:58.692 --> 00:13:02.631
We're going to be looking at incident
management and problem management.

223
00:13:02.631 --> 00:13:06.995
We're going to be looking at request
fulfillment which you could perceive to be

224
00:13:06.995 --> 00:13:11.879
a huge big misnomer, because it's not just
about fulfilling requests, it's actually

225
00:13:11.879 --> 00:13:16.640
about managing requests or dealing
with requests as in the ITIL books.

226
00:13:16.640 --> 00:13:18.900
And then, we're going to be
looking at access management,

227
00:13:18.900 --> 00:13:23.930
which is about giving access and
taking access away also.

228
00:13:23.930 --> 00:13:28.910
And then, we're going to look at the four
functions, or four functional areas,

229
00:13:28.910 --> 00:13:33.990
as I like to call them, within service
operation, within the business as usual.

230
00:13:33.990 --> 00:13:38.160
That's the Service Desk, that's the fairly
obvious one that we can all relate to and

231
00:13:38.160 --> 00:13:39.480
we've all heard of.

232
00:13:39.480 --> 00:13:41.710
And then we've got our
technical management guys.

233
00:13:41.710 --> 00:13:44.134
And these are the people that
look at our infrastructure.

234
00:13:44.134 --> 00:13:48.082
And all the teams and the tools and
the skills that they have to deal with our

235
00:13:48.082 --> 00:13:51.570
networks and our infrastructure and
our service.

236
00:13:51.570 --> 00:13:53.130
We've got operations management.

237
00:13:53.130 --> 00:13:57.610
And they do all of our batch jobs,
they do our backups,

238
00:13:57.610 --> 00:14:00.470
they do our restores,
they do our print scheduling.

239
00:14:00.470 --> 00:14:02.590
And they also have facilities management,

240
00:14:02.590 --> 00:14:05.940
as part of that particular
functional area, too.

241
00:14:05.940 --> 00:14:10.401
And that's the group that look after our
data centers, look after our disaster

242
00:14:10.401 --> 00:14:14.728
recovery sites, or our service continuity
sites as we like to call them, and

243
00:14:14.728 --> 00:14:16.407
look after our backup tapes.

244
00:14:16.407 --> 00:14:18.637
And then we've got our applications guys,
and

245
00:14:18.637 --> 00:14:21.158
these are the guys that do
Applications Management.

246
00:14:21.158 --> 00:14:24.925
And they do, where necessary,
the development and

247
00:14:24.925 --> 00:14:28.271
the support of all of our applications,
too.

248
00:14:28.271 --> 00:14:33.063
So this first bullet point in front of you
now then, I've already mentioned this one,

249
00:14:33.063 --> 00:14:36.293
and I know that it rolls off
the tongue fairly easily to me.

250
00:14:36.293 --> 00:14:37.898
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And

251
00:14:37.898 --> 00:14:43.306
I don't expect it to do that to you and
don't worry, you don't need to.

252
00:14:43.306 --> 00:14:47.910
But what you have to understand
is the concept of a service.

253
00:14:47.910 --> 00:14:50.780
I've already said,
it's not about delivery and outcome.

254
00:14:50.780 --> 00:14:54.608
We're not going to send that email for
you, because we don't know what's in your

255
00:14:54.608 --> 00:14:57.950
head, we might be great people,
cuz I mean let's face it, we're IT.

256
00:14:57.950 --> 00:14:59.630
We know everything.

257
00:14:59.630 --> 00:15:00.890
But we don't know what's in your head.

258
00:15:00.890 --> 00:15:03.080
We don't know what you want to say.

259
00:15:03.080 --> 00:15:06.410
So what we have to do is
facilitate that outcome.

260
00:15:08.090 --> 00:15:11.433
And that's where we talk
about delivering value,

261
00:15:11.433 --> 00:15:16.920
because you know what you want to send and
you now how you want to type that email.

262
00:15:16.920 --> 00:15:21.057
You know how you want to present it, or
how you want to attack that picture or

263
00:15:21.057 --> 00:15:25.194
that photograph, whether you want it
in the body of the email or whether you

264
00:15:25.194 --> 00:15:29.945
want it as an attachment, I don't know any
of these things, you know what you value.

265
00:15:29.945 --> 00:15:35.260
But then it goes on to say without
the ownership of specific costs and risks.

266
00:15:36.520 --> 00:15:38.430
Let's think about that for a moment.

267
00:15:38.430 --> 00:15:41.470
A specific cost of a laptop, we all know.

268
00:15:41.470 --> 00:15:44.618
A laptop can cost us, let's say $1,000.

269
00:15:44.618 --> 00:15:47.740
But what about specific costs and risks?

270
00:15:47.740 --> 00:15:50.944
If we're talking about just one service,

271
00:15:50.944 --> 00:15:56.640
the specific cost of email to a person,
well, we have to take that laptop and

272
00:15:56.640 --> 00:16:02.621
then we have to divide it by the number of
other services that are on that laptop.

273
00:16:02.621 --> 00:16:06.848
Some might say they're using
Microsoft Office, they say they're using,

274
00:16:06.848 --> 00:16:09.237
I don't know, maybe SAP, for instance.

275
00:16:09.237 --> 00:16:11.901
Maybe they've got 20 services.

276
00:16:11.901 --> 00:16:17.030
So, the cost of email then,
is one 20th of that laptop.

277
00:16:17.030 --> 00:16:19.260
Okay, that's just the hardware.

278
00:16:19.260 --> 00:16:21.110
Then we've got the license fee.

279
00:16:21.110 --> 00:16:23.880
And then what about the portion
of the infrastructure as well,

280
00:16:23.880 --> 00:16:26.740
that they're using just for email?

281
00:16:26.740 --> 00:16:30.436
So, the portion of
the infrastructure is one 20th

282
00:16:30.436 --> 00:16:33.461
of the infrastructure to that PC, right?

283
00:16:33.461 --> 00:16:37.780
Well, let's take that up a level, and then
let's look at say router level for that.

284
00:16:37.780 --> 00:16:40.761
And how many PCs have
we got on the router?

285
00:16:40.761 --> 00:16:42.690
It gets complicated.

286
00:16:42.690 --> 00:16:46.750
So, why are we going to transfer
specific costs to our customers?

287
00:16:47.960 --> 00:16:52.076
It's gonna take us more than investment
to work out those specific costs,

288
00:16:52.076 --> 00:16:54.040
than what we're going
be able to recoup back.

289
00:16:54.040 --> 00:16:56.390
So, of course we're mot
gonna transfer those.

290
00:16:56.390 --> 00:16:57.550
And the risks?

291
00:16:57.550 --> 00:17:01.890
I don't expect our customers to
know anything about the cabling.

292
00:17:01.890 --> 00:17:05.490
I don't expect them to know anything
about how it all hangs together.

293
00:17:05.490 --> 00:17:08.860
So, why on earth would I want to
transfer those risks to our customers?

294
00:17:10.570 --> 00:17:12.044
We're supposed to be delivering value.

295
00:17:12.044 --> 00:17:13.890
We're not supposed to be
delivering a headache.

296
00:17:13.890 --> 00:17:16.310
We're supposed to be delivering value.

297
00:17:16.310 --> 00:17:21.210
The idea is, that we are supposed to be
improving the performance of our business

298
00:17:21.210 --> 00:17:23.960
by reducing the constraints.

299
00:17:23.960 --> 00:17:27.054
Now, reducing the constraints
means analyzing those risks, and

300
00:17:27.054 --> 00:17:28.887
we'll take ownership of those risks.

301
00:17:28.887 --> 00:17:32.988
Reducing the constraints means giving
people access that need to have access.

302
00:17:32.988 --> 00:17:36.841
But removing those that don't
need to have access, okay?

303
00:17:36.841 --> 00:17:39.721
The idea is that we want to.

304
00:17:39.721 --> 00:17:43.050
It says there,
increase probability of desired outcomes.

305
00:17:43.050 --> 00:17:48.512
But we want to ensure that every time
you go to send an email, it sends.

306
00:17:48.512 --> 00:17:52.937
And every time you open up your laptop,
your emails are downloaded and

307
00:17:52.937 --> 00:17:55.200
you receive your emails.

308
00:17:55.200 --> 00:17:57.690
That's what increased probability means.

309
00:17:57.690 --> 00:18:02.090
We don't want you to have any doubts
that when you open up your laptop,

310
00:18:02.090 --> 00:18:04.830
that you're going to receive that email.

311
00:18:04.830 --> 00:18:06.441
I want you to open up that laptop and

312
00:18:06.441 --> 00:18:08.840
know that you're emails
are going to be received.

313
00:18:08.840 --> 00:18:10.245
I want you to hit send and

314
00:18:10.245 --> 00:18:13.418
know that you're going to
be able to send that email.

315
00:18:13.418 --> 00:18:15.040
And that it's going to go through.

316
00:18:16.140 --> 00:18:20.450
>> Now Jo, before we move on to
what we're about to see here.

317
00:18:20.450 --> 00:18:24.829
Under service,
is there in ITIL that we're talking about.

318
00:18:24.829 --> 00:18:29.243
Does it distinguish between something
like just outsourcing that,

319
00:18:29.243 --> 00:18:31.993
using a service provider to provide that?

320
00:18:31.993 --> 00:18:35.349
Versus what's an internal resource for
us to do this?

321
00:18:35.349 --> 00:18:40.340
Or, regardless of which side you're on,
you're still providing the same service?

322
00:18:40.340 --> 00:18:42.980
>> Right, so, I'm glad you asked that.

323
00:18:42.980 --> 00:18:46.940
We have in service strategy,
in the first life cycle phase,

324
00:18:46.940 --> 00:18:49.950
we look at the types of service
provider that there are.

325
00:18:49.950 --> 00:18:52.600
Now, whether they be
internal service provider so

326
00:18:52.600 --> 00:18:56.186
that somebody internal to the business
unit, to the organization.

327
00:18:56.186 --> 00:19:00.258
Or whether we have a shed
service service provider.

328
00:19:00.258 --> 00:19:04.822
Which is a service provider within
the organization still, but

329
00:19:04.822 --> 00:19:08.850
that supports services
across all business units.

330
00:19:08.850 --> 00:19:10.870
Or we have external service providers.

331
00:19:10.870 --> 00:19:14.950
And external service providers come
in many different shapes and forms.

332
00:19:14.950 --> 00:19:19.070
They could be a service provider
that provides the whole of IT.

333
00:19:19.070 --> 00:19:22.520
Or they could be a service provider
that provides just one portion.

334
00:19:22.520 --> 00:19:25.560
And you can have many
external service providers.

335
00:19:25.560 --> 00:19:26.870
So, in service strategy,

336
00:19:26.870 --> 00:19:30.920
we look at the concept of different
types of service provider.

337
00:19:30.920 --> 00:19:35.729
And in service design, we make
the decisions as to what type of service

338
00:19:35.729 --> 00:19:39.983
provider we're going to utilize
as we bring in new services.

339
00:19:39.983 --> 00:19:43.610
And as we look to provide
value to the business.

340
00:19:43.610 --> 00:19:46.690
So, what we're looking at
here in service operation,

341
00:19:46.690 --> 00:19:50.490
is what we need to
deliver to the business.

342
00:19:50.490 --> 00:19:52.960
What we need for business as usual.

343
00:19:52.960 --> 00:19:56.595
So, we step outside of the boundaries
of the service provider types.

344
00:19:56.595 --> 00:19:59.100
And we just look at
providing that service.

345
00:19:59.100 --> 00:20:02.982
And it doesn't matter whether it
is internal service provider, or

346
00:20:02.982 --> 00:20:05.032
many external service providers.

347
00:20:05.032 --> 00:20:07.100
They still need all of these elements.

348
00:20:07.100 --> 00:20:10.090
>> Right.
>> These processes need to be in place.

349
00:20:10.090 --> 00:20:12.470
These skills need to be present.

350
00:20:12.470 --> 00:20:13.070
>> All right.

351
00:20:13.070 --> 00:20:16.861
>> So, the slide that we have just coming
up right now, that we had on the screen.

352
00:20:16.861 --> 00:20:21.699
You'll see the functional areas that
we had within, or that we have.

353
00:20:21.699 --> 00:20:25.990
So, within IT operations,
these need to exist.

354
00:20:25.990 --> 00:20:29.040
Whether you are using
an external service provider, or

355
00:20:29.040 --> 00:20:33.360
whether you're using an internal service
provider, or a combination of both.

356
00:20:33.360 --> 00:20:37.962
These functional areas and
these skills need to exist.

357
00:20:37.962 --> 00:20:41.197
And, as I've said, we've already gone
all over these very, very briefly.

358
00:20:41.197 --> 00:20:44.779
And we're going to go in more into
depth in these, in other modules.

359
00:20:46.380 --> 00:20:47.946
So, I mentioned functional areas.

360
00:20:47.946 --> 00:20:52.871
And that last slide actually looked
at the four functional areas

361
00:20:52.871 --> 00:20:54.520
that we have in ITIL.

362
00:20:54.520 --> 00:20:58.324
And a function is simply,
this is just from our ITIL foundation.

363
00:20:58.324 --> 00:21:01.276
It's simply a team, or
a group of people, and

364
00:21:01.276 --> 00:21:04.930
the tools that they use
to carry out processes.

365
00:21:04.930 --> 00:21:08.430
Processes are what they do,
the set of activities.

366
00:21:08.430 --> 00:21:11.780
Functional areas are the people
that actually do them.

367
00:21:11.780 --> 00:21:15.301
They're described as
a self-contained of an organization.

368
00:21:15.301 --> 00:21:19.433
Now we don't tell you
how to organize your IT.

369
00:21:19.433 --> 00:21:21.690
We can't, let's face it.

370
00:21:21.690 --> 00:21:24.950
So, this is why I like to refer
to the misfunctional areas,

371
00:21:24.950 --> 00:21:27.900
as opposed to just functions themselves.

372
00:21:27.900 --> 00:21:32.710
There is a tendency for
people who just read the ITIL

373
00:21:32.710 --> 00:21:37.820
books to look at these and say, hey look,
ITIL's given us an organizational chart.

374
00:21:37.820 --> 00:21:38.736
Well, we're not.

375
00:21:38.736 --> 00:21:40.963
We're just telling you that,
you know what?

376
00:21:40.963 --> 00:21:44.535
If you're going to deliver services,
whether you're an external service

377
00:21:44.535 --> 00:21:47.990
provider or internal,
you need people to manage your network.

378
00:21:47.990 --> 00:21:50.350
So, we're gonna call
them technical people.

379
00:21:50.350 --> 00:21:52.070
You need people to manage applications,

380
00:21:52.070 --> 00:21:54.480
and we're gonna call
them application people.

381
00:21:54.480 --> 00:21:57.970
And you need people to have
a direct contact with your users.

382
00:21:57.970 --> 00:21:59.700
And we call them a service desk.

383
00:22:00.720 --> 00:22:05.330
Now, you see the aims of the functional
areas in bullet points at the bottom of

384
00:22:05.330 --> 00:22:07.330
the slide in front of you.

385
00:22:07.330 --> 00:22:09.627
Such as, having their own knowledge.

386
00:22:09.627 --> 00:22:12.360
And having their own processes and
their own work methods.

387
00:22:13.370 --> 00:22:16.400
And that third bullet point is always
the one that's really interesting.

388
00:22:16.400 --> 00:22:20.040
Service management itself,
the definition of service management,

389
00:22:20.040 --> 00:22:24.070
is a set of specialized
organizational capabilities.

390
00:22:24.070 --> 00:22:28.010
For providing value to customers
in the form of goods or services.

391
00:22:28.010 --> 00:22:31.380
A set of specialized
organizational capabilities.

392
00:22:31.380 --> 00:22:33.237
And this is what we mean
by functional areas.

393
00:22:33.237 --> 00:22:35.085
It's about how organized we are.

394
00:22:35.085 --> 00:22:37.531
And about how in
the specialized knowledge,

395
00:22:37.531 --> 00:22:40.760
to be able to facilitate those
outcomes in those services.

396
00:22:42.910 --> 00:22:45.590
So to summarize, service operation.

397
00:22:45.590 --> 00:22:48.675
The life cycle phase,
our fourth life cycle phase,

398
00:22:48.675 --> 00:22:51.138
is where we look at the business as usual.

399
00:22:51.138 --> 00:22:53.497
It's where we look at delivering value.

400
00:22:53.497 --> 00:22:59.180
And it's where we look at the fact
that value diminishes over time.

401
00:22:59.180 --> 00:23:02.241
And so, what we're interested
in doing is ensuring that

402
00:23:02.241 --> 00:23:05.576
we are continually aligned to
the needs of the organization.

403
00:23:05.576 --> 00:23:09.420
By providing services that
they will continually value.

404
00:23:10.760 --> 00:23:11.378
>> All right, Jo.

405
00:23:11.378 --> 00:23:14.880
Well, thank you for
helping us in the introduction here.

406
00:23:14.880 --> 00:23:17.490
As we get started in service operations,

407
00:23:17.490 --> 00:23:20.160
one of the key elements
that Jo did talk about.

408
00:23:20.160 --> 00:23:23.500
Not only the purpose, but the scope,
as well as the optimization.

409
00:23:23.500 --> 00:23:27.140
And some of these different aspects that
we may not have actually considered during

410
00:23:27.140 --> 00:23:27.980
the foundations.

411
00:23:27.980 --> 00:23:31.133
We're gonna dive a little bit
deeper into the operational side,

412
00:23:31.133 --> 00:23:33.940
helping us to deliver
the value that we need to.

413
00:23:33.940 --> 00:23:37.800
Well, that's a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

414
00:23:37.800 --> 00:23:39.643
Signing of for ITPro TV.

415
00:23:39.643 --> 00:23:41.600
I've been your host Ronny Wong.

416
00:23:41.600 --> 00:23:42.820
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

417
00:23:42.820 --> 00:23:46.083
>> Stay tuned right here for
more ITIL service operation shows.

418
00:23:46.083 --> 00:23:53.142
[MUSIC]

419
00:23:53.142 --> 00:23:55.560
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo begin the foundation refresher.  Jo reviews the key aspects of ITIL foundation by describing the 5 core volume service lifecycles: service strategy, service design, service transition, service operation, and continual service improvement.  She also defines what ITIL means by a Service and Service Management.  Also the key terms that define value: Utility and Warranty by Jo.

in this particular session, is we're

We need to understand
the Foundation material,

Now in our Foundation class in ITIL,

that's associated with ITIL,

along with 75 terms and

And I'll be honest with you,

sometimes the ITIL Foundation class

Certainly, the feedback that you get
from a lot of delegates watching

00:01:52.174 --> 00:01:56.561
ITIL Foundation is that they feel

00:28:23.400 --> 00:28:28.580
without it, emails are not going
to be able to be sent or received.

496
00:28:28.580 --> 00:28:32.960
And then an enhancing
service is an optional extra.

497
00:28:32.960 --> 00:28:37.310
Something that we can do that maybe
sets us apart from our competitors, or

498
00:28:37.310 --> 00:28:39.570
something that we just choose to do.

499
00:28:39.570 --> 00:28:41.940
It's optional for our business.

500
00:28:41.940 --> 00:28:45.544
And that would be something like
a shared calendar, for instance, okay?

501
00:28:45.544 --> 00:28:49.726
So, something that is an optional
extra that's our email,

502
00:28:49.726 --> 00:28:55.302
that's our shared directory, shared
calendar, is the word I'm looking for.

503
00:28:55.302 --> 00:28:59.460
So, these are our core and
our enabling and our enhancing services.

504
00:29:01.300 --> 00:29:04.970
Now, I asked you About value,

505
00:29:04.970 --> 00:29:09.460
little earlier on and
about what we perceive as value.

506
00:29:09.460 --> 00:29:12.170
So I'm just gonna wrap up this section

507
00:29:12.170 --> 00:29:17.240
by going over a couple of slides that
look over The definition of volume.

508
00:29:17.240 --> 00:29:22.310
Now you'll see that in the bottom
of this particular slide

509
00:29:22.310 --> 00:29:27.270
right in front of you now you'll
see that the diagram that

510
00:29:27.270 --> 00:29:32.330
you saw in your Intel foundation class and
notice that diagram that always looks

511
00:29:32.330 --> 00:29:36.250
very very complicated and everybody always
says how I'm I supposed to remember this.

512
00:29:37.410 --> 00:29:39.270
Well, it's really easy,

513
00:29:39.270 --> 00:29:44.530
because you just need to remember the
concepts of utility and warranty, okay.

514
00:29:44.530 --> 00:29:46.980
So the concept of utility is very,

515
00:29:46.980 --> 00:29:50.150
very simply,
does it do what it's supposed to do?

516
00:29:50.150 --> 00:29:52.644
And that's its fitness for purpose.

517
00:29:52.644 --> 00:29:54.818
Does that service send and receive email?

518
00:29:54.818 --> 00:29:56.100
Yes, it does.

519
00:29:56.100 --> 00:29:58.140
Okay then it has a utility.

520
00:29:58.140 --> 00:30:01.640
You could have a web based email service
that will do exactly that for you.

521
00:30:01.640 --> 00:30:02.810
It will deliver that email.

522
00:30:02.810 --> 00:30:11.040
But can I ask you in a business
perspective then Ronnie, would a web based

523
00:30:11.040 --> 00:30:15.280
email deliver you levels of security
that you would feel comfortable with?

524
00:30:15.280 --> 00:30:17.140
Do you think?

525
00:30:17.140 --> 00:30:19.800
>> Not Yeah, not necessarily.

526
00:30:19.800 --> 00:30:23.600
Especially if I'm actually
using a public provider, and

527
00:30:23.600 --> 00:30:28.360
not my own, as far as a portal that allows
me access inside of my own network.

528
00:30:28.360 --> 00:30:29.710
>> Yeah, right.

529
00:30:29.710 --> 00:30:34.000
So what you're saying is
>> Is then, in effect, is that service

530
00:30:34.000 --> 00:30:39.860
provides utility which it does, but
it doesn't provide warranty aspects.

531
00:30:39.860 --> 00:30:42.208
And if we look at the warranty aspects,

532
00:30:42.208 --> 00:30:46.409
you will see that those warranty
Warranty aspects are availability,

533
00:30:46.409 --> 00:30:50.485
capacity, security which is one
that I mentioned and continuity.

534
00:30:50.485 --> 00:30:57.075
And so both utility and warranty have to
exist in order for us to perceive value.

535
00:30:58.125 --> 00:31:01.431
So let's go through those
warranty aspects, okay?

536
00:31:01.431 --> 00:31:03.205
Is their service available enough?

537
00:31:03.205 --> 00:31:10.930
Well okay an Internet based web mail
service might be available enough.

538
00:31:10.930 --> 00:31:12.590
But does it have enough capacity?

539
00:31:13.890 --> 00:31:18.050
Guarantee when you try and send some files
it will tell you that they're too big.

540
00:31:18.050 --> 00:31:19.094
Does it have continuity?

541
00:31:19.094 --> 00:31:22.745
Well, it might do but
we don't have any assurance of that and

542
00:31:22.745 --> 00:31:27.490
that's the key thing about warranty,
is that we have assurance.

543
00:31:27.490 --> 00:31:30.222
And we certainly don't have
any insurance for security.

544
00:31:30.222 --> 00:31:36.430
So, you see both utility and warranty
need to exist for us to perceive value.

545
00:31:36.430 --> 00:31:41.450
It's not just good enough for us to have a
service that does what it says on the can.

546
00:31:41.450 --> 00:31:43.610
We've gotta be able to use it as well.

547
00:31:45.030 --> 00:31:46.450
And this next slide,

548
00:31:46.450 --> 00:31:51.090
which is something that I'm going
to use to wrap up this session.

549
00:31:51.090 --> 00:31:56.230
If you look, the utility effect
in that bottom left hand corner

550
00:31:56.230 --> 00:32:01.030
is all about increasing
the probability and

551
00:32:01.030 --> 00:32:06.530
maintaining that probability of that
service Working, in other words

552
00:32:06.530 --> 00:32:11.560
that service will do what it says on
the cam without the shadow of a doubt,

553
00:32:12.610 --> 00:32:17.740
but the warranty effect has to
actually decrease variances

554
00:32:17.740 --> 00:32:24.060
in the In availability and in capacity and
in continuity and in security.

555
00:32:24.060 --> 00:32:29.422
Because what we actually want to do is we
want to ensure that we have all of those.

556
00:32:29.422 --> 00:32:31.802
So, we want to decrease and

557
00:32:31.802 --> 00:32:37.502
we want to decrease the uncertainty
of providing those aspects.

558
00:32:37.502 --> 00:32:41.082
As we've said,
we have got to have both utility and

559
00:32:41.082 --> 00:32:44.510
warranty in order for
anyone to perceive value.

560
00:32:45.720 --> 00:32:49.120
So for now, we're going to wrap
up this particular session,

561
00:32:50.220 --> 00:32:54.140
which is part one of our
recap over ITIL foundation.

562
00:32:54.140 --> 00:32:57.670
And in our next session, we're going
to look further into our assets and

563
00:32:57.670 --> 00:33:00.740
into our resources and capabilities, etc.

564
00:33:00.740 --> 00:33:05.470
And we're also going to look at processes
and we're going to look at Roles and

565
00:33:05.470 --> 00:33:11.780
we're going to look at all about
responsibilities, etc, too.

566
00:33:11.780 --> 00:33:13.345
>> All right, Jo.
Well, thank you again for

567
00:33:13.345 --> 00:33:15.757
helping us out with this
part of the refresher.

568
00:33:15.757 --> 00:33:19.826
There's a lot more for us to cover but
that means we're gonna go ahead and

569
00:33:19.826 --> 00:33:21.670
end this episode then.

570
00:33:21.670 --> 00:33:25.960
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

571
00:33:25.960 --> 00:33:27.260
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

572
00:33:27.260 --> 00:33:30.880
Stay tuned right here for
another ITIL Foundation Refresher.

573
00:33:34.649 --> 00:33:37.980
[MUSIC]

574
00:33:37.980 --> 00:33:39.810
>> Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with the foundation refresher.  Jo reviews asset, resource, capabilities and processes from the ITIL perspective.  She emphasizes the process model and roles associated with processes.  Lastly, she describes the accountability that belongs to the service owner as well.
episodes.title: ITIL Foundation Refresher Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.016 --> 00:00:02.395
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.395 --> 00:00:06.150
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.150 --> 00:00:08.048
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.048 --> 00:00:12.307
>> You're watching ITPROTV.

5
00:00:12.307 --> 00:00:15.070
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.070 --> 00:00:20.520
You're watching the ITIL Foundation
refresher for your intermediate class.

7
00:00:20.520 --> 00:00:24.560
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and
we're taking a look at another foundation

8
00:00:24.560 --> 00:00:29.320
refresher, a part two, to help us to
round out those skills that we need.

9
00:00:29.320 --> 00:00:34.640
And here to help us, of course, is going
to be our ITIL virtuoso, Ms. Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:34.640 --> 00:00:36.230
Jo, welcome back to the show.

11
00:00:36.230 --> 00:00:38.890
>> Thank you for having me back,
Ronnie, how are you doing?

12
00:00:38.890 --> 00:00:41.020
>> Doing great, taking work and

13
00:00:41.020 --> 00:00:44.870
remembering all those different terms
that I have seen in the foundation.

14
00:00:44.870 --> 00:00:47.980
And now getting those things
kind of brought back up

15
00:00:47.980 --> 00:00:49.160
is really starting to help.

16
00:00:49.160 --> 00:00:52.470
So what do we actually have left to do,
where are we gonna begin?

17
00:00:52.470 --> 00:00:56.587
>> Yeah, I mean, it's this foundation
material that we're recapping over.

18
00:00:56.587 --> 00:01:00.944
There's so much information to absorb,
so much information.

19
00:01:00.944 --> 00:01:05.550
And trust me you're not the only one
because we have delegates that leave

20
00:01:05.550 --> 00:01:06.843
foundation class.

21
00:01:06.843 --> 00:01:11.501
And the feedback that they'll
give you sometimes is just, woah,

22
00:01:11.501 --> 00:01:14.505
it's just so much information to absorb.

23
00:01:14.505 --> 00:01:17.487
And it really is, and
the unfortunate thing is that we

24
00:01:17.487 --> 00:01:21.996
have to get through the foundation, you
have to understand all of the concepts in

25
00:01:21.996 --> 00:01:25.734
the foundation to be able to then
delve deeper into the processes.

26
00:01:25.734 --> 00:01:31.388
And until we can understand really what
a process is, or really what a functional

27
00:01:31.388 --> 00:01:37.060
area is, and what a role should do,
then it's difficult to apply that concept.

28
00:01:37.060 --> 00:01:39.960
And so,
what we're learning here is concepts and

29
00:01:39.960 --> 00:01:41.922
I will admit that there is a lot to learn.

30
00:01:41.922 --> 00:01:44.040
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right, Jo, so

31
00:01:44.040 --> 00:01:47.920
just take us a little bit through
what we reviewed last time.

32
00:01:47.920 --> 00:01:50.750
And then where we're going
to be heading from there.

33
00:01:50.750 --> 00:01:54.313
>> Okay, so in part one we actually
looked at the concept of a service.

34
00:01:54.313 --> 00:01:56.284
And the concept of a service is,

35
00:01:56.284 --> 00:02:01.029
a service is a means of delivering value
by facilitating the outcomes that our

36
00:02:01.029 --> 00:02:05.857
customers want to achieve without
the ownership of specific costs and risks.

37
00:02:05.857 --> 00:02:11.790
Now value is perceived, as I mentioned, we
all have a different perception of value.

38
00:02:11.790 --> 00:02:16.460
And even in a business environment, our
perception of value is still different.

39
00:02:16.460 --> 00:02:22.320
No matter how much we'd like to try and
deliver a one size fits all approach to

40
00:02:22.320 --> 00:02:28.590
our services, to our business, we can't
do that because value is perceived.

41
00:02:28.590 --> 00:02:32.410
So we looked at that and we looked
at the fact that service management,

42
00:02:32.410 --> 00:02:37.431
which ITIL is a framework, is a set of set
of specialized organizational capabilities

43
00:02:37.431 --> 00:02:42.410
for delivering value to customers
in the form or goods and services.

44
00:02:42.410 --> 00:02:47.220
Now I know that I've just rattled off two
descriptions, two definitions to you, and

45
00:02:47.220 --> 00:02:50.760
now that's made me look like
a bit of a nerd [LAUGH].

46
00:02:50.760 --> 00:02:54.189
I'm fully aware of that, okay.

47
00:02:54.189 --> 00:03:00.909
We also noted the concept of value being
broken down into utility and warranty.

48
00:03:00.909 --> 00:03:05.509
And the fact that it's not just about us
being able to do what it says on the can,

49
00:03:05.509 --> 00:03:08.314
we've gotta be able to send and
receive email.

50
00:03:08.314 --> 00:03:14.027
But we've gotta do it in a way that we can
assure our customers of levels of utility,

51
00:03:14.027 --> 00:03:17.782
and warranty, and
availability, and capacity, and

52
00:03:17.782 --> 00:03:20.410
service continuity, and security.

53
00:03:20.410 --> 00:03:24.910
So we've gotta need both that utility and
warranty to be present in order for

54
00:03:24.910 --> 00:03:27.320
them to perceive value.

55
00:03:27.320 --> 00:03:32.010
And so in this particular section we're
gonna start off just by going over

56
00:03:32.010 --> 00:03:33.860
what our service assets were.

57
00:03:33.860 --> 00:03:36.580
I mentioned them in very,

58
00:03:36.580 --> 00:03:42.300
very briefly in the last session about
tangible, and our intangible assets.

59
00:03:42.300 --> 00:03:44.390
And how we use those to
deliver our services.

60
00:03:45.560 --> 00:03:48.220
>> All right, so
let's go head and begin then.

61
00:03:48.220 --> 00:03:50.270
So where are we picking up from there?

62
00:03:50.270 --> 00:03:55.612
>> So, as I said, we begin with
our service assets and our assets.

63
00:03:55.612 --> 00:04:00.542
So what we use within our
organization to deliver value

64
00:04:00.542 --> 00:04:04.090
by way of goods or services, as we say.

65
00:04:04.090 --> 00:04:07.110
And an asset is described there,
you've got some definitions there.

66
00:04:07.110 --> 00:04:10.540
An asset is described as a resource or
a capability.

67
00:04:10.540 --> 00:04:13.540
And a resource is what we
consider to be a tangible asset,

68
00:04:13.540 --> 00:04:16.250
something that you touch and feel.

69
00:04:16.250 --> 00:04:20.780
Such as, is mentioned there,
money, our infrastructure itself,

70
00:04:20.780 --> 00:04:25.960
the software that we have, the actual
data that we have, our hardware.

71
00:04:25.960 --> 00:04:27.898
These are tangible assets,

72
00:04:27.898 --> 00:04:32.508
you'll notice that people span
both capabilities and resources.

73
00:04:32.508 --> 00:04:36.478
So they are tangible assets,
something that you can touch and feel,

74
00:04:36.478 --> 00:04:41.008
but I gave you that warning in that first
section, don't you do that too much.

75
00:04:41.008 --> 00:04:44.787
[LAUGH] And
then people are also intangible assets.

76
00:04:44.787 --> 00:04:49.909
And you know what, under the intangible
assets, soft assets, as they're mentioned

77
00:04:49.909 --> 00:04:55.240
there, our capabilities, we've got things
like how we're managed, who manages us?

78
00:04:55.240 --> 00:04:58.900
We've got the organization itself,
how well organized we are.

79
00:04:58.900 --> 00:05:02.750
If there's complete chaos going on then
we'll never gonna be able to deliver value

80
00:05:02.750 --> 00:05:03.800
to our customers, are we?

81
00:05:03.800 --> 00:05:07.578
Our processes have to be efficient and
effective.

82
00:05:07.578 --> 00:05:12.125
And if our processes don't do what they're
suppose to do, and they're not efficient,

83
00:05:12.125 --> 00:05:16.489
and they're not effective, then you know
what, they're not going to deliver value

84
00:05:16.489 --> 00:05:19.419
to our business, to our users,
and then our knowledge.

85
00:05:19.419 --> 00:05:24.160
And underneath people we've got
experience and skills, too.

86
00:05:24.160 --> 00:05:29.795
And knowledge can be quantified,
we should document our knowledge.

87
00:05:29.795 --> 00:05:32.635
And then it becomes
information that we can

88
00:05:32.635 --> 00:05:34.705
put into our knowledge management system.

89
00:05:34.705 --> 00:05:38.842
So our knowledge, though,
is also our experience, and our skills.

90
00:05:38.842 --> 00:05:41.877
And believe it or not, our attitude, and

91
00:05:41.877 --> 00:05:46.647
attitude fall under the soft assets,
the capabilities.

92
00:05:46.647 --> 00:05:50.476
Morale, I expect to see morale
in there as well, which is why,

93
00:05:50.476 --> 00:05:53.802
as we've moved through
the service operation class,

94
00:05:53.802 --> 00:05:59.460
you'll see that we've put a huge emphasis
on people and on morale and on attitudes.

95
00:05:59.460 --> 00:06:03.210
And on understanding, sort of
organizational change management and

96
00:06:03.210 --> 00:06:04.650
the people aspect.

97
00:06:04.650 --> 00:06:09.510
Because our people are what's going
to enable us to deliver value, but

98
00:06:09.510 --> 00:06:12.750
they're also what's going to hinder
us from delivering value too.

99
00:06:12.750 --> 00:06:16.940
Look at our soft skills,
look at our capabilities there.

100
00:06:16.940 --> 00:06:19.560
And how well we are organized.

101
00:06:19.560 --> 00:06:22.590
Well, that is whilst it might be,

102
00:06:22.590 --> 00:06:25.230
you might consider it to
be driven by management,

103
00:06:25.230 --> 00:06:29.660
cuz management set our organizational
structures, but it's also driven by people

104
00:06:29.660 --> 00:06:33.950
too, as to how collaborative they
are within that organization.

105
00:06:33.950 --> 00:06:37.024
And think about our management.

106
00:06:37.024 --> 00:06:40.400
I know I asked you, I put you on
the spot last time, didn't I, Ronnie?

107
00:06:40.400 --> 00:06:43.530
And I said to you, do you get on
with your managers all of the time?

108
00:06:43.530 --> 00:06:46.845
And the simple fact of the matter
is that there are always going

109
00:06:46.845 --> 00:06:51.465
to be interpersonal conflicts, there are
always going to be interpersonal issues.

110
00:06:51.465 --> 00:06:56.350
And so we've got to accept that,
that even if we've got good management

111
00:06:56.350 --> 00:06:59.570
then there may be
interpersonal issues there.

112
00:06:59.570 --> 00:07:03.860
And certainly, I know that we've
all worked in environments where

113
00:07:03.860 --> 00:07:07.280
there may be a siloed
mentality between teams.

114
00:07:08.810 --> 00:07:13.280
And it doesn't matter how good our
processes are, if our people do not

115
00:07:13.280 --> 00:07:17.350
have the right attitude or don't have
the right experience to be able to follow

116
00:07:17.350 --> 00:07:20.520
those processes,
then they're never going to deliver value.

117
00:07:20.520 --> 00:07:22.040
That's really as simple as that.

118
00:07:22.040 --> 00:07:26.630
So people are very, very important
to this, incredibly important.

119
00:07:26.630 --> 00:07:31.240
So I mentioned processes, well,
let's take a look at a process.

120
00:07:31.240 --> 00:07:35.920
I have mentioned in other sessions
that we look at in service operation

121
00:07:35.920 --> 00:07:39.520
that a process is a set
of structured activities

122
00:07:39.520 --> 00:07:42.630
designed to accomplish
a specific objective.

123
00:07:42.630 --> 00:07:45.700
And it takes an input and
turns it into an output.

124
00:07:45.700 --> 00:07:50.156
I think I remember I've said that,
we've had that discussion before, okay?

125
00:07:50.156 --> 00:07:54.845
So we are looking to deliver
value to our organization by

126
00:07:54.845 --> 00:07:57.553
facilitating their outcomes.

127
00:07:57.553 --> 00:08:02.753
We can't achieve their outcomes for
them, but we can facilitate Them.

128
00:08:02.753 --> 00:08:08.330
So we want to facilitate business process,
which lead to business outcomes,

129
00:08:08.330 --> 00:08:13.920
and we will use our processes in order
to support the services that we deliver.

130
00:08:15.440 --> 00:08:18.180
Then exactly is it says
in the next slide there.

131
00:08:18.180 --> 00:08:21.080
Supporting business processes so

132
00:08:21.080 --> 00:08:25.140
we use our IT processes to
support business processes.

133
00:08:25.140 --> 00:08:29.120
Now processes has four characteristics
is they are written there.

134
00:08:29.120 --> 00:08:30.859
A process has to be measurable.

135
00:08:32.100 --> 00:08:35.370
I know that it's something that
I've mentioned before, but

136
00:08:35.370 --> 00:08:39.520
because I think so
is not a good enough measurement, okay.

137
00:08:39.520 --> 00:08:43.530
We have to have tangible metrics that
tells us whether process is delivering

138
00:08:43.530 --> 00:08:47.520
value or not, whether the process
is effective and efficient.

139
00:08:47.520 --> 00:08:49.730
A process has to deliver
a specific result.

140
00:08:49.730 --> 00:08:52.790
We have to know what that
process is delivering.

141
00:08:52.790 --> 00:08:58.595
It has to be defined and it has to
deliver that result to a customer.

142
00:08:58.595 --> 00:09:01.820
Now, a customer or stakeholder,

143
00:09:01.820 --> 00:09:06.010
I like to use that word because sometimes
it's not always our customers that

>> And I'm Jo Peacock.
