00:23:43.551 --> 00:23:47.036
>> Stay tuned right now for
your ITIL Intermediate introduction.

374
00:23:48.699 --> 00:23:54.351
[MUSIC]

375
00:23:54.351 --> 00:23:57.570
>> Thank you for watching ITPRo.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue in Service Operation Principles.  Jo mentions that the key to the points of continuing to deliver value that is relevant to the business.  She emphasized every part of the IT Service Operations needs to think of balance.  Also in the communication process, we must also maintain relevancy in our communication that is meaningful to the customer as well!
episodes.title: Principles of Service Operation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.101
Welcome to ITPRO.TV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.101 --> 00:00:06.341
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.341 --> 00:00:08.454
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.454 --> 00:00:10.679
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:10.679 --> 00:00:12.467
[MUSIC]

6
00:00:12.467 --> 00:00:15.490
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPRO.TV.

7
00:00:15.490 --> 00:00:19.240
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Operation show.

8
00:00:19.240 --> 00:00:21.230
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong and

9
00:00:21.230 --> 00:00:25.400
today, we're diving into
principles of service operation.

10
00:00:25.400 --> 00:00:29.800
And here to help us is gonna be our ITIL
kung fu master herself, Ms. Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:29.800 --> 00:00:31.450
Jo, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:31.450 --> 00:00:33.100
>> Thank you, great to be here.

13
00:00:33.100 --> 00:00:38.193
>> All right, so as we begin to take
a look at the idea, the principles here,

14
00:00:38.193 --> 00:00:43.800
what are we really going to try to dive
into in terms of the different principles?

15
00:00:43.800 --> 00:00:45.030
Are there a lot that we
have to worry about.

16
00:00:46.070 --> 00:00:47.030
>> Not too many.

17
00:00:47.030 --> 00:00:48.850
What we need to do is understand.

18
00:00:48.850 --> 00:00:51.920
In the last episode,
we explored the idea of value and

19
00:00:51.920 --> 00:00:55.530
the fact that value diminishes
over time and so what we're

20
00:00:55.530 --> 00:01:00.120
going to do in this particular episode is
just explore that factor even further.

21
00:01:00.120 --> 00:01:04.440
So we're going to look at how
we actually maintain value.

22
00:01:04.440 --> 00:01:08.780
And that's what we are gonna be
focusing on over the next few moments.

23
00:01:08.780 --> 00:01:12.040
>> All right so Jo,
when you talk about this idea of value and

24
00:01:12.040 --> 00:01:17.120
its diminishing over time,
which apparently I can't say here, okay.

25
00:01:17.120 --> 00:01:20.730
What are some of the factors that
we're really gonna have to consider

26
00:01:20.730 --> 00:01:21.795
when we start doing it?

27
00:01:21.795 --> 00:01:24.990
You've mentioned in a previous
episode that we do have to worry about

28
00:01:24.990 --> 00:01:29.650
the very fact that there are things that
actually degrade or devalue over time or

29
00:01:29.650 --> 00:01:33.660
long period of time and then some that
actually kind of very quickly happen.

30
00:01:33.660 --> 00:01:35.850
What are some of the other
principles we have to worry about?

31
00:01:35.850 --> 00:01:38.420
>> Well,
let's take a look at our first slide

32
00:01:38.420 --> 00:01:43.010
that we have in front of us right now,
where, that first statement is so true.

33
00:01:43.010 --> 00:01:48.820
And it's so true nowadays in this 21st
century that all businesses face change.

34
00:01:48.820 --> 00:01:52.660
But it's not just that they face change,
it's they will change.

35
00:01:52.660 --> 00:01:53.860
Businesses will change.

36
00:01:53.860 --> 00:01:54.720
Life will change.

37
00:01:54.720 --> 00:01:56.250
Technology will change.

38
00:01:56.250 --> 00:01:59.590
And in fact, it's the only thing
that's fairly inevitable about IT,

39
00:01:59.590 --> 00:02:01.435
is that IT is going to change.

40
00:02:02.575 --> 00:02:08.475
Now we explored in the last episode
about the value diminishes over time.

41
00:02:08.475 --> 00:02:13.030
Well now we're going to tie that in with
the fact that business requirements change

42
00:02:13.030 --> 00:02:14.200
too.

43
00:02:14.200 --> 00:02:18.060
So it's not the fact that you
bought a cell phone last year,

44
00:02:18.060 --> 00:02:22.160
as we mentioned in the last episode and
now you don't perceive as much value in

45
00:02:22.160 --> 00:02:25.440
that cellphone because there's a new
one come out to the marketplace.

46
00:02:25.440 --> 00:02:29.529
Tie that in with the fact that maybe your
requirements have changed and no longer do

47
00:02:29.529 --> 00:02:32.921
you just need to be able to make
a phone call and receive a phone call.

48
00:02:32.921 --> 00:02:35.892
Now you want to be able to do
something else with it as well.

49
00:02:35.892 --> 00:02:40.805
Maybe now you want to live stream,
I don't know, a course online?

50
00:02:40.805 --> 00:02:41.580
>> Right.

51
00:02:41.580 --> 00:02:42.330
>> Yeah.

52
00:02:42.330 --> 00:02:47.242
So you're requirements change over time as
well as your perception of value changes

53
00:02:47.242 --> 00:02:48.420
over time.

54
00:02:48.420 --> 00:02:53.340
So it mentions in our particular
slide here while the value or

55
00:02:53.340 --> 00:02:57.820
the challenge being
compounded by balance issues.

56
00:02:57.820 --> 00:03:00.660
Now, don't worry I'm not going
to do anything as dramatic as

57
00:03:00.660 --> 00:03:03.685
what you can see on that
photograph in the slide there.

58
00:03:03.685 --> 00:03:04.960
>> [LAUGH]
>> Trust me,

59
00:03:04.960 --> 00:03:09.860
we wouldn't wanna do that, but let's
take a look at the value of the balances

60
00:03:09.860 --> 00:03:12.680
that we have to maintain within IT.

61
00:03:12.680 --> 00:03:18.160
And the first one is the balance on
external versus the balance on internal.

62
00:03:18.160 --> 00:03:23.380
An organization and I don't just mean IT,
I mean an organization as a whole.

63
00:03:23.380 --> 00:03:28.750
An organization as a whole that's very,
very focused on an internal perspective.

64
00:03:28.750 --> 00:03:34.669
That looks very, very much at
maintaining customer satisfaction for

65
00:03:34.669 --> 00:03:38.600
this current customers that they have.

66
00:03:38.600 --> 00:03:40.640
Well, if you maintain
an internal perspective,

67
00:03:40.640 --> 00:03:42.240
you get very, very good at what you do.

68
00:03:42.240 --> 00:03:44.280
You're very,
very efficient of what you do.

69
00:03:46.210 --> 00:03:48.800
But before you've noticed,
the rest of the world has moved on.

70
00:03:49.950 --> 00:03:56.252
We can all think of technology companies
where that's happened exactly to them.

71
00:03:56.252 --> 00:04:00.340
Whether it become completely
focused on their core business and

72
00:04:00.340 --> 00:04:03.990
what they actually do as a USP.

73
00:04:03.990 --> 00:04:06.990
Without realizing that the rest
of the world has moved on.

74
00:04:06.990 --> 00:04:10.035
And so that's an organization
that focuses on the internal and

75
00:04:10.035 --> 00:04:13.655
then you've got other organizations
that are considered to be drivers and

76
00:04:13.655 --> 00:04:15.620
that they focus on the external.

77
00:04:15.620 --> 00:04:19.440
You might consider them to be innovators,
for instance, in technology.

78
00:04:20.960 --> 00:04:25.952
Well, an organization that's an innovator
sometimes forgets what's happening back

79
00:04:25.952 --> 00:04:27.260
at base.

80
00:04:27.260 --> 00:04:31.520
And so we have to maintain that balance
and here in IT, we have to support that

81
00:04:31.520 --> 00:04:35.160
and we have to maintain that balance
with our service operations.

82
00:04:35.160 --> 00:04:39.400
We can't everybody going out and
playing with new toys.

83
00:04:39.400 --> 00:04:41.720
We can't have everybody being innovators.

84
00:04:41.720 --> 00:04:46.160
Somebody still has to
maintain the status quo.

85
00:04:46.160 --> 00:04:49.570
Somebody still has to ensure
that our services keep running.

86
00:04:49.570 --> 00:04:53.080
But the fact that our services
are running cannot be the only focus.

87
00:04:53.080 --> 00:04:56.340
So we can't just focus on the internal,

88
00:04:56.340 --> 00:05:01.180
we have to look to the future and
the fact that things are going to change.

89
00:05:01.180 --> 00:05:03.150
And that ties us into the next one,

90
00:05:03.150 --> 00:05:06.820
which is the focus on
Responsiveness versus Stability.

91
00:05:06.820 --> 00:05:10.540
You see, an organization that
can be quite introspective and

92
00:05:10.540 --> 00:05:14.440
quite internally focused,
tends to look for stability.

93
00:05:14.440 --> 00:05:16.610
And stability means minimal change.

94
00:05:16.610 --> 00:05:20.370
It means, I don't want to change anything
on our infrastructure right now,

95
00:05:20.370 --> 00:05:22.930
because there's a risk involved.

96
00:05:22.930 --> 00:05:25.350
So they tend to be risk-averse.

97
00:05:25.350 --> 00:05:31.710
Whereas an IT organization that wants
to be responsive to the business needs,

98
00:05:31.710 --> 00:05:33.610
well that means frequent change.

99
00:05:33.610 --> 00:05:36.130
And let's face it,
we don't like frequent change.

100
00:05:36.130 --> 00:05:38.570
It can be very unstable.

101
00:05:38.570 --> 00:05:44.560
And actually, what happens is we end up
looking as though, from an IT perspective,

102
00:05:44.560 --> 00:05:48.230
we're very disorganized in the way
we manage our IT services.

103
00:05:48.230 --> 00:05:49.510
Because quite often,

104
00:05:49.510 --> 00:05:54.240
an IT service provider that is very
responsive to the business needs,

105
00:05:54.240 --> 00:05:58.585
is asked the question, well can you
not tie these changes in together?

106
00:05:58.585 --> 00:06:02.600
Could you not just do one change per
month rather than one every day?

107
00:06:02.600 --> 00:06:05.100
That would be really good because
it's less disruptive to us.

108
00:06:06.300 --> 00:06:12.030
So we want to be responsive, but
we still have to maintain stability.

109
00:06:12.030 --> 00:06:14.780
And then you've got
the Cost versus Quality.

110
00:06:14.780 --> 00:06:18.650
Now this is one that we can all relate to,
because we all go grocery shopping.

111
00:06:18.650 --> 00:06:20.720
Okay.
We all go shopping for food.

112
00:06:20.720 --> 00:06:25.470
And we all make that decision every
time we walk into a grocery store.

113
00:06:25.470 --> 00:06:30.490
We say, okay, there is an assumption
that if we buy what we would consider to

114
00:06:30.490 --> 00:06:37.075
be the value line brand of a particular
commodity, whatever that may be.

115
00:06:37.075 --> 00:06:41.665
That, if we buy that, then we're
going to suffer on quality, whereas,

116
00:06:41.665 --> 00:06:45.725
if we buy a branded version,
then the quality will be better.

117
00:06:45.725 --> 00:06:47.165
It's an assumption we make.

118
00:06:47.165 --> 00:06:49.745
And it's not necessarily
a true assumption.

119
00:06:49.745 --> 00:06:52.025
But it's nevertheless
an assumption that we make.

120
00:06:53.340 --> 00:06:57.920
Some organizations are very,
what we would call, cash rich and

121
00:06:57.920 --> 00:07:01.010
therefore they think that if
we can just invest more and

122
00:07:01.010 --> 00:07:04.680
more money into IT then therefore
we're going to get quality.

123
00:07:04.680 --> 00:07:07.060
That's not necessarily the case.

124
00:07:07.060 --> 00:07:09.270
So we have to get that balance right.

125
00:07:09.270 --> 00:07:12.050
Understanding that quality does cost but

126
00:07:12.050 --> 00:07:16.220
at the same time, you can carry on
throwing money at IT services and

127
00:07:16.220 --> 00:07:19.800
if they're failing, it doesn't matter
how much money you throw at them.

128
00:07:19.800 --> 00:07:22.170
They're still going to fail.

129
00:07:22.170 --> 00:07:25.250
But then, of course, if we don't
have any money available to us,

130
00:07:25.250 --> 00:07:28.280
then our services are never
going to deliver value.

131
00:07:28.280 --> 00:07:30.550
So again,
we have to get that balance right.

132
00:07:32.060 --> 00:07:35.464
So if you take a look at
the graph in front of you,

133
00:07:35.464 --> 00:07:39.806
you'll see that actually where we
want to be is we want to be in

134
00:07:39.806 --> 00:07:44.766
a position where we have the right
balance between cost and quality.

135
00:07:44.766 --> 00:07:51.942
If we look at that particular graph and we
look at the middle section in that graph,

136
00:07:51.942 --> 00:07:57.768
we want to see that cost is decreasing but
quality is still rising.

137
00:07:57.768 --> 00:08:01.777
And it's a common misconception, again,
as I said, when we walk into the grocery

138
00:08:01.777 --> 00:08:05.768
store, that the more money we put into our
our IT, then the better our IT will get.

139
00:08:05.768 --> 00:08:10.553
And we've gotta be in a position
where we're continually improving IT,

140
00:08:10.553 --> 00:08:12.260
and IT is getting better.

141
00:08:12.260 --> 00:08:17.991
But we're not spending as much money as we
expected to spend, that we're actually,

142
00:08:17.991 --> 00:08:22.090
hopefully, maintaining
the status quo with our budget..

143
00:08:22.090 --> 00:08:26.039
But you never know, we could even be
reducing it as we get more efficient in

144
00:08:26.039 --> 00:08:28.790
supporting those services and
delivering value.

145
00:08:30.390 --> 00:08:35.662
The other thing that we have to take
into consideration, and this particular

146
00:08:35.662 --> 00:08:40.383
slide here looks at the amount of
information that we have access to.

147
00:08:40.383 --> 00:08:43.563
You see,
if you look on the left-hand side,

148
00:08:43.563 --> 00:08:47.345
you have what we call our
decision-making quality.

149
00:08:47.345 --> 00:08:52.098
And there is an assumption that if
somebody has a lot of information at their

150
00:08:52.098 --> 00:08:55.417
fingertips, if their service will do x,
y, and z,

151
00:08:55.417 --> 00:08:58.710
then that means it's a better service,
right?

152
00:08:58.710 --> 00:09:02.417
So we're putting more money into it,
we're getting more functionality, and

153
00:09:02.417 --> 00:09:04.560
it's going to be a better service.

154
00:09:04.560 --> 00:09:07.120
But like I said, that's an assumption, and

155
00:09:07.120 --> 00:09:09.930
sometimes what you get what
we call information overload.

156
00:09:11.090 --> 00:09:16.060
I'm going to go back to the example I used
in the previous section, where I said,

157
00:09:16.060 --> 00:09:18.160
what about that cellphone
that you bought last year?

158
00:09:18.160 --> 00:09:20.952
And so Ronnie,
I'm going to ask you a direct question.

159
00:09:20.952 --> 00:09:22.620
The cellphone that you have right now,

160
00:09:22.620 --> 00:09:26.390
how much of the functionality of
that cellphone do you actually use?

161
00:09:26.390 --> 00:09:30.053
I probably just use about a quarter of it,
more than anything else, right,

162
00:09:30.053 --> 00:09:33.450
I check some emails, I check Facebook,
I do a little bit of browsing.

163
00:09:33.450 --> 00:09:36.720
There are some other things I do,
I play some games on it, but overall,

164
00:09:36.720 --> 00:09:39.620
though, I probably don't use
every bit of the functionality.

165
00:09:39.620 --> 00:09:44.980
>> Right, and that's what we, in ITIL
terms, would consider to be information

166
00:09:44.980 --> 00:09:49.260
overload, or functionality overload,
in that we have bought a new product.

167
00:09:49.260 --> 00:09:53.590
We have brought in some innovation,
some new technology, but

168
00:09:53.590 --> 00:09:55.120
actually, we brought in more than we need.

169
00:09:56.210 --> 00:09:59.330
And this is addressed in the service
strategy life cycle phase,

170
00:09:59.330 --> 00:10:02.408
where we look at the relationship
between IT and the business.

171
00:10:02.408 --> 00:10:03.670
>> Mm-hm.

172
00:10:03.670 --> 00:10:07.600
>> How often has a business user, or
what we would consider to be an internal

173
00:10:07.600 --> 00:10:13.585
customer, sat there at their screen and
said, do you know what, I don't need this.

174
00:10:13.585 --> 00:10:14.630
>> Mm-hm.

175
00:10:14.630 --> 00:10:16.600
>> There's too much here for
me for me to do.

176
00:10:16.600 --> 00:10:20.520
I cannot work with this,
it's too cumbersome, it's too complicated.

177
00:10:20.520 --> 00:10:23.850
I don't need all the functionality,
I need something simple.

178
00:10:23.850 --> 00:10:29.150
And so one of the principles of ITIL
is that keep it simple approach,

179
00:10:29.150 --> 00:10:32.050
it's the very simple
approach to providing value.

180
00:10:33.910 --> 00:10:36.890
So again, when we look at our balances,

181
00:10:36.890 --> 00:10:40.580
we have to think about
reactive versus proactive, and

182
00:10:40.580 --> 00:10:43.840
we've mentioned this when we talked
about responsiveness versus stability.

183
00:10:43.840 --> 00:10:49.340
Are we a reactive service provider, or
are we a proactive service provider?

184
00:10:50.430 --> 00:10:54.690
The service provider, the IT service
provider that the business most values,

185
00:10:54.690 --> 00:10:57.570
is one that can get the balance right.

186
00:10:57.570 --> 00:11:01.944
Are we constantly responding to
the needs of the organization,

187
00:11:01.944 --> 00:11:04.541
the can I have this and can I have that?

188
00:11:04.541 --> 00:11:07.167
Cuz that's not a particularly efficient,
and

189
00:11:07.167 --> 00:11:11.390
the two tenets of ITIL are about
efficiency and effectiveness.

190
00:11:11.390 --> 00:11:15.910
We want to be efficient, and efficiency
means minimal waste, in terms of time,

191
00:11:15.910 --> 00:11:19.670
in terms of money,
in terms of skills as well.

192
00:11:19.670 --> 00:11:25.045
If we're reacting,
we're constantly firefighting.

193
00:11:25.045 --> 00:11:29.737
And if we're reacting to the can I have
this technology, then that means that us

194
00:11:29.737 --> 00:11:34.569
in IT have to go away and learn about that
new technology, and maybe even integrate

195
00:11:34.569 --> 00:11:38.960
it into our current infrastructure
before we can give it to our business.

196
00:11:38.960 --> 00:11:40.279
How long does that take us?

197
00:11:40.279 --> 00:11:41.800
It could take us quite some time.

198
00:11:43.140 --> 00:11:46.960
So what we want to do is put some focus,
not all of the focus,

199
00:11:46.960 --> 00:11:50.950
we want to put some focus on
the proactiveness of our service delivery,

200
00:11:53.040 --> 00:11:55.970
and we've got a process
that does exactly this.

201
00:11:55.970 --> 00:12:00.282
The business relationship management
process will sit amongst our organization,

202
00:12:00.282 --> 00:12:04.270
and we'll say, I see that you're
struggling, performing a certain task.

203
00:12:04.270 --> 00:12:07.400
Do you know what, we've got something
that can help you with that.

204
00:12:08.400 --> 00:12:13.520
And because it's proactive, because it's
something that's come from within IT,

205
00:12:13.520 --> 00:12:18.440
it means that we're already prepared for
this new technology, we know about it.

206
00:12:18.440 --> 00:12:22.450
It may already be integrated into our
infrastructure, and it may be very

207
00:12:22.450 --> 00:12:26.970
seamless to just slot it in, so
we're delivering value to the business.

208
00:12:26.970 --> 00:12:31.816
Now, we still have to react,
we can't be completely 100% proactive,

209
00:12:31.816 --> 00:12:33.120
cuz things change.

210
00:12:33.120 --> 00:12:36.790
So we have to get that balance
right between being proactive and

211
00:12:36.790 --> 00:12:37.950
being reactive.

212
00:12:39.160 --> 00:12:44.059
>> Now, Jo, when you take a look at that,
I think, at least, from my perspective,

213
00:12:44.059 --> 00:12:49.100
those two terms, especially, not the other
terms that we looked at in balance, but

214
00:12:49.100 --> 00:12:54.141
the term reactive, versus proactive today,
reactive just tends to have a negative

215
00:12:54.141 --> 00:12:58.772
connotation to it, even in the IT world,
versus the idea of proactive here.

216
00:12:58.772 --> 00:13:02.270
So trying to keep a balance is
probably the right approach.

217
00:13:02.270 --> 00:13:06.010
But at the same time, we all tend to
gravitate towards that terminology that we

218
00:13:06.010 --> 00:13:09.400
use as being more positive,
rather than the idea that

219
00:13:09.400 --> 00:13:13.290
reactive is always something bad and
proactive is always something good.

220

00:02:23.010 --> 00:02:28.410
Now we could just have a thermostat and a
thermostat will just, sorry a thermometer,

44
00:02:28.410 --> 00:02:32.640
and a thermometer will simply just
monitor the temperature in the room.

45
00:02:32.640 --> 00:02:34.948
It tells you what the temperature is.

46
00:02:34.948 --> 00:02:38.650
Now in our last session we
talked about communication and

47
00:02:38.650 --> 00:02:40.270
the fact that we speak
different languages.

48
00:02:40.270 --> 00:02:44.491
Now I speak in Celsius and I know that
you speak in Farenheit but either way,

49
00:02:44.491 --> 00:02:46.910
it doesn't matter which way we look at it.

50
00:02:46.910 --> 00:02:51.580
We would know, that if we were in the room
and temperature was 35 Celsius, or

51
00:02:51.580 --> 00:02:54.440
it was 90 Fahrenheit, then we'd know,
that that was too hot.

52
00:02:55.620 --> 00:02:59.642
But all the thermometer is going is to do
is just tell you what the temperature is,

53
00:02:59.642 --> 00:03:00.777
that's monitoring.

54
00:03:02.228 --> 00:03:06.510
A thermostat on the other hand,
will tell you not only about what

55
00:03:06.510 --> 00:03:11.189
the temperature is but will then make
an adjustment of the temperature

56
00:03:11.189 --> 00:03:15.280
based on a predefined setting
that you have preprogrammed.

57
00:03:15.280 --> 00:03:17.540
We'd call that a parameter.

58
00:03:17.540 --> 00:03:22.720
So, you might set your thermostat on
your wall to say 72 degrees Fahrenheit.

59
00:03:22.720 --> 00:03:26.178
And so, when the temperature goes
above 72 degrees Fahrenheit,

60
00:03:26.178 --> 00:03:30.760
well the thermostat ensures that the air

61
00:03:30.760 --> 00:03:35.850
conditioning kicks in and
it lowers the temperature in that room.

62
00:03:35.850 --> 00:03:37.880
That's event management.

63
00:03:37.880 --> 00:03:42.890
So event management's job is to detect
events, make sense of them, and

64
00:03:42.890 --> 00:03:45.690
then decide what to do about them.

65
00:03:45.690 --> 00:03:48.710
So there you go,
the purpose of event management.

66
00:03:48.710 --> 00:03:50.750
So, what's that gotta do with IT?

67
00:03:50.750 --> 00:03:56.520
Well, in IT we are continually monitoring
our servers and things happen.

68
00:03:56.520 --> 00:04:02.920
Backups start, backups finish, sometimes
backups fail and event management

69
00:04:02.920 --> 00:04:08.420
monitors all of those activities and
then decides what to do about them.

70
00:04:08.420 --> 00:04:11.260
So let's say I'm going to
ask you a question then.

71
00:04:11.260 --> 00:04:14.120
Let's say a backup starts,
what do we need to do about that?

72
00:04:14.120 --> 00:04:16.370
We get a message to tell
us that a backup starts.

73
00:04:17.450 --> 00:04:21.280
>> Yeah, to backup the machine we would
actually run some type of backup utility

74
00:04:21.280 --> 00:04:26.230
and at least begin the process of
deciding what needs to be backed up and

75
00:04:26.230 --> 00:04:30.960
then of course making sure we have
the capacity to back it up as well.

76
00:04:30.960 --> 00:04:33.780
>> So let's say you get an alert message
that pops up on your screen that

77
00:04:33.780 --> 00:04:35.040
says the backup has started.

78
00:04:35.040 --> 00:04:35.960
What would you do?

79
00:04:35.960 --> 00:04:38.663
>> I would probably monitor it.

80
00:04:38.663 --> 00:04:39.464
>> Exactly.

81
00:04:39.464 --> 00:04:40.942
>> Make sure that it starts
>> Nothing really.

82
00:04:40.942 --> 00:04:41.663
>> Yeah.

83
00:04:41.663 --> 00:04:42.730
>> Yeah, that's okay.

84
00:04:42.730 --> 00:04:45.133
That's what we call
an informational event.

85
00:04:45.133 --> 00:04:48.280
It's just information,
nothing more than that.

86
00:04:48.280 --> 00:04:50.720
You get a message to say
that the backup's finished,

87
00:04:50.720 --> 00:04:52.910
you're probably gonna do
exactly the same thing.

88
00:04:52.910 --> 00:04:54.010
Nothing, that's great.

89
00:04:55.260 --> 00:04:58.010
But then you get a message to
say that the backup has failed.

90
00:04:59.370 --> 00:05:01.850
Now, that's what we would
call either a warning or

91
00:05:01.850 --> 00:05:07.050
an exceptional event depending on what the
expectation was for you to do about that.

92
00:05:08.240 --> 00:05:11.610
A warning event is a warning that
something's about to happen and

93
00:05:11.610 --> 00:05:15.490
an exceptional event is that
there has been a failure and

94
00:05:15.490 --> 00:05:20.090
event management will take those events,
depending on those parameters, and

95
00:05:20.090 --> 00:05:23.540
say right, okay, so the backup has failed.

96
00:05:23.540 --> 00:05:27.410
Now I need to send a message
asking somebody to intervene and

97
00:05:27.410 --> 00:05:30.470
it may be that the backups fail
because the tape's full and

98
00:05:30.470 --> 00:05:32.570
somebody needs to go and replace the tape.

99
00:05:34.060 --> 00:05:36.106
So this is what event management does and
so

100
00:05:36.106 --> 00:05:42.083
the objective of event management
is to detect changes of state.

101
00:05:42.083 --> 00:05:44.340
In other words something's happened.

102
00:05:44.340 --> 00:05:48.220
For the management of our configuration
items, remember those components of

103
00:05:48.220 --> 00:05:52.830
a service, those configuration items that
we referred to in service transition?

104
00:05:53.920 --> 00:05:59.180
And then decide what to do about it that
determine appropriate control actions.

105
00:05:59.180 --> 00:06:02.130
The third bullet point in
the objectives talks about a trigger or

106
00:06:02.130 --> 00:06:04.740
an entry point for other processes.

107
00:06:04.740 --> 00:06:10.400
So the appropriate action could
well be to raise an incident and

108
00:06:10.400 --> 00:06:13.580
we'll take a look at that when we look at
the section of incident management and

109
00:06:13.580 --> 00:06:15.010
problem management.

110
00:06:15.010 --> 00:06:19.490
So when I say to you that a thermostat
on the wall actually compares against

111
00:06:19.490 --> 00:06:24.000
a parameter, that's that next bullet point
down about comparing actual performance.

112
00:06:24.000 --> 00:06:29.402
The actual real temperature of
the room versus the design parameters.

113
00:06:29.402 --> 00:06:35.049
So the real temperature of the room is 78,
we designed it to be maintained at 72 so

114
00:06:35.049 --> 00:06:38.720
we're going to bring in
the air conditioning, okay.

115
00:06:38.720 --> 00:06:42.902
Which is why we talk about a basis for
service assurance as well and also for

116
00:06:42.902 --> 00:06:47.427
service improvement because perhaps
if the temperatures of the room keeps

117
00:06:47.427 --> 00:06:51.447
exceeding 72, then maybe we need
to do something about servicing

118
00:06:51.447 --> 00:06:53.973
that air conditioning unit for instance.

119
00:06:53.973 --> 00:06:59.024
So, as I've already said this
could be completely automated and

120
00:06:59.024 --> 00:07:02.214
anything that needs to be controlled,

121
00:07:02.214 --> 00:07:07.929
anything that needs to be monitored
can come under event management.

122
00:07:07.929 --> 00:07:11.620
And the event management
process simply monitors events,

123
00:07:11.620 --> 00:07:17.500
determines changes of state, makes sense
of them, and then does something about it.

124
00:07:17.500 --> 00:07:21.270
And anything could be
covered by event management.

125
00:07:21.270 --> 00:07:22.730
Could be monitored and

126
00:07:22.730 --> 00:07:26.790
then managed by event management including
environmental considerations, in other

127
00:07:26.790 --> 00:07:31.340
words the temperature in a room but
including the use of software licenses.

128
00:07:31.340 --> 00:07:34.080
Also security activity,
somebody logging in or

129
00:07:34.080 --> 00:07:38.340
somebody logging out or somebody
forgetting their password for instance.

130
00:07:39.522 --> 00:07:43.703
That part of logging in to your
organization where you've forgotten

131
00:07:43.703 --> 00:07:47.823
your password three times and
then it locks you out for ten minutes.

132
00:07:47.823 --> 00:07:49.598
That's event management doing that.

133
00:07:49.598 --> 00:07:53.842
There's not a real person sitting there
watching you through the camera on your

134
00:07:53.842 --> 00:07:58.168
screen saying you've forgotten your
password, I'm gonna lock you out now.

135
00:07:58.168 --> 00:08:01.012
It's event management that does that for
you.

136
00:08:01.012 --> 00:08:04.775
So the value to the business owner
should be fairly self explanatory,

137
00:08:04.775 --> 00:08:07.345
it's about the early
detection of incidents.

138
00:08:07.345 --> 00:08:12.030
When something goes wrong,
event management will automatically detect

139
00:08:12.030 --> 00:08:16.193
that something's gone wrong and
will raise an incident for you.

140
00:08:16.193 --> 00:08:20.090
So as we've already said,
it's all about automated activities.

141
00:08:22.450 --> 00:08:25.980
The last bullet point, because we've
covered all the others on that slide,

142
00:08:25.980 --> 00:08:29.220
the last bullet point talks about
preventing service degradation.

143
00:08:30.300 --> 00:08:34.180
I mentioned that we had three
different types of event.

144
00:08:34.180 --> 00:08:35.640
I mentioned the information event,

145
00:08:35.640 --> 00:08:39.850
where we do absolutely nothing other
than just log that something happened.

146
00:08:39.850 --> 00:08:44.890
The backup started, the backup finishing,
somebody logging in, somebody logging out.

147
00:08:44.890 --> 00:08:49.350
We also have warning events, warning
that a threshold is about to be reached.

148
00:08:49.350 --> 00:08:52.750
So for instance,
capacity is running at say 80%,

149
00:08:52.750 --> 00:08:57.870
we might set a threshold to
alert us when that's happened.

150
00:08:57.870 --> 00:09:01.231
And that's a warning event, so
nothing's been breached yet,

151
00:09:01.231 --> 00:09:03.546
there's been no interruption to service.

152
00:09:03.546 --> 00:09:07.334
But we need to know about it because
we need to do something about it,

153
00:09:07.334 --> 00:09:11.794
hence the preventing service degradation,
or preventive customer service.

154
00:09:11.794 --> 00:09:16.095
And then we've got the warning events,
where there has been a failure.

155
00:09:16.095 --> 00:09:20.369
Where you've tried to put your
password in three times and

156
00:09:20.369 --> 00:09:23.597
forgotten it, and
it has locked you out, or

157
00:09:23.597 --> 00:09:28.409
where capacity is being exceeded,
or where a backup has failed.

158
00:09:28.409 --> 00:09:32.496
And there's a thought point at the bottom
of the screen there that said,

159
00:09:32.496 --> 00:09:36.851
if you were trying to convince your
organization to set up Event Management,

160
00:09:36.851 --> 00:09:38.536
what reasons would you give?

161
00:09:38.536 --> 00:09:41.575
Well, they've given you all of
the reasons in the slides above.

162
00:09:41.575 --> 00:09:45.655
There are quite a few reasons, but
there's also security reasons,

163
00:09:45.655 --> 00:09:49.270
let's think about that
security implication.

164
00:09:49.270 --> 00:09:55.280
It's also, we talked in the last section
about proactive versus reactive.

165
00:09:55.280 --> 00:09:59.110
It's also cheaper to be

166
00:09:59.110 --> 00:10:03.900
aware that capacity is pretty
much near to its threshold, and

167
00:10:03.900 --> 00:10:07.850
it's been like that over the last,
I don't know, six weeks for instance.

168
00:10:07.850 --> 00:10:13.385
So it's cheaper to buy in
capacity when we're preparing,

169
00:10:13.385 --> 00:10:18.680
than it is to have a breach, and
then realize that we need more capacity,

170
00:10:18.680 --> 00:10:22.920
and having to buy servers or
disk space at the last minute.

171
00:10:22.920 --> 00:10:27.015
So actually,
you can save us a lot of money as well, so

172
00:10:27.015 --> 00:10:31.929
that's another point that we could
use to sell to the business,

173
00:10:31.929 --> 00:10:34.672
the benefits of event management.

174
00:10:34.672 --> 00:10:40.490
Event management should be streamlined,
and everything should be logged.

175
00:10:40.490 --> 00:10:45.290
This means that you have to ensure
that you have enough disk space

176
00:10:45.290 --> 00:10:48.050
to be able to store those events.

177
00:10:48.050 --> 00:10:50.900
So you'll need to have policies in
place that are going to help you.

178
00:10:50.900 --> 00:10:57.326
For instance, policies that say, where are
you going to archive all of this data to?

179
00:10:57.326 --> 00:11:01.201
You can't just keep it in your live
service forever and ever and ever.

180
00:11:01.201 --> 00:11:04.260
Do you ever delete any of your events?

181
00:11:04.260 --> 00:11:08.135
Or do you actually just archive them off
onto tapes after a certain period of time?

182
00:11:08.135 --> 00:11:10.567
That's a policy decision you have to make.

183
00:11:10.567 --> 00:11:14.851
You have to decide what
parameters that you need to

184
00:11:14.851 --> 00:11:19.240
input into the event
management tool that you use.

185
00:11:19.240 --> 00:11:22.050
And you will need a tool to
help you with event management.

186
00:11:22.050 --> 00:11:26.253
Either that or you'll need a very large
budget, because you'll need a lot of

187
00:11:26.253 --> 00:11:30.082
people sitting in front of a screen,
monitoring what's happening.

188
00:11:30.082 --> 00:11:31.061
So think about the tool,

189
00:11:31.061 --> 00:11:33.544
think about the parameters that
you're gonna put in the tool.

190
00:11:33.544 --> 00:11:37.802
And service level management
is going to help us with that,

191
00:11:37.802 --> 00:11:43.350
because this is where we define the target
for our operation of our services.

192
00:11:44.750 --> 00:11:46.274
We need to have, and

193
00:11:46.274 --> 00:11:52.330
I really love this fourth bullet
point that talks about standards.

194
00:11:52.330 --> 00:11:57.016
You need to have a set of standards for
what will appear on your alert messages,

195
00:11:57.016 --> 00:11:59.714
those messages that
flash up on the screens.

196
00:11:59.714 --> 00:12:03.310
You also need to have a set of standards
for what you're going to monitor.

197
00:12:03.310 --> 00:12:04.866
Because quite simply,

198
00:12:04.866 --> 00:12:09.998
if I'm the operator that's looking at
these events scrolling on the screen,

199
00:12:09.998 --> 00:12:14.835
and every single event is set up in
a different way and a different format.

200
00:12:14.835 --> 00:12:19.029
We're going to go back to this language
thing that we talked about just a few

201
00:12:19.029 --> 00:12:21.840
minutes ago, and
I don't know what I'm seeing.

202
00:12:21.840 --> 00:12:26.208
I could be seeing 100 different things and
it's very difficult for

203
00:12:26.208 --> 00:12:30.514
me to ascertain which one needs my
attention and which one doesn't.

204
00:12:30.514 --> 00:12:34.334
And so other policies that we would need
to have is what we're going to automate,

205
00:12:34.334 --> 00:12:38.061
and what we're not going to automate,
if there's anything that we're not.

206
00:12:38.061 --> 00:12:42.736
Because let's face it, we're talking
about efficiency and effectiveness, and

207
00:12:42.736 --> 00:12:47.140
as far as event management is concerned,
it's always going to be efficient to

208
00:12:47.140 --> 00:12:52.120
automate as long as the parameters are set
up correctly, in an effective way.

209
00:12:53.660 --> 00:12:56.610
And then what are we going to do
about those exceptional events and

210
00:12:56.610 --> 00:12:58.170
those warning events?

211
00:12:58.170 --> 00:13:03.890
Something has to be done with them,
they have to be what we call escalated.

212
00:13:03.890 --> 00:13:09.230
And maybe we need to raise an incident
record to deal with any failures,

213
00:13:09.230 --> 00:13:13.330
or perhaps to prevent
services being interrupted.

214
00:13:13.330 --> 00:13:17.490
So those policies have to
be very clearly defined.

215
00:13:17.490 --> 00:13:21.820
So this next page actually shows us
what the different types of events are.

216
00:13:21.820 --> 00:13:24.090
There are three different types,
as we've already said.

217
00:13:24.090 --> 00:13:26.590
Informational, just information.

218
00:13:26.590 --> 00:13:31.490
Warning, something's about to happen,
but it hasn't happened yet.

219
00:13:31.490 --> 00:13:34.520
And exceptional, there has been a failure.

220
00:13:36.130 --> 00:13:39.060
Now we also have something else
within event management, and

221
00:13:39.060 --> 00:13:42.700
I've mentioned it a few times,
and we call that an alert.

222
00:13:42.700 --> 00:13:47.698
And an alert is the message that pops
up on the screen that tells you that

223
00:13:47.698 --> 00:13:52.280
something is either about to fail,
or something has failed.

224
00:13:53.720 --> 00:14:00.100
You'll also need to set up a policy and
parameters for alert notification.

225
00:14:01.720 --> 00:14:06.860
In the last section that we looked at,
the principles of service operation,

226
00:14:06.860 --> 00:14:10.747
I talked about communication,
and I asked the question.

227
00:14:10.747 --> 00:14:16.130
How many emails, on a percentage,
do you delete without even opening them?

228
00:14:17.150 --> 00:14:21.184
And I said, I actually admitted and
I shouldn't really, but

229
00:14:21.184 --> 00:14:25.373
I admitted that I deleted probably
about 40% of my emails, so

230
00:14:25.373 --> 00:14:28.257
let's think about alert generation then.

231
00:14:28.257 --> 00:14:32.101
If you're in receipt of
alerts from any server,

232
00:14:32.101 --> 00:14:38.027
at what point in time do you delete
those emails without even opening them?

233
00:14:38.027 --> 00:14:41.137
Now, you're probably going
to delete warning emails,

234
00:14:41.137 --> 00:14:43.295
would you delete exceptional emails?

235
00:14:43.295 --> 00:14:47.792
Well, obviously we shouldn't,
it wouldn't be best practice,

236
00:14:47.792 --> 00:14:49.652
but I know that it happens.

237
00:14:49.652 --> 00:14:52.122
Because if you've got 100 emails a day and

238
00:14:52.122 --> 00:14:54.658
they've all come in in
the last five minutes,

239
00:14:54.658 --> 00:14:58.965
I can be pretty certain that you're not
going to read all those 100 emails.

240
00:14:58.965 --> 00:15:04.114
So again we have to have a policy for
alert generation, but let's face it,

241
00:15:04.114 --> 00:15:08.557
it has to be a common sense policy,
sometimes we do forget that.

242
00:15:08.557 --> 00:15:12.990
We like to generate alerts just for
the sake of generating alerts,

243
00:15:12.990 --> 00:15:17.830
and there needs to be a policy to back
up all aspects of event management.

244
00:15:19.840 --> 00:15:23.670
So that leads us in to
designing event management.

245
00:15:23.670 --> 00:15:28.180
And in service design, that life cycle
phase where we took the ideas from service

246
00:15:28.180 --> 00:15:31.031
strategy, and
then we designed the services, and

247
00:15:31.031 --> 00:15:34.306
we designed the processes
that underpin those services.

248
00:15:34.306 --> 00:15:38.680
Well, event management is one of
those processes that we designed.

249
00:15:38.680 --> 00:15:43.522
And so we designed for any new service and
also for our existing services because

250
00:15:43.522 --> 00:15:48.250
we're interested in value and
maintaining alignment to the business.

251
00:15:48.250 --> 00:15:54.752
So we design on a continual basis,
on an iterative basis.

252
00:15:54.752 --> 00:15:59.729
We look at what we're monitoring,
we look at what we do with those events,

253
00:15:59.729 --> 00:16:03.995
and then we decide What we're going
to do with all these events on

254
00:16:03.995 --> 00:16:07.090
a continual basis to
ensure that we add value.

255
00:16:08.520 --> 00:16:11.763
Now I mentioned about automation.

256
00:16:11.763 --> 00:16:14.608
We've gotta have the right tools
to perform event management.

257
00:16:14.608 --> 00:16:17.812
Event management doesn't just happen.

258
00:16:17.812 --> 00:16:22.680
We have to have the right tools that
allow us to monitor the services that we

259
00:16:22.680 --> 00:16:26.919
have but also allow us to do
something with the information, and

260
00:16:26.919 --> 00:16:30.470
it may allow us to archive or
forward our data as well.

261
00:16:32.020 --> 00:16:38.016
So if I take a look at the bullet points
that we've got here we have to design for

262
00:16:38.016 --> 00:16:39.595
event management.

263
00:16:39.595 --> 00:16:42.515
We have to decide what
we're going to monitor,

264
00:16:42.515 --> 00:16:46.019
bearing in mind that not enough
is gonna be no value to us,

265
00:16:46.019 --> 00:16:50.490
but then too much monitoring is not
going to be valuable to us either.

266
00:16:50.490 --> 00:16:54.500
Because we'll be in a position where
you quite simply can't see the wood for

267
00:16:54.500 --> 00:16:55.480
the trees.

268
00:16:55.480 --> 00:16:58.580
Or as perhaps you would say we
can't see the forest for the trees.

269
00:16:59.670 --> 00:17:02.490
So we have to design what
we're going to monitor and

270
00:17:02.490 --> 00:17:07.790
we have to make sure that the error
messaging that we use is meaningful,

271
00:17:07.790 --> 00:17:11.180
it's very specific, it's clear,
concise and unambiguous.

272
00:17:11.180 --> 00:17:15.619
But more importantly it's in
the language of the audience.

273
00:17:15.619 --> 00:17:22.330
We don't want to be scare mongery,
we want to be honest with our messaging.

274
00:17:22.330 --> 00:17:25.200
And that's actually quite
an important point.

275
00:17:25.200 --> 00:17:28.968
Because if you get a message
that flashes up on your screen

276
00:17:28.968 --> 00:17:33.287
20 times in five minutes, and
it says alert, alert, alert and

277
00:17:33.287 --> 00:17:37.448
then when you actually go and
look further into that alert, and

278
00:17:37.448 --> 00:17:42.812
find out that actually it's only the CPU
that's been running at sort of 65%.

279
00:17:42.812 --> 00:17:45.360
Then the next time you get a message,
you're going to ignore it.

280
00:17:46.810 --> 00:17:50.326
So we have to ensure our
messages are meaningful and

281
00:17:50.326 --> 00:17:52.959
that they're completely relevant.

282
00:17:52.959 --> 00:18:00.109
And, we have to have a way of filtering
and escalating those alerts where needed.

283
00:18:00.109 --> 00:18:03.387
So, of course we have to identify
what the thresholds are and

284
00:18:03.387 --> 00:18:06.670
service level management
will help us with that.

285
00:18:06.670 --> 00:18:10.170
And it says also then that it's
managed by availability management and

286
00:18:10.170 --> 00:18:11.760
capacity management.

287
00:18:11.760 --> 00:18:15.417
And they would be the proactive
parts of availability management and

288
00:18:15.417 --> 00:18:16.685
capacity management.

289
00:18:16.685 --> 00:18:20.627
The proactive parts where
we're looking at redundancy,

290
00:18:20.627 --> 00:18:25.776
where we're looking at reliability and
we're looking at potential threat

291
00:18:25.776 --> 00:18:31.102
to those service level targets that we
place in the service level agreements.

292
00:18:31.102 --> 00:18:37.653
The last particular three words in this
slide are probably the most important.

293
00:18:37.653 --> 00:18:42.721
And that is the fact that event
management has to be based on experience.

294
00:18:42.721 --> 00:18:47.291
Whether that experiences come from
in-house whether that experiences come

295
00:18:47.291 --> 00:18:48.635
from your suppliers.

296
00:18:48.635 --> 00:18:52.868
They will be able to help you with this
for any service that you're implementing.

297
00:18:52.868 --> 00:18:57.686
Or whether that experience comes from
saying industry standard because it's not

298
00:18:57.686 --> 00:19:01.823
something that you ever monitored before,
then it doesn't matter.

299
00:19:01.823 --> 00:19:07.252
We still need to have the experience
to set the right level of alerts and

300
00:19:07.252 --> 00:19:11.220
to set the right parameters for
event management.

301
00:19:12.570 --> 00:19:18.170
So in conclusion I'm going
to just look at the example

302
00:19:18.170 --> 00:19:24.010
that we have in the ITIL book
of the event management process.

303
00:19:24.010 --> 00:19:27.080
And remember what I said,
about event management and

304
00:19:27.080 --> 00:19:29.170
liking it to that thermostart.

305
00:19:29.170 --> 00:19:34.120
Where we monitor the temperature
in a room, and then we

306
00:19:34.120 --> 00:19:38.420
make adjustments based on the parameters
that we've set on that thermostat.

307
00:19:38.420 --> 00:19:42.447
So, let's take a look at this
particular process then.

308
00:19:42.447 --> 00:19:48.950
So the event occurs, something happens
I don't know, a user logged on.

309
00:19:48.950 --> 00:19:51.290
Let's take this one for an example.

310
00:19:51.290 --> 00:19:56.270
So we're notified of the event, in other
words the Event Management System is

311
00:19:56.270 --> 00:20:01.650
notified, or the tool is notified of the
event and it's detected and it logs it.

312
00:20:02.750 --> 00:20:04.610
So then what is it doing?

313
00:20:04.610 --> 00:20:09.384
Well the first thing that the tool has
to do is decide on the significance of

314
00:20:09.384 --> 00:20:10.156
the event.

315
00:20:10.156 --> 00:20:13.177
Is it just informational,
is it a warning, or

316
00:20:13.177 --> 00:20:16.821
is it a exceptional in
the example that I've given you.

317
00:20:16.821 --> 00:20:20.900
And we're going to be just going through
these different slides here over the next

318
00:20:20.900 --> 00:20:22.020
three slides.

319
00:20:22.020 --> 00:20:25.319
So in the example that I gave you,
somebody is logged in it's informational.

320
00:20:25.319 --> 00:20:28.731
So let's follow that left hand arrow then,
and look at it,

321
00:20:28.731 --> 00:20:32.487
the left hand arrow there it just
comes straight down and it says,

322
00:20:32.487 --> 00:20:35.866
okay we can just close the event,
nothing more than that.

323
00:20:38.063 --> 00:20:45.197
So let's go back, and let's say that
that event was a warning event.

324
00:20:45.197 --> 00:20:51.619
You have reached 75% or 80% of disk space.

325
00:20:51.619 --> 00:20:54.880
So, let's follow the middle arrow then,
the warning event.

326
00:20:54.880 --> 00:20:59.580
So the warning event goes in to
the second level event correlation, and

327
00:20:59.580 --> 00:21:04.982
bearing in mind this is just an example,
it's up to you to adopt ITIL processes and

328
00:21:04.982 --> 00:21:08.680
then adapt them to suit your environment.

329
00:21:08.680 --> 00:21:11.940
So let's scroll down then and
look for what this examples tells us.

330
00:21:11.940 --> 00:21:14.530
Well, second level event correlation just

331
00:21:14.530 --> 00:21:17.750
looks at the fact that you might
just have to do something about it.

332
00:21:17.750 --> 00:21:19.289
Do I need to do something?

333
00:21:20.450 --> 00:21:21.340
No and

334
00:21:21.340 --> 00:21:26.940
if the answer is no you don't need to do
anything cuz 75% is perfectly acceptable.

335
00:21:26.940 --> 00:21:31.462
Or 80% and you'll notice that
if 75% is perfectly acceptable,

336
00:21:31.462 --> 00:21:34.612
then look we carry on to
just causing that event.

337
00:21:34.612 --> 00:21:39.500
But if it was at 80% then
maybe it needs further action.

338
00:21:39.500 --> 00:21:42.970
In which case,
we can do one of many things and

339
00:21:42.970 --> 00:21:48.260
we can either generate an auto
response that perhaps goes to

340
00:21:48.260 --> 00:21:51.500
incident management or
problem management or change management.

341
00:21:51.500 --> 00:21:57.050
Or, maybe it generates an alert
that goes to a human intervention,

342
00:21:57.050 --> 00:21:58.590
it goes to a person.

343
00:21:59.970 --> 00:22:02.710
And that person then will
do something about it.

344
00:22:02.710 --> 00:22:05.520
And if necessary,
they'll raise a request for

345
00:22:05.520 --> 00:22:09.330
instance to perhaps make standard change.

346
00:22:09.330 --> 00:22:14.390
If that worked, whatever the person did,
then, if it's effective,

347
00:22:14.390 --> 00:22:15.560
then they'll close the event.

348
00:22:15.560 --> 00:22:19.780
If not,
then we go back potentially to incident,

349
00:22:19.780 --> 00:22:22.169
or problem, or raising a change record.

350
00:22:23.840 --> 00:22:27.025
Then they start third option.

351
00:22:27.025 --> 00:22:29.426
And, the third type of event
is that exceptional event.

352
00:22:29.426 --> 00:22:31.216
That's something failed.

353
00:22:31.216 --> 00:22:33.243
Something has gone wrong.

354
00:22:33.243 --> 00:22:34.764
If something has failed,

355
00:22:34.764 --> 00:22:38.650
then this is not just a warning
where it needs human intervention.

356
00:22:38.650 --> 00:22:42.638
We've got to do something
with that failure.

357
00:22:42.638 --> 00:22:48.560
And so what we may choose to do is either
raise an incident and that incident record

358
00:22:48.560 --> 00:22:54.587
will allow somebody to restore no more
service operation as quickly as possible.

359
00:22:54.587 --> 00:22:57.066
In other words,
get it back up and running.

360
00:22:57.066 --> 00:23:01.133
Or, we raise a problem record and
a problem record will look for

361
00:23:01.133 --> 00:23:04.684
the root cause and
determine why something is failed.

362
00:23:04.684 --> 00:23:07.696
Or we might raise a change of record and

363
00:23:07.696 --> 00:23:13.733
a change record will allow somebody to
make a change to the infrastructure.

364
00:23:13.733 --> 00:23:18.102
Because something has failed and
we need to say swap out a disk or

365
00:23:18.102 --> 00:23:20.333
swap out a server for instance.

366
00:23:20.333 --> 00:23:25.447
Obviously that's sort of quite
exceptional, very exceptional.

367
00:23:25.447 --> 00:23:29.600
Once that has been completed,
then, if it's affected,

368
00:23:29.600 --> 00:23:34.446
then again we close the event and
that's it, the end of that event.

369
00:23:37.252 --> 00:23:44.430
This is just an example from the ITIL book
as to what an event process may look like.

370
00:23:45.710 --> 00:23:50.137
It's up to you to work out
what is the most effective and

371
00:23:50.137 --> 00:23:54.191
the most efficient process flow for
your events.

372
00:23:54.191 --> 00:23:58.504
But it's this process that
underpins the day to day

373
00:23:58.504 --> 00:24:02.324
business as usual running
of your services.

374
00:24:05.437 --> 00:24:08.700
So, in conclusion, in event management,

375
00:24:08.700 --> 00:24:12.227
the only process that may
be fully automated and

376
00:24:12.227 --> 00:24:17.978
it is the process that underpins the day
to day running of all of our services.

377
00:24:17.978 --> 00:24:21.489
>> All right, Jo, and there's been a lot
of information that we've covered so

378
00:24:21.489 --> 00:24:22.360
far in the series.

379
00:24:22.360 --> 00:24:26.450
Is there anything that we need
to kind of just think about or

380
00:24:26.450 --> 00:24:29.130
do at this point Before we proceed on?

381
00:24:29.130 --> 00:24:33.244
>> Yes, within your course
materials that you have downloaded,

382
00:24:33.244 --> 00:24:34.958
you have some exercises.

383
00:24:34.958 --> 00:24:40.671
And we do have recap exercises to
go all of this particular process.

384
00:24:40.671 --> 00:24:45.185
But also part of these exercises
that will help to expand your

385
00:24:45.185 --> 00:24:48.030
understanding of event management.

386
00:24:48.030 --> 00:24:52.158
For instance that question that I
asked about if you're trying to

387
00:24:52.158 --> 00:24:56.748
justify event management within your
organization how would you do it?

388
00:24:56.748 --> 00:25:00.993
>> All right Jo thank you for that
reminder that we do need to take advantage

389
00:25:00.993 --> 00:25:03.612
of those materials that are also provided,

390
00:25:03.612 --> 00:25:07.676
cuz it also helps of course as you
prepare for that ITIL exam as well.

391
00:25:07.676 --> 00:25:11.316
So remember that the concept that we
looked at here under event management and

392
00:25:11.316 --> 00:25:14.739
this is the first process that we're
diving into in service operation.

393
00:25:14.739 --> 00:25:18.035
We also of course, talked about the
different alerts that are out there and

394
00:25:18.035 --> 00:25:20.274
the activities which Jo
showed us here at the end.

395
00:25:20.274 --> 00:25:24.030
But this is a great place for
us to end this episode, then.

396
00:25:24.030 --> 00:25:27.874
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

397
00:25:27.874 --> 00:25:29.009
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

398
00:25:29.009 --> 00:25:34.669
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation shows.

399
00:25:34.669 --> 00:25:40.743
[MUSIC]

400
00:25:40.743 --> 00:25:43.553
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo take a brief look at distinguishing an incident vs a problem.  Using a very simple illustration, Jo helps to clarify the differences and that one doesnt turn into the other. (i.e. an incident turns into a problem).  This is meant to be a brief segment to help with the following segments.
episodes.title: Incidents vs Problems
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.026
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.026 --> 00:00:10.727
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:10.727 --> 00:00:14.577
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

4
00:00:14.577 --> 00:00:18.309
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Operation show.

5
00:00:18.309 --> 00:00:23.276
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and
today we're going to actually jump

6
00:00:23.276 --> 00:00:27.999
into a smaller little segment here
on instances versus problems.

7
00:00:27.999 --> 00:00:33.360
And here to help us out is going to be
our ITIL genius herself Miss Jo Peacock.

8
00:00:33.360 --> 00:00:35.820
Jo, what are we taking a look at here?

9
00:00:35.820 --> 00:00:40.940
>> Okay, what I want to do really is take
the most of the next few minutes just

10
00:00:40.940 --> 00:00:45.490
to get to the bottom of
a common misconception and

11
00:00:45.490 --> 00:00:47.670
a common area of confusion.

12
00:00:47.670 --> 00:00:51.630
In ITIL we look at incident
management as a process and

13
00:00:51.630 --> 00:00:54.260
we also look at problem
management as a process.

14
00:00:55.550 --> 00:00:58.620
But for a lot of organizations,
and in fact for a lot of people,

15
00:00:58.620 --> 00:01:01.230
there is an area of
confusion between the two.

16
00:01:01.230 --> 00:01:03.950
And a lot of organizations will try and

17
00:01:03.950 --> 00:01:08.350
combine the two without fully
understanding what they are.

18
00:01:08.350 --> 00:01:12.915
So what I'd like to try and
do is explain just really what

19
00:01:12.915 --> 00:01:17.605
the difference is between incidents and
problems, and also the difference

20
00:01:17.605 --> 00:01:22.427
between then incident management and
problem management as two processes.

21
00:01:22.427 --> 00:01:24.967
And why, as far as ITIL is concerned,

22
00:01:24.967 --> 00:01:29.757
from a best practice perspective it
doesn't actually make any sense to try and

23
00:01:29.757 --> 00:01:35.813
combine the two because we
have two conflicting purposes.

24
00:01:35.813 --> 00:01:39.733
>> All right, Jo, so how are we
going to help solve this conundrum

25
00:01:39.733 --> 00:01:42.063
of whether it's a problem or an incident?

26
00:01:42.063 --> 00:01:43.263
And how are we gonna do this?

27
00:01:43.263 --> 00:01:46.065
>> Okay, so first of all we need
to understand what an incident is.

28
00:01:46.065 --> 00:01:49.596
And an incident is
an interruption to service, or

29
00:01:49.596 --> 00:01:52.965
it's something that may
interrupt a service.

30
00:01:52.965 --> 00:01:56.294
But we'll go into that a little bit
more in detail when we look at incident

31
00:01:56.294 --> 00:01:57.471
management.

32
00:01:57.471 --> 00:02:01.641
So an incident is an interruption to, or
reduction in the quality of a service.

33
00:02:01.641 --> 00:02:07.287
Now, a problem is the root
cause of an incident.

34
00:02:07.287 --> 00:02:12.373
But quite often when people want
to undertake incident management

35
00:02:12.373 --> 00:02:19.250
they think that what they've got to do
is they've got to fix the problem, okay?

36
00:02:19.250 --> 00:02:20.440
But that's not the case.

37
00:02:21.880 --> 00:02:29.420
So this level management will give us a
set of parameters for providing a service.

38
00:02:29.420 --> 00:02:33.800
So we have to make a service available
between the hours of, let's say, 8 AM and

39
00:02:33.800 --> 00:02:35.980
6 PM on an evening, for ease.

40
00:02:37.270 --> 00:02:43.220
And so incident management is concerned
with interruptions to that service.

41
00:02:43.220 --> 00:02:47.010
Because incident management wants to make
sure that that service stays available

42
00:02:47.010 --> 00:02:49.080
between the hours of 8 AM and 6 PM.

43
00:02:50.830 --> 00:02:54.400
So what incident management is trying to
do is to restore normal service operation.

44
00:02:56.000 --> 00:03:00.100
Incident management doesn't
actually care what caused it.

45
00:03:01.220 --> 00:03:06.670
What incident management wants to
do is just restore the service.

46
00:03:06.670 --> 00:03:12.282
Problem management wants to get to
the bottom of what caused it and

47
00:03:12.282 --> 00:03:16.835
fix the root cause to
prevent further incidents.

48
00:03:16.835 --> 00:03:19.830
Whereas incident management is
concerned with that target and

49
00:03:19.830 --> 00:03:22.250
we wanna keep that service available.

50
00:03:22.250 --> 00:03:26.295
So, I have in my hands
a humble piece of paper.

51
00:03:26.295 --> 00:03:31.314
This
>> [SOUND]

52
00:03:31.314 --> 00:03:32.297
>> Is an incident.

53
00:03:32.297 --> 00:03:35.872
That service has been interrupted.

54
00:03:35.872 --> 00:03:40.618
Normal service operation that's
defined in the service level

55
00:03:40.618 --> 00:03:44.386
agreement has been, well,
broken in this case.

56
00:03:44.386 --> 00:03:52.656
So let's say that my service to you is to
provide you with a piece of paper, okay.

57
00:03:52.656 --> 00:03:54.060
What am I gonna do?

58
00:03:54.060 --> 00:03:58.810
How do I restore normal service operation?

59
00:03:58.810 --> 00:04:03.260
>> You could try that weird,
sticky glue or you could try tape.

60
00:04:03.260 --> 00:04:05.390
>> Right, okay, so, well it just so

61
00:04:05.390 --> 00:04:09.030
happens, as if by magic,
I've got some tape.

62
00:04:09.030 --> 00:04:13.680
So what I'm going to do Is I'm gonna
tape that piece of paper together and

63
00:04:13.680 --> 00:04:15.805
now we have a restored service.

64
00:04:15.805 --> 00:04:17.820
>> There you go, all right,
sounds good, yep.

65
00:04:17.820 --> 00:04:20.884
>> So this tape that we've got in our
hands is what we call a work around.

66
00:04:20.884 --> 00:04:25.056
Now, there's an issue though.

67
00:04:25.056 --> 00:04:32.080
>> [SOUND]
>> Cuz that incident's happened again.

68
00:04:33.330 --> 00:04:38.860
So we can use a workaround again to
restore normal service operation.

69
00:04:38.860 --> 00:04:41.475
That's great!
And I still have a service.

70
00:04:41.475 --> 00:04:45.180
>> Okay, it looks a little bit raggidy,
but I still have the service.

71
00:04:46.650 --> 00:04:49.600
So I can carry on using workarounds and

72
00:04:49.600 --> 00:04:54.110
I can carry on until I've used
an entire reel of tape, if I wanted.

73
00:04:56.280 --> 00:04:59.080
But eventually somebody's
gonna have to fix the problem.

74
00:04:59.080 --> 00:05:01.510
But what's the problem?

75
00:05:02.630 --> 00:05:03.850
>> You're tearing the paper.

76
00:05:03.850 --> 00:05:04.357
>> Okay.

77
00:05:04.357 --> 00:05:07.250
>> [LAUGH]
>> So let's be more specific.

78
00:05:07.250 --> 00:05:08.807
What or who is the problem?

79
00:05:08.807 --> 00:05:10.240
>> [LAUGH] That would be you.

80
00:05:10.240 --> 00:05:11.122
You'd be the problem.

81
00:05:11.122 --> 00:05:12.690
>> That would be me, right, okay.

82
00:05:12.690 --> 00:05:13.620
I am the problem.

83
00:05:13.620 --> 00:05:14.270
>> Right.
>> Okay,

84
00:05:14.270 --> 00:05:16.370
I hold my hands up to being the problem.

85
00:05:17.400 --> 00:05:18.690
So how do we solve the problem?

86
00:05:18.690 --> 00:05:24.260
>> We would have to get you
to stop tearing the paper,

87
00:05:24.260 --> 00:05:30.080
so we can try and make sure that we bind
your hands and keep them away from paper.

88
00:05:30.080 --> 00:05:31.920
>> Okay, or
we can take the paper away from me.

89
00:05:31.920 --> 00:05:33.257
>> We can take the paper away from you.

90
00:05:33.257 --> 00:05:36.066
>> Yeah, right.
So there is a difference between the two.

91
00:05:36.066 --> 00:05:40.481
Incident management simply
brings out the tape,

92
00:05:40.481 --> 00:05:45.230
it doesn't care whether it happens again.

93
00:05:45.230 --> 00:05:49.520
But problem management wants
to do something about me.

94
00:05:49.520 --> 00:05:55.477
Now, that sounds fairly
straight forward until now.

95
00:05:55.477 --> 00:06:02.327
Problem management, however, will want
to find out what exactly is causing it.

96
00:06:02.327 --> 00:06:06.627
And quite often, problem management
will walk into a situation,

97
00:06:06.627 --> 00:06:09.640
and what they see is
a ripped up piece of paper.

98
00:06:11.700 --> 00:06:15.150
So they say, well okay then, don't fix it.

99
00:06:16.460 --> 00:06:19.820
Don't restore normal
service operation just yet,

100
00:06:19.820 --> 00:06:21.800
cuz I want to see what's causing it.

101
00:06:23.510 --> 00:06:26.330
Because I want to see it happen again and

102
00:06:26.330 --> 00:06:31.160
then I can get to the bottom of what's
causing the interruptions to service.

103
00:06:32.850 --> 00:06:37.100
The issue with that is, and the biggest
challenge to incident management is

104
00:06:37.100 --> 00:06:39.600
that while problem management to saying,
look,

105
00:06:39.600 --> 00:06:44.010
I need you to keep the service down so
I can watch to see what's going on.

106
00:06:44.010 --> 00:06:45.890
Incident management is saying hey,
you know what?

107
00:06:45.890 --> 00:06:49.100
We've got these availability
targets that we have to maintain,

108
00:06:49.100 --> 00:06:51.740
so I'm just gonna carry
on getting the tape out.

109
00:06:54.070 --> 00:06:57.610
So incidents and problems are two
completely different things, because

110
00:06:57.610 --> 00:07:01.080
an incident is an interruption to service
and the problem is what's caused it.

111
00:07:02.550 --> 00:07:06.060
Problem management will want to find
out what's caused the incident and

112
00:07:06.060 --> 00:07:10.300
will want to keep the service down
sometimes in order to try and

113
00:07:11.320 --> 00:07:13.370
stop it from happening in the future.

114
00:07:13.370 --> 00:07:15.970
Whereas incident management just
simply wants to get the tape out.

115
00:07:17.180 --> 00:07:22.340
So now I'm going to ask you a question,
and this is a question that I

116
00:07:22.340 --> 00:07:26.885
ask everybody, so don't feel unique.

117
00:07:26.885 --> 00:07:30.910
[LAUGH] When does an incident
then become a problem?

118
00:07:30.910 --> 00:07:34.105
>> When does an incident become a problem?

119
00:07:34.105 --> 00:07:35.957
I really don't know now.

120
00:07:35.957 --> 00:07:36.457
[LAUGH] I really don't know.

121
00:07:38.890 --> 00:07:42.810
>> Well I can tell you that every single
person that's watching this right now

122
00:07:42.810 --> 00:07:44.610
has started off with the word when.

123
00:07:45.740 --> 00:07:49.580
When there's been so many instance,
when there has been so many interruptions.

124
00:07:50.960 --> 00:07:57.070
But the answer is never, because they
are two completely different things.

125
00:07:57.070 --> 00:07:57.980
There is no when.

126
00:07:57.980 --> 00:08:02.390
An incident, well, this is an incident.

127
00:08:04.090 --> 00:08:05.920
But this is the problem.

128
00:08:07.370 --> 00:08:14.430
So the question I'm asking you
is when does this become this?

129
00:08:15.490 --> 00:08:16.080
Well it doesn't.

130
00:08:18.270 --> 00:08:22.600
Let's look at it in another situation
then, I can give you another example.

131
00:08:22.600 --> 00:08:27.112
Let's say that I went outside into the
parking lot and I fell into a pothole and

132
00:08:27.112 --> 00:08:27.952
broke my leg.

133
00:08:27.952 --> 00:08:32.726
That break would

134
00:08:32.726 --> 00:08:37.842
be the incident.

135
00:08:37.842 --> 00:08:38.382
What would be the problem?

136
00:08:38.382 --> 00:08:39.106
>> [LAUGH]
>> That I wasn't

137
00:08:39.106 --> 00:08:39.701
watching where I was going.

138
00:08:39.701 --> 00:08:44.570
>> Well no, yeah, the problem is
there is a hole that you fell into.

139
00:08:45.850 --> 00:08:48.480
>> No,
well the problem is that there is a hole.

140
00:08:48.480 --> 00:08:50.360
>> Okay, there's a hole, all right.

141
00:08:50.360 --> 00:08:52.540
>> That hole though can
cause many incidents.

142
00:08:53.990 --> 00:08:56.170
Because, you see,
I can go to the hospital and

143
00:08:56.170 --> 00:09:00.130
I can get my leg set in a cast and
that would get me walking again.

144
00:09:00.130 --> 00:09:03.400
In other words, restore my service, yeah.

145
00:09:03.400 --> 00:09:05.700
But somebody else could come along and

146
00:09:05.700 --> 00:09:11.820
fall into that pothole and they could
break their leg or sprain their ankle.

147
00:09:11.820 --> 00:09:13.834
And they'd have to go to the hospital and

148
00:09:13.834 --> 00:09:17.638
they'd have to have their normal service
restored as quickly as possible.

149
00:09:17.638 --> 00:09:21.888
But that incident is going
to keep on happening until

150
00:09:21.888 --> 00:09:25.568
somebody comes along and
fixes the problem.

151
00:09:25.568 --> 00:09:28.850
Until somebody comes along and
fills in the hole.

152
00:09:30.740 --> 00:09:33.850
So problem management's job is to come and
fill in the hole.

153
00:09:35.130 --> 00:09:39.910
Incident management's job is to supply the
crutches to get everybody walking again.

154
00:09:41.410 --> 00:09:44.350
Two completely different things.

155
00:09:44.350 --> 00:09:46.543
Two completely different purposes.

156
00:09:46.543 --> 00:09:54.810
We both are concerned with delivering
value, but two different elements.

157
00:09:54.810 --> 00:09:58.740
So the question of when does
an incident become a problem, well,

158
00:09:58.740 --> 00:10:02.140
that's like saying when does my
broken leg become that pothole?

159
00:10:02.140 --> 00:10:03.062
It just doesn't.

160
00:10:03.062 --> 00:10:07.398
And so the examples that I've used
here are really just to try and

161
00:10:07.398 --> 00:10:12.158
clear up that common misconception
between incidents and problems.

162
00:10:12.158 --> 00:10:16.996
And also to try and articulate why
in ITIL, in this best practice

163
00:10:16.996 --> 00:10:22.050
environment that we operate in,
we look at them both separately.

164
00:10:22.050 --> 00:10:27.060
And we address them both separately with
separate processes with separate aims.

165
00:10:27.060 --> 00:10:29.530
Now, as we move into problem management,

166
00:10:29.530 --> 00:10:32.950
you'll see that problem management
has a lot more depth to it than

167
00:10:32.950 --> 00:10:37.690
just fixing potholes or tying my
hands up to stop me ripping up paper.

168
00:10:39.070 --> 00:10:42.330
But really,
the purpose of this particular section

169
00:10:42.330 --> 00:10:45.130
was just to look at
the difference between them.

170
00:10:45.130 --> 00:10:49.180
And when we do this we realize
that actually they're not as

171
00:10:49.180 --> 00:10:51.555
similar as we once thought they were.

172
00:10:51.555 --> 00:10:55.400
>> Correct.
All right Jo, well thank you again for

173
00:10:55.400 --> 00:10:59.980
helping us make that clear distinction
Between the ideas of problems and

174
00:10:59.980 --> 00:11:00.490
incidences.

175
00:11:00.490 --> 00:11:04.990
And it will help us as we continue on with
the course, the incident management and

176
00:11:04.990 --> 00:11:06.640
the problem management itself.

177
00:11:06.640 --> 00:11:10.510
All right, well that's a great place for
us to sign off then.

178
00:11:10.510 --> 00:11:14.040
For ITProTV, I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

179
00:11:14.040 --> 00:11:15.180
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

180
00:11:15.180 --> 00:11:18.512
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation shows.

181
00:11:18.512 --> 00:11:25.911
[MUSIC]

182
00:11:25.911 --> 00:11:28.476
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo take a look at the incident management process.  Jo emphasizes the goal is two fold: restore normal service operations and deliver value to the organization.  This is done by managing incidents where they minimize the adverse effects, ensure to the agreed SLA and restoration of services in a timely fashion, according to Jo.  This is also a point where it is emphasized to stop and review the concepts up to this point!

son of a gun, what was I about

24

>> I am doing well, and ready to get

of incident management here
>> We've already just taken a look in that

26

little previous segment that we did.

Comparing the difference, and

31

And therefore why we would want to

34

Now we're going to delve further

35

And we're going to take a look at what
incident management is actually going to

36
00:01:57.783 --> 00:02:01.530
focus on, and
the objectives of incident management.

37
00:02:01.530 --> 00:02:04.500
And we're going to look at an example
