38
00:02:04.500 --> 00:02:06.238
And then following that,

39
00:02:06.238 --> 00:02:11.453
once we're finished with incident
management as a process, then we will take

40
00:02:11.453 --> 00:02:17.150
a further in-depth look into problem
management as well, in another session.

41
00:02:17.150 --> 00:02:20.590
But for the moment, we're going to
concentrate on incident management,

42
00:02:20.590 --> 00:02:24.870
and we're going to look at how we
restore normal service operation.

43
00:02:24.870 --> 00:02:27.800
>> All right, Jo, so
restoring normal service operations.

44
00:02:27.800 --> 00:02:31.605
That sounds like there's more
steps involved in the process, so

45
00:02:31.605 --> 00:02:33.896
where is the first step for us to begin?

46
00:02:33.896 --> 00:02:35.426
>> The first thing that we've gotta do is,

47
00:02:35.426 --> 00:02:38.550
we've gotta understand the objectives
of incident management.

48
00:02:38.550 --> 00:02:44.500
Now, in a previous session, I outlined
the purpose of incident management,

49
00:02:44.500 --> 00:02:47.900
and it's in the bottom right hand
corner of your screen right now.

50
00:02:47.900 --> 00:02:51.910
The purpose of incident management is
to restore normal service operation

51
00:02:51.910 --> 00:02:53.755
as quickly as possible.

52
00:02:53.755 --> 00:02:57.667
It's all about minimizing the adverse
impact on business operations.

53
00:02:57.667 --> 00:03:04.687
Remember, we are in a position where we
are delivering value to the organization.

54
00:03:04.687 --> 00:03:11.960
We are in a position where we are running
a business as usual live environment.

55
00:03:11.960 --> 00:03:14.930
So we have to be able to
deliver those services,

56
00:03:14.930 --> 00:03:20.210
at a level that has been previously
agreed in the service level agreements.

57
00:03:20.210 --> 00:03:24.270
And we have to ensure
that we deliver those

58
00:03:24.270 --> 00:03:26.400
services to add value to the business.

59
00:03:27.760 --> 00:03:32.405
So, the objectives of incident management
is simply to restore normal service

60
00:03:32.405 --> 00:03:34.498
operation as quickly as possible.

61
00:03:34.498 --> 00:03:40.385
It's to ensure that we use a standardized
process for managing incidents.

62
00:03:40.385 --> 00:03:43.309
It's about consistency, and
that's a word I like to use.

63
00:03:43.309 --> 00:03:48.396
Because, of course, we have those two
tenets of ITIL, the efficiency and

64
00:03:48.396 --> 00:03:53.915
effectiveness, and consistency will
help us towards that goal of efficiency.

65
00:03:55.010 --> 00:04:00.436
Its about ensuring that our organization
understands what we are trying to do for

66
00:04:00.436 --> 00:04:05.720
them in terms of delivering value, but
also in terms of restoration of service.

67
00:04:05.720 --> 00:04:09.568
Sometimes the complaints that you
hear from organizations is that,

68
00:04:09.568 --> 00:04:14.142
I reported an incident to the service
desk, I reported it 30 minutes ago and

69
00:04:14.142 --> 00:04:16.089
I dont know whats happening.

70
00:04:17.150 --> 00:04:18.750
The scope of incident management and

71
00:04:18.750 --> 00:04:22.220
the objective of incident management
is not just to restore normal service

72
00:04:22.220 --> 00:04:26.960
operation, it's actually to ensure
that we deliver value in its entirety.

73
00:04:26.960 --> 00:04:30.291
And that's about communication too,
effective communication.

74
00:04:30.291 --> 00:04:33.872
I never ever want to hear from anyone
in the organization that they don't

75
00:04:33.872 --> 00:04:36.680
understand what's
happening with an incident.

76
00:04:36.680 --> 00:04:39.750
If you've reported an incident
to the service desk and

77
00:04:39.750 --> 00:04:44.290
to IT, then it's important that we keep
you up to date with what's happening.

78
00:04:44.290 --> 00:04:46.594
Because if we don't
manage your expectations,

79
00:04:46.594 --> 00:04:49.358
if you don't know what's
happening with your incident.

80
00:04:49.358 --> 00:04:54.308
Then you could decide that well,
maybe I can do other things

81
00:04:54.308 --> 00:04:58.780
right now while you're
working on that incident.

82
00:04:58.780 --> 00:05:00.980
It's about efficient use
of your time as well.

83
00:05:02.330 --> 00:05:05.320
So we want to improve our
communication as well

84
00:05:05.320 --> 00:05:09.210
as improve the time that we restore
normal service operation, as we say.

85
00:05:09.210 --> 00:05:14.500
And it's all about being professional,
it's about adopting that business focus.

86
00:05:14.500 --> 00:05:17.960
Because everything that we do
is to support our organization,

87
00:05:17.960 --> 00:05:20.060
is to support our business.

88
00:05:20.060 --> 00:05:24.591
It's to deliver value to them and
align ourselves with them.

89
00:05:24.591 --> 00:05:27.932
Which means that we have got
to communicate with them, and

90
00:05:27.932 --> 00:05:30.760
let them know what's happening.

91
00:05:30.760 --> 00:05:32.760
It's about their priorities,

92
00:05:32.760 --> 00:05:36.680
it's not down to me to decide
what I want to work on next.

93
00:05:36.680 --> 00:05:39.473
It's about what's important
to our business, and

94
00:05:39.473 --> 00:05:42.656
what our organization tells me
they want me to work on next.

95
00:05:42.656 --> 00:05:46.072
Look at that bottom bullet
point under the objective,

96
00:05:46.072 --> 00:05:49.810
maintaining customer and
user satisfaction.

97
00:05:49.810 --> 00:05:54.010
And the service quality is not just about
what it looks like on the screen, but

98
00:05:54.010 --> 00:05:57.010
it's about the delivery with our
service that we give to you.

99
00:05:58.260 --> 00:05:59.040
So an incident,

100
00:05:59.040 --> 00:06:03.960
as we explored in the last topic,
an incident is an interruption to service.

101
00:06:04.990 --> 00:06:09.660
Now we explored in the last topic or
the topic before that,

102
00:06:09.660 --> 00:06:11.760
we looked at event management.

103
00:06:11.760 --> 00:06:15.776
And an event is any change of
state that has significance for

104
00:06:15.776 --> 00:06:17.474
the IT infrastructure.

105
00:06:17.474 --> 00:06:21.721
Which means that an event is
something that's happened, and

106
00:06:21.721 --> 00:06:27.534
we looked at events being informational,
backups starting or backups finishing.

107
00:06:27.534 --> 00:06:29.499
We looked at warning events,

108
00:06:29.499 --> 00:06:35.590
we looked at exceptional events where
something is broken, something has failed.

109
00:06:35.590 --> 00:06:40.182
Well, that means then if an incident
is an interruption to service,

110
00:06:40.182 --> 00:06:44.625
that means that an incident is
actually by definition, an event.

111
00:06:44.625 --> 00:06:46.683
Something's happened, so

112
00:06:46.683 --> 00:06:52.010
an incident is any event that either
disrupts or could disrupt a service.

113
00:06:53.060 --> 00:06:57.340
Because an incident is
an interruption to or

114
00:06:57.340 --> 00:07:04.450
a reduction in the quality of service,
as I explained in our last section.

115
00:07:05.500 --> 00:07:11.490
So an incident is not just about
a piece of paper being ripped in two,

116
00:07:11.490 --> 00:07:16.800
but an incident is any event that
degrades the quality of service.

117
00:07:16.800 --> 00:07:21.850
So it's about not being able to use
that piece of paper as your service,

118
00:07:21.850 --> 00:07:23.968
not being able to write on it.

119
00:07:23.968 --> 00:07:28.522
So an incident is any event that the the
disrupt or could disrupt a service, and

120
00:07:28.522 --> 00:07:31.220
it's a reduction in
the quality of a service.

121
00:07:32.800 --> 00:07:34.310
Where do you think, let me ask you,

122
00:07:34.310 --> 00:07:38.670
Ronnie, where do you think that
definition of a service is to be found?

123
00:07:40.450 --> 00:07:44.330
>> I would assume it would found
under the service level agreement,

124
00:07:44.330 --> 00:07:45.816
that's my assumption.

125
00:07:45.816 --> 00:07:47.549
>> Yeah, and you'd be exactly right.

126
00:07:47.549 --> 00:07:48.500
>> Okay, [LAUGH].

127
00:07:48.500 --> 00:07:55.050
>> Exactly right, service is defined
in the SLA, why is that important?

128
00:07:55.050 --> 00:07:56.691
Well, it's really important
to incident management.

129
00:07:56.691 --> 00:08:01.704
Without service level management process,
we couldn't define an incident,

130
00:08:01.704 --> 00:08:05.684
because an incident is defined
as an interruption to service.

131
00:08:05.684 --> 00:08:07.994
Well, if you don't know
what a service looks like,

132
00:08:07.994 --> 00:08:09.790
then how do you know what an incident is?

133
00:08:10.880 --> 00:08:13.490
So let's say, that my service means that,

134
00:08:13.490 --> 00:08:16.100
now I need you to use
your imagination here.

135
00:08:16.100 --> 00:08:21.790
My service means that every morning
I go to that printer over there.

136
00:08:21.790 --> 00:08:25.140
There's a printer over there, we're
imagining it, and it's nice, it's fancy,

137
00:08:25.140 --> 00:08:26.920
it looks really good.

138
00:08:26.920 --> 00:08:29.180
We go to that printer over there,
and we get our report.

139
00:08:30.460 --> 00:08:32.100
And that's my service.

140
00:08:32.100 --> 00:08:35.964
And every morning I go
over to that printer and

141
00:08:35.964 --> 00:08:38.922
I get that report in color, okay.

142
00:08:38.922 --> 00:08:43.940
This morning I went to that printer

we're gonna use our incident management
call logging tool to help us with this.

376
00:22:07.397 --> 00:22:12.060
Now the concept of models
is an interesting concept.

377
00:22:12.060 --> 00:22:16.730
It's about achieving efficiency
within our processes.

378
00:22:16.730 --> 00:22:22.192
It's about understanding that sometimes
we do the same thing over and over again.

379
00:22:22.192 --> 00:22:26.834
And if you look in your materials, your
downloaded materials over the next two to

380
00:22:26.834 --> 00:22:31.681
three slides, you'll see that we've got
an incident management process flow that

381
00:22:31.681 --> 00:22:35.450
we're going to look at in a little
more depth in the next session.

382
00:22:37.107 --> 00:22:42.433
Do you want to stick to that process
flow for every single incident?

383
00:22:42.433 --> 00:22:45.109
Well, no, of course not.

384
00:22:45.109 --> 00:22:48.700
I want to be able to restore
service as quickly as possible.

385
00:22:50.010 --> 00:22:55.186
Which means that even though I need
to follow a structured process,

386
00:22:55.186 --> 00:22:57.400
I want to be efficient too.

387
00:22:57.400 --> 00:23:01.500
So what we do is we
predefine sets of steps.

388
00:23:02.810 --> 00:23:07.130
We still have a process, of course we do,
and it's still a structured process.

389
00:23:07.130 --> 00:23:12.460
But we predefine those steps that we can.

390
00:23:12.460 --> 00:23:15.480
And we'll look a little bit more in
depth in that as we look at the incident

391
00:23:15.480 --> 00:23:18.390
process flow in a moment,
in our next section.

392
00:23:19.650 --> 00:23:22.680
We're also going to talk in the next
section about escalation and

393
00:23:22.680 --> 00:23:26.610
about hierarchical and functional
escalation, and about setting priorities.

394
00:23:27.860 --> 00:23:33.520
But just as a recap, really,
a winding up to this particular section,

395
00:23:33.520 --> 00:23:36.630
I want to mention major incidents.

396
00:23:36.630 --> 00:23:41.200
And the last topic we're going to
cover here is the understanding that

397
00:23:41.200 --> 00:23:44.540
something significant is going
to happen to your organization.

398
00:23:44.540 --> 00:23:47.990
Whether you want it to or not, and
it doesn't matter how proactive you are,

399
00:23:47.990 --> 00:23:50.630
there are some things
that we cannot avoid.

400
00:23:50.630 --> 00:23:55.097
So the organization will help you to
determine, in the same way that they'll

401
00:23:55.097 --> 00:23:58.533
help you to determine what
services are important to them,

402
00:23:58.533 --> 00:24:03.227
they'll help you to determine when an
incident is considered a major incident.

403
00:24:03.227 --> 00:24:07.274
In other words,
it has significant disruption to them,

404
00:24:07.274 --> 00:24:11.842
to the business, to our achievement
of corporate objectives.

405
00:24:11.842 --> 00:24:18.440
And in the instance of a major incident,
then we will have separate procedures.

406
00:24:18.440 --> 00:24:24.950
The separate procedures will allocate a
defined manager of that incident process.

407
00:24:26.820 --> 00:24:31.910
The process may differ depending
on the type of incident it is and

408
00:24:31.910 --> 00:24:33.210
the service that it is.

409
00:24:33.210 --> 00:24:37.240
And of course, we've got models for
that, predefined steps, for

410
00:24:37.240 --> 00:24:42.320
each type of major incident and predefined
steps for each service, potentially.

411
00:24:42.320 --> 00:24:45.100
But it will have a defined owner.

412
00:24:45.100 --> 00:24:48.720
And with a major incident, when we
have gone through all of our steps,

413
00:24:48.720 --> 00:24:51.930
we will always,
in conjunction with problem management,

414
00:24:51.930 --> 00:24:55.350
conduct what we call
a major incident review.

415
00:24:55.350 --> 00:25:00.150
And that's to conduct lessons learned and
to see whether we can improve

416
00:25:00.150 --> 00:25:04.710
the efficiency of that process in
the future to get everything up and

417
00:25:04.710 --> 00:25:08.000
running again,
restore service even quicker.

418
00:25:08.000 --> 00:25:10.860
Okay, so the last bullet point on this
slide, just to wrap up this session,

419
00:25:10.860 --> 00:25:12.302
really involves incident tracking.

420
00:25:12.302 --> 00:25:15.790
And I mentioned a tool.

421
00:25:15.790 --> 00:25:20.305
And I said that we needed to have
a tool in place that can help us

422
00:25:20.305 --> 00:25:25.090
manage our incidents,
that will allow us to log incidents, and

423
00:25:25.090 --> 00:25:27.500
then will give us consistency.

424
00:25:27.500 --> 00:25:31.540
That tool will also allow for
alerts and will allow us to identify

425
00:25:31.540 --> 00:25:35.960
what incidents are in danger of
breaching the service level targets.

426
00:25:37.040 --> 00:25:42.000
That tool will allow us to
track every incident throughout

427
00:25:42.000 --> 00:25:46.980
its life and it will also allow us to
produce management information that will

428
00:25:46.980 --> 00:25:52.360
show whether we are indeed meeting
the targets to find in the SLA and

429
00:25:52.360 --> 00:25:55.470
whether we are indeed delivering
value to the organization.

430
00:25:57.230 --> 00:26:01.946
So, to summarize,
Incident management is about restoring

431
00:26:01.946 --> 00:26:05.926
normal service operation
as quickly as possible.

432
00:26:05.926 --> 00:26:10.428
And an incident is any event
that either disrupts, or

433
00:26:10.428 --> 00:26:16.810
could disrupt, service as defined
in the service level agreement.

434
00:26:16.810 --> 00:26:21.965
And of course, as we've already looked at,
without that service level agreement,

435
00:26:21.965 --> 00:26:24.910
incident management is very,
very difficult.

436
00:26:24.910 --> 00:26:27.739
>> All right Jo,
there's a lot of different things

437
00:26:27.739 --> 00:26:32.293
in perhaps this particular episode in
incident management that might require

438
00:26:32.293 --> 00:26:35.990
a little bit more in-depth thought for
us to go through.

439
00:26:35.990 --> 00:26:39.250
Are there any helps in our
course that we can provide for

440
00:26:39.250 --> 00:26:42.910
those that are viewing it right
now to just take advantage of?

441
00:26:42.910 --> 00:26:47.010
>> Yes, we have exercises available for
everybody, and

442
00:26:47.010 --> 00:26:49.400
at the end of the next section that we do,

443
00:26:49.400 --> 00:26:53.960
we have some specific exercises that look
at the incident management process flow.

444
00:26:53.960 --> 00:26:58.093
At the end of this section,
what I would like everybody to do, and

445
00:26:58.093 --> 00:27:00.650
what I would recommend everybody does,

446
00:27:00.650 --> 00:27:05.558
is to go over the process objectives and
the purpose of incident management.

447
00:27:05.558 --> 00:27:08.193
And also get themselves familiar and

448
00:27:08.193 --> 00:27:13.463
comfortable with the definition of
an incident, especially as directed

449
00:27:13.463 --> 00:27:18.234
to Problem Management 2 because
that's very, very important.

450
00:27:18.234 --> 00:27:22.623
As we delve further into incident
management, and into problem management in

451
00:27:22.623 --> 00:27:26.690
future sessions, then we need to
ensure that that distinction is made.

452
00:27:27.740 --> 00:27:31.020
>> All right Jo, well thank you again for
helping us out and

453
00:27:31.020 --> 00:27:34.710
learning a little bit more about
the idea of incident management as well.

454
00:27:34.710 --> 00:27:38.620
And being able to take advantage some of
the stuff that we actually saw right here,

455
00:27:38.620 --> 00:27:40.500
as well as what we have
in our course material.

456
00:27:40.500 --> 00:27:44.838
And that means it's a great time for us to
go ahead and sign off for this episode.

457
00:27:44.838 --> 00:27:47.546
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

458
00:27:47.546 --> 00:27:49.016
>> And I'm Joe Peacock.

459
00:27:49.016 --> 00:27:53.448
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation shows.

460
00:27:53.448 --> 00:27:54.910
[MUSIC]

461
00:27:54.910 --> 00:27:58.184
Thank you for

462
00:27:58.184 --> 00:28:03.246
watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo take a look at the incident management process flow.  Jo walks through the process flow to help viewers figure out of what they are facing is an incident or request fulfillment.  She reminds us that once an incident is discovered and logged it is also prioritized based on urgency and impact.  These decisions in the flow process is based on the definitions of incident handling within the SLA.
episodes.title: Incident Management Process Flow
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.581
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,

2
00:00:01.581 --> 00:00:06.546
I'm your host Don Pezet coming at you
live from San Francisco's [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.546 --> 00:00:08.438
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.438 --> 00:00:12.440
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.440 --> 00:00:15.230
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:15.230 --> 00:00:20.290
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Operation show.

7
00:00:20.290 --> 00:00:22.070
We are about to get started here.

8
00:00:22.070 --> 00:00:23.440
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong,

9
00:00:23.440 --> 00:00:27.770
and today we're gonna take a look at
Incident Management Process Flow,

10
00:00:27.770 --> 00:00:32.528
and here to help us out, of course,
is going to be well our ITIL guru,

11
00:00:32.528 --> 00:00:36.450
extraordinaire Ms. Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:36.450 --> 00:00:37.880
Jo, welcome back to the show.

13
00:00:37.880 --> 00:00:39.560
>> Thank you,
thank you very much for having me.

14
00:00:39.560 --> 00:00:40.065
How are you?

15
00:00:40.065 --> 00:00:41.630
.> I am doing fine, Jo.

16
00:00:41.630 --> 00:00:43.020
Now as we take a look,

17
00:00:43.020 --> 00:00:47.400
we've already talked about Incident
Management in pretty decent depth here.

18
00:00:47.400 --> 00:00:52.280
When we get into the process
flow of things, what are we

19
00:00:52.280 --> 00:00:55.880
really taking a look at now that we have
kind of the foundations down of that?

20
00:00:55.880 --> 00:00:58.910
>> Okay, so what we're going to
do in this particular section

21
00:00:58.910 --> 00:01:03.920
is we're going to look at a sample
of an incident process flow.

22
00:01:03.920 --> 00:01:08.930
Now, it's very clear right from
the very start within ITIL that

23
00:01:08.930 --> 00:01:10.210
ITIL is a framework.

24
00:01:11.310 --> 00:01:17.040
And as a framework, we will encourage
organizations to adopt the framework.

25
00:01:17.040 --> 00:01:20.950
But then it has to be adapted to suit
the needs of the organization for

26
00:01:20.950 --> 00:01:22.510
efficiency and effectiveness.

27
00:01:22.510 --> 00:01:25.770
Because let's face it,
no two organizations are the same.

28
00:01:25.770 --> 00:01:31.430
So what we have here is just an example
of an incident management process flow.

29
00:01:31.430 --> 00:01:36.247
What your incident management process flow
would look like is completely different to

30
00:01:36.247 --> 00:01:40.250
what somebody else's incident
management process flow will look like.

31
00:01:40.250 --> 00:01:42.950
No two organizations are the same.

32
00:01:42.950 --> 00:01:48.360
Even organizations that on the surface
appears to be doing exactly the same

33
00:01:48.360 --> 00:01:52.070
thing, they were working a slightly
different way, depending on perhaps

34
00:01:52.070 --> 00:01:57.160
geographical location or perhaps depending
on the strategy of the organization.

35
00:01:57.160 --> 00:02:00.645
So no two processes will look the same.

36
00:02:00.645 --> 00:02:03.595
Now in a previous section,
we talked about models and

37
00:02:03.595 --> 00:02:06.625
we talked about pre-defining
some of the steps, and

38
00:02:06.625 --> 00:02:11.625
what we're just going to look at here
is the steps that we need to go through

39
00:02:11.625 --> 00:02:16.075
within incident management in order
to restore normal service operation.

40
00:02:16.075 --> 00:02:18.995
That doesn't mean that we have to
go through all of these steps,

41
00:02:18.995 --> 00:02:21.575
we can pre-define some of these steps and

42
00:02:21.575 --> 00:02:26.500
so, what I'm gonna do here is just
give you an example of a process flow.

43
00:02:26.500 --> 00:02:31.070
And we're going to look at some
of the key characteristics

44
00:02:31.070 --> 00:02:34.560
of each particular process.

45
00:02:34.560 --> 00:02:38.690
We're going to look at what can be
predefined, what can't be predefined and

46
00:02:38.690 --> 00:02:40.490
how we can achieve that.

47
00:02:40.490 --> 00:02:41.520
Jo, that sounds great.

48
00:02:41.520 --> 00:02:45.420
One of the things that when I, I guess
I first encountered the idea of ITIL,

49
00:02:45.420 --> 00:02:48.430
I always came at it from the perspective,

50
00:02:48.430 --> 00:02:52.450
right, of somebody implementing this
stuff, and not understanding that term and

51
00:02:52.450 --> 00:02:55.990
that foundational idea of it being
a framework, which means it's not really

52
00:02:55.990 --> 00:03:00.700
prescriptive of anything that we're doing
but it's more definitive of those things.

53
00:03:00.700 --> 00:03:04.210
And so I think that if we're coming
from an IT background sometimes and

54
00:03:04.210 --> 00:03:05.320
we're used to doing it,

55
00:03:05.320 --> 00:03:08.480
we always think that there's gotta be
something prescriptive behind this.

56
00:03:08.480 --> 00:03:11.940
But the goal is to get us to be
able to manage better not so

57
00:03:11.940 --> 00:03:14.250
much as setting down every point, right.

58
00:03:14.250 --> 00:03:17.410
>> Right, so
ITIL is not a one size fits all approach.

59
00:03:17.410 --> 00:03:20.410
It doesn't work like that because
no two organizations are the same.

60
00:03:21.900 --> 00:03:26.880
ITIL is not a pill that's going to cure
all of the dysfunction within your IT

61
00:03:26.880 --> 00:03:28.820
organization, either.

62
00:03:28.820 --> 00:03:30.900
We can't do that.

63
00:03:30.900 --> 00:03:36.250
The way that I look at it, let's say
that your IT organization was a living,

64
00:03:36.250 --> 00:03:38.800
breathing being.

65
00:03:38.800 --> 00:03:41.330
An animal, whatever that animal may be.

66
00:03:41.330 --> 00:03:44.200
What we're going to do is we're
gonna give you a skeleton and

67
00:03:44.200 --> 00:03:49.540
we're gonna tell you that you need
these bones, that's what you need.

68
00:03:49.540 --> 00:03:51.965
But we're not gonna tell you how
how to fit that skeleton together,

69
00:03:51.965 --> 00:03:54.565
we're going to give you some
pointers that will help you.

70
00:03:54.565 --> 00:03:58.805
But it's up to you as to what you
want that project to look like.

71
00:03:58.805 --> 00:04:02.535
Whether you want it to have four legs or
whether you want it to have two arms or

72
00:04:02.535 --> 00:04:03.435
two legs.

73
00:04:03.435 --> 00:04:07.745
Whether you want it to have three eyes or
whether you want it to have one eye.

74
00:04:07.745 --> 00:04:11.190
Whether you want it to have skin or
whether you want it to have fur.

75
00:04:11.190 --> 00:04:12.740
Entirely up to you.

76
00:04:12.740 --> 00:04:16.990
So only you know what IT looks like for
your organization.

77
00:04:16.990 --> 00:04:19.010
We're going to give you a set of bones,
and we're going to say,

78
00:04:19.010 --> 00:04:24.080
you need these bones, but
it's up to you to make it into something

79
00:04:24.080 --> 00:04:27.630
that works for you and
something that fits you.

80
00:04:27.630 --> 00:04:32.080
And so that's why when you described it
as looking very unique, even though we're

81
00:04:32.080 --> 00:04:35.750
following the same thing, it works that
way, because it is that framework.

82
00:04:35.750 --> 00:04:39.280
>> Yes, yeah, and that's why,
as I say, I describe it as a skeleton.

83
00:04:39.280 --> 00:04:42.285
We've all got one, and yet we all look
completely different on the outside.

84
00:04:43.315 --> 00:04:47.025
>> Alright Jo, so where are we going to
begin with this particular structure that

85
00:04:47.025 --> 00:04:48.375
you're talking about?

86
00:04:48.375 --> 00:04:52.745
>> So in this session,
we're going to look through a example of

87
00:04:52.745 --> 00:04:56.595
an ITIL incident management process.

88
00:04:56.595 --> 00:05:01.360
Now this is the example that comes
straight out of the ideal books And so

89
00:05:01.360 --> 00:05:03.780
we're going to start off
right at the very top,

90
00:05:03.780 --> 00:05:06.307
cuz that's a very good place to start,
isn't it?

91
00:05:06.307 --> 00:05:08.210
[LAUGH] And so we're going to look,

92
00:05:08.210 --> 00:05:12.300
first of all, in that first step
there at the incident identification.

93
00:05:12.300 --> 00:05:16.400
And incidents are notified
to us in 101 different ways.

94
00:05:16.400 --> 00:05:20.030
It could come from event management.

95
00:05:20.030 --> 00:05:22.120
So it could come automatically.

96
00:05:22.120 --> 00:05:26.777
It could come from the web interface
with user logging on to the web-based

97
00:05:26.777 --> 00:05:30.680
front end of the tool and
log into incident in that way.

98
00:05:30.680 --> 00:05:33.660
It could come from a phone call
in to the service desk, or

99
00:05:33.660 --> 00:05:35.260
it could come via an email.

100
00:05:35.260 --> 00:05:40.030
Nowadays it can come via text and a lot
of our service management tools actually

101
00:05:40.030 --> 00:05:44.060
have apps associated with them, so
you could even log an incident via an app.

102
00:05:45.310 --> 00:05:47.150
So that's how we identify an incident,

103
00:05:47.150 --> 00:05:51.490
and the first thing that we've got
to do is we call this filtering.

104
00:05:51.490 --> 00:05:54.340
And filtering is just
simply asking the question,

105
00:05:54.340 --> 00:05:58.480
is this really an incident or
is it a request?

106
00:05:58.480 --> 00:06:00.470
Is it a request for something?

107
00:06:00.470 --> 00:06:05.330
And the reason we do this is that
some organizations will, they

108
00:06:05.330 --> 00:06:10.470
like to manage request fulfillment through
their instant management process flow.

109
00:06:10.470 --> 00:06:12.310
And so we want to, first of all,

110
00:06:12.310 --> 00:06:16.740
filter that incident to make sure that,
yes it's an incident.

111
00:06:16.740 --> 00:06:21.130
There's something wrong and we need to
restore service, or no, it's a request and

112
00:06:21.130 --> 00:06:24.490
actually it's user asking
if they can have something.

113
00:06:25.540 --> 00:06:30.270
So, let's assume then that this is
an incident and normal service needs to be

114
00:06:30.270 --> 00:06:34.270
restored, in which case then, we're going
down the right-hand side of this slide.

115
00:06:34.270 --> 00:06:40.220
In which case then, we log the incident
and then we would categorize the incident.

116
00:06:40.220 --> 00:06:43.740
Now, this is where this looks
entirely unique to you.

117
00:06:45.170 --> 00:06:48.550
You will notice that on the left hand side
of the slide as you are looking at it

118
00:06:48.550 --> 00:06:53.380
right now, there are two options
that are presented to you.

119
00:06:53.380 --> 00:06:58.810
The first one looks at the application or
the service and drills down into sort

120
00:06:58.810 --> 00:07:03.680
of the application with sub categories
of database or server or disk drive.

121
00:07:03.680 --> 00:07:07.067
Now obviously that's a very, very
technical way of looking at things and

122
00:07:07.067 --> 00:07:09.790
I don't expect any of our
users to be able to do this.

123
00:07:09.790 --> 00:07:12.450
And this would involve
a certain skill level and

124
00:07:12.450 --> 00:07:15.415
the service desk goes well
to be able to do this.

125
00:07:15.415 --> 00:07:20.640
So, we could if we chose to or
we could categorize via

126
00:07:20.640 --> 00:07:25.620
in the second instance that you've got,
hey you could categorize via location.

127
00:07:25.620 --> 00:07:28.800
And then location in the sub
category be in service and

128
00:07:28.800 --> 00:07:33.640
another sub category being
application that is impacted.

129
00:07:34.640 --> 00:07:36.750
You could categorize that way.

130
00:07:36.750 --> 00:07:39.540
You could categorize by business unit.

131
00:07:39.540 --> 00:07:42.100
You could categorize by
geographical location.

132
00:07:42.100 --> 00:07:44.260
You could categorize by language.

133
00:07:44.260 --> 00:07:48.090
You could categorize by whether or
not that service is a VBF.

134
00:07:49.410 --> 00:07:54.580
And VBF is an ITIL acronym that we
discover in service strategy and

135
00:07:54.580 --> 00:07:55.930
in service design.

136
00:07:55.930 --> 00:07:58.430
And it means vital business function.

137
00:07:58.430 --> 00:08:02.910
And a vital business function
is a service that is

138
00:08:02.910 --> 00:08:08.260
critical to the operation
of the organization.

139
00:08:08.260 --> 00:08:10.880
So it really is entirely up to you and,
as I said,

140
00:08:10.880 --> 00:08:15.750
this process is going to look like what
you need the process to look like.

141
00:08:15.750 --> 00:08:19.140
So after categorization,
then we prioritize.

142
00:08:19.140 --> 00:08:22.820
And we prioritize based on two things.

143
00:08:22.820 --> 00:08:26.700
We prioritize based on both impact and
urgency.

144
00:08:28.600 --> 00:08:31.490
So, let me ask you a question then,
Ronnie.

145
00:08:31.490 --> 00:08:36.960
So let's say that our payroll goes
down two days before you get paid.

146
00:08:36.960 --> 00:08:38.380
>> Okay.

147
00:08:38.380 --> 00:08:40.590
>> High impact or low impact?

148
00:08:40.590 --> 00:08:41.470
>> High impact.

149
00:08:41.470 --> 00:08:42.190
>> I would think so.

150
00:08:42.190 --> 00:08:43.720
And what about urgency?

151
00:08:43.720 --> 00:08:44.540
High or low?

152
00:08:45.630 --> 00:08:47.060
Urgency would be pretty high.

153
00:08:47.060 --> 00:08:50.990
>> Pretty high right because if that money
doesn't hit our accounts in two days

154
00:08:50.990 --> 00:08:52.760
time, yeah, we're not going to be happy.

155
00:08:52.760 --> 00:08:53.410
>> Right.

156
00:08:53.410 --> 00:08:57.920
>> Right, okay, so I would set
a priority of probably one on that one.

157
00:08:57.920 --> 00:08:59.020
>> Sure.
>> Yeah, okay.

158
00:09:00.020 --> 00:09:05.080
So lets say the payroll goes down then
two days after we've just been paid.

159
00:09:05.080 --> 00:09:07.590
That high impact or low impact?

160
00:09:07.590 --> 00:09:08.410
>> That'd be low impact.

161
00:09:09.420 --> 00:09:10.590
>> No it wouldn't.

162
00:09:10.590 --> 00:09:13.660
The impact is still exactly the same.

163
00:09:13.660 --> 00:09:16.140
It still impacts the same
number of people.

164
00:09:16.140 --> 00:09:17.350
>> Okay, yeah, sure, right, okay.

165
00:09:17.350 --> 00:09:18.900
>> It still impacts
the entire organization.

166
00:09:18.900 --> 00:09:20.430
>> I get it, right.

167
00:09:20.430 --> 00:09:21.860
But then let's look at urgency.

168
00:09:21.860 --> 00:09:23.880
High urgency or low urgency?

169
00:09:23.880 --> 00:09:24.710
>> Low urgency.

170
00:09:24.710 --> 00:09:27.240
>> Right.
okay, so the urgency has been reduced.

171
00:09:27.240 --> 00:09:27.940
>> Okay.
>> So

172
00:09:27.940 --> 00:09:31.380
the priority in that case then is reduced.

173
00:09:31.380 --> 00:09:32.390
>> Right.

174
00:09:32.390 --> 00:09:36.960
>> So whilst before it was a priority
one two days before we got paid, now,

175
00:09:36.960 --> 00:09:39.792
two days after we get paid
the priority may well be a three.

176
00:09:39.792 --> 00:09:45.860
Now you're going to find a table for
what is considered to be a priority one,

177
00:09:45.860 --> 00:09:49.990
and a priority two, and a priority three
In a certain document that we think is

178
00:09:49.990 --> 00:09:54.230
really important to incident management
and, of course, that is in the SLA.

179
00:09:54.230 --> 00:09:59.730
That service level agreement is going to
tell us what constitutes priority one,

180
00:09:59.730 --> 00:10:01.620
and what constitutes priority two,

181
00:10:01.620 --> 00:10:05.810
three, etc., depending on how many
prioritization levels we go down to.

182
00:10:05.810 --> 00:10:10.540
And we do that for efficiency purposes,

183
00:10:10.540 --> 00:10:15.530
because It's not fair on a service
desk analyst to expect them

184
00:10:15.530 --> 00:10:20.300
to make a call based on one phone
call as to what the impact is or

185
00:10:20.300 --> 00:10:24.460
as to what the urgency is
of any given incident, so

186
00:10:24.460 --> 00:10:28.280
we have it in the service level agreement
where the customer has agreed to it.

187
00:10:28.280 --> 00:10:33.030
They've signed the SLA And where IT
have agreed to that prioritization too.

188
00:10:33.030 --> 00:10:37.743
Now, I also mentioned
in a previous section

189
00:10:37.743 --> 00:10:42.910
that we have targets assigned for
incident management that

190
00:10:42.910 --> 00:10:48.090
during the incident management
process itself, I expect the tool to

191
00:10:48.090 --> 00:10:52.150
flag up when something is about to breach
it's service level target for a response.

192
00:10:53.460 --> 00:10:57.030
Again, that's something else
I expect to find in the SLA.

193
00:10:57.030 --> 00:11:02.360
Because again it's an agreement between
the customer and IT, where we will say,

194
00:11:02.360 --> 00:11:07.430
okay then we would consider
than this to be a priority one.

195
00:11:07.430 --> 00:11:09.430
And if this is a priority one,

196
00:11:09.430 --> 00:11:13.890
then we would respond to this
within ten minutes for instance.

197
00:11:13.890 --> 00:11:18.500
That's just an example obviously, but
this comes part of the tailoring ITIL,

198
00:11:18.500 --> 00:11:21.540
adapting it to suit your environment.

199
00:11:21.540 --> 00:11:24.190
I can't give you a table of defaults on

200
00:11:24.190 --> 00:11:27.770
what I expect your
prioritization to look like.

201
00:11:27.770 --> 00:11:32.000
That's prioritization,
agreed with the customer.

202
00:11:32.000 --> 00:11:33.990
So then let's go onto the next step then.

203
00:11:33.990 --> 00:11:37.060
And the next step there looks at
whether it's a major incident.

204
00:11:37.060 --> 00:11:40.610
And I've already discussed with
you in a previous section that if

205
00:11:40.610 --> 00:11:45.290
it's a major incident, then we have
a separate major incident procedure.

206
00:11:45.290 --> 00:11:50.360
And that separate major incident procedure
will outline who the owner of that

207
00:11:50.360 --> 00:11:55.210
incident is and who takes accountability
for ensuring that the incident progresses

208
00:11:55.210 --> 00:12:01.090
throughout it's life cycle, that it
adheres to its service level targets and

209
00:12:01.090 --> 00:12:03.710
that it is communicated
to the organization.

210
00:12:05.060 --> 00:12:11.609
So then, if it's not a major incident,
then we'll diagnose as any other incident.

211
00:12:12.990 --> 00:12:16.830
And so there's an example on this
slide here of what prioritization

212
00:12:16.830 --> 00:12:20.892
might look like based on that
last conversation that we had.

213
00:12:20.892 --> 00:12:25.630
And as I said, I expect so
see this in the service level agreement.

214
00:12:26.970 --> 00:12:29.100
So, now we are going to investigate.

215
00:12:30.400 --> 00:12:34.030
And we can do this next step by
the way at any point in time.

216
00:12:34.030 --> 00:12:35.580
And the next step is escalation.

217
00:12:36.630 --> 00:12:41.560
And if you have been presented with
an incident that is considered to be that

218
00:12:41.560 --> 00:12:46.120
VBF, that vital business function,
then I expect escalation,

219
00:12:46.120 --> 00:12:50.900
certainly hierarchical escalation,
to happen immediately.

220
00:12:50.900 --> 00:12:56.300
So hierarchical escalation means quite
simply escalating to senior management.

221
00:12:56.300 --> 00:12:59.830
Whereas, functional escalation means

222
00:12:59.830 --> 00:13:04.310
escalating to another team or
another functional area.

223
00:13:05.640 --> 00:13:07.660
So I'm gonna ask you another question,
Ronnie.

224
00:13:07.660 --> 00:13:10.650
Why do think we might want to
escalate to senior management?

225
00:13:10.650 --> 00:13:12.580
Why would we want to
escalate hierarchically?

226
00:13:14.000 --> 00:13:16.270
If a decision that needs to be made and

227
00:13:16.270 --> 00:13:19.830
we're not sure if we actually
have the authority to make it.

228
00:13:19.830 --> 00:13:21.570
That's my guess.

229
00:13:21.570 --> 00:13:23.440
>> Yeah,
that's quite a good guess actually.

230
00:13:23.440 --> 00:13:25.720
>> Okay.
>> Yeah, we'd escalate usually for

231
00:13:25.720 --> 00:13:29.750
two reasons and
one of which is for a awareness.

232
00:13:29.750 --> 00:13:30.570
>> Okay.
>> Because senior

233
00:13:30.570 --> 00:13:35.060
management obviously want to know
exactly what is impacting the business.

234
00:13:35.060 --> 00:13:37.330
Okay.
>> And we also escalate for

235
00:13:37.330 --> 00:13:39.520
dedicated resources.

236
00:13:39.520 --> 00:13:40.190
>> Yeah.

237
00:13:40.190 --> 00:13:42.330
>> For decisions to be made.

238
00:13:42.330 --> 00:13:45.960
Sometimes, we might have to spend
money in order to restore service.

239
00:13:45.960 --> 00:13:50.780
Sometimes, we might need dedicated
resources functionally too.

240
00:13:50.780 --> 00:13:54.980
So, and it happens,
let's face it, we're in IT.

241
00:13:54.980 --> 00:13:58.740
We're incident management here and
we escalate an incident to,

242
00:13:58.740 --> 00:14:02.730
say, another support team and
then they take a look at it and

243
00:14:02.730 --> 00:14:05.210
think that it's really not
got anything to do with them.

244
00:14:05.210 --> 00:14:08.840
And so it gets passed on to somebody
else and then they take a look at it and

245
00:14:08.840 --> 00:14:11.780
they think, well it's really
not a network problem, it's

246
00:14:11.780 --> 00:14:15.980
definitely a server problem so we pass
it to somebody else, and you know what?

247
00:14:15.980 --> 00:14:19.190
We've got these targets in this
service level agreement, and

248
00:14:19.190 --> 00:14:24.100
if we've got a four-hour resolution
target in that SLA and then we've

249
00:14:25.540 --> 00:14:30.800
spent three hours passing it around
from one functional area to another,

250
00:14:30.800 --> 00:14:35.160
we're pretty close to being
in breach of that target.

251
00:14:35.160 --> 00:14:39.740
So we might choose to escalate
hierarchically to get somebody to

252
00:14:39.740 --> 00:14:41.930
take ownership of that.

253
00:14:41.930 --> 00:14:44.940
And it's something that you don't
necessarily want to admit happened.

254
00:14:44.940 --> 00:14:49.080
But we're in IT and
sometimes it's difficult to

255
00:14:49.080 --> 00:14:54.660
ascertain exactly who
can fix that incident.

256
00:14:54.660 --> 00:14:58.760
At any point in time,
as I have said, we can escalate and

257
00:14:58.760 --> 00:15:04.600
then we move into investigation and
diagnosis and then resolution identified.

258
00:15:05.740 --> 00:15:10.329
One thing that I want to
say about the resolution.

259
00:15:11.650 --> 00:15:14.940
We always notify our users.

260
00:15:16.600 --> 00:15:20.720
Recovering means in the next step,
recovery means recovering data.

261
00:15:20.720 --> 00:15:21.220
Okay?

262
00:15:22.580 --> 00:15:30.020
Resolution is about resolving and
restoring service.

263
00:15:30.020 --> 00:15:33.830
So, resolving what happened, maybe getting
that previous tape out from one of our

264
00:15:33.830 --> 00:15:40.300
previous episodes, and
recovery means recovering the data.

265
00:15:40.300 --> 00:15:43.460
So, we restore service and
we recover data.

266
00:15:43.460 --> 00:15:48.660
Now, the next step there is incident
closure, and it's never going to be best

267
00:15:48.660 --> 00:15:53.910
practice to close an incident without
first confirming with the user

268
00:15:53.910 --> 00:15:59.230
that the incident has indeed been closed
and that service has indeed been restored.

269
00:16:01.010 --> 00:16:06.470
So in terms of the three strikes I'm out
rule that sometimes seems to be fairly

270
00:16:06.470 --> 00:16:12.920
popular within I.T., designed to advocate
the three strikes and out rule, yes or no?

271
00:16:12.920 --> 00:16:17.060
Well, if it's in the SLA and

272
00:16:17.060 --> 00:16:21.840
it's been agreed by the customer,
than that's fine.

273
00:16:21.840 --> 00:16:23.280
Because don't forget,

274
00:16:23.280 --> 00:16:26.590
this is all about what you need
incident management to look like.

275
00:16:26.590 --> 00:16:31.020
You see, we've got to provide
value to our customers.

276
00:16:31.020 --> 00:16:33.820
And not telling them that
something's been restored, and

277
00:16:33.820 --> 00:16:38.510
not telling them that they've actually got
a resolution, that's not best practice and

278
00:16:38.510 --> 00:16:40.210
that's certainly not delivering value.

279
00:16:41.340 --> 00:16:44.820
But then pestering them
every ten minutes for

280
00:16:44.820 --> 00:16:48.910
a week because they haven't responded to
your phone calls or they haven't replied

281
00:16:48.910 --> 00:16:52.850
to your emails, that's not
necessarily delivering value either.

282
00:16:52.850 --> 00:16:54.110
So how do we get around that?

283
00:16:54.110 --> 00:16:55.980
How do we find that compromise?

284
00:16:55.980 --> 00:17:00.610
Well, what we do is we ensure that if
we're employing something like a three

285
00:17:00.610 --> 00:17:06.090
strikes and out rule, that we will
incorporate that into the SLA so

286
00:17:06.090 --> 00:17:08.660
that it's agreed by the customer.

287
00:17:10.420 --> 00:17:14.450
Ultimately, you can do whatever you
want as long as it's been agreed by your

288
00:17:14.450 --> 00:17:19.300
customer because this is about making
ITIL right for your organization and

289
00:17:19.300 --> 00:17:21.780
delivering value to you.

290
00:17:21.780 --> 00:17:26.690
So, the next slide then
just simply looks at

291
00:17:27.700 --> 00:17:32.330
the entire workflow all on one page,
just to summarize.

292
00:17:33.930 --> 00:17:38.820
So now what we'd like you to do is we'd
like you to take everything that we've

293
00:17:38.820 --> 00:17:44.060
covered in the last few modules
of incident management, and

294
00:17:44.060 --> 00:17:49.920
we'd like you to go to your exercise
guide and to look at the case

295
00:17:49.920 --> 00:17:54.590
study that's in your exercise guide and
the exercises that have been given to you.

296
00:17:54.590 --> 00:17:58.400
And that should take between 60 minutes,
an hour, to an hour and a half.

297
00:17:59.560 --> 00:18:01.130
Okay.
Now it's not a priority to

298
00:18:01.130 --> 00:18:02.780
use the case study that you've been given.

299
00:18:02.780 --> 00:18:05.550
You can use your own organization, but

300
00:18:05.550 --> 00:18:09.700
it is imperative that you understand
the concepts within incident management.

301
00:18:09.700 --> 00:18:15.450
And so our forum is always available if
you do have any questions following this.

302
00:18:15.450 --> 00:18:20.070
All right Jo, well thank you again for
helping us to understand the idea here

303
00:18:20.070 --> 00:18:23.530
of incident management and
using the idea of a process flow.

304
00:18:23.530 --> 00:18:28.800
There are a lot of times that I remember,
especially being relatively new in IT,

305
00:18:28.800 --> 00:18:32.890
it was more of just a scatter gun
approach in which, it's like,

306
00:18:32.890 --> 00:18:36.280
all right, somebody fix it,
that was all that we had to do.

307
00:18:36.280 --> 00:18:37.810
But this is much more efficient,

308
00:18:37.810 --> 00:18:40.720
it gives us a bit of a process
that we can go through and

309
00:18:40.720 --> 00:18:45.110
it gives us solutions along the way as we
work through that process flow as well.

310
00:18:45.110 --> 00:18:48.270
So it is something that we want to take
the time to make sure that we learn.

311
00:18:48.270 --> 00:18:51.280
Make sure you take advantage of
those course materials for us too.

312
00:18:51.280 --> 00:18:53.960
Now that's a great place for us to end for
us to end this episode then.

313
00:18:53.960 --> 00:18:58.270
For ITProTV, I'm your host Ronnie Wong
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

314
00:18:58.270 --> 00:19:03.674
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation shows.

315
00:19:03.674 --> 00:19:09.568
[MUSIC]

316
00:19:09.568 --> 00:19:11.390
Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss the incident Management Metrics.  Jo helps us to understand how to achieve the SLA by using metrics like CSF and KPIs to help.
episodes.title: Incident Management Metrics
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:06.567
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:06.567 --> 00:00:08.240
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.240 --> 00:00:12.001
You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.001 --> 00:00:15.265
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV,

5
00:00:15.265 --> 00:00:19.790
you're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Operation show.

6
00:00:19.790 --> 00:00:21.290
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong and

7
00:00:21.290 --> 00:00:25.160
today, we're jumping into
instant management metrics.

8
00:00:25.160 --> 00:00:30.700
And here to help us is gonna be of course,
our IT giant herself, Miss Jo Peacock.

9
00:00:30.700 --> 00:00:32.460
Jo, welcome back to the studios,
how are you doing today?

10
00:00:32.460 --> 00:00:34.660
>> Hi, I am fine thank you, fine.

11
00:00:34.660 --> 00:00:36.178
How are you?
>> I am doing great,

12
00:00:36.178 --> 00:00:39.747
as we are now taking a look
at the idea of metrics.

13
00:00:39.747 --> 00:00:44.101
Now, Joe I've been in the IT business for
a long time now.

14
00:00:44.101 --> 00:00:48.964
I don't think I've ever really followed
any particular metrics as far as instant

15
00:00:48.964 --> 00:00:50.440
management goes.

16
00:00:50.440 --> 00:00:52.020
So what are really taking a look at here.

17
00:00:52.020 --> 00:00:55.662
>> Well, I mean the first thing that
I want to mention about metrics, and

18
00:00:55.662 --> 00:00:59.305
when you mention you've been in IT for
quite a number of years now-

19
00:00:59.305 --> 00:01:00.065
>> I've just said a while,

20
00:01:00.065 --> 00:01:00.970
I didn't say years.

21
00:01:00.970 --> 00:01:01.636
>> [LAUGH] Okay then.

22
00:01:01.636 --> 00:01:02.785
>> [CROSSTALK] I mean-
>> Okay.

23
00:01:02.785 --> 00:01:03.549
>> Yeah [LAUGH].

24
00:01:03.549 --> 00:01:07.984
>> All right, [LAUGH] hey now look,
come on, you called me a giant earlier,

25
00:01:07.984 --> 00:01:08.537
[LAUGH].

26
00:01:08.537 --> 00:01:12.367
So when we look at metrics,
when we wanna talk about metrics,

27
00:01:12.367 --> 00:01:15.627
the first thing that pops to my mind,
and I don't know about yours.

28
00:01:15.627 --> 00:01:19.237
But I have seen so
many reports that are just so

29
00:01:19.237 --> 00:01:23.042
simply reports for
the sake of having reports.

30
00:01:23.042 --> 00:01:27.622
Pretty pictures just because we
need to have pretty pictures, and

31
00:01:27.622 --> 00:01:31.850
I wonder how many of those
reports are actually looked at.

32
00:01:31.850 --> 00:01:36.683
I wonder how many of those metrics that
are taken that are actually needed.

33
00:01:36.683 --> 00:01:38.120
>> Mm-hm.

34
00:01:38.120 --> 00:01:42.650
>> And here in the IT world,
we have what we call knowledge management.

35
00:01:42.650 --> 00:01:45.850
A knowledge management really
looks at the principle

36
00:01:45.850 --> 00:01:49.520
of having reports only where relevant.

37
00:01:49.520 --> 00:01:52.850
In other words, we call it wisdom.

38
00:01:54.290 --> 00:01:57.130
Believe it or not sorry,
we have wisdom in IT.

39
00:01:58.440 --> 00:02:03.060
It's the premise that,
you see on its own individual

40
00:02:03.060 --> 00:02:08.030
data sources have very,
very limited meaning.

41
00:02:08.030 --> 00:02:12.280
And what we do is we add in
relationships to those data sources and

42
00:02:12.280 --> 00:02:14.020
that gives us information.

43
00:02:14.020 --> 00:02:17.330
Which we then analyze to
give us knowledge and

44
00:02:17.330 --> 00:02:21.360
we present of a nice pretty picture
like the graphs that you see.

45
00:02:21.360 --> 00:02:26.980
And that allows us to make an informed
decision, therefore, giving us wisdom.

46
00:02:26.980 --> 00:02:30.550
So, let's turn that on its head
cuz I started off with data.

47
00:02:32.180 --> 00:02:36.360
What that means is that every
single pretty picture that we see,

48
00:02:36.360 --> 00:02:38.520
every single report that we see.

49
00:02:38.520 --> 00:02:42.282
Whether it's from service level management

CSI is also interested in efficiency too.

277
00:17:03.939 --> 00:17:05.896
It's interested in speed.

278
00:17:05.896 --> 00:17:11.658
CSI is interested in delivering value
to the business in an efficient way,

279
00:17:11.658 --> 00:17:16.321
with minimal wastage in terms of time and
in terms of money and

280
00:17:16.321 --> 00:17:19.260
skills, but still being effective.

281
00:17:20.753 --> 00:17:25.210
So CSI is going to analyze
those incident reports.

282
00:17:25.210 --> 00:17:30.090
And CSI is going to tell us, because
they're the experts in efficiency and

283
00:17:30.090 --> 00:17:30.770
effectiveness.

284
00:17:30.770 --> 00:17:31.980
And they're going to tell us,

285
00:17:31.980 --> 00:17:36.630
whether incident management is actually
doing what it's supposed to do.

286
00:17:36.630 --> 00:17:41.426
Seeing whether incident management is
fulfilling its objectives and its purpose.

287
00:17:43.489 --> 00:17:48.096
So the challenges that we have
then to incident management.

288
00:17:48.096 --> 00:17:50.906
And again, our reporting and

289
00:17:50.906 --> 00:17:56.650
our CSS will help us to determine
what those challenges are.

290
00:17:56.650 --> 00:18:00.210
And later after implementation,
what those risks are.

291
00:18:00.210 --> 00:18:02.300
And the challenges to incident management.

292
00:18:02.300 --> 00:18:05.540
I would say the number one
challenge to incident management,

293
00:18:05.540 --> 00:18:07.280
is that second bullet point down.

294
00:18:08.800 --> 00:18:13.490
And that's the fact that, and I know I've
alluded to this in a previous session.

295
00:18:13.490 --> 00:18:16.210
It's the fact that not
all incidents are logged.

296
00:18:16.210 --> 00:18:18.906
>> Right.
>> And we're never gonna get an accurate

297
00:18:18.906 --> 00:18:22.542
picture of what is happening
in our live environment,

298
00:18:22.542 --> 00:18:24.686
if we don't log all incidents.

299
00:18:24.686 --> 00:18:28.821
So the fact that your friend sends you a
text and asks you to look into something,

300
00:18:28.821 --> 00:18:32.030
and you're in the middle of
something else but that's okay,

301
00:18:32.030 --> 00:18:35.880
because you think that you can get
onto that and do it within 10 minutes.

302
00:18:36.930 --> 00:18:40.112
That's great as long as it's logged.

303
00:18:40.112 --> 00:18:43.249
Should we like everybody's
come through the service desk.

304
00:18:43.249 --> 00:18:47.641
Yeah, and that would be best practice,
but you know what?

305
00:18:47.641 --> 00:18:51.093
We're realists too and we understand
that the text messages still happen, and

306
00:18:51.093 --> 00:18:53.130
all we would say is make sure it's logged.

307
00:18:53.130 --> 00:18:56.905
We need an accurate picture as to what
is happening on our infrastructure.

308
00:18:57.995 --> 00:19:01.895
Without that accuracy, we're not able
to deliver value to the business.

309
00:19:01.895 --> 00:19:03.245
Because we're not efficient and

310
00:19:03.245 --> 00:19:08.615
we're not effective, if we don't know
what is happening on our environment.

311
00:19:08.615 --> 00:19:11.149
So we have to log all of our incidents.

312
00:19:11.149 --> 00:19:17.403
We have to ensure that we have
integration between all of our processes,

313
00:19:17.403 --> 00:19:22.543
and with our configuration
management system [INAUDIBLE].

314
00:19:22.543 --> 00:19:26.130
Our configuration management
system is a system made up of

315
00:19:26.130 --> 00:19:28.253
databases [INAUDIBLE] databases,

316
00:19:28.253 --> 00:19:33.370
that contain all of the information
about the components of our services.

317
00:19:33.370 --> 00:19:39.240
Namely our CIs,
our configuration management details,

318
00:19:39.240 --> 00:19:42.020
all are kept on our configuration
management system, and

319
00:19:42.020 --> 00:19:46.330
our configuration items
are logged within this system.

320
00:19:46.330 --> 00:19:50.790
Well, the purpose of configuration
management is to provide accurate and

321
00:19:50.790 --> 00:19:53.976
reliable information,
about all of our services and

322
00:19:53.976 --> 00:19:56.116
the components of those services.

323
00:19:57.741 --> 00:20:02.837
The first place where we
often find these inaccuracies

324
00:20:02.837 --> 00:20:07.388
highlighted, is when we
call the service desk.

325
00:20:09.325 --> 00:20:14.205
The user calls the service desk and
they'll say, hi, my name is Jo and

326
00:20:14.205 --> 00:20:16.270
I can't get into email.

327
00:20:16.270 --> 00:20:19.200
And the service desk analyst,
what do you think is the first thing that

328
00:20:19.200 --> 00:20:23.020
a service desk analyst
would ask in that instance?

329
00:20:24.190 --> 00:20:29.080
>> I would assume that they would ask,
what have they tried to do or

330
00:20:29.080 --> 00:20:29.790
something like that.

331
00:20:29.790 --> 00:20:33.018
I'm not exactly sure what they would
ask in that particular instance.

332
00:20:33.018 --> 00:20:35.475
>> You don't think they'd
ask who they were?

333
00:20:35.475 --> 00:20:37.070
>> Who they were, probably not.

334
00:20:37.070 --> 00:20:38.400
I'd doubt it.

335
00:20:38.400 --> 00:20:41.150
>> Okay.
>> Yeah but no you're right, they should.

336
00:20:41.150 --> 00:20:43.350
>> Yeah,
were told by the research analysts.

337
00:20:43.350 --> 00:20:45.940
So the first thing you
ask is what is the name,

338
00:20:45.940 --> 00:20:47.820
what's the user ID of
the person who's calling.

339
00:20:48.918 --> 00:20:51.390
Because, and I'll tell you why we do this,

340
00:20:51.390 --> 00:20:56.000
it's because if we input the details
into the call logging system,

341
00:20:56.000 --> 00:21:01.490
then what we have hopefully if we've got
that accurate information being pulled

342
00:21:01.490 --> 00:21:06.760
from the CMDB, then we should have all
that information at our finger tips.

343
00:21:06.760 --> 00:21:07.840
>> Correct.

344
00:21:07.840 --> 00:21:10.390
>> So if you call me on the service desk,

345
00:21:10.390 --> 00:21:14.380
my first reaction is to ask you your
name and ask you for your user ID.

346
00:21:14.380 --> 00:21:17.206
>> Right.
>> I type in your user ID, and then all of

347
00:21:17.206 --> 00:21:23.097
a sudden it tells me who you are, where
you're located, what machine you're using,

348
00:21:23.097 --> 00:21:28.044
what PC you have, what portion of
the infrastructure you're on, etc.

349
00:21:28.044 --> 00:21:33.464
And all of that information is pulled out
of this configuration management system,

350
00:21:33.464 --> 00:21:35.844
that is on the slides in front of you.

351
00:21:35.844 --> 00:21:41.842
And so, the service desk
are the first people to determine,

352
00:21:41.842 --> 00:21:47.846
whether the information that's
in that CMS is inaccurate.

353
00:21:47.846 --> 00:21:48.678
>> Alright.

354
00:21:48.678 --> 00:21:51.972
>> So that integration is really,
really important.

355
00:21:51.972 --> 00:21:55.370
Now I don't know if we can take a look
at that yet, the slide's in front of us.

356
00:21:55.370 --> 00:21:58.270
That allows us to be
an effective service desk.

357
00:21:58.270 --> 00:22:02.477
Because that integration that exist.

358
00:22:02.477 --> 00:22:06.660
Well, if the service desk update
the information in the configuration

359
00:22:06.660 --> 00:22:12.760
management system, then that ensures that
accurate information is kept in our CMDB.

360
00:22:12.760 --> 00:22:17.820
So the next time the change
management want to raise a change,

361
00:22:17.820 --> 00:22:23.010
they look at a particular I
know an asset number let's say,

362
00:22:23.010 --> 00:22:27.810
or a CI number and they look at that CI
and they say, we'd like to change that CI.

363
00:22:27.810 --> 00:22:34.450
They can be assured that the information
contained about that CI is accurate.

364
00:22:34.450 --> 00:22:38.220
So let's say they wanted to swap
out a router on the third floor.

365
00:22:38.220 --> 00:22:43.092
Well, they simply go into the CMS,
they look at that router number and

366
00:22:43.092 --> 00:22:46.494
it tells them exactly
who's using that router.

367
00:22:46.494 --> 00:22:50.618
Now just imagine how happy you'd be
if you got a notification to say,

368
00:22:50.618 --> 00:22:53.390
we're going to swap out
a router at lunch time.

369
00:22:53.390 --> 00:22:55.150
You'd know what was happening.

370
00:22:55.150 --> 00:22:59.890
Just imagine how unhappy you'd be if
you didn't receive that information,

371
00:22:59.890 --> 00:23:02.820
because the last time you
called the service desk,

372
00:23:02.820 --> 00:23:06.560
the analysts didn't take
your exact location.

373
00:23:06.560 --> 00:23:10.250
Didn't change the information
in the call login system,

374
00:23:10.250 --> 00:23:15.550
it didn't therefore change in
the configuration management system.

375
00:23:15.550 --> 00:23:21.620
And now you're being impacted just because
of inefficient incident management.

376
00:23:21.620 --> 00:23:23.200
>> Right, I agree.

377
00:23:23.200 --> 00:23:25.820
>> So that integration there is really,
really important and

378
00:23:25.820 --> 00:23:28.120
that's what makes
an effective service desk.

379
00:23:28.120 --> 00:23:32.520
But that's also what allows us to
tie all of our processes together.

380
00:23:32.520 --> 00:23:35.580
And we look at configuration
management in a lot more detail,

381
00:23:35.580 --> 00:23:37.285
in our service transition modules.

382
00:23:39.040 --> 00:23:41.830
So, what about the risks?

383
00:23:41.830 --> 00:23:44.860
What are going cause us to fail
within incident management?

384
00:23:46.290 --> 00:23:47.914
Look at that incident back log.

385
00:23:47.914 --> 00:23:52.915
Look at how many incidents we've
got outstanding in our queue.

386
00:23:52.915 --> 00:23:56.800
That's what leads to user dissatisfaction.

387
00:23:56.800 --> 00:24:01.000
Now, if you've already got an incident
back log, what do you do [LAUGH] about it?

388
00:24:01.000 --> 00:24:04.880
Well, [LAUGH] I know of some organizations
that will say, well that's okay, Jo.

389
00:24:04.880 --> 00:24:06.320
We'll just change the times.

390
00:24:06.320 --> 00:24:08.840
We'll just change the priorities
of our incidents.

391
00:24:08.840 --> 00:24:11.320
Well of course that's not
really best practice.

392
00:24:11.320 --> 00:24:12.120
>> Right.

393
00:24:12.120 --> 00:24:15.740
>> What we need to do is ensure that we've
got the right processes in place and

394
00:24:15.740 --> 00:24:17.910
that we do have the right
targets in place.

395
00:24:17.910 --> 00:24:22.890
And maybe we do have to revisit some of
those targets, but we have to ensure that

396
00:24:22.890 --> 00:24:26.910
the targets that we have are relevant and
that they're in the service level

397
00:24:26.910 --> 00:24:30.830
agreement, because they're needed and
because they add value to the business.

398
00:24:30.830 --> 00:24:33.880
And then we can use our reporting,
our CMS and

399
00:24:33.880 --> 00:24:37.040
our KPIs,
to highlight any training issues.

400
00:24:37.040 --> 00:24:40.818
And that could be training issues
within the service desk itself,

401
00:24:40.818 --> 00:24:44.056
could be training issues
within our technical teams, or

402
00:24:44.056 --> 00:24:47.375
it could be training issues
within the user environment.

403
00:24:47.375 --> 00:24:49.902
Remember, we talked about
this very early on in

404
00:24:49.902 --> 00:24:53.756
an earlier module about the fact that
incident management can highlight

405
00:24:53.756 --> 00:24:57.010
training issues in our
user environment too.

406
00:24:57.010 --> 00:25:02.310
So, if we get the reporting right,
then actually, we can highlight any

407
00:25:02.310 --> 00:25:07.220
issues there, any risks straight away,
and that allows us to tackle them.

408
00:25:08.960 --> 00:25:12.520
So the last slide that I
really want to look at in this

409
00:25:12.520 --> 00:25:15.610
particular section is
the service desk involvement.

410
00:25:15.610 --> 00:25:18.150
You see, I've mentioned
the Service Desk quite a lot,

411
00:25:18.150 --> 00:25:21.700
quite extensively throughout all
our system management modules.

412
00:25:21.700 --> 00:25:26.030
Because the Service Desk takes
ownership of incident management.

413
00:25:27.140 --> 00:25:32.230
This is the only time in ITIL where we
actually tell you which functional team,

414
00:25:32.230 --> 00:25:35.840
which functional area,
should own which process.

415
00:25:35.840 --> 00:25:38.210
The only time that we do that and

416
00:25:38.210 --> 00:25:42.970
the Service Desk takes accountability for
incident management.

417
00:25:42.970 --> 00:25:50.129
And so, it's not unusual that he Service
Desk Manager is also the manager as well.

418
00:25:50.129 --> 00:25:55.054
The Service Desk acts as a single point of
contact between IT and the business and

419
00:25:55.054 --> 00:25:59.096
we're gonna come to that in more
detail a little bit later on one of

420
00:25:59.096 --> 00:26:00.365
the other modules.

421
00:26:01.645 --> 00:26:03.265
But we call it a SPOC,

422
00:26:03.265 --> 00:26:07.875
a single point of communication as
is on that last bullet point there.

423
00:26:07.875 --> 00:26:11.600
And so the Service Desk
assumes responsibility for

424
00:26:11.600 --> 00:26:17.970
all of the incident management process
flow including all of that communication,

425
00:26:17.970 --> 00:26:22.530
and including managing those incidents
throughout their life cycle, okay.

426
00:26:24.062 --> 00:26:26.780
So, now what I'd like everybody to do,
because, again,

427
00:26:26.780 --> 00:26:31.180
we've covered more information here,
certainly, to do with metrics.

428
00:26:31.180 --> 00:26:34.280
And the concepts and
the differentiation between a CSF and

429
00:26:34.280 --> 00:26:38.150
a KPI can be quite a challenging
one to get your head around.

430
00:26:38.150 --> 00:26:43.910
So now is the time for us to review or
for you to review your notes and

431
00:26:43.910 --> 00:26:49.820
go back over the CSF and KPI concepts and
highlight to us if there

432
00:26:49.820 --> 00:26:54.760
are any challenges that you face, and if
you have any questions relating to this.

433
00:26:56.038 --> 00:26:59.515
>> All right, Jo,
well thank you again for helping us,

434
00:26:59.515 --> 00:27:02.528
if not,
at least introducing me to the realm,

435
00:27:02.528 --> 00:27:07.029
the idea here of using metrics inside
of service operations as well.

436
00:27:07.029 --> 00:27:11.489
Remember that these concepts are very key
if we are gonna be part of taking a look

437
00:27:11.489 --> 00:27:16.156
at the continual service improvement,
as well as learning those different terms

438
00:27:16.156 --> 00:27:20.760
that you need reminding of the CSF as
well as the KPIs that are out there too.

439
00:27:20.760 --> 00:27:22.700
So, a lot of acronyms that
you have to take a look at.

440
00:27:22.700 --> 00:27:24.640
But there is time for you to do that.

441
00:27:24.640 --> 00:27:28.610
So, it is recommended by Jo that you do
take the time to make sure that you review

442
00:27:28.610 --> 00:27:31.850
those concepts before you
move forward here as well.

443
00:27:31.850 --> 00:27:35.100
Well that's a great place for
us to sign off on this episode then.

444
00:27:35.100 --> 00:27:38.310
For ITProTV, I'm your host Ronnie Wong
>> And

445
00:27:38.310 --> 00:27:40.903
I'm Jo Peacock
>> Stay tuned right here for

446
00:27:40.903 --> 00:27:43.991
more ITIL Intermediate Service Operation
shows.

447
00:27:43.991 --> 00:27:49.935
[MUSIC]

448
00:27:49.935 --> 00:27:53.096
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo begin with Problem Management Principles.  The emphasis on problem management helps to prevent incidents from occurring, find the root cause of incidents using proactive and reactive techniques that are available to our organization.  It sets the foundations of the some of the details to come in later shows on problem management.
episodes.title: Problem Management Objectives
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:08.388
Welcome to ITProTV [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:08.388 --> 00:00:12.276
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.276 --> 00:00:15.959
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.959 --> 00:00:19.376
You're watching the ITIL Intermediate
on Service Operation.

5
00:00:19.376 --> 00:00:20.926
I'm your host Ronnie Wong,

6
00:00:20.926 --> 00:00:24.990
and today we're gonna take a look
at problem management objectives.

7
00:00:24.990 --> 00:00:29.820
And here to help us is our ITIL
royalty herself, Ms. Jo Peacock.

8
00:00:29.820 --> 00:00:31.016
Jo, welcome back to the show.

9
00:00:31.016 --> 00:00:32.257
>> [LAUGH] Good morning.

10
00:00:32.257 --> 00:00:33.238
How are you, Ronnie?

11
00:00:33.238 --> 00:00:35.530
>> I am doing fine, Jo.

12
00:00:35.530 --> 00:00:41.080
As we have already taken a look a little
bit about some of the incident management.

13
00:00:41.080 --> 00:00:42.984
Take us a little bit back through that and

14
00:00:42.984 --> 00:00:45.560
then tell us where we're
gonna be heading now.

15
00:00:45.560 --> 00:00:49.626
>> So in our first few sessions we
looked at the objectives of operations,

16
00:00:49.626 --> 00:00:50.950
service operation.

17
00:00:50.950 --> 00:00:54.630
And service operation is all
about the business as usual.

18
00:00:54.630 --> 00:00:57.830
It's all about the life services,
delivering value.

19
00:00:57.830 --> 00:01:02.570
And in earlier sessions, we looked at
the concept of value being perceived.

20
00:01:04.040 --> 00:01:07.120
We also looked at the interaction
with other processes,

21
00:01:07.120 --> 00:01:12.350
such as service level management which
of course was key to service operation.

22
00:01:12.350 --> 00:01:17.249
Without service level management, we just
don't know how to deliver our services and

23
00:01:17.249 --> 00:01:20.082
what parameters to deliver
our services within.

24
00:01:20.082 --> 00:01:24.247
So service level management then
gave us a very good grounding for

25
00:01:24.247 --> 00:01:29.160
incident management which was
the second process actually that

26
00:01:29.160 --> 00:01:33.755
we looked at throughout
our previous sessions.

27
00:01:33.755 --> 00:01:39.530
And incident management is where we try
and restore normal service operation.

28
00:01:39.530 --> 00:01:45.230
Normal service operation as defined
in that service level agreement.

29
00:01:45.230 --> 00:01:46.480
And we call it an SLA,

30
00:01:46.480 --> 00:01:50.650
a service level agreement, because
it's been agreed with the customer.

31
00:01:50.650 --> 00:01:55.578
So, in incident management
we're trying to fix something.

32
00:01:55.578 --> 00:01:57.864
Now we did little
exercise if you remember.

33
00:01:57.864 --> 00:02:02.260
In one of the session we did little
exercise with a piece of paper and

34
00:02:02.260 --> 00:02:06.894
a roll of tape where we look at
the difference between an incident which

35
00:02:06.894 --> 00:02:11.545
was that rip in that piece of paper and
the problem which were my hands.

36
00:02:11.545 --> 00:02:16.120
And the difference between them and the
difference between restoring service which

37
00:02:16.120 --> 00:02:19.858
is simply getting the tape and
sticking the paper back together, and

38
00:02:19.858 --> 00:02:22.387
fixing the problem which
was rather drastic.

39
00:02:22.387 --> 00:02:25.665
I just wanna say Ronnie,
you wanted to tie my hands behind my back.

40
00:02:25.665 --> 00:02:26.785
>> Yeah, that was wrong.

41
00:02:26.785 --> 00:02:28.870
>> Yeah, that was wrong,
[LAUGH] that was wrong.

42
00:02:28.870 --> 00:02:30.966
[LAUGH] So, now what we're going to do,

43
00:02:30.966 --> 00:02:34.087
we spent some time in looking
at incident management.

44
00:02:34.087 --> 00:02:41.430
And exactly how we get the tape and that
piece of paper and we restore service.

45
00:02:41.430 --> 00:02:45.320
And we have to do it within a certain time
frame, so that tape had better be handy.

46
00:02:45.320 --> 00:02:46.880
But that tape was a workaround and

47
00:02:46.880 --> 00:02:50.680
those workarounds are defined
by problem management.

48
00:02:50.680 --> 00:02:54.100
Problem management will tell
us what type of tape to use,

49
00:02:54.100 --> 00:02:55.730
that will tell us what tape works best.

50
00:02:56.770 --> 00:03:01.840
But problem management also will look at,
as I've already said,

51
00:03:01.840 --> 00:03:05.580
you know the extreme [LAUGH]
the tying my hands behind my back.

52
00:03:05.580 --> 00:03:12.280
And problem management's objective
is simply to prevent incidents,

53
00:03:12.280 --> 00:03:18.333
to prevent problems, and
to look at the root cause of incidents.

54
00:03:18.333 --> 00:03:24.340
So, problem management's role is to
find out exactly why something happened.

databases.
