00:17:32.002 --> 00:17:35.907
And I said to you, this Configuration
Management system was the foundation for

281
00:17:35.907 --> 00:17:37.400
Incident Management,

282
00:17:37.400 --> 00:17:42.430
because it gave us all of the information
about all of our configuration items.

283
00:17:43.490 --> 00:17:47.360
And we went through the example where I
asked you, if you called the service desk,

284
00:17:47.360 --> 00:17:50.300
what would the service desk
analyst ask for first?

285
00:17:50.300 --> 00:17:50.809
>> By the name.

286
00:17:50.809 --> 00:17:53.490
>> Right, your name or your user ID.

287
00:17:53.490 --> 00:17:57.470
And from there, they would extract
all of the information about you, and

288
00:17:57.470 --> 00:17:59.070
about the laptop that you had.

289
00:18:00.260 --> 00:18:02.500
Well, when they extract all
of that information, and

290
00:18:02.500 --> 00:18:05.070
it's pulled into the core login system,
do you know what?

291
00:18:05.070 --> 00:18:09.777
It also pulls the history of that laptop,
so they can see exactly how many

292
00:18:09.777 --> 00:18:14.980
incidents you have, and
how many problems, you have or have had.

293
00:18:16.390 --> 00:18:20.170
So straight away, we now realize that we

294
00:18:20.170 --> 00:18:25.072
can directly relate incidents
to problem records.

295
00:18:25.072 --> 00:18:29.874
So when we raise a problem record,
we can see immediately the impact.

296
00:18:29.874 --> 00:18:34.899
Because we know how many incidents have
been raised against that asset number,

297
00:18:34.899 --> 00:18:36.329
against your laptop.

298
00:18:36.329 --> 00:18:39.490
And the same works for
every single service as well.

299
00:18:41.530 --> 00:18:43.957
So the relationship with
Incident Management and

300
00:18:43.957 --> 00:18:46.410
Problem Management is very important.

301
00:18:46.410 --> 00:18:50.518
And I know that we did a little session
on the difference between them, but

302
00:18:50.518 --> 00:18:52.051
they are heavily related.

303
00:18:52.051 --> 00:18:56.013
So if we go back, then,
to that slide that we were looking at.

304
00:18:56.013 --> 00:19:01.049
And in the bottom left-hand corner, sorry,
bottom right-hand corner of that slide.

305
00:19:02.320 --> 00:19:07.019
We see some of the techniques that we
would use within Problem Management,

306
00:19:07.019 --> 00:19:08.668
to get to that root cause.

307
00:19:08.668 --> 00:19:13.600
Some brainstorming sessions,
we use techniques such as Ishikawa,

308
00:19:13.600 --> 00:19:16.925
which is what we might
call fishbone diagram.

309
00:19:16.925 --> 00:19:19.474
Or the five whys, the five hows.

310
00:19:19.474 --> 00:19:25.132
How we would get to the bottom of
a problem, How we'd get to the root cause.

311
00:19:25.132 --> 00:19:28.980
And there are so many Problem Management
techniques out there,

312
00:19:28.980 --> 00:19:31.698
that we would use to
identify the root cause.

313
00:19:34.024 --> 00:19:35.930
So why bother with Problem Management?

314
00:19:35.930 --> 00:19:40.550
I mean, why don't we just fix
the issue that we have at hand?

315
00:19:40.550 --> 00:19:42.042
Why don't we just get out the tape?

316
00:19:43.725 --> 00:19:46.142
Well, how frustrated are you gonna be,

317
00:19:46.142 --> 00:19:48.852
that you have to keep
rebooting your laptop?

318
00:19:48.852 --> 00:19:50.617
>> Well,
depending on the frequency, right,

319
00:19:50.617 --> 00:19:52.203
it would probably become frustrating.

320
00:19:52.203 --> 00:19:54.969
But after a couple of, or
three times that it's happening.

321
00:19:54.969 --> 00:19:56.842
There's gotta be another issue,

322
00:19:56.842 --> 00:20:00.230
than the rebooting is actually
just fixing anything.

323
00:20:00.230 --> 00:20:03.590
It is at least managing, but
it would be frustrating really quickly.

324
00:20:03.590 --> 00:20:05.413
>> And
that's why we need Problem Management,

325
00:20:05.413 --> 00:20:08.100
that's exactly why we
need Problem Management.

326
00:20:08.100 --> 00:20:10.170
We talk about increased
service productivity,

327
00:20:10.170 --> 00:20:15.510
because quite simply, if you're rebooting
your laptop, then you're not working.

328
00:20:15.510 --> 00:20:18.320
Which is, of course,
the bad staff productivity.

329
00:20:18.320 --> 00:20:20.270
And then lower support costs,

330
00:20:20.270 --> 00:20:23.230
because you're not calling
the service desk every five minutes.

331
00:20:23.230 --> 00:20:24.564
You're not reporting it,

332
00:20:24.564 --> 00:20:28.016
because we're going to fix
the problem with the laptop, okay?

333
00:20:28.016 --> 00:20:33.670
So then, what type of policies do we
need then, within Problem Management?

334
00:20:33.670 --> 00:20:38.600
Well, one of the basic principles of
Problem Management is that problems and

335
00:20:38.600 --> 00:20:43.110
incidents really need to be logged
in the same core logging system.

336
00:20:43.110 --> 00:20:46.410
Even though it says they should be
tracked separately from incidents,

337
00:20:46.410 --> 00:20:48.615
they're two completely different entities.

338
00:20:48.615 --> 00:20:51.787
But we should have a single
management system, for

339
00:20:51.787 --> 00:20:54.160
both our problems and our incidents.

340
00:20:54.160 --> 00:20:59.627
That allow us to relate them together, to
each other, through both the incident and

341
00:20:59.627 --> 00:21:04.880
problem records, and also through the
asset numbers within the CMBD, as well.

342
00:21:06.390 --> 00:21:10.239
Now, we're going to look at
the Problem Management process flow in

343
00:21:10.239 --> 00:21:11.680
a later session.

344
00:21:11.680 --> 00:21:16.390
But that bottom bullet point about having
a consistent classification scheme.

345
00:21:16.390 --> 00:21:19.950
We're going to use the same classification
scheme that we use in Incident Management,

346
00:21:19.950 --> 00:21:22.880
which will really increase
that consistency.

347
00:21:22.880 --> 00:21:26.653
We need to have that standardization,
okay.

348
00:21:26.653 --> 00:21:31.255
So I mentioned, earlier on,
when we looked at Incident Management,

349
00:21:31.255 --> 00:21:33.291
I mentioned incident models.

350
00:21:33.291 --> 00:21:38.513
About you taking a look at
a Incident Management process flow,

351
00:21:38.513 --> 00:21:41.183
and pre-defining some steps.

352
00:21:41.183 --> 00:21:43.566
It's exactly the same
with Problem Management,

353
00:21:43.566 --> 00:21:45.331
we're going to do exactly the same.

354
00:21:45.331 --> 00:21:50.150
When you define your
Problem Management process,

355
00:21:50.150 --> 00:21:54.071
I expect to you to define Problem Models,

356
00:21:54.071 --> 00:21:59.015
predefined steps for
different types of problems.

357
00:21:59.015 --> 00:22:03.716
Now, there's something that I haven't
mentioned before coming up, and

358
00:22:03.716 --> 00:22:07.610
that's the Known Error and
the Known Error Database, okay.

359
00:22:07.610 --> 00:22:10.975
So let's go back to this
example that I gave you.

360
00:22:10.975 --> 00:22:15.595
And the example that I used
of the piece of paper and

361
00:22:15.595 --> 00:22:19.890
the tape,
that we used in a previous session.

362
00:22:21.170 --> 00:22:24.701
So that example of that piece of paper,

363
00:22:24.701 --> 00:22:29.949
we know that I have this liking for
tearing up pieces of paper.

364
00:22:31.144 --> 00:22:35.100
So this is what we call a Known Error, and

365
00:22:35.100 --> 00:22:37.190
a Known Error is simply
the fact that we know.

366
00:22:38.820 --> 00:22:45.510
So, one of the ways of restoring service,
okay, in a very efficient way.

367
00:22:45.510 --> 00:22:49.040
Cuz bear in mind, we're still concerned
with efficiency and effectiveness.

368
00:22:49.040 --> 00:22:52.551
One of the ways of restore
a service in an efficient way,

369
00:22:52.551 --> 00:22:55.479
is simply just to have
some tape on hand for me.

370
00:22:55.479 --> 00:22:57.821
I'm gonna start ripping
up pieces of paper,

371
00:22:57.821 --> 00:23:00.976
so therefore somebody needs to
have a roll of tape next to me.

372
00:23:00.976 --> 00:23:03.243
So that I can just take off that tape, and

373
00:23:03.243 --> 00:23:06.190
I can just put the paper
back together again, okay?

374
00:23:06.190 --> 00:23:08.770
That's what's called a Known Error.

375
00:23:08.770 --> 00:23:14.320
And a Known Error is a problem for which
we know the root cause, you remember,

376
00:23:14.320 --> 00:23:19.633
they were my hands, and for
which a workaround has been identified.

377
00:23:19.633 --> 00:23:24.100
Well, we identified the workaround,
it was that roll of tape, right?

378
00:23:25.370 --> 00:23:27.190
So what we'll do is we'll document that.

379
00:23:28.400 --> 00:23:32.424
So the next time that it happens,
we'll have that workaround to hand.

380
00:23:32.424 --> 00:23:36.320
And we document that and
put it into the Known Error Database.

381
00:23:37.510 --> 00:23:41.400
Even though it's used by
Problem Management to restore service,

382
00:23:41.400 --> 00:23:45.345
that Known Error is still
owned by Problem Management.

383
00:23:45.345 --> 00:23:50.220
So it's used by Incident Management,
and it's owned by Problem Management.

384
00:23:51.300 --> 00:23:54.072
Let's put this into an IT perspective.

385
00:23:54.072 --> 00:24:00.171
So your laptop keeps locking up, we know
that your laptop is prone to locking up.

386
00:24:00.171 --> 00:24:04.289
So what we're going to do is, we're gonna
document a Known Error that says, okay,

387
00:24:04.289 --> 00:24:06.750
Ronnie's laptop is prone to locking up.

388
00:24:06.750 --> 00:24:11.430
So if it happened, then just reboot it,
that's the workaround.

389
00:24:11.430 --> 00:24:15.090
And what we've done is we've
taken a Known Error, and

390
00:24:15.090 --> 00:24:17.040
we've documented it with a workaround.

391
00:24:17.040 --> 00:24:20.200
And you might ask, well, what's
the point in this, why do we do this?

392
00:24:21.560 --> 00:24:24.002
Well, because when you
call the service desk,

393
00:24:24.002 --> 00:24:27.064
you're not going to get the same
person every single time.

394
00:24:27.064 --> 00:24:29.930
And one time you might get me,
and of course,

395
00:24:29.930 --> 00:24:32.457
I know everything that I'm doing, okay.

396
00:24:33.550 --> 00:24:38.290
But another time, you might get
somebody else who's just started,

397
00:24:38.290 --> 00:24:39.910
who doesn't even know who you are.

398
00:24:41.050 --> 00:24:44.530
And wouldn't it be great,
if when you called the service desk,

399
00:24:44.530 --> 00:24:46.470
it didn't matter who you spoke to?

400
00:24:46.470 --> 00:24:49.243
They're able to take your name and
your user ID, and

401
00:24:49.243 --> 00:24:52.281
as soon as they type in your details,
they can say, hey.

402
00:24:52.281 --> 00:24:56.998
Ronnie's got a Known Error on his laptop,
and this is what you do if

403
00:24:56.998 --> 00:25:01.730
it's happened again, and
it prompts that service desk analyst.

404
00:25:03.660 --> 00:25:05.500
That's kind of what we call efficiency.

405
00:25:05.500 --> 00:25:06.090
>> It is.

406
00:25:06.090 --> 00:25:09.932
>> Yeah, and that's what we
want to achieve in ITIL, okay.

407
00:25:09.932 --> 00:25:13.883
So now, we've looked at the principles
of Problem Management, and

408
00:25:13.883 --> 00:25:17.167
we look to the objectives of
Problem Management, okay?

409
00:25:17.167 --> 00:25:19.453
And what I'd like you to do right now,

410
00:25:19.453 --> 00:25:23.035
is to take a look at the materials
that you've downloaded.

411
00:25:23.035 --> 00:25:26.910
And look at the exercises
relating to the principles and

412
00:25:26.910 --> 00:25:29.718
the objectives of Problem Management.

413
00:25:29.718 --> 00:25:33.839
Now we'd recommend 60 minutes,
we'd recommend an hour for you to do that.

414
00:25:33.839 --> 00:25:38.220
And just take a look at the case study,I
f you don't want to use the case study,

415
00:25:38.220 --> 00:25:42.020
then use the examples from
your own organization.

416
00:25:42.020 --> 00:25:44.790
>> All right, Jo, well that's
a great place for us to sign off,

417
00:25:44.790 --> 00:25:48.440
cuz there's more episodes to come for
Problem Management.

418
00:25:48.440 --> 00:25:52.190
For ITProTV, I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

419
00:25:52.190 --> 00:25:53.500
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

420
00:25:53.500 --> 00:25:58.228
>> Stay tuned right here, for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation shows.

421
00:25:58.228 --> 00:26:04.532
[MUSIC]

422
00:26:04.532 --> 00:26:07.376
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss and walk through the problem management process flow chart.  The process flow shows us an effective and efficient way of problem management according to the team. Jo helps us to remember the problems are identified, logged, the problem management team must also categorize and prioritize the problems then take the time to investigate and diagnosis.  She explains also following that, we may need a workaround, resolution or change needed then closure.
episodes.title: Problem Management Process Flow
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.468
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
Im your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.468 --> 00:00:06.387
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.387 --> 00:00:08.258
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.258 --> 00:00:12.352
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.352 --> 00:00:15.859
>> Welcome to another great episode,
right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.859 --> 00:00:19.717
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Operation show.

7
00:00:19.717 --> 00:00:20.637
I'm your host,

8
00:00:20.637 --> 00:00:25.187
Ronnie Wong, and today we're taking a look
at Problem Management process flow.

9
00:00:25.187 --> 00:00:27.894
We've already talked about the idea
of some of the principles behind

10
00:00:27.894 --> 00:00:29.210
Problem Management.

11
00:00:29.210 --> 00:00:32.350
And now we're about to actually
learn about the process flow itself

12
00:00:32.350 --> 00:00:36.690
from the potentate of ITIL, Jo Peacock.

13
00:00:36.690 --> 00:00:37.944
Jo, welcome back to the show.

14
00:00:37.944 --> 00:00:39.790
>> Hi, Ronnie, how are you this morning?

15
00:00:39.790 --> 00:00:43.979
>> I am doing great as we continue on
to learn more about Problem Management.

16
00:00:43.979 --> 00:00:46.868
Great material so
far as we've talked about it,

17
00:00:46.868 --> 00:00:52.120
especially the differences between
incidences and Problem Management itself.

18
00:00:52.120 --> 00:00:55.315
But now this process flow,
that should help us out even more, so

19
00:00:55.315 --> 00:00:57.397
Jo, what are we gonna take a look at here?

20
00:00:57.397 --> 00:01:03.682
>> Okay, so very similar to when we looked
at the Incident Management process flow.

21
00:01:03.682 --> 00:01:06.811
We're going to take a look at
Problem Management right now.

22
00:01:06.811 --> 00:01:10.412
And we've already talked about
the differences between an incident and

23
00:01:10.412 --> 00:01:11.010
a problem.

24
00:01:11.010 --> 00:01:14.339
And therefore, the difference
between Incident Management and

25
00:01:14.339 --> 00:01:15.495
Problem Management.

26
00:01:15.495 --> 00:01:19.040
But then we've also talked about
similarities between Incident and

27
00:01:19.040 --> 00:01:23.028
Problem Management as well, and the fact
that the two are very much related.

28
00:01:23.028 --> 00:01:26.564
And we're going to take a look
at the process flow itself now.

29
00:01:26.564 --> 00:01:30.260
And you will see when you look at
this process flow, it looks very,

30
00:01:30.260 --> 00:01:32.901
very similar to one that
you've already seen.

31
00:01:32.901 --> 00:01:35.830
That would be the Incident Management
process flow.

32
00:01:35.830 --> 00:01:39.220
There are a few differences and
we're going to go through them.

33
00:01:39.220 --> 00:01:42.347
But in the last session,
we talked about models and

34
00:01:42.347 --> 00:01:46.358
we've talked about models within
Incident Management as well.

35
00:01:46.358 --> 00:01:51.228
And we've talked right away throughout
service operation about the fact that

36
00:01:51.228 --> 00:01:53.882
we adapt ITIL to suit our own environment,

37
00:01:53.882 --> 00:01:57.690
that we have to make ITIL efficient and
effective for us.

38
00:01:57.690 --> 00:02:02.250
So what we've got here is just an example
of a Problem Management process

39
00:02:02.250 --> 00:02:03.157
flow, okay.

40
00:02:03.157 --> 00:02:07.110
This is not what you would
have in your organization.

41
00:02:07.110 --> 00:02:09.360
This is not a one size fits all.

42
00:02:09.360 --> 00:02:13.410
This is not a pill that you
can take that's going to solve

43
00:02:13.410 --> 00:02:17.420
all of your challenges within
IT service management.

44
00:02:17.420 --> 00:02:22.002
This is just simply a framework for

45
00:02:22.002 --> 00:02:25.658
your adaptation for ITIL.

46
00:02:25.658 --> 00:02:28.910
>> All right, now Jo, I'm noticing
something a little bit, to me,

47
00:02:28.910 --> 00:02:32.240
unusual about the process flow that
we're about to take a look at.

48
00:02:32.240 --> 00:02:36.672
It actually looks fairly linear in
comparison to what we've seen in event

49
00:02:36.672 --> 00:02:39.750
management and
even in Incident Management here.

50
00:02:39.750 --> 00:02:43.423
So is this as straightforward
as it sounds?

51
00:02:43.423 --> 00:02:45.839
>> [LAUGH] I was just about to say,
just wait.

52
00:02:45.839 --> 00:02:47.146
>> [LAUGH] Okay.

53
00:02:47.146 --> 00:02:50.453
>> [LAUGH] It is actually as
straightforward as it sounds, and

54
00:02:50.453 --> 00:02:51.668
in the last episode,

55
00:02:51.668 --> 00:02:55.796
we looked at the fact that you might
not always want to resolve a problem.

56
00:02:55.796 --> 00:03:00.077
But we have to make that decision as to
whether we want to resolve a problem.

57
00:03:00.077 --> 00:03:02.738
But it is fairly linear.

58
00:03:02.738 --> 00:03:05.258
It is fairly straightforward.

59
00:03:05.258 --> 00:03:08.990
If you look at this, we detect
the problem, we log it, categorize it,

60
00:03:08.990 --> 00:03:12.000
prioritize it, and
investigate and diagnose it.

61
00:03:12.000 --> 00:03:15.411
And we've got that relationship with
the Configuration Management System.

62
00:03:15.411 --> 00:03:18.238
It looks fairly similar to
Incident Management and

63
00:03:18.238 --> 00:03:20.300
it is fairly straightforward.

64
00:03:20.300 --> 00:03:21.307
That doesn't make it easy though.

65
00:03:21.307 --> 00:03:21.860
>> No.

66
00:03:21.860 --> 00:03:26.456
>> There's a big difference
between being simple and easy.

67
00:03:26.456 --> 00:03:27.028
>> Right.
>> And

68
00:03:27.028 --> 00:03:30.011
we like the keep it simple
approach within ITIL.

69
00:03:30.011 --> 00:03:33.727
And we like the keep it
sensible approach as well.

70
00:03:33.727 --> 00:03:38.575
We want to make sure that whatever
process you define is relevant

71
00:03:38.575 --> 00:03:40.710
to your organization.

72
00:03:40.710 --> 00:03:44.340
It can't just be a one
size fits all approach.

73
00:03:44.340 --> 00:03:47.931
You can't just take it out of the ITIL
publications and make it fit,

74
00:03:47.931 --> 00:03:49.134
cuz it simply won't.

75
00:03:49.134 --> 00:03:50.410
Let's take a look at this.

76
00:03:51.740 --> 00:03:55.460
You'll notice that there is difference
between Incident Management and

77
00:03:55.460 --> 00:03:58.940
Problem Management because you see
right at the very top the inputs in

78
00:03:58.940 --> 00:04:00.981
the Problem Management are different.

79
00:04:00.981 --> 00:04:04.559
Sure, we're got
the Incident Management coming in.

80
00:04:04.559 --> 00:04:05.275
But look at this.

81
00:04:05.275 --> 00:04:08.470
We've got event management,
we've got the service desk,

82
00:04:08.470 --> 00:04:10.794
we've got proactive Problem Management.

83
00:04:10.794 --> 00:04:14.721
And we've even got some problems
coming from suppliers, or

84
00:04:14.721 --> 00:04:17.494
it mentions contractors in there as well.

85
00:04:17.494 --> 00:04:22.898
You see, anybody can report a potential
problem, absolutely anybody.

86
00:04:22.898 --> 00:04:27.110
Remember these known errors that I
talked about in the last section.

00:18:53.280 --> 00:18:57.970
And It follows the same categorization
as incident management, and

313
00:18:57.970 --> 00:19:00.270
it should also be undertaken and

314
00:19:00.270 --> 00:19:04.850
logged in the same service management
tool as incident management too.

315
00:19:04.850 --> 00:19:10.770
So that we can have those relationships in
place, but ultimately what we are looking

316
00:19:10.770 --> 00:19:16.820
to do, is we're looking to resolve
the root causes of one or more incidents.

317
00:19:16.820 --> 00:19:18.342
Jo, thank you again for

318
00:19:18.342 --> 00:19:23.070
helping us to review this idea of
the process flow in problem management.

319
00:19:23.070 --> 00:19:27.115
It really is going to become helpful as
we continue to develop our skills here in

320
00:19:27.115 --> 00:19:28.465
service operations, and

321
00:19:28.465 --> 00:19:32.288
it is something that we should consider
that it is never going to be ad hoc.

322
00:19:32.288 --> 00:19:37.895
There should be some process to what
we are doing to help us in the ideas,

323
00:19:37.895 --> 00:19:39.865
ideals of ITIL, right?

324
00:19:39.865 --> 00:19:43.680
The efficiency and the effectiveness
of everything that we're doing here.

325
00:19:43.680 --> 00:19:46.730
Well, that's a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

326
00:19:46.730 --> 00:19:50.490
Signing off for ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

327
00:19:50.490 --> 00:19:51.670
>> And I'm Joy.

328
00:19:51.670 --> 00:19:55.016
>> Stay right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation shows.

329
00:19:55.016 --> 00:20:01.812
[MUSIC]

330
00:20:01.812 --> 00:20:09.199
>> Thank you for watching itpro.tv.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue discussing problem management.  This time Jo leads us through the different metrics and relationships that must be considered in problem management.  They discuss the inter-process relationship between configuration, capacity, availability and knowledge management and problem management effectiveness and efficiency.  They also talk about the challenges and risks associated with the problem management process.

34

38

40

41

47
00:02:31.910 --> 00:02:34.040

48
00:02:34.040 --> 00:02:38.100
But we've not found out the root cause,
which is the problem.

49
00:02:38.100 --> 00:02:42.600
And so, we choose to raise a problem,
in that instance.

50
00:02:42.600 --> 00:02:45.700
We choose,
we don't automatically raise a problem.

51
00:02:45.700 --> 00:02:48.320
So, that's a trigger,
that choice is a trigger.

52
00:02:48.320 --> 00:02:51.870
And there are many other trigger's that we
looked at, such as event management, and

53
00:02:51.870 --> 00:02:55.200
even suppliers that can
give us information.

54
00:02:55.200 --> 00:02:56.830
Now, we'd consider them to be triggers,
but

55
00:02:56.830 --> 00:03:00.855
we'd also consider them to be
inputs into problem management.

56
00:03:00.855 --> 00:03:07.020
The problem management also does
a lot of investigation, diagnosis.

57
00:03:07.020 --> 00:03:11.811
Problem management techniques are used
within problem management to identify root

58
00:03:11.811 --> 00:03:12.356
causes.

59
00:03:12.356 --> 00:03:16.306
And a problem management technique
could be something as simple as what we

60
00:03:16.306 --> 00:03:17.610
call a top.

61
00:03:17.610 --> 00:03:19.780
A technical observation post.

62
00:03:19.780 --> 00:03:24.970

wait it out and see what happens.

63
00:03:26.060 --> 00:03:31.770

instances where we've seen failures.

64
00:03:31.770 --> 00:03:37.280
We've seen your laptop, it's locked up,

65
00:03:37.280 --> 00:03:41.140

66
00:03:41.140 --> 00:03:44.630

find out exactly what's going on.

67
00:03:44.630 --> 00:03:46.900
And so that's a technique that we use.

68
00:03:46.900 --> 00:03:50.800
But you see it's, again,
it's an input into problem management

69
00:03:50.800 --> 00:03:55.600
the skills that are required to be
able to undertake those techniques.

70
00:03:55.600 --> 00:03:57.750

72

related incidents as I like to call them.

73
00:04:05.210 --> 00:04:09.987
And we've talked in previous sessions

74
00:04:09.987 --> 00:04:11.407
management and the CMS.

00:04:11.407 --> 00:04:17.050
And that gives us information on our CIs,
our configuration items, okay.

76
00:04:18.100 --> 00:04:20.860
And then we've got the relationship
with incident management.

77
00:04:20.860 --> 00:04:23.830
But because we're all on
one call logging system

78
00:04:23.830 --> 00:04:27.380
we've also got the relationship
with change management as well.

79
00:04:27.380 --> 00:04:31.860
And also with request fulfillment and
event management too.

80
00:04:31.860 --> 00:04:36.240
So all of that is an input
into problem management.

81
00:04:36.240 --> 00:04:40.820
We also take information,
such as the event logs themselves,.

82
00:04:40.820 --> 00:04:43.030
Such as the requirements and

the targets that we have agreed with our
customers in our service level agreements.

84
00:04:49.260 --> 00:04:50.870
We'll take into consideration.

85
00:04:50.870 --> 00:04:54.890
Remember we did in the last section,
a severity assessment, so

86
00:04:54.890 --> 00:04:57.370
we'll take that it consideration too.

87
00:04:57.370 --> 00:05:01.440
So things like budget is

88
00:05:01.440 --> 00:05:05.780
Also, the strategy of the organization and
the strategy of our IT.

89
00:05:05.780 --> 00:05:11.350
That is an input into problem management
along with customer feedback,

90
00:05:11.350 --> 00:05:16.940
along with even risk management too and
hand in hand with availability management,

91
00:05:16.940 --> 00:05:20.770
a process that we look at in

92
00:05:20.770 --> 00:05:25.530

management to identify

00:05:25.530 --> 00:05:30.440

then make decisions hand in hand with

94
00:05:30.440 --> 00:05:35.590

95
00:05:35.590 --> 00:05:38.490
And we'll make those decisions
based on a risk assessment.

96
00:05:39.820 --> 00:05:43.305
Do we actually want to prevent

97
00:05:43.305 --> 00:05:46.570
Do we wanna wear the redundancy
on mirroring, or

98
00:05:46.570 --> 00:05:49.640
do we actually want to just accept
the risk and say, well you know,

99
00:05:49.640 --> 00:05:53.650
you don't know It's probably
not going to happen.

100
00:05:53.650 --> 00:05:55.650
So let's not worry about it.

101
00:05:55.650 --> 00:05:56.565
Okay?

102
00:05:56.565 --> 00:06:00.145
And then of course what comes

00:06:00.145 --> 00:06:04.410
you'd like to think resolve problems

104
00:06:04.410 --> 00:06:06.250
But you know what?

105
00:06:06.250 --> 00:06:07.355
We don't always want to resolve a problem.

106
00:06:07.355 --> 00:06:10.890
And we looked at them in more
depths in the last section.

107
00:06:10.890 --> 00:06:14.270
So it's not always resolved problems,
it could be closed problems.

108
00:06:14.270 --> 00:06:19.295

we've made a definite decision

109
00:06:19.295 --> 00:06:22.865
to close that problem and

110
00:06:22.865 --> 00:06:26.365
And maybe that decision may
be documented in the SLA.

111
00:06:26.365 --> 00:06:27.155
Who knows?

112
00:06:27.155 --> 00:06:29.505
But it would certainly
be part of strategy.

113
00:06:29.505 --> 00:06:33.196
And we would have somebody that would

114
00:06:33.196 --> 00:06:37.576
Now known an error records come
out of problem management too and

of course they're used by
incident management in order

116
00:06:41.389 --> 00:06:45.367
to resolve incidents to restore services.

00:06:45.367 --> 00:06:47.747
And then improvement opportunities.

00:06:47.747 --> 00:06:52.877
I would expect to see that as an output

119
00:06:52.877 --> 00:06:58.530

120
00:06:58.530 --> 00:07:04.950
ways, sorry in the plural that we can

121
00:07:04.950 --> 00:07:09.270
It's all about delivering
value to our organization.

122
00:07:09.270 --> 00:07:13.930
We want to facilitate the outcomes
that they need in order to

123
00:07:13.930 --> 00:07:16.978

124
00:07:16.978 --> 00:07:23.980

00:07:23.980 --> 00:07:27.350

00:07:27.350 --> 00:07:29.190
service level agreement and

00:07:53.348 --> 00:07:55.641

00:07:58.854 --> 00:08:03.530
Now configuration management provides

00:08:03.530 --> 00:08:06.770

So some components of services are shared.

You don't have 15 for

00:08:31.544 --> 00:08:32.917
>> [LAUGH]
>> To be honest.

146
00:08:32.917 --> 00:08:35.910
I can barely remember the password for
one nowadays.

147
00:08:36.960 --> 00:08:41.180
So, configuration management not just
gives us the configuration of all our

148
00:08:41.180 --> 00:08:46.180
services and tells us what our CIs are,
it also importantly gives us those

149
00:08:46.180 --> 00:08:50.160

00:08:50.160 --> 00:08:53.560

152

So configuration management really
has to be that sort of accurate and

153
00:09:04.485 --> 00:09:09.479
reliable information that we use
in problem management to get to

154
00:09:09.479 --> 00:09:12.899
the bottom of why things are happening,
and

155
00:09:12.899 --> 00:09:17.540
also then to fix that problem,
to solve the root cause.

156
00:09:17.540 --> 00:09:22.690
So without accurate and reliable

157
00:09:22.690 --> 00:09:24.130
it would be very, very difficult for

158
00:09:24.130 --> 00:09:30.100
us to effectively undertake problem
management, very difficult.

159
00:09:30.100 --> 00:09:35.740
So configuration management has a role

160
00:09:35.740 --> 00:09:41.502
We also have a role, and that role is to

161
00:09:41.502 --> 00:09:46.290
So if we see inaccuracies than

162
00:09:46.290 --> 00:09:51.110
If we have made changes, if we've

00:09:51.110 --> 00:09:54.470
then we have to make sure

164
00:09:54.470 --> 00:09:56.660

165
00:09:58.258 --> 00:10:02.137
Now I mentioned availability
management and availability and

166

167
00:10:06.391 --> 00:10:09.217
They sit within the service
design life cycle process.

168
00:10:09.217 --> 00:10:12.365
And they're both split
into both proactive and

169
00:10:12.365 --> 00:10:15.745
reactive, very similar to
problem management, actually.

170
00:10:15.745 --> 00:10:17.555
And now these are processes.

171
00:10:17.555 --> 00:10:23.250
And what I'd like you to understand is
really a process is a set of activities.

172
00:10:23.250 --> 00:10:28.843
Now I can perform more than
one process at any one time.

173
00:10:28.843 --> 00:10:31.630
Well all right I could
when I was in my 20s,

174
00:10:31.630 --> 00:10:33.215
I don't supposed I'm that good at it now.

175
00:10:33.215 --> 00:10:37.624
[LAUGH] But I can perform more than
one process in any point in time so

176
00:10:37.624 --> 00:10:42.622
the person that's performing
proactive problem management could

177
00:10:42.622 --> 00:10:47.182
also be performing proactive
availability management, and

178
00:10:47.182 --> 00:10:49.741
proactive capacity management.

179
00:10:49.741 --> 00:10:54.180
You see, availability
management is about identifying

180
00:10:54.180 --> 00:10:58.064
potential points of failure and
then planning for

181
00:10:58.064 --> 00:11:03.400
what we are going to do about
those potential points of failure.

182
00:11:03.400 --> 00:11:06.330
That's the proactive side
of availability management.

183
00:11:06.330 --> 00:11:11.455
And capacity management from a proactive
perspective is about identify

184
00:11:11.455 --> 00:11:17.430
a capacity requirements and preventing
breeches to those capacity requirements.

185
00:11:17.430 --> 00:11:19.760
So preventing capacity failures, okay.

186
00:11:20.940 --> 00:11:25.599
These are the proactive sides
of those particular processes.

187
00:11:25.599 --> 00:11:30.233
So, when proactive problem management
is looking at preventing failure and

188
00:11:30.233 --> 00:11:32.942
preventing incidents, well guess what, so

189
00:11:32.942 --> 00:11:36.598
is capacity management and so
is availability management.

190
00:11:36.598 --> 00:11:41.950
So they work hand in hand together
to prevent interruption to service.

191
00:11:41.950 --> 00:11:46.215
That level of service that's outlined
in the service level agreement.

192
00:11:46.215 --> 00:11:50.224
Now, all three of these processes
have reactive elements too,

193
00:11:50.224 --> 00:11:55.410
and problem management has a reactive
element, reacting to incidents.

194
00:11:55.410 --> 00:11:59.645
And part of the objectives
of both capacity and

195
00:11:59.645 --> 00:12:05.943
availability management is also to
help with problem management and

196
00:12:05.943 --> 00:12:10.627
with incident management
in resolving problems.

197
00:12:10.627 --> 00:12:14.293
And also restoring service
to ensure that we maintain

198
00:12:14.293 --> 00:12:19.080
those levels of service that
had been agreed in the SLA.

199
00:12:19.080 --> 00:12:24.430
So capacity and availability management
work hand in hand with problem management

200
00:12:24.430 --> 00:12:26.130
and with incident management too.

201
00:12:27.470 --> 00:12:30.270
And that brings us around
then to knowledge management.

202
00:12:30.270 --> 00:12:34.965
Now, I mentioned in a previous section
that knowledge management was about

203
00:12:34.965 --> 00:12:36.000
having wisdom.

204
00:12:37.340 --> 00:12:40.308
I've also mentioned in a previous module

205
00:12:40.308 --> 00:12:45.155
about the fact you thought we were
in IT and we like pretty pictures.

206
00:12:45.155 --> 00:12:47.220
And we like to produce reports.

207
00:12:47.220 --> 00:12:51.950
And sometimes it feels like, they're just
reports for the sake of having reports.

208
00:12:51.950 --> 00:12:54.940
A graph just because we feel
like we should have one.

209
00:12:54.940 --> 00:12:57.100
That nobody really looks at.

210
00:12:58.590 --> 00:13:02.950
Well, knowledge management is about
insuring that we have got the right

211
00:13:02.950 --> 00:13:09.300
information available, at the right
time to enable informed decision making.

212
00:13:09.300 --> 00:13:12.610
Now problem management does trend

00:27:01.600 --> 00:27:05.204
If problem management is not efficient,
if problem management is not effective,

449
00:27:05.204 --> 00:27:07.571
because say for instance,
we don't have the skills,

450
00:27:07.571 --> 00:27:10.270
then we're going to
have a problem backlog.

451
00:27:10.270 --> 00:27:12.670
We're gonna have a backlog
in the number of problems.

452
00:27:12.670 --> 00:27:14.450
And we don't want that, obviously.

453
00:27:14.450 --> 00:27:17.999
We want to demonstrate that we can
deliver value to the business.

454
00:27:19.140 --> 00:27:22.710
So it's very,
very important that we understand

455
00:27:22.710 --> 00:27:26.490
what skills are needed to
perform problem management.

456
00:27:26.490 --> 00:27:31.685
And so we also have to consider the staff
in numbers as well as the skills.

457
00:27:31.685 --> 00:27:35.846
But we also have to consider
the decisions that we have to make.

458
00:27:35.846 --> 00:27:38.973
I've seen many organizations, and I mean,

459
00:27:38.973 --> 00:27:42.759
thousands of organizations
that I've been into, and

460
00:27:42.759 --> 00:27:47.959
I consulted where I see problem records
sit in there for years in the queue.

461
00:27:49.300 --> 00:27:53.420
And I ask why they do that, and they
will often tell me, well you know what,

462
00:27:53.420 --> 00:27:57.015
we don't want to resolve the problem,
so we've left the problem open.

463
00:27:57.015 --> 00:27:58.492
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well,

464
00:27:58.492 --> 00:28:02.309
if you don't want to resolve the problem
that's fine, and you document that you

465
00:28:02.309 --> 00:28:06.740
don't want to resolve the problem, and
communicate that with the organization.

466
00:28:06.740 --> 00:28:10.040
And if it's in the SLA that
at this point in time,

467
00:28:10.040 --> 00:28:15.990
we've decided that service is going to be
retired, then we can close that problem.

468
00:28:15.990 --> 00:28:17.400
We don't have to keep it open.

469
00:28:18.430 --> 00:28:22.040
But, it has to be documented, and

470
00:28:22.040 --> 00:28:25.138
it has to be agreed with the business
that that's what we're going to do.

471
00:28:25.138 --> 00:28:29.830
>> All right Jo, well, thank you again for
helping us out here when we start

472
00:28:29.830 --> 00:28:34.130
taking look at the idea of some of these
metrics that we've been talking about.

473
00:28:34.130 --> 00:28:38.597
And remember that in this episode, we did
take a look at some of the inner process

474
00:28:38.597 --> 00:28:42.274
relationships as well as the critical
success factors and KPIs.

475
00:28:42.274 --> 00:28:45.393
And lastly, right here we talked
about some of the challenges and

476
00:28:45.393 --> 00:28:49.363
risks associated with what we're actually
gonna be seeing that really do help us to

477
00:28:49.363 --> 00:28:53.450
make sure that we understand, what is
at stake if we don't manage this well.

478
00:28:53.450 --> 00:28:55.030
Now, Jo, you have something else to say?

479
00:28:55.030 --> 00:28:59.620
>> Yeah, and I just wanted to add that I
do really recommend that what we do right

480
00:28:59.620 --> 00:29:03.019
now is take a look at the notes
that you've downloaded.

481
00:29:03.019 --> 00:29:07.594
There is a lot more information in
the notes in regards to problem management

482
00:29:07.594 --> 00:29:13.210
techniques, and that's something that you
will need to do some further research on.

483
00:29:13.210 --> 00:29:17.580
And also in regards to the relationship
between all over processes and

484
00:29:17.580 --> 00:29:22.650
relationships between all that talk,
so we allocate at least an hour.

485
00:29:22.650 --> 00:29:25.660
We would tell you that,
that's what you should be doing for

486
00:29:25.660 --> 00:29:30.240
your next hour or at least on appropriate
time, take a look through the notes.

487
00:29:30.240 --> 00:29:34.810
And if you do have any questions about any
of the problem management techniques, or

488
00:29:34.810 --> 00:29:38.810
about any of the relationships at all,
then we have the forum.

489
00:29:38.810 --> 00:29:43.089
And that's exactly why I'm here, to help
you navigate your way through those notes.

490
00:29:44.130 --> 00:29:45.220
All right, Joe, well thank you.

491
00:29:45.220 --> 00:29:48.510
It's a great reminder as we
continue on our study towards

492
00:29:48.510 --> 00:29:51.670
the idea of everything that
we want to learn about ITIL.

493
00:29:51.670 --> 00:29:54.950
But it's also a great place for
us to end this episode then.

494
00:29:54.950 --> 00:29:59.405
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

495
00:29:59.405 --> 00:30:01.210
>> And I've been Jo Peacock.

496
00:30:01.210 --> 00:30:05.969
>> Stay tuned right here for
more ITIL Service Operation shows.

497
00:30:05.969 --> 00:30:11.852
[MUSIC]

498
00:30:11.852 --> 00:30:15.135
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo talk about  equest fulfillment.  Jo leads us through the idea of request fulfillment and identifies that users seek either a service or knowledge in request fulfillment.  Unlike an incident, which causes service interruption, according to Jo, a request fulfillment will provide a consistent and standardized service through the policies that are in place to guide how a company manages this request fulfillment.
episodes.title: Request Fulfillment
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.718
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.718 --> 00:00:06.422
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.422 --> 00:00:08.272
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.272 --> 00:00:12.105
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.105 --> 00:00:14.981
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.981 --> 00:00:19.050
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Operation show.

7
00:00:19.050 --> 00:00:24.120
I'm you host Ronnie Wong and today,
we're diving into request fulfillment.

8
00:00:24.120 --> 00:00:28.830
And here to help us out is gonna be
our very own Dumbledore of ITIL.

9
00:00:28.830 --> 00:00:30.999
>> [LAUGH]
>> Ms. Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:30.999 --> 00:00:32.724
Jo, welcome back to the show.

11
00:00:32.724 --> 00:00:37.950
>> Wow, well what can I say to that
other than do I need to grow the beard?

12
00:00:37.950 --> 00:00:39.074
>> No, you do?

13
00:00:39.074 --> 00:00:40.262
>> Okay then, well that's fine.

14
00:00:40.262 --> 00:00:41.740
Cuz I think I might so-
>> I told you,

15
00:00:41.740 --> 00:00:43.850
you'd find out what I was saying here.

16
00:00:43.850 --> 00:00:48.870
So Jo, in the realm of request
fulfillment as we get started,

17
00:00:49.890 --> 00:00:56.100
for someone outside of ITIL, like I am,
I'm not really jumped into it fully.

18
00:00:56.100 --> 00:00:57.800
It sounds like fulfilling a wish list.

19
00:00:57.800 --> 00:00:58.875
Is that what we're talking about?

20
00:00:58.875 --> 00:00:59.667
>> Absolutely not.

21
00:00:59.667 --> 00:01:00.560
>> Okay.
[LAUGH]

22
00:01:00.560 --> 00:01:02.500
>> Absolutely not.

23
00:01:02.500 --> 00:01:06.795
The one thing that I can tell you is that,
unlike Harry Potter-

24
00:01:06.795 --> 00:01:07.432
>> [LAUGH]

25
00:01:07.432 --> 00:01:09.590
>> [LAUGH] Not everyone gets their wishes

26
00:01:09.590 --> 00:01:12.170
fulfilled, and I don't have a magic wand.

27
00:01:12.170 --> 00:01:12.960
>> Aw, well.

28
00:01:12.960 --> 00:01:13.800
>> I wish I did.

29
00:01:13.800 --> 00:01:18.300
[LAUGH] No, we don't give everybody
everything that they want.

30
00:01:18.300 --> 00:01:24.809
And so, actually request fulfillment,
you could think about it as a misnomer or

31
00:01:24.809 --> 00:01:30.648
you could think about it as just slightly,
I wouldn't say misleading,

32
00:01:30.648 --> 00:01:34.982
but misconstrued sometimes
by some organizations.

33
00:01:34.982 --> 00:01:37.804
Because it's not about
fulfilling requests,

34
00:01:37.804 --> 00:01:40.490
it's actually about dealing with request.

35
00:01:40.490 --> 00:01:43.022
>> Okay.
>> And actually, that's the word used in

36
00:01:43.022 --> 00:01:46.510
the autopublication is
the word dealing with request.

37
00:01:46.510 --> 00:01:51.220
We like to transposed that into managing
request and it's about handling and

38
00:01:51.220 --> 00:01:56.233
managing request but it's about dealing
with request and sometimes, we say no.

39
00:01:56.233 --> 00:01:59.310
>> Okay, so
where are we gonna begin today?

40
00:01:59.310 --> 00:02:02.100
>> Right, well we're just gonna
look at the principles really

41
00:02:02.100 --> 00:02:03.930
of request fulfillment.

42
00:02:03.930 --> 00:02:08.560
And just look at the process itself and
what request fulfillment strives to do and

43
00:02:08.560 --> 00:02:10.823
the policies, and objectives, etc.

44
00:02:10.823 --> 00:02:14.290
And then, we're going to get a little
bit further in another session.

45
00:02:14.290 --> 00:02:17.591
We're going to delve into
the actual process itself.

46
00:02:17.591 --> 00:02:21.371
>> All right, so let's go and start with
what we see right here on the screen,

47
00:02:21.371 --> 00:02:24.270
what do we take again in
terms of the purpose?

48
00:02:24.270 --> 00:02:26.732
>> All right, well,
as I've already told you,

49
00:02:26.732 --> 00:02:31.104
the purpose of request fulfillment is
actually to deal with requests from users.

50
00:02:31.104 --> 00:02:37.121
And it provides a common,
consistent method for

51
00:02:37.121 --> 00:02:41.830
users to request things from IT.

52
00:02:41.830 --> 00:02:44.360
Now, I say things and
that sounds really ambiguous and

53
00:02:44.360 --> 00:02:46.730
it probably sounds like
a really clumsy word.

54
00:02:46.730 --> 00:02:52.581
But I like to summarize request
fulfillment into two types of requests.

55
00:02:52.581 --> 00:02:54.740
Okay, we have two types
of requests from users.

56
00:02:54.740 --> 00:02:59.650
We have the, can I have something and
the call you tell me something?

57
00:02:59.650 --> 00:03:04.420
So can I have is all about
standard components of a service.

58
00:03:04.420 --> 00:03:06.690
So, can I have a new laptop, please?

59
00:03:06.690 --> 00:03:10.893
Could I have access to
a particular service, please?

60
00:03:10.893 --> 00:03:13.140
So could I have something?

61
00:03:13.140 --> 00:03:16.660
And then, can you tell me something
as a request for information.

62
00:03:16.660 --> 00:03:21.255
They're both requests, so can you tell me
how to add two cells together in Excel,

63
00:03:21.255 --> 00:03:22.130
for instance.

64
00:03:22.130 --> 00:03:24.780
Or can you tell me whether
the service desk is going to be

65
00:03:24.780 --> 00:03:26.230
available over the weekend?

66
00:03:27.700 --> 00:03:29.695
So two different types of requests.

67
00:03:29.695 --> 00:03:32.099
So those bullet points in the objectives,

68
00:03:32.099 --> 00:03:35.924
you'll see that they can be split
into can I have and can you tell me.

69
00:03:35.924 --> 00:03:40.380
So providing a channel for users to
request standard services such as can

70
00:03:40.380 --> 00:03:44.189
I have a new laptop or
can I have access, can I have something.

71
00:03:44.189 --> 00:03:48.380
Providing information to users
about service availability is can

72
00:03:48.380 --> 00:03:49.885
you tell me something.

73
00:03:49.885 --> 00:03:54.080
Sourcing and
delivering elements of requested services.

74
00:03:54.080 --> 00:03:55.560
Can I have something?

75
00:03:55.560 --> 00:04:00.382
And again, general information,
complaints, comments, can you tell me?

76
00:04:00.382 --> 00:04:06.430
So there are two elements there are no,
there isn't a clear definition.

77
00:04:06.430 --> 00:04:11.710
But anything that really falls into
the realms of can I have something or

78
00:04:11.710 --> 00:04:15.590
can you tell me something is
part of request fulfillment.

79
00:04:17.240 --> 00:04:21.840
Now, and this is where, there is a little
bit of ambiguity there because that

80
00:04:21.840 --> 00:04:23.800
third bullet point under scope.

81
00:04:23.800 --> 00:04:27.660
It says can be dealt with by a separate
team or a separate management tool.

82
00:04:29.010 --> 00:04:32.830
We would like, we would prefer for

83
00:04:32.830 --> 00:04:36.860
the sake of efficiency and for
effectiveness and for the relationships,

84
00:04:36.860 --> 00:04:40.680
we would prefer that it's dealt with
within the same service management tool.

85
00:04:41.740 --> 00:04:46.834
We would also recommend
that request fulfillment is

86
00:04:46.834 --> 00:04:53.443
managed as a separate process and
not part of incident management.

87
00:04:55.539 --> 00:05:00.080
In a previous module, we looked at
incident management process flow.

88
00:05:00.080 --> 00:05:05.934
And in that particular module, as you
looked at the incident management process,

89
00:05:05.934 --> 00:05:10.281
probably along the second step,
maybe second or third step of

90
00:05:10.281 --> 00:05:15.398
the incident management process,
we actually filtered the incident.

91
00:05:15.398 --> 00:05:16.877
And we made that decision.

92
00:05:16.877 --> 00:05:18.967
Was it a request or was it an incident?

93
00:05:18.967 --> 00:05:23.525
And we said, if it's a request,
then it should be handled differently.

94
00:05:23.525 --> 00:05:28.812
Now, some organizations will choose to
manage requests as part of incident

95
00:05:28.812 --> 00:05:34.690
management using exactly the same tool and
exactly the same module within the tool.

96
00:05:34.690 --> 00:05:39.787
That can make, it can,
not necessarily does, but that can make it

97
00:05:39.787 --> 00:05:45.636
very difficult to differentiate between
requests and between incidents.

98
00:05:45.636 --> 00:05:50.408
And of course, a request is, can I
have something whereas an incident is

99
00:05:50.408 --> 00:05:55.115
an interruption to a service or
a reduction in the quality of a service.

100
00:05:55.115 --> 00:05:59.545
So from the user perspective, an incident
is something that's gone wrong.

101
00:05:59.545 --> 00:06:03.040
Whereas a request is
something that they want.

102
00:06:03.040 --> 00:06:06.105
So you can manage it as
a type of incident and

103
00:06:06.105 --> 00:06:09.570
just simply have it as a category
within incident management.

104
00:06:09.570 --> 00:06:14.400
But we would recommend that it's
managed as a separate process itself.

105
00:06:16.560 --> 00:06:21.044
What we want to achieve, again with
focus on efficiency and effectiveness

106
00:06:21.044 --> 00:06:26.026
with Request Fulfillment, and what we want
to achieve is actually a consistent and

107
00:06:26.026 --> 00:06:28.249
standard way of managing requests.

108
00:06:28.249 --> 00:06:33.484
And Request Fulfilment is quite
often triggered and managed up and

109
00:06:33.484 --> 00:06:39.012
to a point, by the end user interface
to the service management tool.

110
00:06:39.012 --> 00:06:43.247
Now, I mentioned in a previous
episode that we have different

111
00:06:43.247 --> 00:06:46.343
interfaces into service
management tool and

112
00:06:46.343 --> 00:06:50.823
we'll sometimes have uses that
will log request on incidents and

113
00:06:50.823 --> 00:06:55.558
problems directly using the front-end
interface to the Internet.

114
00:06:55.558 --> 00:07:00.132
But sometimes, nowadays, these service
management tools, they collapse.

115
00:07:00.132 --> 00:07:03.879
You can do it via text message,
you can log a request via email,

116
00:07:03.879 --> 00:07:08.191
you can do it via an app on your cell
phone that allows you to log a request or

117
00:07:08.191 --> 00:07:10.130
to log an incident or a problem.

118
00:07:11.420 --> 00:07:16.358
The idea is that first bullet point is the
one that we really want to achieve which

119
00:07:16.358 --> 00:07:18.948
is quick access to request fulfillment.

120
00:07:18.948 --> 00:07:24.223
And therefore, quick access to standard
services and quick access to information.

121
00:07:24.223 --> 00:07:27.517
So already,
I started talking about information.

122
00:07:27.517 --> 00:07:30.117
So that process of knowledge
management is going to really,

123
00:07:30.117 --> 00:07:32.247
really help us with this too.

124
00:07:32.247 --> 00:07:36.797
Also, problem management could help us
with this with some known errors and

125
00:07:36.797 --> 00:07:37.944
some FAQs as well.

126
00:07:37.944 --> 00:07:41.546
So we do have interfaces
into those other processes.

127
00:07:41.546 --> 00:07:42.656
Don't get me wrong.

128
00:07:42.656 --> 00:07:45.758
Request fulfillment is not stand alone.

129
00:07:45.758 --> 00:07:49.301
But if we have that consistency,
if we have process models,

130
00:07:49.301 --> 00:07:53.261
those pretty fine sets of steps that
we looked at in both incident and

131
00:07:53.261 --> 00:07:57.020
in problem management,
then we should have less bureaucracy.

132
00:07:57.020 --> 00:08:04.283
We should have greater efficiency,
while still maintaining the control.

133
00:08:04.283 --> 00:08:09.120
So, really a request fulfillment
needs to have policies.

134
00:08:10.750 --> 00:08:14.920
We need to have some
form of decision making

135
00:08:14.920 --> 00:08:19.150
that says whether a request can be
granted, or whether it can't be granted.

136
00:08:21.350 --> 00:08:24.780
That applies to both elements
of request fulfillment.

137
00:08:24.780 --> 00:08:28.550
If I call the service desk and I speak
to you Ronnie, and I call you up and

138
00:08:28.550 --> 00:08:33.380
I say can I have a new laptop please,
are you gonna say yes to me straight away?

139
00:08:34.610 --> 00:08:35.460
>> Probably not,

140
00:08:35.460 --> 00:08:37.000
it would probably depend on guidelines,
>> [LAUGH]

141
00:08:37.000 --> 00:08:38.612
>> More than likely, whether or

142
00:08:38.612 --> 00:08:39.980
not you're gonna get a new laptop or not.

143
00:08:39.980 --> 00:08:42.640
>> So it wouldn't depend on
whether you liked me or not?

144
00:08:42.640 --> 00:08:46.585
>> Well, not for a job, no [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Right, so we have to have

145
00:08:46.585 --> 00:08:52.354
a policy in place that says whether I
should be allowed a new laptop or not.

146
00:08:52.354 --> 00:08:57.149
Okay, so what about if I called you up and
I said, okay then,

147
00:08:57.149 --> 00:09:01.661
could you tell me how to add in
a new cost type into to say SAP

148
00:09:01.661 --> 00:09:07.620
a financial management program,
would you help me with that?

149
00:09:07.620 --> 00:09:11.190
>> Yes,
if I actually had the ability to do so and

150
00:09:11.190 --> 00:09:13.570
that was part of my job I probably would.

151
00:09:13.570 --> 00:09:14.780
>> Right.

152
00:09:14.780 --> 00:09:17.774
But you didn't check whether I
should have had access to SAP.

153
00:09:17.774 --> 00:09:20.128
>> That is correct.
>> And whether I should actually have

154
00:09:20.128 --> 00:09:22.350
access to that information.

155
00:09:22.350 --> 00:09:23.350
>> Right, I did not.

156
00:09:23.350 --> 00:09:27.480
>> So, access to information, and I make
that point deliberately because access to

157
00:09:27.480 --> 00:09:32.450
information is not just about
giving access to that information.

158
00:09:32.450 --> 00:09:35.640
We also have to check whether a person
actually should have access to that

159
00:09:35.640 --> 00:09:36.520
information.

160
00:09:36.520 --> 00:09:39.690
Now I'm not telling you that everything
should be on a need to know basis and

161
00:09:39.690 --> 00:09:42.610
we should be really really
secretive with our information,

162
00:09:42.610 --> 00:09:45.380
because that's not the case at all.

163
00:09:45.380 --> 00:09:49.790
But it's the same as when we move
into the Access Management Module.

164
00:09:49.790 --> 00:09:56.040
We'll look at people having access
to certain services but perhaps they

165
00:09:56.040 --> 00:10:00.670
don't have the relevant security clearance
or authorization to have access to.

166
00:10:00.670 --> 00:10:02.690
And it's the same with our information.

167
00:10:02.690 --> 00:10:05.650
Obviously in certain organizations, and

168
00:10:05.650 --> 00:10:09.300
we better remind that ITIL came
from a government background,

169
00:10:09.300 --> 00:10:15.055
certain information is classified or
has a classification ranking and

170
00:10:15.055 --> 00:10:18.940
that relates to or
applies to whatever the organization is.

171
00:10:18.940 --> 00:10:21.824
So sometimes we don't always want
to give out that information and

172
00:10:21.824 --> 00:10:24.572
the same way that we don't always
want to give out that laptop.

173
00:10:24.572 --> 00:10:26.832
It's not always approved.

174
00:10:26.832 --> 00:10:29.507
So we will have policies in place,

175
00:10:29.507 --> 00:10:33.488
most definitely for
every single type of request.

176
00:10:33.488 --> 00:10:36.574
And that last bullet point
under the policies and

177
00:10:36.574 --> 00:10:41.200
principles there refers to
the authorization considerations, okay.

178
00:10:41.200 --> 00:10:43.880
So, I just wanna take you
through those bullet points

179
00:10:43.880 --> 00:10:47.700
there on the left hand side and
the third one down that's really

180
00:10:47.700 --> 00:10:52.470
sort of not self-explanatory is that
connection to a standard change.

181
00:10:53.780 --> 00:10:57.940
Change management is covered in the
service transition life cycle phase, so

182
00:10:57.940 --> 00:11:00.370
we're not gonna spend a lot
of time talking about that.

183
00:11:00.370 --> 00:11:03.700
But a standard change is a request for

184
00:11:03.700 --> 00:11:09.060
change that has been preauthorized
by change management because it has

185
00:11:09.060 --> 00:11:13.080
an acceptable level of impact
to the IT infrastructure.

186
00:11:14.250 --> 00:11:16.570
So the first time we see
this particular change, or

187
00:11:16.570 --> 00:11:19.780
the first time somebody has asked for
something, we're going to go through

188
00:11:19.780 --> 00:11:24.720
a change process which looks at
the risk to the IT infrastructure.

189
00:11:24.720 --> 00:11:28.940
And then the second time we see that,
change management may turn around and say,

190
00:11:28.940 --> 00:11:32.650
I don't need to see that type of change
anymore, I'm really not interested in it.

191
00:11:32.650 --> 00:11:35.137
It's got an acceptable level of change, so

192
00:11:35.137 --> 00:11:38.711
therefore I'm gonna let request
fulfillment deal with that.

193
00:11:38.711 --> 00:11:44.527
I'm gonna go back to this laptop again,
and if I ask for a new laptop, the first

194
00:11:44.527 --> 00:11:49.902
time I ask for a new laptop, I expect
if it's a brand new model of laptop,

195
00:11:49.902 --> 00:11:55.368
I expect change management to be involved
because I expect them to do a risk

196
00:11:55.368 --> 00:12:01.960
evaluation on whether that laptop is
providing a danger to the infrastructure.

197
00:12:01.960 --> 00:12:05.370
Is that laptop going to cause
impact to the infrastructure

198
00:12:05.370 --> 00:12:06.680
in a negative way, okay.

199
00:12:07.690 --> 00:12:09.585
So the first time that happens then,

200
00:12:09.585 --> 00:12:13.260
I'm expecting change
management to get involved.

201
00:12:13.260 --> 00:12:18.490
But then the next time somebody ask for
that exact model of laptop, well,

202
00:12:18.490 --> 00:12:22.530
the risk evaluation's been done, and
it has an acceptable level of risk.

203
00:12:22.530 --> 00:12:27.285
So we pre-authorize it, it is now
what we call a standard change, and

204
00:12:27.285 --> 00:12:31.050
we allow request fulfillment to manage it.

205
00:12:31.050 --> 00:12:35.193
Now, that doesn't override
the authorization considerations in there,

206
00:12:35.193 --> 00:12:38.502
because I still need to have
authorization for that laptop.

207
00:12:38.502 --> 00:12:41.335
>> Right
>> But it's still an expenditure, but

208
00:12:41.335 --> 00:12:46.340
what I'm talking about here is
the impact to the IT infrastructure.

209
00:12:46.340 --> 00:12:47.660
That's what I'm referring to.

210
00:12:49.130 --> 00:12:52.612
So let's take a look then at these bullet
points on the right-hand side, then.

211
00:12:52.612 --> 00:12:57.010
And we look at the principles and
the concepts of request fulfillment.

212
00:12:57.010 --> 00:12:59.980
Now, if you look at some of
the wording on those bullet points,

213
00:12:59.980 --> 00:13:05.090
you see status tracking and
prioritization and escalation and

214
00:13:05.090 --> 00:13:08.660
approvals and closure and
fulfillment activities.

215
00:13:08.660 --> 00:13:13.505
You know what, this process looks very
similar to the incident management process

216
00:13:13.505 --> 00:13:15.485
and the problem management process.

217
00:13:15.485 --> 00:13:18.515
And that's one of
the reasons why we do them,

218
00:13:19.585 --> 00:13:23.325
sorry that's one of the reasons why
it may be combined with incident

219
00:13:23.325 --> 00:13:27.025
management because if you look at some
of the steps they look fairly similar.

220
00:13:28.195 --> 00:13:30.315
But let's think about this logically.

221
00:13:30.315 --> 00:13:32.185
All request have to be prioritized.

222
00:13:33.660 --> 00:13:38.410
If I ask for a new laptop, should I get
it tomorrow or should I get it next week?

223
00:13:39.670 --> 00:13:41.540
Well, it depends on the impact.

224
00:13:41.540 --> 00:13:45.891
If I don't have a laptop and
it's causing an impact to the business,

225
00:13:45.891 --> 00:13:48.077
then I probably need it tomorrow.

226
00:13:48.077 --> 00:13:51.477
But if actually, I have a laptop
already and I just want to upgrade,

227
00:13:51.477 --> 00:13:55.420
then it could probably wait until
next week or even next month.

228
00:13:55.420 --> 00:14:00.380
So there has to be prioritization,
but there also has to be,

229
00:14:00.380 --> 00:14:05.030
guess what, it'll always links
to the service level agreement.

230
00:14:05.030 --> 00:14:10.940
We have to have targets defined in
our service level agreement for

231
00:14:10.940 --> 00:14:11.991
request fulfillment.

232
00:14:11.991 --> 00:14:16.320
And those targets should not only
include prioritization table,

233
00:14:16.320 --> 00:14:20.560
the same type of prioritization table
that appears in incident management and

234
00:14:20.560 --> 00:14:27.530
appears in problem management, but
it should also include the time scales.

235
00:14:27.530 --> 00:14:32.010
Now the time scales aren't just about
fulfilling a request, the time scales

236
00:14:32.010 --> 00:14:37.570
are also about rejecting a request too,
because sometimes we say no.

237
00:14:39.070 --> 00:14:43.317
So we still have to come back within
an agreed amount of time to say no, okay.

238
00:14:44.540 --> 00:14:47.607
We don't just say yes all the time
as we've already established, okay.

239
00:14:49.410 --> 00:14:53.910
So again, very similar to the other
processes that we looked at within service

240
00:14:53.910 --> 00:15:00.460
operation, I am expecting to
see models for these processes.

241
00:15:00.460 --> 00:15:05.430
Okay, we'll give you an example of
a process, and there will be one coming

242
00:15:05.430 --> 00:15:10.380
up in the next module in a couple
of slides time in your notes.

243
00:15:11.460 --> 00:15:16.990
But, it's up to you to decide what
your request process looks like and

244
00:15:16.990 --> 00:15:21.140
what the models look like because every
single organization has a different

245
00:15:21.140 --> 00:15:21.919
set of requests.

246
00:15:22.970 --> 00:15:25.470
What we will tell you is,
that really you should try and

247
00:15:25.470 --> 00:15:28.320
utilize self help systems
wherever you can.

248
00:15:28.320 --> 00:15:32.988
So or you should for
the sake of efficiency and effectiveness,

249
00:15:32.988 --> 00:15:36.069
utilize those apps on your cell phone, or

250
00:15:36.069 --> 00:15:39.695
the internet linking to
that call login system.

251
00:15:39.695 --> 00:15:42.615
And you know what,
that link in to the call login

252
00:15:42.615 --> 00:15:47.437
system can also be used to allow users to
track the status of their own request.

253
00:15:47.437 --> 00:15:52.055
And it's not just about the service desk
managing those requests, it's also about

254
00:15:52.055 --> 00:15:56.107
users being able to track what's
happening with their requests, okay.

255
00:15:57.360 --> 00:16:01.380
So as we've already said, Very,
very similar to incident management.

256
00:16:01.380 --> 00:16:02.915
We prioritize requests,

257
00:16:02.915 --> 00:16:08.120
and I expect to see prioritization
table in our service level agreement.

258
00:16:08.120 --> 00:16:13.039
We can escalate requests, if I feel I'm
not getting my laptop quick enough,

259
00:16:13.039 --> 00:16:17.749
then I'm gonna want to escalate that,
cuz I'm a very impatient person.

260
00:16:17.749 --> 00:16:18.755
>> Okay [LAUGH].

261
00:16:18.755 --> 00:16:21.123
>> Well,
I'm used to having that long cape and

262
00:16:21.123 --> 00:16:24.333
that magic wand that I can just wave and
have it there again.

263
00:16:24.333 --> 00:16:28.364
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm an impatient person, so

264
00:16:28.364 --> 00:16:30.034
I need to escalate.

265
00:16:30.034 --> 00:16:32.900
We don't just escalate if things
aren't happening quick enough.

266
00:16:32.900 --> 00:16:36.040
We might escalate if we don't
get the result that we want.

267
00:16:36.040 --> 00:16:39.284
Let's just say I opted for
a particular model of laptop,

268
00:16:39.284 --> 00:16:41.455
because I really, really like that.

269
00:16:41.455 --> 00:16:45.216
And some people have an affiliation
with a certain brand, and

270
00:16:45.216 --> 00:16:50.890
if that's the brand I wanted, and you came
to me and said, you're not having that.

271
00:16:50.890 --> 00:16:54.778
Well, there may be a business
justification for me asking for

272
00:16:54.778 --> 00:16:56.959
that particular device or model.

273
00:16:56.959 --> 00:17:01.894
In which case, then, I may need to
escalate that, because it's not in

274
00:17:01.894 --> 00:17:07.674
the request fulfillment policies to grant
me that, but I may have justification.

275
00:17:07.674 --> 00:17:12.131
So there needs to be some form of
escalation, and there needs to be some

276
00:17:12.131 --> 00:17:16.513
form of authorization,
sometimes by way of financial approval, or

277
00:17:16.513 --> 00:17:20.615
maybe HR approval, or
maybe just business requirements.

278
00:17:20.615 --> 00:17:26.020
If I need a particular device
because it's going to facilitate

279
00:17:26.020 --> 00:17:31.320
me achieving my business outcome, well,
that's the definition of a service.

280
00:17:31.320 --> 00:17:35.283
And therefore that's exactly
what I want to achieve, so

281
00:17:35.283 --> 00:17:37.438
you should allow me to do that.

282
00:17:37.438 --> 00:17:41.817
>> All right, Jo, before you move on here,
on the previous slide that we looked at,

283
00:17:41.817 --> 00:17:45.757
there was an unusual word that I saw
right here, under request tracking.

284
00:17:45.757 --> 00:17:49.280
We'll actually take a look at
the whole thing here for a moment.

285
00:17:49.280 --> 00:17:54.355
What is the difference, I see this
unusual word that says rejected and

286
00:17:54.355 --> 00:17:59.612
canceled, you've gotta explain
the differences between that for me.

287
00:17:59.612 --> 00:18:02.450
If I have a request in, and
it's rejected or it's canceled,

288
00:18:02.450 --> 00:18:06.017
what is the real difference here, in
the way that you're taking a look at it?

289
00:18:06.017 --> 00:18:09.403
>> Well, if you have a request in and
I reject it, and I say,

290
00:18:09.403 --> 00:18:14.590
no, I'm sorry, but I just don't authorize
that at all, then that's rejected.

291
00:18:14.590 --> 00:18:18.712
But you might submit a request,
and then you may cancel it, so

292
00:18:18.712 --> 00:18:20.626
you might change your mind.

293
00:18:20.626 --> 00:18:23.475
Maybe you've decided you wanted something
bigger and better, [LAUGH] it can happen.

294
00:18:23.475 --> 00:18:28.693
>> [LAUGH] All right, thank you.

295
00:18:28.693 --> 00:18:34.584
>> So let's just carry on then with those
basic concepts of request fulfillment.

296
00:18:34.584 --> 00:18:39.053
And we talk about automation in there,
now, I mentioned that event management is

297
00:18:39.053 --> 00:18:41.728
the only process that
could be fully automated.

298
00:18:41.728 --> 00:18:47.080
Well, we probably are going to have some
sort of automation in request fulfillment.

299
00:18:47.080 --> 00:18:54.028
Then we might have automation in ways of
answering the, can you tell me something.

300
00:18:54.028 --> 00:18:58.212
If I was a user,
how impressed would I feel as a user, and

301
00:18:58.212 --> 00:19:02.039
how much value would I feel,
if I was able to get onto

302
00:19:02.039 --> 00:19:06.990
that self-help interface and
I was able to type in something.

303
00:19:06.990 --> 00:19:10.378
Some little web search engine that said,
how do I do this?

304
00:19:10.378 --> 00:19:13.921
And it took me to all of the knowledge
management documents that told me how

305
00:19:13.921 --> 00:19:14.500
to do that.

306
00:19:15.680 --> 00:19:18.010
It would save me having to
call up the service desk,

307
00:19:18.010 --> 00:19:22.130
and save me having to raise a request,
and save me having to perhaps

308
00:19:22.130 --> 00:19:26.500
wait in a call queuing system to
be able to get to that answer.

309
00:19:26.500 --> 00:19:29.010
It might be just a very,
very simple answer as well.

310
00:19:30.310 --> 00:19:34.116
So we talk about automation,
but it really does work,

311
00:19:34.116 --> 00:19:36.945
we can also automate approvals as well.

312
00:19:38.598 --> 00:19:43.757
You see, it's not unusual for a call
center manager, now I don't say that it is

313
00:19:43.757 --> 00:19:49.365
usual, I just said it's not unusual, for
a call center manager to pre-authorize.

314
00:19:49.365 --> 00:19:53.446
It's perfectly acceptable for
a call center manager to say,

315
00:19:53.446 --> 00:19:58.715
I allow any of my team to spend,
let's say, up to 500 pounds, or $700.

316
00:19:58.715 --> 00:20:01.720
And anything above that,
then I want to know about.

317
00:20:02.720 --> 00:20:08.020
Not unusual for that at all, so we may
chose to automate, then, that request.

318
00:20:08.020 --> 00:20:12.923
Does it really need to be seen by
a service desk analyst, no, of course not.

319
00:20:12.923 --> 00:20:17.522
If the call center manager has logged
onto the call login system, and

320
00:20:17.522 --> 00:20:20.080
has pre-authorized up to $700.

321
00:20:20.080 --> 00:20:26.257
Well, then if I log in, then, and ask for
a new laptop and it's less than $700,

322
00:20:26.257 --> 00:20:31.129
it's straight away going to go
towards the fulfillment team, for

323
00:20:31.129 --> 00:20:34.885
them to fulfill that request,
so we can automate.

324
00:20:34.885 --> 00:20:38.265
Now, obviously we can't automate
the fulfilling of the actual laptop,

325
00:20:38.265 --> 00:20:41.230
because let's face it,
we still gotta get the laptop in.

326
00:20:41.230 --> 00:20:43.602
It's still got to have a build put on it,
and

327
00:20:43.602 --> 00:20:47.455
I know that we're into drone
technology and everything nowadays, but

328
00:20:47.455 --> 00:20:50.105
it's not going to just
suddenly land on my desk.

329
00:20:50.105 --> 00:20:53.289
Not yet, give it a couple of years and
then it may well happen.

330
00:20:53.289 --> 00:20:58.945
[LAUGH] We may have to forward some
requests to specialist groups.

331
00:20:58.945 --> 00:21:01.350
And I talk about the example
I just gave you,

332
00:21:01.350 --> 00:21:05.700
desktop support groups that will
actually perform builds on the laptops.

333
00:21:05.700 --> 00:21:09.817
But also specialist groups in terms of
knowledge as well, because, you know what.

334
00:21:09.817 --> 00:21:14.722
I don't expect the service desk analyst to
have access to all of the knowledge, or

335
00:21:14.722 --> 00:21:19.010
to be able to answer some of
the more complicated questions.

336
00:21:19.010 --> 00:21:23.510
Certainly, if I was on a service desk,
and you called me and

337
00:21:23.510 --> 00:21:29.363
asked me how to add a new I'd pretty
much be at a loss, to be honest.

338
00:21:29.363 --> 00:21:33.456
One thing that I do want to point out,
and this applies to incident management,

339
00:21:33.456 --> 00:21:37.690
as well as request fulfillment, is the
service desk has taken ownership of this.

340
00:21:37.690 --> 00:21:41.850
So the service desk will
close the requests,

341
00:21:41.850 --> 00:21:46.370
on condition that the user is
satisfied with that request.

342
00:21:47.570 --> 00:21:52.750
The only exception to this is
cancellations, as we just mentioned.

343
00:21:52.750 --> 00:21:59.520
And also requests that have been
generated through the self-help facility,

344
00:21:59.520 --> 00:22:02.920
and that have been responded to
through the self help facility.

345
00:22:02.920 --> 00:22:06.954
In other words, I've logged
onto the self-help facility and

346
00:22:06.954 --> 00:22:09.985
I've typed in my question,
how do I do this?

347
00:22:09.985 --> 00:22:14.500
It's taken me to an article, and
actually, I've found my answer.

348
00:22:14.500 --> 00:22:18.324
In that case, though, I'm still expecting
to see some sort of response from this

349
00:22:18.324 --> 00:22:22.420
self-help facility that says,
did you get the answer to your question?

350
00:22:23.620 --> 00:22:29.440
That goes into that, usage can be
measured there, why do I need to do that?

351
00:22:29.440 --> 00:22:32.910
Well, I want to see that information
because I want to be able to identify

352
00:22:32.910 --> 00:22:33.964
training needs.

353
00:22:33.964 --> 00:22:39.810
Cuz if five people have accessed
that particular help document,

354
00:22:39.810 --> 00:22:44.280
if five people have gone in within
the last, say, two or three hours and

355
00:22:44.280 --> 00:22:49.670
asked how to add a cost center into,
or cost type, into SAP.

356
00:22:49.670 --> 00:22:53.874
Then maybe we've got a training
requirement in the user community,

357
00:22:53.874 --> 00:22:58.235
so I still want access to that,
I still want to perform trend analysis.

358
00:22:58.235 --> 00:23:00.665
Because it does identify training needs,
and

359
00:23:00.665 --> 00:23:03.540
it identifies where we're
getting common requests.

360
00:23:03.540 --> 00:23:06.913
And maybe it'll help us be more
efficient in the future, so

361
00:23:06.913 --> 00:23:10.490
that's part of continual
service improvement.

362
00:23:10.490 --> 00:23:15.070
Now, in the next section,
what I'd like us to do is,

363
00:23:15.070 --> 00:23:18.180
we'll go over the request
fulfillment process floor.

364
00:23:18.180 --> 00:23:23.810
And in that particular section,
we will look at the actual process,

365
00:23:23.810 --> 00:23:29.000
how we may choose to define our models,
and the authorization process too.

366
00:23:29.000 --> 00:23:34.776
But for the moment, what I would like
you to do is to refer to your notes and

367
00:23:34.776 --> 00:23:40.203
take a look at the exercises that
are in your downloaded materials.

368
00:23:40.203 --> 00:23:45.894
And just review the policies and
the guidelines for request fulfillment.

369
00:23:45.894 --> 00:23:47.770
>> All right, Jo, well, thank you again.

370
00:23:47.770 --> 00:23:50.730
When taking a look at the idea
of request fulfillment,

371
00:23:50.730 --> 00:23:54.330
remember that this is not
saying yes to everything.

372
00:23:54.330 --> 00:23:57.400
It is about how we handle
these requests that come in.

373
00:23:57.400 --> 00:24:00.607
Take a look at the examples and
the material that's provided for you.

374
00:24:00.607 --> 00:24:05.475
That will help to cement these concepts
into your mind as you are continuing

375
00:24:05.475 --> 00:24:06.797
in all things ITIL.

376
00:24:06.797 --> 00:24:09.826
Well, that's a great place for
us to also end this episode, then.

377
00:24:09.826 --> 00:24:13.176
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

378
00:24:13.176 --> 00:24:14.676
>> And I've been Dumbledore.

379
00:24:14.676 --> 00:24:18.901
>> Stay tuned right here for
more ITIL service operation shows.

380
00:24:18.901 --> 00:24:26.277
[MUSIC]

381
00:24:26.277 --> 00:24:28.851
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo examine the Request Fulfillment Process Flow. Jo starts from the beginning with understanding the triggers and takes us through the closure.  She emphasizes the ideal of the framework as being the important part of the process flow rather than the individual components.  The goal is to make a process flow that meet your organizational needs and provides a better value to you, says Jo.
