Yeah, perfect or spot on as I was saying,
yup absolutely right.

236
00:13:36.070 --> 00:13:38.960
And we do exactly the same
with request fulfillment,

237
00:13:38.960 --> 00:13:44.050
we will prioritize based on impact
to the organization and priority.

238
00:13:44.050 --> 00:13:48.240
Now I know I touched on the subject in
the previous session, but the impact to

239
00:13:48.240 --> 00:13:53.610
the organization really is, what will the
impact be to the business of this request

240
00:13:53.610 --> 00:13:58.520
not being fulfilled, or
not being managed in a timely manner?

241
00:13:59.640 --> 00:14:03.450
And then the urgency of course
is how quickly do we want it?

242
00:14:03.450 --> 00:14:07.720
And of course,
the definition of each individual

243
00:14:07.720 --> 00:14:12.430
priority will be found in
the service level agreement.

244
00:14:12.430 --> 00:14:15.700
That's what we've agreed
with our customers.

245
00:14:15.700 --> 00:14:20.301
But not only will a definition
be found in the SLA also a time

246
00:14:20.301 --> 00:14:25.580
scale targets will be found in
the SLA too for fulfillment or

247
00:14:25.580 --> 00:14:29.620
rejection of that request,
cuz again, we don't always fulfill.

248
00:14:31.180 --> 00:14:34.230
So at this point in time
once we've prioritized,

249
00:14:34.230 --> 00:14:37.920
we make sure that we have got
the relevant authorization.

250
00:14:38.940 --> 00:14:42.959
Now it's split into two here, but it
actually can be split into more than this.

251
00:14:44.110 --> 00:14:48.010
Split in two, I'm gonna start with
financial management there,because I

252
00:14:48.010 --> 00:14:53.710
already mentioned that request fulfillment
in the previous session is about

253
00:14:53.710 --> 00:14:58.610
accessing standard components
of a service such as,

254
00:14:58.610 --> 00:15:02.420
say a new laptop or a printer,
a standard component.

255
00:15:02.420 --> 00:15:05.990
Now we will need financial
authorization for that.

256
00:15:05.990 --> 00:15:11.120
I also mentioned in a previous session
that it is possible that, that financial

257
00:15:11.120 --> 00:15:16.800
information, or sorry, that financial
authorization can be given in advance.

258
00:15:16.800 --> 00:15:21.835
So the call center manager could
authorize a prebudget of say,

259
00:15:21.835 --> 00:15:26.588
$700 I think was the example
I used in the last session.

260
00:15:26.588 --> 00:15:31.892
So they could say, well look,
anybody in my team could spend

261
00:15:31.892 --> 00:15:37.305
up to $700 without me having
to authorize it separately.

262
00:15:37.305 --> 00:15:42.109
And that would be something
that we would input into our

263
00:15:42.109 --> 00:15:45.770
models within the request process flow.

264
00:15:45.770 --> 00:15:50.101
Another authorization that it
mentions there is access management.

265
00:15:50.101 --> 00:15:54.733
Because another typical request
that we get in is the request for

266
00:15:54.733 --> 00:15:57.410
access to a certain service, okay.

267
00:15:58.630 --> 00:16:02.020
And, again, that would have to
go through access management,

268
00:16:02.020 --> 00:16:06.190
which is another process we will
be covering in a different module.

269
00:16:06.190 --> 00:16:10.895
Or it will also have to go,
perhaps, to IT security management,

270
00:16:10.895 --> 00:16:14.754
which is a process to be
found in ITIL service design.

271
00:16:14.754 --> 00:16:21.150
And IT security management will
set the policies for access.

272
00:16:21.150 --> 00:16:24.272
Who can have access to
what particular service?

273
00:16:24.272 --> 00:16:29.310
Remember that example that I gave you
about me asking for information for SAP.

274
00:16:29.310 --> 00:16:31.637
If I'm not allowed to have access to SAP,

275
00:16:31.637 --> 00:16:35.236
should I be allowed to have access
to the information, as well?

276
00:16:35.236 --> 00:16:35.986
No, no.

277
00:16:35.986 --> 00:16:40.078
>> Right, okay, so
if I call the service desk and asked for

278
00:16:40.078 --> 00:16:43.050
access to SAP, then I should be denied.

279
00:16:43.050 --> 00:16:43.571
>> Mm-hm.

280
00:16:43.571 --> 00:16:44.877
>> Yeah, okay.

281
00:16:44.877 --> 00:16:50.026
So this is what happens then at the start
of the request fulfillment process flow.

282
00:16:50.026 --> 00:16:54.911
And the next slide really just
reinforces everything that I have

283
00:16:54.911 --> 00:16:59.983
mentioned about prioritization and
also about categorization.

284
00:16:59.983 --> 00:17:04.555
And, again, we'd use, because we're
logging in the same management tool as

285
00:17:04.555 --> 00:17:07.354
incident and
problem management, we're going

286
00:17:07.354 --> 00:17:12.510
to use the same type of categorization as
we do for incident and problem management.

287
00:17:12.510 --> 00:17:16.069
Just bearing in mind
that these are requests.

288
00:17:17.130 --> 00:17:20.830
So they could be functional requests,
they could be standard changes.

289
00:17:20.830 --> 00:17:23.900
So we could choose to categorize by type,

290
00:17:23.900 --> 00:17:27.560
which is something that we wouldn't
find in incident and problem management.

291
00:17:28.700 --> 00:17:33.490
So let's just assume that in the last
stage on the previous process flow was

292
00:17:33.490 --> 00:17:35.400
request an authorization.

293
00:17:35.400 --> 00:17:39.300
Let's just assume, then, that
authorization has either been given or

294
00:17:39.300 --> 00:17:40.050
it's been denied.

295
00:17:40.050 --> 00:17:41.230
And if it's been denied,

296
00:17:41.230 --> 00:17:45.750
then we go back to the requester
to inform them of the decision.

297
00:17:45.750 --> 00:17:51.130
If it's been authorized, then we review
the request just to make sure that we

298
00:17:51.130 --> 00:17:55.460
are giving that person, that requester,

299
00:17:55.460 --> 00:17:59.899
the right information, or that we're
giving them the right component.

300
00:18:01.310 --> 00:18:04.460
And at this point in time,
that's when we route the request

301
00:18:04.460 --> 00:18:08.310
to the person who's actually
going to fulfill the request.

302
00:18:09.350 --> 00:18:14.040
So we route it to, say, the second
level support team, or maybe our

303
00:18:14.040 --> 00:18:18.350
desktop support guys, because they're
going to deliver that brand new laptop.

304
00:18:18.350 --> 00:18:19.500
And we may need to escalate.

305
00:18:20.740 --> 00:18:25.897
We'd need to escalate functionally
to another support team.

306
00:18:25.897 --> 00:18:30.351
Or we may need to escalate hierarchically,
for instance,

307
00:18:30.351 --> 00:18:33.387
if we need something expedited, okay.

308
00:18:33.387 --> 00:18:36.240
And, of course, escalation,
I use those two words,

309
00:18:36.240 --> 00:18:39.600
those two exact same words,
in incident management, as well.

310
00:18:41.390 --> 00:18:43.210
So now we need to consider, then,

311
00:18:43.210 --> 00:18:47.840
once it's been given to the relevant
team to fulfill the request,

312
00:18:47.840 --> 00:18:53.070
we need to consider whether any
configuration items have been impacted.

313
00:18:54.780 --> 00:18:57.030
Now, if you remember from incident and

314
00:18:57.030 --> 00:19:02.050
from problem management, I told you
that this configuration management

315
00:19:02.050 --> 00:19:06.720
database was the foundation to
all of our other processes.

316
00:19:07.980 --> 00:19:11.870
But the configuration management system,
and the configuration management system

317
00:19:11.870 --> 00:19:16.610
database, is needed to
provide accurate and

318
00:19:16.610 --> 00:19:20.530
reliable information to support
all of those other processes.

319
00:19:20.530 --> 00:19:23.850
So the one thing that we have to make
sure that we do when we're fulfilling any

320
00:19:23.850 --> 00:19:31.010
request is, if we make a change or
we update any CI information,

321
00:19:31.010 --> 00:19:36.200
then it has to be reflected in
the configuration management system.

322
00:19:36.200 --> 00:19:40.900
So if I'm giving you a new laptop, which
I may well do because you've asked for

323
00:19:40.900 --> 00:19:45.570
it and it's gonna cost less than $700, so
I'm gonna give you a new one, well, I need

324
00:19:45.570 --> 00:19:49.700
to make sure that I update the information
in our configuration management system.

325
00:19:50.840 --> 00:19:55.530
So that if you get a problem or you have
an incident with that laptop at any point

326
00:19:55.530 --> 00:19:58.390
in time,
when you call the service desk and

327
00:19:58.390 --> 00:20:02.860
you give them your name, then they've
immediately got all of the relevant

328
00:20:02.860 --> 00:20:07.410
information right in front of them
in that service management system.

329
00:20:07.410 --> 00:20:09.680
It also helps with change management, too,

330
00:20:09.680 --> 00:20:15.280
because if I want to swap out a router
in this particular room here,

331
00:20:15.280 --> 00:20:19.305
I need to know who is using
what equipment on that router.

332
00:20:19.305 --> 00:20:23.010
And I have to have that
accurate information, okay.

333
00:20:24.160 --> 00:20:25.800
So at this point in time, then,

334
00:20:25.800 --> 00:20:29.650
we ascertain whether any
CIs are being impacted.

335
00:20:29.650 --> 00:20:34.200
And if there isn't any CIs impacted,
then we fulfill the request and

336
00:20:34.200 --> 00:20:38.000
we let the requester know
that it's been fulfilled.

337
00:20:38.000 --> 00:20:39.020
Well, they usually see.

338
00:20:39.020 --> 00:20:43.690
I mean, let's face it, you know when a new
laptop lands on your desk, right, okay.

339
00:20:43.690 --> 00:20:46.360
If it needs to be referred
to change management,

340
00:20:46.360 --> 00:20:49.200
then we would escalate
to change management.

341
00:20:49.200 --> 00:20:52.320
And then the next step there is to close.

342
00:20:52.320 --> 00:20:55.740
Now, you'll notice that there is
a link to financial management

343
00:20:55.740 --> 00:20:57.940
when we close that request.

344
00:20:57.940 --> 00:21:02.155
And that is to let financial management
know that we've spent the money, yeah.

345
00:21:02.155 --> 00:21:06.350
It's no good just spending money,
especially if its been pre-authorized.

346
00:21:06.350 --> 00:21:09.390
We can't just spend money and
then not tell anybody we spent money.

347
00:21:09.390 --> 00:21:11.680
Otherwise, how do we can keep
an eye on our budgets and

348
00:21:11.680 --> 00:21:14.920
our accounting if we don't tell
people how much money we've spent?

349
00:21:15.920 --> 00:21:16.927
I mean, sure,

350
00:21:16.927 --> 00:21:21.748
this cost center manager might have
authorized any spend up to $ 700.

351
00:21:21.748 --> 00:21:25.081
And if that's just one laptop,
then that's $700.

352
00:21:25.081 --> 00:21:28.881
But if there are ten people in his team
and they've all asked for a new laptop,

353
00:21:28.881 --> 00:21:30.358
then that's $7,000.

354
00:21:30.358 --> 00:21:30.875
>> Right.

355
00:21:30.875 --> 00:21:34.660
>> Right, so we need to make sure
that we can account for that money.

356
00:21:34.660 --> 00:21:38.480
So we ensure we let
financial management know.

357
00:21:38.480 --> 00:21:42.920
And the other thing that we do as part
of closure is it's the service desk's

358
00:21:42.920 --> 00:21:48.360
responsibility to ensure that
we check with the requestor,

359
00:21:48.360 --> 00:21:51.050
the person that's asked for that request.

360
00:21:51.050 --> 00:21:54.240
That we've delivered what they expected.

361
00:21:54.240 --> 00:21:58.540
And that they're happy cuz ultimately what
we want to do is deliver value to them.

362
00:21:59.880 --> 00:22:03.910
We would undertake this whether
it's a request for information or

363
00:22:03.910 --> 00:22:06.370
whether it's a request for a new laptop.

364
00:22:06.370 --> 00:22:09.210
If you've asked for a new laptop,
I'm going to come back to you and

365
00:22:09.210 --> 00:22:12.735
I'm going to say to you, are you happy
with that laptop that you've got?

366
00:22:12.735 --> 00:22:16.060
I've fulfilled your request,
are you happy?

367
00:22:16.060 --> 00:22:19.870
But if you've asked me for information,
I'm also going to come back to you and

368
00:22:19.870 --> 00:22:22.910
I'm going to say, okay,
are you happy with the answer I gave you?

369
00:22:22.910 --> 00:22:25.050
Does that answer your question?

370
00:22:25.050 --> 00:22:29.810
And it's just that confirmation that
the user is indeed happy, the requester is

371
00:22:29.810 --> 00:22:35.000
happy, and
that we can close that record knowing that

372
00:22:35.000 --> 00:22:39.060
it doesn't need to be reopened because we
haven't actually fulfilled that request.

373
00:22:40.190 --> 00:22:46.200
So in a nutshell, that is
the request management process flow.

374
00:22:46.200 --> 00:22:50.310
What I can tell you, and what I want to
reinforce, really, cuz I already mentioned

375
00:22:50.310 --> 00:22:56.060
this at the start of the session, is that
this process flow is just an example.

376
00:22:56.060 --> 00:23:01.353
And, really, it is up to you to adapt the
framework that we give you in ITIL, and

377
00:23:01.353 --> 00:23:06.760
to ensure that you are aligned to
the needs of your organization,

378
00:23:06.760 --> 00:23:10.300
and that the process that you form for

379
00:23:10.300 --> 00:23:15.710
your organization meets the need and
delivers value.

380
00:23:15.710 --> 00:23:19.304
What we don't want to do is to hinder.

381
00:23:19.304 --> 00:23:23.472
And that is something that, quite often,
is seen within request fulfillment,

382
00:23:23.472 --> 00:23:27.414
is that there's a perception there
that this is just another bureaucracy.

383
00:23:27.414 --> 00:23:32.326
And it's just gonna get in the way when
all I wanna do is I just wanna buy

384
00:23:32.326 --> 00:23:33.350
a new laptop.

385
00:23:33.350 --> 00:23:36.830
I just wanna add a new component
to the infrastructure.

386
00:23:36.830 --> 00:23:40.360
Or I just want some information,
why do I have to go in and log it?

387
00:23:41.790 --> 00:23:46.940
If request fulfillment has been
configured to be efficient,

388
00:23:46.940 --> 00:23:51.930
then the user will never ever notice
that requests have been logged.

389
00:23:51.930 --> 00:23:53.910
Bureaucracy will not exist.

390
00:23:53.910 --> 00:23:59.150
And they will not be aware of what it
is that we're doing in the background.

391
00:23:59.150 --> 00:24:05.810
But we can give them the assurance that if
they've got any questions to do with that

392
00:24:05.810 --> 00:24:10.090
request that we are tracking that request,
and that we can answer them straight away.

393
00:24:11.310 --> 00:24:15.881
>> Jo, I agree, the idea of understanding
the formalization of request fulfillment

394
00:24:15.881 --> 00:24:19.879
is something that may be difficult for
a new organization starting out.

395
00:24:19.879 --> 00:24:23.790
Because a lot of times, especially
when startups, small startups happen,

396
00:24:23.790 --> 00:24:25.130
they just purchase.

397
00:24:25.130 --> 00:24:26.476
>> Yep.
>> And then they get used

398
00:24:26.476 --> 00:24:29.350
to that idea of if I need it,
I need to buy it.

399
00:24:29.350 --> 00:24:33.190
And as organizations continue to grow,
they've got to realize that

400
00:24:33.190 --> 00:24:37.140
putting this process in place gives them
the checks and balances that they need

401
00:24:37.140 --> 00:24:40.450
to be able to operate more efficiently
as well as more effectively.

402
00:24:40.450 --> 00:24:43.090
So this flow, and this process
flow that we're talking about,

403
00:24:43.090 --> 00:24:45.640
is really something that is
essential to our organization.

404
00:24:45.640 --> 00:24:51.000
Now, Jo, do we actually have to think
about some other materials, as well?

405
00:24:51.000 --> 00:24:55.370
Do we have an assignment with this
particular show that we're doing?

406
00:24:56.390 --> 00:24:59.770
>> We don't have a direct assignment
with this particular show.

407
00:24:59.770 --> 00:25:03.795
Obviously, as with all of the modules,
you do have corresponding notes.

408
00:25:03.795 --> 00:25:08.110
And we always recommend that
you review those notes.

409
00:25:08.110 --> 00:25:11.220
At the end of the next assignment,
in the next.

410
00:25:11.220 --> 00:25:13.280
Sorry, at the end of the next session,

411
00:25:13.280 --> 00:25:16.590
which is where we look at
relationships and we look at metrics,

412
00:25:16.590 --> 00:25:20.598
there is an assignment which will take
approximately an hour to undertake.

413
00:25:20.598 --> 00:25:25.462
And so, yes I'll be directing you to that
[LAUGH] at the end of the next assignment,

414
00:25:25.462 --> 00:25:26.389
without fail.

415
00:25:26.389 --> 00:25:30.853
>> [LAUGH] All right Jo, well, thank you
again for helping us to understand this

416
00:25:30.853 --> 00:25:35.020
nature of request fulfillment
process flow a little bit better.

417
00:25:35.020 --> 00:25:38.350
And that is a great place for
us to also sign off for this episode.

418
00:25:38.350 --> 00:25:41.490
For ITProTV, I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

419
00:25:41.490 --> 00:25:42.610
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

420
00:25:42.610 --> 00:25:47.114
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation shows.

421
00:25:47.114 --> 00:25:53.691
[MUSIC]

422
00:25:53.691 --> 00:25:56.838
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo complete the request fulfillment process by discussing the inter-process relationships and metrics of request fulfillment process.   The team discusses the some of the considerations when attempting to create CSFs and determining the KPIs to help.  Jo also emphasizes the importance of the configuration management process to provide the single source of reliable and accurate information.
episodes.title: Request Fulfillment Metrics
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:01.210
Welcome to ITPRO TV.

2
00:00:01.210 --> 00:00:06.519
I am you host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.519 --> 00:00:08.226
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.226 --> 00:00:12.034
>> You are watching ITPRO TV.

5
00:00:12.034 --> 00:00:14.579
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPRO TV.

6
00:00:14.579 --> 00:00:19.410
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Operation show.

7
00:00:19.410 --> 00:00:21.270
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:21.270 --> 00:00:25.240
Today, we're gonna be diving in to
the request for filament matrix.

9
00:00:25.240 --> 00:00:29.050
We're specifically looking at
different types of relationships, and

10
00:00:29.050 --> 00:00:33.550
of course, even matrix that we have to
get under our sleeve here a little bit.

11
00:00:33.550 --> 00:00:38.310
And here to help us out is gonna be
our mastermind in ITIL, Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:38.310 --> 00:00:38.919
Jo, welcome back to the show.

13
00:00:38.919 --> 00:00:39.636
>> Thank you.

14
00:00:39.636 --> 00:00:40.501
How are you, Ronnie?

15
00:00:40.501 --> 00:00:42.500
>> I am doing great, Jo.

16
00:00:42.500 --> 00:00:46.243
As we begin to take a look at some of
these different things that we really have

17
00:00:46.243 --> 00:00:50.687
to cover, the process relationships, I'm
assuming this is what we're talking about,

18
00:00:50.687 --> 00:00:54.079
as well as some of these metrics that
we need to understand to help us to

19
00:00:54.079 --> 00:00:56.674
figure out whether we're
doing well in this or not.

20
00:00:56.674 --> 00:00:58.440
>> Yes.

21
00:00:58.440 --> 00:01:00.580
Like all processes within ITIL,

22
00:01:00.580 --> 00:01:05.210
all of these processes, including
request fulfillment, are intertwined.

23
00:01:06.300 --> 00:01:10.800
And without that relationship between
all of the processes, then quite simply,

24
00:01:10.800 --> 00:01:13.980
we're not able to deliver
value to the business.

25
00:01:13.980 --> 00:01:16.880
Just imagine if everybody
is working in a silo.

26
00:01:16.880 --> 00:01:19.730
When you've got people that
are working independently,

27
00:01:19.730 --> 00:01:22.470
not talking to each other,
there's no efficiency there.

28
00:01:22.470 --> 00:01:25.910
There's no collaboration there,
there's no cooperation.

29
00:01:25.910 --> 00:01:30.510
And the end result is always going
to be a little bit hit-and-miss.

30
00:01:30.510 --> 00:01:33.250
Certainly, it's not
going to be consistent.

31
00:01:33.250 --> 00:01:35.630
So it's exactly the same with processes.

32
00:01:35.630 --> 00:01:39.500
Where you've got processes that
are operating independently, well,

33
00:01:39.500 --> 00:01:41.600
the results are going to be
a little bit hit-and-miss.

34
00:01:41.600 --> 00:01:44.010
There's gonna be no consistency there.

35
00:01:44.010 --> 00:01:47.510
I mean, let's take a look at

00:30:37.100 --> 00:30:42.280
They will manage any
reopening of any request.

495
00:30:42.280 --> 00:30:45.020
Now we'd like to think that we
never ever reopen a request,

496
00:30:45.020 --> 00:30:50.525
because we either give the users what they
ask for, or we've already told them no.

497
00:30:50.525 --> 00:30:54.159
[LAUGH] But,
sometimes we have to reopen a request.

498
00:30:54.159 --> 00:30:57.201
Maybe it's because I asked for
some information and

499
00:30:57.201 --> 00:31:01.771
the information that I gave wasn't quite
right, so I need to ask for it again.

500
00:31:01.771 --> 00:31:06.292
But we should have pretty fine guidelines
for this, cuz otherwise what tends to

501
00:31:06.292 --> 00:31:10.554
happen is that users will call up, and
they'll call up two or three times.

502
00:31:10.554 --> 00:31:13.091
And when we keep reopening
the same request,

503
00:31:13.091 --> 00:31:17.498
then we don't have correlation between
the number of phone calls we've had,

504
00:31:17.498 --> 00:31:20.320
and the number of requests
that have been logged.

505
00:31:21.400 --> 00:31:26.418
So we want to ensure that we have full
information and accurate information,

506
00:31:26.418 --> 00:31:29.906
as to what is actually
happening on our service desk.

507
00:31:29.906 --> 00:31:35.136
So now it's time to look
at your exercise guide,

508
00:31:35.136 --> 00:31:42.291
and the exercise guide in the material
has some self study for you.

509
00:31:42.291 --> 00:31:47.089
Looking at a particular case study,
but I would prefer you to think of

510
00:31:47.089 --> 00:31:53.550
an organization yourselves, and to use
maybe your own organization as an example.

511
00:31:53.550 --> 00:31:57.550
I will give you probably about
60 minutes worth of study time.

512
00:31:57.550 --> 00:32:00.360
I mean feel free to take
longer if you want to.

513
00:32:00.360 --> 00:32:04.700
And we do have the forum available for
you if you do have any questions.

514
00:32:04.700 --> 00:32:06.190
Then please come back to us and

515
00:32:06.190 --> 00:32:10.100
we'll be happy to answer any
questions about your self study, or

516
00:32:10.100 --> 00:32:13.860
about any of the topics that we've covered
so far in this particular session.

517
00:32:14.915 --> 00:32:15.430
>> Alright Jo,

518
00:32:15.430 --> 00:32:20.340
well thank you again for helping us to
understand this process a little bit more.

519
00:32:20.340 --> 00:32:22.050
In terms of understanding whether or

520
00:32:22.050 --> 00:32:26.150
not we're actually fulfilling
requests in a effective and

521
00:32:26.150 --> 00:32:29.890
efficient matter, using of course
those metrics that we've talked about.

522
00:32:29.890 --> 00:32:31.790
These are gonna be very important points.

523
00:32:31.790 --> 00:32:34.600
A lot of times it's easy to
think that we've done something.

524
00:32:34.600 --> 00:32:37.260
Well here's how you prove that
it's actually been working,

525
00:32:37.260 --> 00:32:41.040
is by taking a look at this
particular aspect of these metrics.

526
00:32:41.040 --> 00:32:43.990
Well that's a great place for
us to also sign off for this episode then.

527
00:32:43.990 --> 00:32:46.610
Signing off for ITPro.TV.

528
00:32:46.610 --> 00:32:48.080
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

529
00:32:48.080 --> 00:32:49.360
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

530
00:32:49.360 --> 00:32:52.429
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation Shows.

531
00:32:52.429 --> 00:32:59.495
[MUSIC]

532
00:32:59.495 --> 00:33:01.985
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo introduce the next process Access Management.  Jo describes the principles and shows the process flow for access management.  She relates back the CIA triad principles of Confidentiality, Integrity and Availability.  Also, she describes the metrics use to help us keep our process providing value to the organization.
episodes.title: Access Management Principles and Process Flow
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.028 --> 00:00:00.890
Welcome to IT Pro TV.

2
00:00:00.890 --> 00:00:01.981
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:01.981 --> 00:00:06.362
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.362 --> 00:00:08.224
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.224 --> 00:00:11.653
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.653 --> 00:00:15.270
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.270 --> 00:00:19.820
You are watching ITIL Intermediate
Service Operation show, and

8
00:00:19.820 --> 00:00:21.870
I am your host Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:21.870 --> 00:00:25.790
We're going to be taking a look at another
category right now which is going to be

10
00:00:25.790 --> 00:00:29.480
access management as well as
the process flow to that.

11
00:00:29.480 --> 00:00:35.900
And here to help us of course is going
to be our genius in ITIL, Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:35.900 --> 00:00:37.620
Jo, welcome back to the studio.

13
00:00:37.620 --> 00:00:39.664
>> Thank you, it's good to be here.

14
00:00:39.664 --> 00:00:43.212
>> Jo, as we get started here and
we're now kind of transitioning away

15
00:00:43.212 --> 00:00:45.900
from our last process that
we're taking a look at.

16
00:00:45.900 --> 00:00:50.762
The idea of access management may actually
kind of be a little bit more vague

17
00:00:50.762 --> 00:00:53.520
to those of us that are not in it yet.

18
00:00:53.520 --> 00:00:57.219
So help us out with that and what are we
really going to be taking a look at here?

19
00:00:58.260 --> 00:01:04.275
>> Okay, in assess management we are
really concentrating on what we call CIA.

20
00:01:04.275 --> 00:01:07.650
And I don't mean any sort of
government [LAUGH] enforcement agency.

21
00:01:07.650 --> 00:01:11.795
Of what I actually mean is
the confidentiality, the integrity and

22
00:01:11.795 --> 00:01:13.725
the availability of our data.

23
00:01:13.725 --> 00:01:18.283
>> I'm making sure that we can
ensure the confidentiality and

24
00:01:18.283 --> 00:01:22.932
the integrity, and
also ensure that the data is available to

25
00:01:22.932 --> 00:01:27.141
those who should have access to it,
when they need it.

26
00:01:27.141 --> 00:01:29.828
But only to those that should
have access to it, and

27
00:01:29.828 --> 00:01:33.040
not to those that shouldn't
have access to it.

28
00:01:33.040 --> 00:01:36.360
>> All right, so Jo, in the IT world
when we start talking about this

29
00:01:36.360 --> 00:01:38.760
it really sounds like the beginning and

30
00:01:38.760 --> 00:01:42.380
the underpinnings of the security
principles that we need to have in place.

31
00:01:42.380 --> 00:01:44.210
So is this more about just security?

32
00:01:44.210 --> 00:01:46.305
Is that what we're taking a look at?

33
00:01:46.305 --> 00:01:48.325
>> It's more about enforcing security.

34
00:01:48.325 --> 00:01:52.120
>> Okay, so we have a process
called security management, and

35
00:01:52.120 --> 00:01:55.400
that sits within or
service design life cycle phase.

36
00:01:55.400 --> 00:02:01.250
Now that really is a high level
process where we look at security.

37
00:02:01.250 --> 00:02:06.030
It doesn't go into as much
depth as say ISO 27002, for

38
00:02:06.030 --> 00:02:09.950
instance, which is the international
standard for IT security.

39
00:02:09.950 --> 00:02:15.180
But nevertheless,
it sets the policies for IT security.

40
00:02:15.180 --> 00:02:20.940
So there we are setting the policies for
the type of security level that we need

41
00:02:20.940 --> 00:02:26.392
for our organization and also how
we are going to maintain security.

42
00:02:26.392 --> 00:02:30.880
Here in access management what we
are doing is we are undertaking

43
00:02:30.880 --> 00:02:35.510
the activities that security
management set out.

44
00:02:35.510 --> 00:02:38.607
So in security management,
they design security.

45
00:02:38.607 --> 00:02:43.380
Here, what we do is we give people
access and we take access away.

46
00:02:43.380 --> 00:02:48.282
And it sounds very very simple, but
nevertheless we need a separate

47
00:02:48.282 --> 00:02:52.926
process just to ensure that we
are adhering to the principles and

48
00:02:52.926 --> 00:02:57.313
the policies that have been set
out in security management.

49
00:02:57.313 --> 00:03:01.696
And also in availability management,
too, which again,

50
00:03:01.696 --> 00:03:06.177
is another process within
service design life cycle phase.

51
00:03:06.177 --> 00:03:09.898
Because ultimately,
if security is compromised,

52
00:03:09.898 --> 00:03:14.140
then it effects the availability
of our services.

53
00:03:14.140 --> 00:03:19.120
So availability management and IT security
management will set the policies, and

54
00:03:19.120 --> 00:03:23.630
access management simply gives access and
takes access away.

55
00:03:23.630 --> 00:03:26.860
>> All right, so Jo, help us out with
some of the principles that we're

56
00:03:26.860 --> 00:03:30.860
going to be taking a look at as we go
through the idea of the process here.

57
00:03:30.860 --> 00:03:34.220
>> Well, as you can see on
the first slide, the purpose of

58
00:03:34.220 --> 00:03:39.040
access management is really simple
to provide the rights for users.

59
00:03:39.040 --> 00:03:43.200
So give them access, and
execute the security management policies.

60
00:03:43.200 --> 00:03:47.090
And that also means taking access away.

61
00:03:47.090 --> 00:03:51.310
So we're going to be talking about
things like leavers policy and

62
00:03:51.310 --> 00:03:53.900
a new starters policy, for instance.

63
00:03:53.900 --> 00:03:59.010
When somebody new comes into
the organization, then HR normally

64
00:03:59.010 --> 00:04:03.360
tell us that somebody new is coming, but
then how quickly do we give them access?

65
00:04:03.360 --> 00:04:06.240
Are they subject to any form
of security clearance, or

66
00:04:06.240 --> 00:04:09.170
do we just give them access
straight away on day one?

67
00:04:09.170 --> 00:04:11.850
And what about when somebody
leaves the organization?

68
00:04:11.850 --> 00:04:14.200
How quickly do we rescind that access?

69
00:04:14.200 --> 00:04:15.470
How quickly do we take it away?

70
00:04:16.490 --> 00:04:21.250
Now, I mentioned about how quickly but,
of course, we've got targets for this too.

71
00:04:21.250 --> 00:04:24.384
So the targets for
assigning new user IDs or

72
00:04:24.384 --> 00:04:28.484
maybe somebody's changed a role,
they changed jobs.

73
00:04:28.484 --> 00:04:32.056
They've got a new role and
they need to have their rights and

74
00:04:32.056 --> 00:04:36.145
their privileges updated, so
we'll have targets for all of that.

75
00:04:36.145 --> 00:04:39.803
And they will be found firmly enough
in the service level agreement,

76
00:04:39.803 --> 00:04:42.400
along with all our other
service level targets.

77
00:04:43.570 --> 00:04:48.540
So if once we understand what the targets
are and what the requirements are that

78
00:04:48.540 --> 00:04:52.340
are defined in the service level
agreement, and we understand the policies

79
00:04:52.340 --> 00:04:56.620
that have been set by IT security
management and by availability management.

80
00:04:56.620 --> 00:05:01.970
Then we're able to provide access,
update access, and take access away.

81
00:05:01.970 --> 00:05:05.908
And again,
in that scope there it looks at the CIA,

82
00:05:05.908 --> 00:05:10.408
that confidentiality,
integrity, and availability.

83
00:05:10.408 --> 00:05:14.723
So this is not part of the availability
of the services as a whole, this just

84
00:05:14.723 --> 00:05:20.005
ensures that the services are available to
those that need to have access to them.

85
00:05:20.005 --> 00:05:24.205
And that it's not available to [LAUGH]
those that shouldn't have access, but

86
00:05:24.205 --> 00:05:30.040
also that we are aware that
security is very, very important.

87
00:05:30.040 --> 00:05:33.550
If we give out access to a service
where we shouldn't have done

88
00:05:33.550 --> 00:05:37.070
that could actually the availability for
absolutely everybody.

89
00:05:38.790 --> 00:05:42.204
So the policies are set within security.

90
00:05:42.204 --> 00:05:44.434
And those policies might have
something to do with it.

91
00:05:44.434 --> 00:05:49.459
I mentioned ISO 27002,
we might have Sarbanes-Oxley or

92
00:05:49.459 --> 00:05:54.320
even COBIT, which of course is for
the financial industry.

93
00:05:54.320 --> 00:05:57.360
We may have those policies
that include that,

94
00:05:57.360 --> 00:06:00.710
that have been set by
IT security management.

95
00:06:00.710 --> 00:06:06.150
But here in assess management we
provide a process that can be audited,

96
00:06:06.150 --> 00:06:12.420
so that we can ensure compliance too
Sarbanes-Oxley,COBIT or ISO 27002.

97
00:06:12.420 --> 00:06:17.640
It mentions the hidden business
values about peace of mind.

98
00:06:17.640 --> 00:06:23.350
It's about that security, and not as in
IT security, but about that assurance and

99
00:06:23.350 --> 00:06:29.250
that security that we don't
have any holes in our access.

100
00:06:29.250 --> 00:06:34.590
That only the right people have the right
level of access to do their role and

101
00:06:34.590 --> 00:06:38.425
no one has complete global
access to absolutely everything.

102
00:06:39.575 --> 00:06:45.585
So the access management policy is in
line with the IT security policy and

103
00:06:45.585 --> 00:06:47.805
with availability management.

104
00:06:47.805 --> 00:06:54.130
And really what we want to do is ensure
that we've got all of the ability,

105
00:06:54.130 --> 00:06:56.930
should we say,
to audit everything that happens.

106
00:06:56.930 --> 00:07:01.195
So when access is given it's audited,
when access is taken away it's audited.

107
00:07:01.195 --> 00:07:06.440
Well that means then really we should
be logging requests for access.

108
00:07:06.440 --> 00:07:07.590
So it's a request.

109
00:07:07.590 --> 00:07:16.190
It's part of the request fulfillment log
in within our core management system.

110
00:07:16.190 --> 00:07:22.270
And we log that request and then an access
management process will take over and

111
00:07:22.270 --> 00:07:24.820
grant access and take access away.

112
00:07:24.820 --> 00:07:29.963
And we might use tools, for instance,
like Active Directory, for instance,

113
00:07:29.963 --> 00:07:34.981
to grant privileges and to update
privileges and to update levels of access.

114
00:07:34.981 --> 00:07:38.248
So it's here that we talk
about things like rights, for

115
00:07:38.248 --> 00:07:40.785
instance, the right that our users have.

116
00:07:40.785 --> 00:07:44.708
And when you think about documentation,
you think about updates rights.

117
00:07:44.708 --> 00:07:48.614
You think about whether somebody
has author rights, for instance.

118
00:07:48.614 --> 00:07:52.006
And that's what we're talking about
here in access management, okay?

119
00:07:52.006 --> 00:07:55.870
So generally,
your requests will come in from HR.

120
00:07:55.870 --> 00:07:59.292
But then that really depends on
the security policy we have.

121
00:07:59.292 --> 00:08:00.304
It might come in from HR.

122
00:08:00.304 --> 00:08:05.048
It might come in from a line manager for
instance.

123
00:08:05.048 --> 00:08:07.599
But nevertheless,
just because one person's asked for

124
00:08:07.599 --> 00:08:10.533
something doesn't mean that
they're automatically given it.

125
00:08:10.533 --> 00:08:12.741
Remember request fulfillment, okay?

126
00:08:12.741 --> 00:08:17.009
If I call the service desk and
ask for access to payroll well,

127
00:08:17.009 --> 00:08:18.778
what are they gonna say?

128
00:08:18.778 --> 00:08:19.606
>> No.

129
00:08:19.606 --> 00:08:21.360
>> Well not necessarily.

130
00:08:21.360 --> 00:08:22.360
And that's the thing.

131
00:08:22.360 --> 00:08:25.412
You say yeah,
your first knee jerk reaction would be.

132
00:08:25.412 --> 00:08:27.342
>> Yeah.
>> We're not letting Jo have access

133
00:08:27.342 --> 00:08:27.960
to payroll.

134
00:08:27.960 --> 00:08:29.790
She will set her own salary.

135
00:08:29.790 --> 00:08:31.881
And you're right.

136
00:08:31.881 --> 00:08:36.046
But if I've just changed roles,
and I'm now the HR Director,

137
00:08:36.046 --> 00:08:38.810
then I should have access to payroll.

138
00:08:38.810 --> 00:08:39.850
>> Right.

139
00:08:39.850 --> 00:08:45.400
>> So what Access Management does and
this may well be done on the service desk.

140
00:08:45.400 --> 00:08:51.773
But what Access Management does is they
will do two forms of verification.

141
00:08:51.773 --> 00:08:56.462
So lets say then Ronnie that you
wanted access to payroll okay.

142
00:08:56.462 --> 00:09:00.300
The first thing that I'm going to do is,
I'm going to ask you for

143
00:09:00.300 --> 00:09:03.728
ID because I want to check that
you are who you say you are.

144
00:09:03.728 --> 00:09:07.490
It's not that I don't trust you, but
we're talking about payroll here.

145
00:09:07.490 --> 00:09:09.030
>> Right.
>> You could do some damage.

146
00:09:10.240 --> 00:09:12.490
Well you could do our
accounts some damage, but

147
00:09:12.490 --> 00:09:14.860
you could do your own
bonded count a lot of good.

148
00:09:14.860 --> 00:09:16.130
>> Right.
>> That so,

149
00:09:16.130 --> 00:09:18.280
I'm gonna check that you
are who you say you are.

150
00:09:18.280 --> 00:09:20.110
>> Okay.
>> That's the first thing that I'm going

151
00:09:20.110 --> 00:09:23.670
to do, you could be an impostor,you
could be trying to be Cathy.

152
00:09:24.700 --> 00:09:25.380
>> That's true.

153
00:09:25.380 --> 00:09:26.700
>> Yeah right?

154
00:09:26.700 --> 00:09:31.420
So I'm gonna check that you are who you
say you are and then I'm going to look at

155
00:09:31.420 --> 00:09:37.170
my security policy and I'm going to see
whether you should have access to payroll.

156
00:09:37.170 --> 00:09:37.690
>> Okay.
>> So

157
00:09:37.690 --> 00:09:42.382
there're two types of verification there,
and one is that you are indeed Ronnie, and

158
00:09:42.382 --> 00:09:45.477
the second is that Ronnie
should have access to payroll.

159
00:09:45.477 --> 00:09:50.104
Now of course we have to tie things
in with HR at this point in time,

160
00:09:50.104 --> 00:09:53.135
because HR are the people
that will perform

161
00:09:53.135 --> 00:09:58.145
your transfer over to the payroll
department, to the HR department.

162
00:09:58.145 --> 00:09:58.793
>> Mm-hm.

163
00:09:58.793 --> 00:10:02.645
>> So therefore, they have to tell us,
they have to advise us.

164
00:10:02.645 --> 00:10:06.468
So at least they have to confirm,
that you should have access, and

165
00:10:06.468 --> 00:10:08.268
that you have actually moved.

166
00:10:08.268 --> 00:10:09.377
>> Mm-hm.

167
00:10:09.377 --> 00:10:15.080
>> So I'm, that relationship,
or the relationships

168
00:10:15.080 --> 00:10:19.350
that we have between all of our ITIL
processes, in this particular instance,

169
00:10:19.350 --> 00:10:24.050
extends beyond our ITIL processes and
actually moves in to HR as well.

170
00:10:24.050 --> 00:10:30.035
So the process that we have does
need to have a relationship into HR,

171
00:10:30.035 --> 00:10:33.399
which we may consider external to IT.

172
00:10:33.399 --> 00:10:37.247
But depending on the type
of service provider we are,

173
00:10:37.247 --> 00:10:41.781
we might actually be a shared
services operation, as it were,

174
00:10:41.781 --> 00:10:46.229
a shared services type of service
provider in which case we may

175
00:10:46.229 --> 00:10:51.302
actually be in the same business
unit as HR, that's not impossible.

176
00:10:51.302 --> 00:10:55.354
So what we also need to do,
and it's the last bullet, or

177
00:10:55.354 --> 00:11:00.881
the second from last bullet point there
which talks about communication and

178
00:11:00.881 --> 00:11:04.263
escalation and
handling of security events.

179
00:11:04.263 --> 00:11:11.350
What we also need to do is to report
any attempt to access any services.

180
00:11:11.350 --> 00:11:14.454
That, let's fact it,
they shouldn't be accessing.

181
00:11:14.454 --> 00:11:19.257
So if you are pretending to be Kathy,
and you've come and you've asked for

182
00:11:19.257 --> 00:11:23.009
access to payroll,
then I need to do something with that.

183
00:11:23.009 --> 00:11:24.840
I can't just ignore that.

184
00:11:24.840 --> 00:11:30.082
You could be my best friend in the entire
world, but if you've asked me to do

185
00:11:30.082 --> 00:11:36.093
something that I really shouldn't be doing
just because I have the access to do that.

186
00:11:36.093 --> 00:11:39.299
Then I need to have some form of,
