if we have new profiles,

418
00:25:41.040 --> 00:25:43.528
it has to go through change management.

419
00:25:43.528 --> 00:25:49.670
Service continuity management and
information security management,

420
00:25:49.670 --> 00:25:53.730
well they both have policies for
the continuity of our services.

421
00:25:53.730 --> 00:25:56.620
And very similar to
availability management,

422
00:25:56.620 --> 00:26:01.330
if security is breached then that could
affect the availability of our services.

423
00:26:01.330 --> 00:26:07.970
So we have to ensure that we remember
to include security and continuity.

424
00:26:07.970 --> 00:26:13.150
Because access, giving the wrong access to
the wrong person could affect continuity.

425
00:26:13.150 --> 00:26:16.760
And of course, our service catalog
is our list of our services.

426
00:26:16.760 --> 00:26:21.130
So that will tell us what services
we need to have access control over.

427
00:26:22.750 --> 00:26:25.570
So what about metrics then?

428
00:26:25.570 --> 00:26:27.590
Critical success factors.

429
00:26:27.590 --> 00:26:30.930
We've looked in previous modules
about critical success factors and

430
00:26:30.930 --> 00:26:33.680
what they are, and
it's something that we have to achieve.

431
00:26:33.680 --> 00:26:38.280
And we've mentioned that critical success
factors are generally intangible.

432
00:26:38.280 --> 00:26:42.730
And if you look at the CSFs that we
have here, which is just an example,

433
00:26:42.730 --> 00:26:47.420
we talk about maintaining CIA or
timely communication.

434
00:26:47.420 --> 00:26:52.958
Well you see that the KPIs that talk
about timely all have something to

435
00:26:52.958 --> 00:26:59.760
do with providing access or taking access
away within those service level targets.

436
00:26:59.760 --> 00:27:03.053
They're the ones that
are agreed in our SLAs.

437
00:27:03.053 --> 00:27:06.238
We also have KPIs to deal with CIA, and

438
00:27:06.238 --> 00:27:11.815
those KPIs look at allocation of
inappropriate security access,

439
00:27:11.815 --> 00:27:16.710
where it's been given and
it shouldn't have been given.

440
00:27:18.610 --> 00:27:21.040
The number of audit findings,
for instance,

441
00:27:21.040 --> 00:27:23.020
that have brought up discrepancies.

442
00:27:24.310 --> 00:27:29.710
What about incidents that
are raised to reset passwords?

443
00:27:29.710 --> 00:27:32.380
Now, we mentioned when we
looked at request fulfillment,

444
00:27:32.380 --> 00:27:33.760
we mentioned that dilemma.

445
00:27:33.760 --> 00:27:35.720
Is it an incident, or is it a password?

446
00:27:35.720 --> 00:27:39.330
Because it's an interruption to a service.

447
00:27:39.330 --> 00:27:42.280
So is it an incident, or is it a request?

448
00:27:42.280 --> 00:27:44.990
Well that's down to your policies,
it's to how you define that.

449
00:27:46.040 --> 00:27:51.240
But you see, if we reset
the password too many times for

450
00:27:51.240 --> 00:27:54.320
a particular user,
there's something wrong.

451
00:27:55.800 --> 00:27:58.630
Either there's something wrong
with our security policy that

452
00:27:58.630 --> 00:28:00.090
they can't remember their password.

453
00:28:00.090 --> 00:28:04.350
And sometimes security becomes so
secure it becomes insecure.

454
00:28:04.350 --> 00:28:07.980
You know those security policies
that require an uppercase letter and

455
00:28:07.980 --> 00:28:13.310
a lowercase letter and a special character
and they've gotta be 16 characters long

456
00:28:13.310 --> 00:28:16.690
and you can't have 2 consecutive
characters the same.

457
00:28:16.690 --> 00:28:19.310
And, you've got to have
at least five numbers.

458
00:28:19.310 --> 00:28:21.838
And what's the solution to that?

459
00:28:21.838 --> 00:28:24.200
I know, a post-it note.

460
00:28:24.200 --> 00:28:25.560
That's the solution to that.

461
00:28:25.560 --> 00:28:27.787
You know, the one that get's
stuck on top of the screen.

462
00:28:27.787 --> 00:28:31.873
So we become so secure we become insecure.

463
00:28:31.873 --> 00:28:35.188
If we keep forgetting our passwords,
it's because they are difficult for

464
00:28:35.188 --> 00:28:37.920
us to remember, but
technology will help us with that.

465
00:28:37.920 --> 00:28:40.912
Nowadays we have
fingerprint recognition and

466
00:28:40.912 --> 00:28:45.443
a lot of other things that we cando
instead of remembering a password.

467
00:28:45.443 --> 00:28:49.037
So you see they give off
the opportunity to improve, but

468
00:28:49.037 --> 00:28:54.315
it's access management that provides
security management with the information

469
00:28:54.315 --> 00:28:59.536
on how many incidents there are to do with
say forgotten passwords for instance.

470
00:28:59.536 --> 00:29:04.572
And also security gets wind of
the fact that a lot of passwords

471
00:29:04.572 --> 00:29:09.705
are being reset at a certain time
of day or by a certain person,

472
00:29:09.705 --> 00:29:16.260
then it may be that somebody is requesting
access that they shouldn't have.

473
00:29:16.260 --> 00:29:18.960
Maybe access to someone else's user ID.

474
00:29:18.960 --> 00:29:22.150
Cuz of course, the one thing that we
really don't encourage is the sharing of

475
00:29:22.150 --> 00:29:22.750
user IDs.

476
00:29:24.000 --> 00:29:26.790
So access management then is
all about giving access and

477
00:29:26.790 --> 00:29:29.030
it's all about taking it away.

478
00:29:29.030 --> 00:29:32.710
And the challenge is that we
have to get over are things like

479
00:29:32.710 --> 00:29:35.310
verifying that that person
is who they say they are.

480
00:29:35.310 --> 00:29:40.340
You know, I've known some organizations
where they will actually ask you

481
00:29:40.340 --> 00:29:43.600
to come to the service desk
with your driver's license.

482
00:29:45.020 --> 00:29:48.270
In fact I have worked in
government organizations and

483
00:29:48.270 --> 00:29:54.510
my role is head of IT services for
Her Majesty's Treasury and the OGC.

484
00:29:54.510 --> 00:29:58.610
We had policies in place where you had
to come with your government approved

485
00:29:58.610 --> 00:30:01.390
ID in order to have your password reset

486
00:30:01.390 --> 00:30:06.170
because we needed to ensure that
you are who you said you were.

487
00:30:06.170 --> 00:30:09.740
And irrespective of what your
position was within the country,

488
00:30:09.740 --> 00:30:13.100
we needed to be able to determine
that you were who you said you were.

489
00:30:13.100 --> 00:30:17.550
Cuz giving access away to the wrong
person could be quite catastrophic for

490
00:30:17.550 --> 00:30:20.190
the nation's finances.

491
00:30:20.190 --> 00:30:23.520
So, that is a huge, big challenge to us.

492
00:30:23.520 --> 00:30:26.380
And managing those rights and restricting.

493
00:30:26.380 --> 00:30:31.321
Have you ever to turn around to somebody
and say no, you can't have access?

494
00:30:31.321 --> 00:30:34.470
>> [LAUGH]
>> Have you ever tried to say to a prime

495
00:30:34.470 --> 00:30:38.220
minister, well I'd really need you to come
down to the service desk with your ID

496
00:30:38.220 --> 00:30:40.600
before I reset your password?

497
00:30:40.600 --> 00:30:43.290
It's a challenge [LAUGH].

498
00:30:43.290 --> 00:30:45.460
But, of course,
there are risks associated, too.

499
00:30:45.460 --> 00:30:51.550
And these are things that could help
us fail [LAUGH] with access management.

500
00:30:51.550 --> 00:30:54.530
And not that we ever need
any help in failing, but

501
00:30:54.530 --> 00:30:56.890
things like the technology that we have.

502
00:30:56.890 --> 00:31:01.340
If we don't have technology to
facilitate this then it's very,

503
00:31:01.340 --> 00:31:05.420
very difficult to enforce
access management.

504
00:31:05.420 --> 00:31:10.620
To enforce somebody to come down and
bring their user ID, for instance.

505
00:31:10.620 --> 00:31:12.220
What if they're 500 miles away?

506
00:31:13.400 --> 00:31:16.890
We have to have the technology
that can help us support that,

507
00:31:16.890 --> 00:31:20.870
because the thing that we don't
want is sort of backdoor access.

508
00:31:20.870 --> 00:31:24.050
We don't want people
granting access just because

509
00:31:24.050 --> 00:31:26.965
I think it sounded like them on the phone.

510
00:31:26.965 --> 00:31:30.272
We've got to monitor
that backdoor access and

511
00:31:30.272 --> 00:31:34.099
the access that comes in from
all the sources as well.

512
00:31:34.099 --> 00:31:36.958
So in a nutshell,
that is access management.

513
00:31:36.958 --> 00:31:40.377
And now what we'd like you
to do is to go back and

514
00:31:40.377 --> 00:31:45.640
take a look at the notes that you have
available to you with this class and

515
00:31:45.640 --> 00:31:49.230
do some self-study on access management.

516
00:31:49.230 --> 00:31:52.740
And I'd really like you
to specifically focus on

517
00:31:52.740 --> 00:31:56.980
the challenges of access management
within your organization.

518
00:31:56.980 --> 00:31:57.930
And yes,

519
00:31:57.930 --> 00:32:02.700
we acknowledge that there is a huge,
big relationship into security management.

520
00:32:02.700 --> 00:32:07.170
Because without having that defined
process within security management,

521
00:32:07.170 --> 00:32:11.230
then it's gonna be very,
very difficult to ensure that we maintain

522
00:32:11.230 --> 00:32:15.130
the right level of access that will allow
us to be secure in our environment.

523
00:32:16.380 --> 00:32:19.052
>> All right Jo, well, thank you again for

524
00:32:19.052 --> 00:32:23.849
helping us out when it comes to access
management and understanding that

525
00:32:23.849 --> 00:32:28.030
process much better than what we
had before we began this show.

526
00:32:28.030 --> 00:32:30.620
Remember that we took a look
at the basic principles,

527
00:32:30.620 --> 00:32:34.305
as well as the process flow and,
of course, even the matrix that we've been

528
00:32:34.305 --> 00:32:37.145
talking about as well throughout
this entire series too.

529
00:32:37.145 --> 00:32:41.400
And all these are great things that we
have to keep in mind as we continue in our

530
00:32:41.400 --> 00:32:43.930
career towards more ITIL knowledge.

531
00:32:43.930 --> 00:32:46.670
And that's a great place for
us to also sign off then.

532
00:32:46.670 --> 00:32:49.650
For ITProTV, I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

533
00:32:49.650 --> 00:32:50.730
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

534
00:32:50.730 --> 00:32:55.093
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation shows.

535
00:32:55.093 --> 00:33:02.058
[MUSIC]

536
00:33:02.058 --> 00:33:04.486
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo dive into Monitoring and Control. According to Jo, this a common service operation activity. Jo discusses monitoring and controls loops: open system and closed system. The purpose is to provide activities that help us to efficiently and effectively meet SLA targets.
episodes.title: Monitoring and Control
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.113 --> 00:00:02.546
Welcome to ITPro TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.546 --> 00:00:06.474
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.474 --> 00:00:08.236
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.236 --> 00:00:12.239
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.239 --> 00:00:15.705
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV,

6
00:00:15.705 --> 00:00:19.759
you're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Operation show.

7
00:00:19.759 --> 00:00:24.690
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today we're
beginning a new process, taking a look at

8
00:00:24.690 --> 00:00:29.560
common service activities, specifically
addressing monitoring and controls.

9
00:00:29.560 --> 00:00:35.406
And here to help us once again is gonna be
our our girl wonder in ITIL Jo Peacock,

10
00:00:35.406 --> 00:00:38.070
Jo, welcome back to the studios.

11
00:00:38.070 --> 00:00:41.231
>> Thank you very much,
great to be here again, Ronnie, and

12
00:00:41.231 --> 00:00:45.244
I just want to say that you can carry on
calling me a girl as long as you like.

13
00:00:45.244 --> 00:00:47.381
>> All right.
>> If you could shave a few years off

14
00:00:47.381 --> 00:00:50.917
with every single session,
I would be really grateful.

15
00:00:50.917 --> 00:00:51.458
>> All right,

16
00:00:51.458 --> 00:00:53.680
now I wish I actually had that-
>> [LAUGH]

17
00:00:53.680 --> 00:00:55.460
>> Magical ability to do that for

18
00:00:55.460 --> 00:00:59.900
all of us but, the ability that
I do have though is to at least

19
00:00:59.900 --> 00:01:01.720
turn over this show to you as we begin.

20
00:01:01.720 --> 00:01:04.850
We'll talk about monitoring and
controlling, so

21
00:01:04.850 --> 00:01:09.302
this is gonna be a new process for
me in terms of understanding anything.

22
00:01:09.302 --> 00:01:12.465
So Jo, where are we beginning?

23
00:01:12.465 --> 00:01:16.460
[LAUGH]
>> Okay, this isn't actually a process.

24
00:01:16.460 --> 00:01:17.000
>> Okay.

25
00:01:17.000 --> 00:01:17.500
>> All right?
>> All right.

26
00:01:17.500 --> 00:01:19.072
>> What we're doing now,

27
00:01:19.072 --> 00:01:23.158
the next three sections or
sessions that we will be covering,

28
00:01:23.158 --> 00:01:27.290
are what we call our common
service operation activities.

29
00:01:27.290 --> 00:01:30.747
So these are common activities
that are found within the service

30
00:01:30.747 --> 00:01:32.162
operation environment.

31
00:01:32.162 --> 00:01:37.474
So, that business as usual live
environment, so, these aren't processes,

32
00:01:37.474 --> 00:01:41.694
these are activities that
are specific to each organization.

33
00:01:41.694 --> 00:01:46.773
And, all we can do with these
particular activities is just

34
00:01:46.773 --> 00:01:52.564
give you examples of what we expect
to see in any live organization,

35
00:01:52.564 --> 00:01:55.928
in any business as usual environment.

36
00:01:55.928 --> 00:01:59.275
Now, they will appear in any shape or
form,

37
00:01:59.275 --> 00:02:04.078
in some guise or another, but
they are going to appear, okay.

38
00:02:04.078 --> 00:02:09.166
So as it says here, activities
are generally technical in nature,

39
00:02:09.166 --> 00:02:13.915
so they're going to vary from
organization to organization.

40
00:02:13.915 --> 00:02:19.400
They're there to integrate our technology
and the processes and the people.

41
00:02:19.400 --> 00:02:23.820
So really, our technology is here
to facilitate those processes,

42
00:02:23.820 --> 00:02:29.105
it's also here to deliver services and
facilitate outcomes for the customers.

43
00:02:29.105 --> 00:02:35.649
And these activities are just the things
that we do generally as we said, technical

44
00:02:35.649 --> 00:02:41.980
in nature, so they don't necessarily
have a process purpose to them.

45
00:02:41.980 --> 00:02:46.376
But they are a means to an end, so they're
something that we do because we need to.

46
00:02:47.962 --> 00:02:52.007
So the first one that we're going to look
at it, and in this particular section

47
00:02:52.007 --> 00:02:55.954
here, we're going to concentrate on
what we call monitoring and control.

48
00:02:55.954 --> 00:03:00.905
And as it says there, it's a continual
cycle of monitoring, reporting and action,

49
00:03:00.905 --> 00:03:03.400
so Ronnie, I'm gonna put you on the spot.

50
00:03:03.400 --> 00:03:04.684
>> Sure thing.

51
00:03:04.684 --> 00:03:07.907
>> Okay, how good are you
at dictionary definitions?

52
00:03:07.907 --> 00:03:10.757
>> I am terrible at dictionary
definitions, but I will try and

53
00:03:10.757 --> 00:03:11.443
give you one.

54
00:03:11.443 --> 00:03:12.811
>> Okay, excellent.

55
00:03:12.811 --> 00:03:15.340
>> [LAUGH]
>> So do you know what the difference is

56
00:03:15.340 --> 00:03:17.635
between continuous and continual?

57
00:03:17.635 --> 00:03:21.725
>> Continuous and continual,
I don't think I do,

58
00:03:21.725 --> 00:03:26.330
I'm trying to think here,
no, I don't, yeah.

59
00:03:26.330 --> 00:03:31.117
>> Okay, not to worry, because not
many other people do either, and

60
00:03:31.117 --> 00:03:34.965
in fact they tend to be words
that we use interchangeably,

61
00:03:35.975 --> 00:03:39.625
thinking that they both mean pretty
much the same thing, but they don't.

62
00:03:39.625 --> 00:03:46.355
Continuous means ongoing, all the time,
whereas continual is iterative,

63
00:03:46.355 --> 00:03:50.509
it takes one step at a time,
it's repeatable.

64
00:03:50.509 --> 00:03:52.802
>> Right.
>> It's the difference between driving and

65
00:03:52.802 --> 00:03:53.306
walking.

66
00:03:53.306 --> 00:03:54.350
>> Okay.

67
00:03:54.350 --> 00:03:59.879
>> When you're driving, your wheels are
constantly turning, continuously turning.

68
00:03:59.879 --> 00:04:03.767
So, maybe you want to get,
let's say you want to get over there,

69
00:04:03.767 --> 00:04:07.430
that's where you want to go,
in that general direction.

70
00:04:07.430 --> 00:04:12.120
And you've got an endpoint in mind and
you could drive, but

71
00:04:12.120 --> 00:04:16.460
then you never really get a true
picture of exactly where you are.

72
00:04:16.460 --> 00:04:21.568
Because by the time you have looked
at your GPS, it's got its signal from

73
00:04:21.568 --> 00:04:27.210
the satellite somewhere up in the ether,
and that signals bounced back to you.

74
00:04:27.210 --> 00:04:32.258
Your wheels have actually moved on,
so it's never truly accurate,

75
00:04:32.258 --> 00:04:37.217
and how many times have you gone past
that turn in that you wanted to go

76
00:04:37.217 --> 00:04:42.375
down before you've realized that
you needed to go down that turning.

77
00:04:42.375 --> 00:04:47.790
So it's not so easy to change direction
either when we're moving continuously.

78
00:04:49.140 --> 00:04:54.205
And then there's walking,
now walking is an iterative process,

79
00:04:54.205 --> 00:04:57.196
it's continual, it's step by step.

80
00:04:57.196 --> 00:05:03.245
But with every single step that I take,
I have got an exact point in time,

81
00:05:03.245 --> 00:05:08.698
I know exactly where I am so
I know exactly how far I've got to go and

82
00:05:08.698 --> 00:05:12.095
how far I've been, how far I've come.

83
00:05:12.095 --> 00:05:16.390
So it's an iterative process,
it's step by step, and you know what?

84
00:05:16.390 --> 00:05:20.409
I can change direction with the next step,
it's easy.

85
00:05:20.409 --> 00:05:21.284
>> Okay.
>> Okay?

86
00:05:21.284 --> 00:05:27.253
So, we still get to the same end point,
but we do it in an iterative way,

87
00:05:27.253 --> 00:05:33.350
which is why we talk here about
the continual cycle of monitoring.

88
00:05:33.350 --> 00:05:37.667
It's not continuous,
it's continual, it's repeatable,

89
00:05:37.667 --> 00:05:40.361
it's iterative, it's step by step.

90
00:05:40.361 --> 00:05:45.079
Monitoring and action, so
when monitoring something and

91
00:05:45.079 --> 00:05:48.651
then we're doing something about it here.

92
00:05:48.651 --> 00:05:52.109
Now we've got a process that
actually helps us with that, and

93
00:05:52.109 --> 00:05:55.780
the process tells us how to do it,
and this is actually what we do.

94
00:05:55.780 --> 00:05:59.124
And of course,
that process is event management, and

95
00:05:59.124 --> 00:06:03.267
I told you when we looked at event
management in a previous session,

96
00:06:03.267 --> 00:06:07.010
I mentioned that event management
may be fully automated.

97
00:06:07.010 --> 00:06:11.702
And monitoring and control is
something that may be fully automated,

98
00:06:11.702 --> 00:06:14.095
this is exactly what we'd expect.

99
00:06:14.095 --> 00:06:17.346
So monitoring and control,

100
00:06:17.346 --> 00:06:22.090
I expect this to be a closed loop process.

101
00:06:22.090 --> 00:06:24.038
>> Okay.

102
00:06:24.038 --> 00:06:29.360
>> I'm going to take us back to a previous
session, and in Event Management,

103
00:06:29.360 --> 00:06:34.274
I mentioned the difference between
a thermostat and a thermometer.

104
00:06:34.274 --> 00:06:39.234
And I referred to a thermometer as just
being something that we keep on the wall

105
00:06:39.234 --> 00:06:43.220
and that tells us exactly what
the temperatures is right now.

106
00:06:43.220 --> 00:06:48.450
And I said that's just monitored, it's not
doing anything else other than monitoring.

107
00:06:48.450 --> 00:06:53.568
Whereas a thermostat actually tells us
what the temperature is on the wall and

108
00:06:53.568 --> 00:06:57.979
then adjusts the heating or
the air conditioning depending on what

109
00:06:57.979 --> 00:07:01.383
the temperature is and
what parameter we've set.

110
00:07:01.383 --> 00:07:05.714
Well that's what we call
a closed loop system,

111
00:07:05.714 --> 00:07:09.396
an open loop system actually responds to

112
00:07:09.396 --> 00:07:14.182
the fact that the temperature
has dropped in a room.

113
00:07:14.182 --> 00:07:17.408
And we'd do something like,
we'd go and light a fire or

114
00:07:17.408 --> 00:07:20.167
we turn a heater on ourselves,
we light a fire.

115
00:07:20.167 --> 00:07:25.659
Now there's nothing that turns that fire
off, when we light a fire in a room,

116
00:07:25.659 --> 00:07:30.074
it's open loop,
it's a one-off activity that we go and do.

117
00:07:30.074 --> 00:07:33.663
And if we look at the thermometer on
the wall, the thermometer will change,

118
00:07:33.663 --> 00:07:37.383
it will gradually start to get hotter and
then it will carry on getting hotter.

119
00:07:37.383 --> 00:07:41.508
And it doesn't start to get any cooler
until we can't just suddenly turn off

120
00:07:41.508 --> 00:07:44.738
the heat, right, we have to wait for
that fire to die down.

121
00:07:44.738 --> 00:07:48.667
That's what we call an open loop
system it's one specific task, and

122
00:07:48.667 --> 00:07:52.610
as it says there, it's independent
of any other influence, okay.

123
00:07:52.610 --> 00:07:54.598
Whereas a closed loop system,

124
00:07:54.598 --> 00:07:59.040
well that thermostat that we have on
the wall is a closed loop system.

125
00:07:59.040 --> 00:08:02.618
And I just wanna take you to that
particular diagram there, and

126
00:08:02.618 --> 00:08:04.791
on the right-hand side of the slide.

127
00:08:04.791 --> 00:08:07.665
And we start off With the norm, and

128
00:08:07.665 --> 00:08:12.334
the norm is the temperature
that we have set in the room.

129
00:08:12.334 --> 00:08:16.331
So we've set that temperature to,
and let's work in Fahrenheit here,

130
00:08:16.331 --> 00:08:19.258
we set this temperature to say,
72 Fahrenheit.

131
00:08:19.258 --> 00:08:24.958
And all the time, we are monitoring
the temperature in the room.

132
00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:29.568
And we're comparing to that
standard that we've set of 72.

133
00:08:29.568 --> 00:08:32.556
And if it falls below,
then we move over to control.

134
00:08:32.556 --> 00:08:38.808
It falls below 72, so we come down to
that activity and we turn on the heating.

135
00:08:38.808 --> 00:08:43.020
And then we're monitoring and
comparing against the norm.

136
00:08:43.020 --> 00:08:43.890
And when it reaches 72,

137
00:08:43.890 --> 00:08:49.260
then the following control activity
is to turn off the heating, okay?

138
00:08:50.390 --> 00:08:54.150
So what we have there is
a closed loop process.

139
00:08:55.170 --> 00:09:00.702
Now the next slide then, whoa,
that looks a little bit worse I would say.

140
00:09:00.702 --> 00:09:03.678
So this is what we call
a complex monitor control loop.

141
00:09:03.678 --> 00:09:06.339
So I want you to take a look at it.

142
00:09:06.339 --> 00:09:09.584
Again, I'm gonna use
the analogy of heating,

143
00:09:09.584 --> 00:09:13.190
because it seems to make sense for
everybody.

144
00:09:13.190 --> 00:09:16.976
So you have to tell me if it's not making
sense for you, because I can try and

145
00:09:16.976 --> 00:09:19.914
do something else if you want, okay?

146
00:09:19.914 --> 00:09:23.441
But let's take a look at the top
right-hand side there then.

147
00:09:23.441 --> 00:09:26.880
The top right-hand side,
you'll see exactly the same things here.

148
00:09:26.880 --> 00:09:30.738
So we've got our norm, which is what
we've set, that's our temperature of 72.

149
00:09:30.738 --> 00:09:35.518
And then we are continually,
continually not continuously,

150
00:09:35.518 --> 00:09:37.960
monitoring against that norm.

151
00:09:39.660 --> 00:09:43.828
But you'll see we have individual
monitor control loops underneath.

152
00:09:43.828 --> 00:09:49.218
Well let's say, for instance,
in the last slide we just did one room.

153
00:09:49.218 --> 00:09:53.489
Now we're going to do a whole building.

154
00:09:53.489 --> 00:09:58.001
And each individual room
has its own thermostat.

155
00:09:58.001 --> 00:10:02.490
So for the entire building there,
we want to maintain

156
00:10:02.490 --> 00:10:07.292
the temperature across all
of the rooms of 72 degrees.

157
00:10:08.560 --> 00:10:13.407
So we compare against
that norm of 72 degrees.

158
00:10:13.407 --> 00:10:18.309
But then what we will do, when it comes to
cross to control, we could have one room

159
00:10:18.309 --> 00:10:22.864
say, that room on the left that's
a little bit warmer than 72 degrees.

160
00:10:22.864 --> 00:10:29.527
So what we might do there is we might
choose to put the air conditioning on.

161
00:10:29.527 --> 00:10:33.681
The room in the middle, well, that
actually might be perfect at 72 degrees,

162
00:10:33.681 --> 00:10:35.580
so we'll choose to do nothing.

163
00:10:35.580 --> 00:10:37.989
But the room on the right-hand side,

164
00:10:37.989 --> 00:10:41.700
well that actually might fall
way below the 72 degrees.

165
00:10:41.700 --> 00:10:45.865
Which is what's causing the entire
building to fall below that 72 degrees, so

166
00:10:45.865 --> 00:10:47.900
we'll increase the heat in that room.

167
00:10:47.900 --> 00:10:52.097
And we'll monitor until it
reaches the desired temperature.

168
00:10:52.097 --> 00:10:57.681
But over all, in that top right-hand
corner what we're doing is,

169
00:10:57.681 --> 00:11:00.992
we are monitoring the entire building.

170
00:11:00.992 --> 00:11:06.255
And then we are adjusting the controls
in each room to ensure that

171
00:11:06.255 --> 00:11:11.136
the entire building maintains
a consistent temperature.

172
00:11:11.136 --> 00:11:17.720
So this is a closed loop system, but it's
what we call a complex closed loop system.

173
00:11:17.720 --> 00:11:19.657
A complex monitor control loop.

174
00:11:21.964 --> 00:11:23.660
So now let's look at ITIL.

175
00:11:25.260 --> 00:11:30.577
And ITIL itself is a monitor control loop.

176
00:11:30.577 --> 00:11:34.657
We start off, and
actually what we've got here in

177
00:11:34.657 --> 00:11:39.126
the top right-hand corner
is us starting off with, or

178
00:11:39.126 --> 00:11:44.196
monitoring from CSI,
from continual service improvement.

179
00:11:44.196 --> 00:11:49.871
Because believe it or not, that's exactly
what continual service improvement does,

180
00:11:49.871 --> 00:11:51.773
it monitors against a norm.

181
00:11:51.773 --> 00:11:58.320
And if we are not, that norm being aligned
to the business, if we are not aligned

182
00:11:58.320 --> 00:12:03.980
to the needs of the organization then
we may implement an improvement.

183
00:12:03.980 --> 00:12:07.494
In other words, we create an idea for
a new service or for

184
00:12:07.494 --> 00:12:10.630
an amendment to a service and
service strategy.

185
00:12:10.630 --> 00:12:13.611
Which we then design in service design and

186
00:12:13.611 --> 00:12:18.380
then in service transition we build and
test and we deploy it.

187
00:12:18.380 --> 00:12:22.790
And then on an ongoing basis we check
that that service is aligned to

188
00:12:22.790 --> 00:12:24.618
the needs of the business.

189
00:12:24.618 --> 00:12:27.348
And then we go back to
service strategy and

190
00:12:27.348 --> 00:12:32.496
make any adjustments that we need to
ensure that the services that we deliver,

191
00:12:32.496 --> 00:12:37.806
and what we have in the bottom of that
slide there are three individual services.

192
00:12:37.806 --> 00:12:38.844
For example,

193
00:12:38.844 --> 00:12:44.648
that those three individual services
are aligned to the needs of the business.

194
00:12:44.648 --> 00:12:48.388
And what we have around
the outside of this complex,

195
00:12:48.388 --> 00:12:53.669
this service management monitor control
loop are all of our influences.

196
00:12:53.669 --> 00:12:56.810
Influences from our business
executives because, of course,

197
00:12:56.810 --> 00:12:59.496
they give us our preferences and
tell us what we value.

198
00:12:59.496 --> 00:13:04.329
Influences from our users which
set the level of warranty,

199
00:13:04.329 --> 00:13:07.625
how we're going to use those services.

200
00:13:07.625 --> 00:13:12.011
Influences from account management and
our suppliers.

201
00:13:12.011 --> 00:13:16.891
And also influences from our internal and
external staff,

202
00:13:16.891 --> 00:13:21.378
our experts that will tell us
how they want us to work and

203
00:13:21.378 --> 00:13:24.515
how we can work with that technology.

204
00:13:24.515 --> 00:13:31.430
So we start off with monitoring and
control in our service level agreement.

205
00:13:31.430 --> 00:13:34.988
Well actually, we don't start off
in the service level agreements,

206
00:13:34.988 --> 00:13:37.895
we start off,
you notice those different letter there?

207
00:13:37.895 --> 00:13:40.608
That's the service level requirement.

208
00:13:40.608 --> 00:13:45.198
We start by generating service level
requirements way back in the service

209
00:13:45.198 --> 00:13:47.050
design life cycle phase.

210
00:13:47.050 --> 00:13:51.083
And I want you to think of these service
level requirements as a draft SLAs,

211
00:13:51.083 --> 00:13:53.240
because that's what they are.

212
00:13:53.240 --> 00:13:57.609
It's where we document the initial
requirements of our customers and

213
00:13:57.609 --> 00:13:58.355
our users.

214
00:13:58.355 --> 00:14:01.910
And then over a period of time,
throughout design and

215
00:14:01.910 --> 00:14:06.150
transition, we negotiate
these service level targets.

216
00:14:06.150 --> 00:14:10.855
And then as we move through early
life support, after deployment,

217
00:14:10.855 --> 00:14:15.641
and we sign off that service level
agreement, then the service level

218
00:14:15.641 --> 00:14:20.444
requirement actually becomes
the signed SLA after signing, okay?

219
00:14:20.444 --> 00:14:24.932
So the objectives, as it says for
monitoring and control,

220
00:14:24.932 --> 00:14:26.650
begins with the SLRs.

221
00:14:26.650 --> 00:14:31.640
What that really means is, these SLRs tell
us what level of service we're to provide.

222
00:14:31.640 --> 00:14:35.390
And of course we've got to monitor
against that level of service.

223
00:14:35.390 --> 00:14:40.330
And we monitor both internally,
within the technology, but

224
00:14:40.330 --> 00:14:42.690
we also monitor externally.

225
00:14:42.690 --> 00:14:48.065
In other words we monitor the services
that we are delivering as a whole,

226
00:14:48.065 --> 00:14:51.336
irrespective of who owns that technology.

227
00:14:51.336 --> 00:14:56.844
Because both of those are very important,
we are delivering value to our users.

228
00:14:56.844 --> 00:14:58.665
And we can't deliver value to our users,

229
00:14:58.665 --> 00:15:01.120
if we're not keeping an eye
on what we're delivering.

230
00:15:02.520 --> 00:15:05.623
So we have different types of monitoring.

231
00:15:05.623 --> 00:15:07.523
We have what we call active monitoring.

232
00:15:07.523 --> 00:15:12.063
And active monitoring is where we for
instance may monitor a server console for

233
00:15:12.063 --> 00:15:12.761
instance.

234
00:15:12.761 --> 00:15:17.267
And we're sitting in front of that server
console, and we're watching things happen.

235
00:15:17.267 --> 00:15:24.191
Passive monitoring is where we're using
technology to do that monitoring for us.

236
00:15:24.191 --> 00:15:29.179
And it's feeding activities to
an external, it says a listening device,

237
00:15:29.179 --> 00:15:31.889
but it could be a log file, for instance.

238
00:15:31.889 --> 00:15:36.100
So things like logging in and logging out.

239
00:15:36.100 --> 00:15:40.714
When a user logs into a system and
when they log out again, that's logged.

240
00:15:42.375 --> 00:15:45.185
But do we really need to know about that?

241
00:15:45.185 --> 00:15:46.647
Well not at the moment, no.

242
00:15:46.647 --> 00:15:49.774
But somebody might ask us
about that at a later date.

243
00:15:49.774 --> 00:15:53.949
So we do passive monitoring
on those sort of activities.

244
00:15:53.949 --> 00:15:58.540
And we might do passive monitoring, but I
would expect us to do active monitoring on

245
00:15:58.540 --> 00:16:01.435
things like backup starting and
backup finishing.

246
00:16:01.435 --> 00:16:06.650
Because we want to check that a backup
started and that it's completed okay.

247
00:16:06.650 --> 00:16:10.701
But passive monitoring is any monitoring
where we need to keep the results.

248
00:16:10.701 --> 00:16:11.630
We might need them.

249
00:16:11.630 --> 00:16:15.020
We might need to see who's had
access to our computer room, but

250
00:16:15.020 --> 00:16:17.460
we don't necessarily need
to see them in real time.

251
00:16:18.680 --> 00:16:24.970
Then we have reactive monitoring, and
reactive monitoring responds to a trigger.

252
00:16:24.970 --> 00:16:29.000
And that's where,
let's go back to that thermostat again.

253
00:16:29.000 --> 00:16:33.740
It clicks in, you hear an audible click
usually when the thermostat kicks in,

254
00:16:33.740 --> 00:16:36.450
because the temperature has got too warm.

255
00:16:36.450 --> 00:16:40.045
And so the air conditioning has come
on and that might generate an alert.

256
00:16:40.045 --> 00:16:42.959
That might say, hey look,
I've had to bring the air conditioning on.

257
00:16:42.959 --> 00:16:46.721
Now, I have been and
I have to confess this,

258
00:16:46.721 --> 00:16:52.445
in my years as a mainframe operator
which were a long, long time ago.

259
00:16:52.445 --> 00:16:57.375
I was in a situation where a computer room
of ours, or a machine room as we used to

260
00:16:57.375 --> 00:17:01.441
call it, where the air conditioning
failed in a computer room.

261
00:17:01.441 --> 00:17:05.049
And when the air conditioning failed and
this was for

262
00:17:05.049 --> 00:17:09.484
a very, very, very large telecom
organization within the UK.

263
00:17:09.484 --> 00:17:13.263
When the air conditioning failed
at the data center, we had to shut

264
00:17:13.263 --> 00:17:17.803
down the mainframe and that means shutting
down the entire telephone network.

265
00:17:17.803 --> 00:17:22.056
That was not something that I'd ever
wish to experience again because

266
00:17:22.056 --> 00:17:27.175
the temperature in that computer room
rose to well over 100 degrees Fahrenheit,

267
00:17:27.175 --> 00:17:29.020
well over that.

268
00:17:29.020 --> 00:17:33.635
So yeah, we want to generate an alert once
something like that starts to happen.

269
00:17:33.635 --> 00:17:36.389
Proactive monitoring is
about detecting patterns.

270
00:17:36.389 --> 00:17:41.276
It's really about not just responding
to triggers that happen, but

271
00:17:41.276 --> 00:17:48.360
it's about detecting patterns and trend
analysis, that's proactive monitoring.

272
00:17:48.360 --> 00:17:50.680
Continuous monitoring is
monitoring all the time.

273
00:17:50.680 --> 00:17:53.020
Remember the difference
between continuous and

274
00:17:53.020 --> 00:17:56.282
continual, continuous
monitoring is all the time.

275
00:17:56.282 --> 00:18:01.116
And exception-based monitoring is where we
just simply report on things that happen

276
00:18:01.116 --> 00:18:03.072
that are different from the norm.

277
00:18:03.072 --> 00:18:07.636
And, of course,
we can use any combination of those.

278
00:18:07.636 --> 00:18:12.310
There is no right or wrong, it's whatever
is required for your organization.

279
00:18:13.520 --> 00:18:17.590
So, of course, what we have to do,
is we have to measure.

280
00:18:18.860 --> 00:18:20.600
We measure what is happening.

281
00:18:20.600 --> 00:18:22.528
That's part of monitoring and control.

282
00:18:22.528 --> 00:18:26.710
And measuring simply
means that we understand

283
00:18:26.710 --> 00:18:30.830
what parameters we are looking to take.

284
00:18:32.560 --> 00:18:36.310
And the metrics are the actual
numbers that we physically take.

285
00:18:37.870 --> 00:18:42.960
So the measurements, for instance
we may measure when backup starts.

286
00:18:42.960 --> 00:18:47.116
So the measurements we take are when a
backup starts and when a backup finishes,

287
00:18:47.116 --> 00:18:48.677
they're the measurements.

288
00:18:48.677 --> 00:18:54.436
The metrics that we take are that
the backup started at 22:15 and

289
00:18:54.436 --> 00:18:56.629
finished at 02:17.

290
00:18:56.629 --> 00:19:00.160
They're the metrics,
the actual physical numbers.

291
00:19:00.160 --> 00:19:04.640
And, of course, those key performance
indicators, if we look in previous

292
00:19:04.640 --> 00:19:08.737
sections, we've actually seen examples
of key performance indicators.

293
00:19:08.737 --> 00:19:13.593
And key performance indicators will look
at things like the average time that

294
00:19:13.593 --> 00:19:19.354
a backup takes to complete, say over
a period of six months or maybe a week.

295
00:19:21.710 --> 00:19:24.750
Monitoring without control
is completely irrelevant.

296
00:19:25.960 --> 00:19:28.620
What's the point in getting
all of those reports and

297
00:19:28.620 --> 00:19:31.040
all of those statistics if we
don't do anything with it?

298
00:19:31.040 --> 00:19:35.540
And remember, we have a process called
knowledge management within ITIL.

299
00:19:35.540 --> 00:19:39.090
And knowledge management works on
the understanding that we have the right

300
00:19:39.090 --> 00:19:42.976
information available to us
to make informed decisions.

301
00:19:42.976 --> 00:19:46.823
If all of that information is
telling us absolutely nothing and

302
00:19:46.823 --> 00:19:52.160
we can't make an informed decisions from
it, then we're measuring the wrong thing.

303
00:19:52.160 --> 00:19:55.270
We need to be able to make informed
decisions from our information.

304
00:19:55.270 --> 00:19:59.600
So understand why you're taking
metrics before you take them,

305
00:19:59.600 --> 00:20:00.820
understand the purpose.

306
00:20:02.150 --> 00:20:05.590
Event management, of course,
is key to all of this.

307
00:20:05.590 --> 00:20:12.408
This is the process that manages
all of the monitoring and control.

308
00:20:12.408 --> 00:20:15.340
So that's the monitoring and
control activity.

309
00:20:15.340 --> 00:20:19.530
It's one of our common
service operation activities.

310
00:20:19.530 --> 00:20:25.085
And in our next sessions, we're going to
be looking more in-depth at the functional

311
00:20:25.085 --> 00:20:30.114
areas that we have, within service
operations, within business as usual.

312
00:20:30.114 --> 00:20:32.802
And what we're going to be
doing is just analyzing

313
00:20:32.802 --> 00:20:35.630
the activities that
they undertake as well.

314
00:20:35.630 --> 00:20:40.620
Now service operation, obviously,
involves business as usual so

315
00:20:40.620 --> 00:20:42.665
it involves a lot of monitoring and
control.

316
00:20:42.665 --> 00:20:47.520
And monitoring and control applies to
every single functional area in some way,

317
00:20:47.520 --> 00:20:48.850
shape, or form.

318
00:20:48.850 --> 00:20:52.916
But now we're going to be
looking in the next sections at

319
00:20:52.916 --> 00:20:56.735
specific roles within
specific functional areas.

320
00:20:56.735 --> 00:20:58.163
>> All right, Jo.

321
00:20:58.163 --> 00:21:02.733
Thank you again for introducing us to the
concept of these different activities that

322
00:21:02.733 --> 00:21:06.398
are really gonna keep our business
lined up the way that it needs to,

323
00:21:06.398 --> 00:21:08.091
operating against that norm.

324
00:21:08.091 --> 00:21:11.631
Making sure we have the monitoring and
the controls to be able to see that, and

325
00:21:11.631 --> 00:21:14.290
to be able to put things
back where they need to be.

326
00:21:14.290 --> 00:21:17.690
Now there's a lot more of these different
activities that we need to go through,

327
00:21:17.690 --> 00:21:20.470
but that's gonna be for another day.

328
00:21:20.470 --> 00:21:24.518
So signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

329
00:21:24.518 --> 00:21:25.775
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

330
00:21:25.775 --> 00:21:30.682
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation shows.

331
00:21:30.682 --> 00:21:36.567
[MUSIC]

332
00:21:36.567 --> 00:21:40.222
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo take a look at several of the Common Service Operation Activities.  Jo provides some insight into some of the activities that are part of the common everyday service operations that make providing service to a company see the value of our services.  The services discussed include:IT Operations, Server and Mainframe Management Support, Network Management, Storage and Archive, Database Administration, Directory Services Management, desktop and mobile device support and middleware management.
episodes.title: Common Service Operation Activities
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.019 --> 00:00:01.969
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:01.969 --> 00:00:06.458
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.458 --> 00:00:08.221
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.221 --> 00:00:12.141
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.141 --> 00:00:15.533
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.533 --> 00:00:19.121
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Operation show.

7
00:00:19.121 --> 00:00:20.909
I'm your host Ronnie Wong,

8
00:00:20.909 --> 00:00:25.243
and today we're diving into common
service operation activities.

9
00:00:25.243 --> 00:00:27.446
And here to help us is gonna
be our ITIL maven, Ms.

10
00:00:27.446 --> 00:00:30.239
Jo Peacock, Jo, welcome back to the show,
how are you doing?

11
00:00:30.239 --> 00:00:33.075
>> Thank you for having me,
I'm fine, how are you Ronnie?

12
00:00:33.075 --> 00:00:38.340
>> I am doing great, as we now head into
this area of common service activities.

13
00:00:38.340 --> 00:00:43.126
I mistakenly called it a process,
I think, in a previous episode, so

14
00:00:43.126 --> 00:00:46.217
make sure you distinguish that for
me again.

15
00:00:46.217 --> 00:00:48.545
And then tell me what we're
gonna be seeing today.

16
00:00:48.545 --> 00:00:52.453
>> Okay, well,
a process is a set of activities, so

17
00:00:52.453 --> 00:00:57.957
a process is something that takes
an input and turns it into an output.

18
00:00:57.957 --> 00:01:02.283
For instance, if I use the incident
management process as an example,

19
00:01:02.283 --> 00:01:06.897
a process will take, the objective of
the incident management process is to

20
00:01:06.897 --> 00:01:09.150
restore normal service operation.

21
00:01:09.150 --> 00:01:13.212
Which means that the output is something
that's been fixed, so the input,

22
00:01:13.212 --> 00:01:17.605
therefore, is something that's been
broken, something that's not working.

23
00:01:17.605 --> 00:01:20.189
So we take something that's not working,
and

24
00:01:20.189 --> 00:01:24.114
transform it into something that's
working, so that's a process.

25
00:01:24.114 --> 00:01:29.023
But a process is made up of activities,
and activities are just the things

26
00:01:29.023 --> 00:01:34.188
that we do within the process in order
to facilitate achieving that outcome.

27
00:01:34.188 --> 00:01:39.096
So what we're going to look at over
the next couple of sections, actually,

28
00:01:39.096 --> 00:01:44.096
are just some of the common activities
that exist within service operation.

29
00:01:44.096 --> 00:01:46.830
So this operation, as you know,
is the business as usual,

30
00:01:46.830 --> 00:01:48.211
it's the live environment.

31
00:01:48.211 --> 00:01:51.094
So it's about keeping everything up and
running, and

32
00:01:51.094 --> 00:01:55.485
so we're looking at just some of the
common activities that organizations do.

33
00:01:55.485 --> 00:02:01.617
There's no right or wrong in this section,
there is no definitive,

34
00:02:01.617 --> 00:02:05.622
this is the ITIL way
that you need to do this.

35
00:02:05.622 --> 00:02:11.297
These are just activities that people may
recognize, some people may not recognize,

36
00:02:11.297 --> 00:02:15.760
especially if they don't have any
involvement in that particular area of IT.

37
00:02:15.760 --> 00:02:16.912
But that's okay,

38
00:02:16.912 --> 00:02:21.811
we're just outlining really what happens
in service operation, that's all.

39
00:02:21.811 --> 00:02:25.816
>> All right, so let's go ahead and
start, then, what is our first step, or

40
00:02:25.816 --> 00:02:28.309
what are we gonna be taking
a look at right now?

41
00:02:28.309 --> 00:02:34.251
>> Okay, so the first thing that we're
going to do on our first slide is,

42
00:02:34.251 --> 00:02:41.126
we look at IT operations itself, and the
running of the service that we may have.

43
00:02:41.126 --> 00:02:45.388
Organizations 20 odd years ago,
and a lot of organizations, okay,

44
00:02:45.388 --> 00:02:49.663
30 years ago now [LAUGH],
I'm showing my age, I just wish it was 20.

45
00:02:49.663 --> 00:02:53.487
We all had mainframes, and
that's how we all started, and

46
00:02:53.487 --> 00:02:59.163
then we kind of move through to local area
networks, LANs, mid-range systems, etc.

47
00:02:59.163 --> 00:03:04.272
And even starting off as a mainframe
operator, we had what we called a network

48
00:03:04.272 --> 00:03:09.160
operation center, or an operations bridge,
where we managed console.

49
00:03:10.210 --> 00:03:15.191
This is where the process called
event management happens.

50
00:03:15.191 --> 00:03:20.515
So within the IT operation's functional
area, we will have console management,

51
00:03:20.515 --> 00:03:25.420
so we'll have that in that work operation
center, sometimes called a NOC.

52
00:03:25.420 --> 00:03:29.774
We'll have the operations bridge,
if we want to call it that,

53
00:03:29.774 --> 00:03:33.401
where we just simply manage
the day-to-day jobs.

54
00:03:33.401 --> 00:03:37.398
We manage the servers, we manage all
of the events that are happening on

55
00:03:37.398 --> 00:03:40.460
the servers, and
as we learned in a previous section,

56
00:03:40.460 --> 00:03:44.170
event management can sometimes
trigger incidents too.

57
00:03:44.170 --> 00:03:47.420
So this is where some
incidents are generated,

58
00:03:47.420 --> 00:03:50.360
where some incident records are raised.

59
00:03:50.360 --> 00:03:52.776
So that point about routine activities,

60
00:03:52.776 --> 00:03:55.613
that's what happens in
the operations bridge.

61
00:03:55.613 --> 00:04:00.240
Now, you might think that that sounds
like a very sort of mundane role, but

62
00:04:00.240 --> 00:04:03.409
actually it's a really,
really important role.

63
00:04:03.409 --> 00:04:10.530
Because these are the guys, this is
the area where failures are noticed first.

64
00:04:11.950 --> 00:04:15.592
So it's really, really important
that the operations bridge, or

65
00:04:15.592 --> 00:04:20.560
the NOC as we like to call it, it's really
important that this is on the ball.

66
00:04:20.560 --> 00:04:22.040
These guys are on the ball, and

67
00:04:22.040 --> 00:04:27.410
they are able to respond to
any event very, very quickly.

68
00:04:27.410 --> 00:04:30.893
What they may also do, and
it could be in a separate team, or

69
00:04:30.893 --> 00:04:35.228
it could be in the operations bridge,
they might also do job scheduling.

70
00:04:35.228 --> 00:04:41.717
So when we talk about job scheduling,
examples are such as batch runs for,

71
00:04:41.717 --> 00:04:48.103
say, statements if you're in a bank,
or if you are in a utility company,

72
00:04:48.103 --> 00:04:52.441
you will do statement rounds for
a billing, etc.

73
00:04:52.441 --> 00:04:56.814
So that's part of job scheduling,
as well as backup and restores that will,

74
00:04:56.814 --> 00:05:00.651
quite often, take place either in
the operations bridge or maybe,

75
00:05:00.651 --> 00:05:02.363
again, by a different team.

76
00:05:02.363 --> 00:05:05.827
And it's just monitoring
that backups work, and

77
00:05:05.827 --> 00:05:10.538
that the tapes have gone to the relevant
place where they need to go.

78
00:05:10.538 --> 00:05:14.583
And then also we might have printing,
there might be a print shop involved.

79
00:05:14.583 --> 00:05:18.746
Sometimes printing is something
that happens outside of

80
00:05:18.746 --> 00:05:21.440
the network operations bridge.

81
00:05:21.440 --> 00:05:26.572
It might even happen in an external
organization, with a third-party supplier,

82
00:05:26.572 --> 00:05:29.667
we might choose to use
a supplier to do this for us.

83
00:05:29.667 --> 00:05:32.874
Like when you get your cell phone bill,

84
00:05:32.874 --> 00:05:37.548
etc, a lot of times that
doesn't come from the company.

85
00:05:37.548 --> 00:05:42.072
It comes from a separate company,
and they just do the printing.

86
00:05:42.072 --> 00:05:46.354
Nevertheless, it still has to be
controlled internally, somebody has

87
00:05:46.354 --> 00:05:50.793
to manage that contract, and supplier
management will help us with that.

88
00:05:50.793 --> 00:05:55.695
But also, our operations guys have to
monitor to make sure that this works

89
00:05:55.695 --> 00:05:58.083
okay and that it's happening too.

90
00:05:58.083 --> 00:06:02.638
So one of the other areas we've got then
within service operation, bearing in mind

91
00:06:02.638 --> 00:06:07.250
that this is business as usual, we have
our server guys, our mainframe guys.

92
00:06:07.250 --> 00:06:10.357
And they're doing support
of those servers, so

93
00:06:10.357 --> 00:06:14.828
they might be doing things like licensing,
and third level support,

94
00:06:14.828 --> 00:06:17.879
even procurement advice,
as it says up there.

95
00:06:17.879 --> 00:06:21.927
What these guys are doing,
though, is support, so

96
00:06:21.927 --> 00:06:26.987
not only are they programming jobs,
they're scheduling jobs,

97
00:06:26.987 --> 00:06:32.244
but they're also picking up
the pieces when something goes wrong.

98
00:06:32.244 --> 00:06:35.211
So the fact that it says that
it's a specialized team, hey,

99
00:06:35.211 --> 00:06:37.780
you've gotta have the right
skills to do that.

100
00:06:37.780 --> 00:06:40.509
I mean, I couldn't go and
do that, I don't know about you.

101
00:06:40.509 --> 00:06:41.178
>> it's possible.

102
00:06:41.178 --> 00:06:45.233
[CROSSTALK] [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, 30 years ago,

103
00:06:45.233 --> 00:06:49.137
maybe, I was quite good at JCL, but.

104
00:06:49.137 --> 00:06:50.144
>> Yeah, yeah.

105
00:06:50.144 --> 00:06:52.129
>> [LAUGH] That was a long time ago.

106
00:06:52.129 --> 00:06:55.538
And so we've got the guys with
the right skills that can do that,

107
00:06:55.538 --> 00:06:59.753
cuz the last thing you need is somebody
like me, going in there and interfering.

108
00:06:59.753 --> 00:07:04.624
Nowadays, I wanna draw your attention to
the second from last bullet point there,

109
00:07:04.624 --> 00:07:09.098
which talks about virtual servers,
cuz nowadays, we have virtualization.

110
00:07:09.098 --> 00:07:15.023
And so we might manage what we
consider to be internal cloud service,

111
00:07:15.023 --> 00:07:18.200
etc, within this particular team.

112
00:07:18.200 --> 00:07:24.650
Now I've already told you, okay, we do
not tell you how to organize your IT,

113
00:07:24.650 --> 00:07:27.670
and we won't tell you what your
processes should look like.

114
00:07:27.670 --> 00:07:30.670
We'll just tell you that you
need to have processes, so

115
00:07:30.670 --> 00:07:32.310
this is outside of the processes.

116
00:07:32.310 --> 00:07:36.809
These are the teams and the skills that
they need to have that you've probably got

117
00:07:36.809 --> 00:07:40.328
within your organization, but
they'll perform processes.

118
00:07:40.328 --> 00:07:44.619
So, if they're doing support, then they're
going to be doing problem management,

119
00:07:44.619 --> 00:07:47.514
they're going to be doing
some incident management too.

120
00:07:47.514 --> 00:07:51.395
They're probably going to be doing
some availability management, and

121
00:07:51.395 --> 00:07:53.250
some capacity management, too.

122
00:07:53.250 --> 00:07:58.125
So these guys are actually going to be
doing a lot of the problem Process is that

123
00:07:58.125 --> 00:08:03.770
we look at throughout the service life
cycle but four servers and mainframes.

124
00:08:03.770 --> 00:08:07.373
Look at the other activities that they do,
defining build standards,

125
00:08:07.373 --> 00:08:11.114
that's part of service design,
that's part of project work, surely.

126
00:08:11.114 --> 00:08:14.950
So they're gonna be doing some of
the encoding and installing service.

127
00:08:16.290 --> 00:08:20.100
I remember the days when I used to get my
hands dirty like that, and I miss that,

128
00:08:20.100 --> 00:08:20.751
I really do.

129
00:08:20.751 --> 00:08:21.302
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

130
00:08:21.302 --> 00:08:24.396
you don't wanna see me crawling
behind a rack anymore, trust me.

131
00:08:24.396 --> 00:08:28.545
[LAUGH] But ongoing maintenance, etc.

132
00:08:28.545 --> 00:08:33.420
Quite often, we would prefer to have
the server team do that, and to be honest,

133
00:08:33.420 --> 00:08:35.628
it's quicker for
us to have a server team doing that,

134
00:08:35.628 --> 00:08:38.510
than it is to get
an outside vendor involved.

135
00:08:38.510 --> 00:08:42.542
So this is not beyond the realm of
possibility that we can be doing this

136
00:08:42.542 --> 00:08:43.386
internally.

137
00:08:46.307 --> 00:08:49.084
And then, of course,
now we separate these things out, but

138
00:08:49.084 --> 00:08:52.555
let's think about the scalability
of any organization.

139
00:08:52.555 --> 00:08:55.925
The larger the organization,
the more likely it is that

140
00:08:55.925 --> 00:08:59.490
these things will be separated out,
these teams will be separated.

141
00:08:59.490 --> 00:09:00.830
The smaller the organization,

142
00:09:00.830 --> 00:09:04.290
the more likely we are that these
teams are going to be combined.

143
00:09:04.290 --> 00:09:08.262
And so, it's not impossible for
the server guys and the mainframe guys and

144
00:09:08.262 --> 00:09:10.736
the network guys to all
be one in the same team.

145
00:09:10.736 --> 00:09:14.703
And we don't mind, as long as you
understand what roles you need

146
00:09:14.703 --> 00:09:19.780
in your organization, then we really
really don't mind how you organize.

147
00:09:19.780 --> 00:09:20.860
You can organize for

148
00:09:20.860 --> 00:09:23.990
efficiency and effectiveness,
that's what we want you to do.

149
00:09:23.990 --> 00:09:26.531
>> Now, Jo, as you talk about that,

150
00:09:26.531 --> 00:09:31.275
the goal here in making sure that
these activities are in place.

151
00:09:31.275 --> 00:09:35.162
And what we're doing is really to
address the scalability regardless of

152
00:09:35.162 --> 00:09:36.190
the size, right?

153
00:09:36.190 --> 00:09:40.313
So if my company grows from a very
small shop to a large shop,

154
00:09:40.313 --> 00:09:44.282
I'm not having to kind of put
the steps in place as I grow.

155
00:09:44.282 --> 00:09:46.650
I've already got it set up and
understand that process,

156
00:09:46.650 --> 00:09:48.450
is that what you're trying to say?

157
00:09:48.450 --> 00:09:51.914
>> Well, in service strategy,
in that life cycle phase,

158
00:09:51.914 --> 00:09:55.242
we actually look a lot more
in depth at organization.

159
00:09:55.242 --> 00:09:59.674
And how we move from a flat structure in
a small organization, to a completely

160
00:09:59.674 --> 00:10:04.850
collaborative structure in a very,
very large international organization.

161
00:10:04.850 --> 00:10:09.420
Now, we're not telling you that you
have to have these teams in place.

162
00:10:09.420 --> 00:10:10.710
We're not gonna tell you that,

163
00:10:10.710 --> 00:10:13.050
because we don't know what
your organization looks like.

164
00:10:13.050 --> 00:10:16.500
And it may be that even in
a really large organization,

165
00:10:16.500 --> 00:10:21.690
let's say an international organization,
you might outsource some of these roles.

166
00:10:21.690 --> 00:10:25.010
You might outsource IT in its entirety,
and

167
00:10:25.010 --> 00:10:27.370
you might have an external
service provider.

168
00:10:27.370 --> 00:10:29.978
And, you know what, you might even
have multiple service providers.

169
00:10:29.978 --> 00:10:35.130
So you may have one team doing network
support and network management.

170
00:10:35.130 --> 00:10:36.621
Let's say, for instance,

171
00:10:36.621 --> 00:10:40.487
Cisco, a lot of organizations use
Cisco to do their network management.

172
00:10:40.487 --> 00:10:43.311
But then you might have
somebody else that comes in and

173
00:10:43.311 --> 00:10:47.260
manages another portion of
the infrastructure, like servers, etc.

174
00:10:47.260 --> 00:10:51.180
So you might have HP coming in, and
they'll do the hardware support.

175
00:10:51.180 --> 00:10:55.680
And they do the server, the software,
the firmware support for

176
00:10:55.680 --> 00:10:58.510
the servers, and
the operating system support.

177
00:10:58.510 --> 00:11:05.790
So, it's not impossible to
have any format for structure.

178
00:11:05.790 --> 00:11:10.674
We're just telling you that
these jobs will need to happen,

179
00:11:10.674 --> 00:11:14.237
depending on what your organization does.

180
00:11:14.237 --> 00:11:18.973
Everybody's got a network nowadays, so
we have to have some form of network

181
00:11:18.973 --> 00:11:22.510
management, and
somebody has to make the decision.

182
00:11:22.510 --> 00:11:26.719
Let's look at IP address management,
somebody's gotta make a decision whether

183
00:11:26.719 --> 00:11:30.506
we have dynamic IP addressing, or
whether we have static IP addressing.

184
00:11:30.506 --> 00:11:33.916
Now, if it's a very,
very small organization and

185
00:11:33.916 --> 00:11:37.089
you don't have anybody
with the right skills,

186
00:11:37.089 --> 00:11:41.900
and with the right level of experience
to be able to make that decision.

187
00:11:41.900 --> 00:11:46.000
And maybe you're going to let somebody
like Cisco come in and advise you, or

188
00:11:46.000 --> 00:11:50.570
maybe even make that decision for
you and take the management off you.

189
00:11:50.570 --> 00:11:54.998
But it has to happen nevertheless, even
in our own homes, we make that decision.

190
00:11:54.998 --> 00:11:59.189
I mean, let's think about my home,

191
00:11:59.189 --> 00:12:04.203
I have cameras absolutely
all over my home.

192
00:12:04.203 --> 00:12:07.910
Some of them are set up on static IP,
some of them are on dynamic IP.

193
00:12:07.910 --> 00:12:12.511
So I have to reboot my routers,
then things might change.

194
00:12:12.511 --> 00:12:17.390
But I have to make that decision,
and we all have to.

195
00:12:17.390 --> 00:12:21.540
So it really depends on,
not just the scale, but

196
00:12:21.540 --> 00:12:24.600
also the type of organization, too.

197
00:12:24.600 --> 00:12:29.302
If we're a small family run business that
maybe has got, let's say, for instance,

198
00:12:29.302 --> 00:12:33.702
a coffee shop that maybe's got 10,
20 branches, somebody has to do this.

199
00:12:33.702 --> 00:12:37.393
They have to have a network, they have
to manage their point of sale, so

200
00:12:37.393 --> 00:12:39.440
they have to have a network.

201
00:12:39.440 --> 00:12:42.062
But if their experience is
in coffee shop management,

202
00:12:42.062 --> 00:12:45.373
their experience is probably not
going to be in network management.

203
00:12:45.373 --> 00:12:50.635
So they get somebody to do that for
them, so our network teams and

204
00:12:50.635 --> 00:12:55.620
our server teams,
they are very specialist in what they do.

205
00:12:55.620 --> 00:12:58.223
And as we say,
we put firewalls and gateways and

206
00:12:58.223 --> 00:13:01.361
internet service providers
under network management.

207
00:13:01.361 --> 00:13:04.363
But you know what, you might not put
your firewalls under the network,

208
00:13:04.363 --> 00:13:05.852
you might put them under servers.

209
00:13:05.852 --> 00:13:11.339
We really don't mind, as long as your
acknowledge you have to have a firewall.

210
00:13:11.339 --> 00:13:16.007
Yeah, and that's what we're saying,
is you have to have some form of security.

211
00:13:16.007 --> 00:13:20.787
I mean, let's look at storage and
archiving, some people would put,

212
00:13:20.787 --> 00:13:23.813
and again,
it can depend on scalability, or

213
00:13:23.813 --> 00:13:27.178
it can depend on the purpose
of the organization.

214
00:13:27.178 --> 00:13:31.390
Some people put storage and
archive in with server management.

215
00:13:31.390 --> 00:13:34.920
Because you're managing space, you're
managing space on your disk arrays, and

216
00:13:34.920 --> 00:13:37.850
so therefore,
that falls under the servers.

217
00:13:37.850 --> 00:13:42.800
It might fall under the networks
in your organization, or

218
00:13:42.800 --> 00:13:47.757
it might be a completely different team,
we don't mind.

219
00:13:47.757 --> 00:13:49.519
But when we think about storage and

220

archives, you think about sort
