00:26:56.050 --> 00:26:59.922
and government buildings I don't
expect you bring your own device.

451
00:26:59.922 --> 00:27:02.945
Okay, if I do see you bring your own
device then I'm getting worried in

452
00:27:02.945 --> 00:27:03.721
that situation.

453
00:27:03.721 --> 00:27:04.549
>> Definitely.

454
00:27:04.549 --> 00:27:06.002
>> But yeah.

455
00:27:06.002 --> 00:27:11.604
I expect to see desktop support
evolve more into the device support,

456
00:27:11.604 --> 00:27:13.350
mobile support.

457
00:27:13.350 --> 00:27:16.480
Especially over the next few years,
I think that's going to happen.

458
00:27:16.480 --> 00:27:19.990
So we need to have somebody that
has the technical skills and

459
00:27:19.990 --> 00:27:23.630
experience to be able to
provide that support.

460
00:27:23.630 --> 00:27:30.590
And it's not just about support, it's
about build, and testing, and deploying.

461
00:27:30.590 --> 00:27:36.200
If I'm bringing my own device, then
somebody needs to check that it's okay for

462
00:27:36.200 --> 00:27:38.240
me to plug that into the network.

463
00:27:38.240 --> 00:27:41.572
Because you don't know what
I've got on my device.

464
00:27:41.572 --> 00:27:45.210
I might have a very good
detection tool on my device.

465
00:27:46.860 --> 00:27:49.596
And now you see my device plugged
into the network here and

466
00:27:49.596 --> 00:27:51.140
now you're worried and I know.

467
00:27:51.140 --> 00:27:55.125
[LAUGH] But
I might have a very good detection tool.

468
00:27:55.125 --> 00:27:57.511
I might have all sorts
of things on my device.

469
00:27:57.511 --> 00:28:02.345
So this is what desktop support
should be doing now is they should

470
00:28:02.345 --> 00:28:07.088
be moving with the 21st century and
providing the building,

471
00:28:07.088 --> 00:28:11.311
and the testing, and
the deployment of these devices.

472
00:28:11.311 --> 00:28:17.037
But also the supporting too, including
connectivity support as we say here for

473
00:28:17.037 --> 00:28:20.210
a lot of mobile users or home users.

474
00:28:20.210 --> 00:28:23.347
Nowadays a lot of people are working
from home and we can do that.

475
00:28:23.347 --> 00:28:29.749
We have the right amount of technology now
to be able to be in the office virtually.

476
00:28:31.370 --> 00:28:34.650
So the last thing that I want to cover
in this particular section before

477
00:28:34.650 --> 00:28:40.030
we move on to other activities in
the next section is middleware.

478
00:28:40.030 --> 00:28:44.440
Middleware is bit of an ambiguous one
cuz as it says here middleware is that

479
00:28:44.440 --> 00:28:48.990
software that integrates software
components across disparate applications.

480
00:28:50.760 --> 00:28:53.440
Sometimes we let our
server guys manage this.

481
00:28:54.700 --> 00:28:58.220
Sometimes depending on the organization
we've got a separate team to manage this.

482
00:28:59.360 --> 00:29:01.980
Sometimes, we let our desktop
support guys manage this.

483
00:29:03.120 --> 00:29:06.220
Sometimes we let our
application guys manage this.

484
00:29:08.080 --> 00:29:09.936
It really is down to the organization.

485
00:29:09.936 --> 00:29:14.173
There is no right or
wrong way to do middleware support.

486
00:29:14.173 --> 00:29:19.324
However we have to acknowledge that
middleware support is very very important

487
00:29:19.324 --> 00:29:24.017
because when it comes to detection and
resolving incidences.

488
00:29:24.017 --> 00:29:28.965
When it comes to incident management
middleware is the gray ambiguous area in

489
00:29:28.965 --> 00:29:30.530
the middle.

490
00:29:30.530 --> 00:29:35.720
Where there is quite often contention
over who takes responsibility for it.

491
00:29:35.720 --> 00:29:40.830
This is where we see incidents
being passed around from

492
00:29:40.830 --> 00:29:43.120
one support team to another.

493
00:29:43.120 --> 00:29:47.515
It's not a server issue,
it's actually a software issue.

494
00:29:47.515 --> 00:29:49.595
And then it goes to
the application team and

495
00:29:49.595 --> 00:29:54.365
the application team says, it's not an
application issue, it's a network issue.

496
00:29:54.365 --> 00:29:56.451
And then it goes to the network guys, and

497
00:29:56.451 --> 00:29:58.482
then they throw it back
to the server guys.

498
00:29:58.482 --> 00:30:02.411
And before you know it,
this incident has been passed around for

499
00:30:02.411 --> 00:30:07.307
three hours, and we've got a four hour
service level target on that incident.

500
00:30:07.307 --> 00:30:13.234
So the real advice, best advice that I can
give anyone when it comes to middleware

501
00:30:13.234 --> 00:30:19.641
management, is make sure you have very
distinctive roles and responsibilities.

502
00:30:19.641 --> 00:30:24.610
We don't care where middleware sits,
we don't care if you have a separate team.

503
00:30:24.610 --> 00:30:26.090
You can put it in with the service.

504
00:30:26.090 --> 00:30:28.450
You can put it in with desktop support.

505
00:30:28.450 --> 00:30:31.130
But please make sure that
you have the right roles and

506
00:30:31.130 --> 00:30:36.910
responsibilities to avoid
what we call incident tennis.

507
00:30:36.910 --> 00:30:42.244
Yeah, we don't need that incident being
batted around from one team to the next.

508
00:30:42.244 --> 00:30:47.665
We need to have direct responsibility for
any particular incident.

509
00:30:47.665 --> 00:30:50.810
So that it can be managed
through to resolution.

510
00:30:50.810 --> 00:30:53.078
>> All right, Jo, well thank you again for

511
00:30:53.078 --> 00:30:56.970
helping us with some of these common
service operation activities.

512
00:30:56.970 --> 00:31:02.030
That we should all consider as we continue
forward in our knowledge in ITIL.

513
00:31:02.030 --> 00:31:04.710
Well a lot of these activities that we
looked at really evolve around that word

514
00:31:04.710 --> 00:31:05.890
management, as well.

515
00:31:05.890 --> 00:31:09.702
Which means decision making activities
are also gonna to be here, too.

516
00:31:09.702 --> 00:31:12.920
But there's more, of course,
of these activities to come.

517
00:31:12.920 --> 00:31:16.000
So we're going to save that for
another part, as well.

518
00:31:16.000 --> 00:31:20.940
But, for this episode, signing off for
ITPRO.TV, I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

519
00:31:20.940 --> 00:31:22.152
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

520
00:31:22.152 --> 00:31:27.266
>> Stay tuned right here for more ITIL
intermediate service operation shows.

521
00:31:27.266 --> 00:31:33.330
[MUSIC]

522
00:31:33.330 --> 00:31:36.139
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with some of the common service operation activities.  This time, Jo take a look across the different processes and shows how integral service operation activities are woven through every process in the ITIL lifecycle.  The following activities are mentioned: Internet/Web Management, Facilities and Datacenter Management, change management, service asset & configuration management, Release and Deployment Management, capacity management, demand management and  availability management.
episodes.title: Common Service Operation Activities Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:02.745
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.745 --> 00:00:05.455
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.455 --> 00:00:08.327
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.327 --> 00:00:12.275
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.275 --> 00:00:15.355
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.355 --> 00:00:19.445
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Operation show.

7
00:00:19.445 --> 00:00:20.845
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:20.845 --> 00:00:26.155
And today we're diving into a another part
on common service operation activities.

9
00:00:26.155 --> 00:00:30.638
And this time, with, of course, the
mastermind of ITIL herself, Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:30.638 --> 00:00:32.497
Jo, welcome back to the show,
how's it going?

11
00:00:32.497 --> 00:00:34.554
>> Thank you Ronnie,
it's fine, pleased to be here.

12
00:00:34.554 --> 00:00:35.750
How are you?

13
00:00:35.750 --> 00:00:38.630
>> I am doing fine as we continue on with

14
00:00:38.630 --> 00:00:41.000
taking a look at some of
these different activities.

15
00:00:41.000 --> 00:00:42.730
We've already hit a lot of them.

16
00:00:42.730 --> 00:00:46.150
And Jo I think you've warned me that
there's actually quite a bit of these for

17
00:00:46.150 --> 00:00:47.180
us to cover.

18
00:00:47.180 --> 00:00:52.030
So let's get started and take a look
at what we actually need to see.

19
00:00:52.030 --> 00:00:57.970
>> Okay, so we are in part two of
the service operation activities and

20
00:00:57.970 --> 00:01:00.362
we're going to continue
looking at the activity.

21
00:01:00.362 --> 00:01:04.621
Sort of starting off where we left it off
yesterday, in the last session sorry,

22
00:01:04.621 --> 00:01:08.761
and then we are going to start looking
at some of the relationships between

23
00:01:08.761 --> 00:01:09.724
the processes.

24
00:01:09.724 --> 00:01:14.124
In the previous session I mentioned
that some of these activities

25
00:01:14.124 --> 00:01:16.770
are performed by specific processes.

26
00:01:16.770 --> 00:01:19.870
So we're going to start off
looking at those processes.

27
00:01:19.870 --> 00:01:23.694
And then again, in our next
session which would be part three,

28
00:01:23.694 --> 00:01:26.508
we'll carry on looking
at those processes and

29
00:01:26.508 --> 00:01:30.130
what activities are performed
within service operation.

30
00:01:30.130 --> 00:01:31.095
So just recap,

31
00:01:31.095 --> 00:01:36.245
the service operation lifecycle phase is
the business as usual lifecycle phase.

32
00:01:36.245 --> 00:01:39.442
So this is where we are delivering and
maintaining and

33
00:01:39.442 --> 00:01:43.570
running those services in
that live environment.

34
00:01:43.570 --> 00:01:48.920
So, the next section then that we are
going to look at really is the activities

35
00:01:48.920 --> 00:01:54.130
that are contained within
the Internet/Web management arena.

36
00:01:54.130 --> 00:01:58.224
You might have a different team
that manages your Internet or

37
00:01:58.224 --> 00:01:59.838
your intranet as well.

38
00:01:59.838 --> 00:02:01.890
And you might even have two teams.

39
00:02:01.890 --> 00:02:06.570
You might have one team that looks at
intranet and manages all of the services

40
00:02:06.570 --> 00:02:11.410
on the intranet, including things like
the service catalog, for instance.

41
00:02:11.410 --> 00:02:15.900
You might have a separate team
that manages the Internet,

42
00:02:15.900 --> 00:02:22.652
which is the external web page that
your external customers will look at.

43
00:02:22.652 --> 00:02:24.510
One thing's very,

44
00:02:24.510 --> 00:02:29.500
very clear though, you need to have
a standard for web development.

45
00:02:29.500 --> 00:02:30.780
Because you have to have a brand.

46
00:02:30.780 --> 00:02:32.590
You have to have a brand image.

47
00:02:32.590 --> 00:02:36.225
And it doesn't matter what
size organization you are and

48
00:02:36.225 --> 00:02:41.705
what arena you're in, what industry sector
you're in, you have to have a brand image.

49
00:02:41.705 --> 00:02:43.265
And that's really important.

50
00:02:43.265 --> 00:02:45.119
There has to be that consistency.

51
00:02:45.119 --> 00:02:48.602
And it's something that even very,
very small organizations,

52
00:02:48.602 --> 00:02:53.020
I mentioned in the last section,
you might have a chain of coffee shops.

53
00:02:53.020 --> 00:02:57.040
Even a chain of coffee shops has
a logo and has a brand image.

54
00:02:57.040 --> 00:03:01.200
And so that's something that we have
to carry through to our Internet sites.

55
00:03:01.200 --> 00:03:06.073
And whether it be an Internet site for
external customers or

56
00:03:06.073 --> 00:03:10.561
whether it be an intranet site for
our internal teams.

57
00:03:10.561 --> 00:03:14.700
Nevertheless, we still need to have
a brand image in our standards.

58
00:03:14.700 --> 00:03:18.860
This is gonna be the look and
feel of our Internet site, okay.

59
00:03:18.860 --> 00:03:23.250
I mean,
even here at ITProTV we've got a logo.

60
00:03:23.250 --> 00:03:25.330
So, we have this brand image and

61
00:03:25.330 --> 00:03:29.740
that's what we've got to maintain
within this particular team.

62
00:03:29.740 --> 00:03:33.780
There's nothing wrong with using
an external organization to

63
00:03:33.780 --> 00:03:36.595
help us with this and
a lot of organizations do that.

64
00:03:36.595 --> 00:03:39.565
Then it's just an external
service provider as we call it.

65
00:03:39.565 --> 00:03:44.953
And supply management will mange that
particular contract with that supplier or

66
00:03:44.953 --> 00:03:45.910
that vendor.

67
00:03:47.098 --> 00:03:49.940
What's very key is that we've gotta
work with application management,

68
00:03:49.940 --> 00:03:52.320
we've gotta work with
technical management teams.

69
00:03:52.320 --> 00:03:55.149
And we've also gotta work
with our business as well.

70
00:03:55.149 --> 00:04:00.165
A business will take accountability for
what they want to

71
00:04:00.165 --> 00:04:05.086
see on the Internet,
the external view of our website.

72
00:04:05.086 --> 00:04:09.694
That really is down to the marketing teams
within the organization as to what they

73
00:04:09.694 --> 00:04:12.080
want to show the world as a business view.

74
00:04:13.090 --> 00:04:19.200
IT will take leadership of what
is to be seen on the intranet.

75
00:04:19.200 --> 00:04:25.426
Now, we may have a separate intranet
team that will actually look at IT's,

76
00:04:25.426 --> 00:04:29.415
how do I say,
IT's delivery into the business or

77
00:04:29.415 --> 00:04:33.330
it may just be something
that we do internally.

78
00:04:33.330 --> 00:04:37.905
Perhaps by service catalog management
because the service catalog is

79
00:04:37.905 --> 00:04:40.856
going to be a key part
of that intranet site.

80
00:04:40.856 --> 00:04:45.368
Either way we look at it, and
we're in the 21st century now and

81
00:04:45.368 --> 00:04:50.220
there are not many organizations out
there that don't have an Internet site.

82
00:04:51.550 --> 00:04:56.305
Even small, independent businesses
where you have independent consultants,

83
00:04:56.305 --> 00:04:59.650
they generally got their
own Internet site.

84
00:04:59.650 --> 00:05:08.040
So this is becoming more of
an importance to a lot of organizations.

85
00:05:08.040 --> 00:05:11.220
Because it's not just enough that
we have that Internet site, but

86
00:05:11.220 --> 00:05:12.969
we have to keep it maintained as well.

87
00:05:14.020 --> 00:05:15.970
So that means maintaining content.

88
00:05:15.970 --> 00:05:19.270
It means ensuring that
content is up to date and

89
00:05:19.270 --> 00:05:22.670
that we have the right information
in the content as well.

90
00:05:22.670 --> 00:05:26.030
There's a difference between
keeping what we have up to date and

91
00:05:26.030 --> 00:05:30.420
then adding in new content and
keeping our relevance up to date as well.

92
00:05:32.600 --> 00:05:37.110
So then another activity then we have,
now this sits within

93
00:05:37.110 --> 00:05:41.710
our IT operations function itself,
our functional area.

94
00:05:41.710 --> 00:05:45.380
We have data center management,
and facilities management.

95
00:05:45.380 --> 00:05:49.540
Now you will see that we're talking about
management of the physical environment.

96
00:05:49.540 --> 00:05:51.210
We're talking about buildings management.

97
00:05:51.210 --> 00:05:53.480
We're talking about
data center management.

98
00:05:53.480 --> 00:05:58.010
We're talking about equipment,
we're talking about power and UPSs and

99
00:05:58.010 --> 00:06:02.240
environmental conditions,
like air conditioning, etc.

100
00:06:02.240 --> 00:06:08.019
And people say to me, quite often I
get asked, why is facilities in IT?

101
00:06:10.153 --> 00:06:13.353
Well, I always refer them
back to service strategy and

102
00:06:13.353 --> 00:06:17.970
service design where we actually
identify the components of a service.

103
00:06:17.970 --> 00:06:22.882
And the components of a service are all
of those configuration items that make up

104
00:06:22.882 --> 00:06:27.220
a service that quite simply we
couldn't have a service without them.

105
00:06:27.220 --> 00:06:32.215
So service is a means of delivering value
by facilitating outcomes the customers

106
00:06:32.215 --> 00:06:36.410
want to achieve without the ownership
of specific costs and risks.

107
00:06:36.410 --> 00:06:38.840
That's the ITIL definition
of this service.

108
00:06:38.840 --> 00:06:43.960
In other words, we want to deliver value,
we want to facilitate an outcome,

109
00:06:43.960 --> 00:06:46.681
that outcome being is that, let's say for

110
00:06:46.681 --> 00:06:50.160
example, I want to enable our
business to send and receive email.

111
00:06:51.790 --> 00:06:55.717
So let me ask you Ronnie then, if I
want to enable our business to send and

112
00:06:55.717 --> 00:06:59.546
receive email, what do they need in
order to send and receive email?

113
00:06:59.546 --> 00:07:03.391
>> I need at least an email server-
>> Okay yeah.

114
00:07:03.391 --> 00:07:05.859
>> To do that and
then an Internet connection.

115
00:07:05.859 --> 00:07:06.921
>> Yeah.

116
00:07:06.921 --> 00:07:09.380
>> They're going to be sending it
across the Internet and the network.

117
00:07:09.380 --> 00:07:13.070
>> Right, but
don't they need a PC as well?

118
00:07:13.070 --> 00:07:14.810
>> Yes they need something to be received.

119
00:07:14.810 --> 00:07:16.032
To be able to receive the emails on.

120
00:07:16.032 --> 00:07:17.066
>> Right, okay.

121
00:07:17.066 --> 00:07:19.294
So they need a PC, and
they need the software.

122
00:07:19.294 --> 00:07:21.272
So they need the infrastructure too.

123
00:07:21.272 --> 00:07:23.125
They need the server,
they need the network.

124
00:07:23.125 --> 00:07:25.469
They also need somebody to install it for
them.

125
00:07:25.469 --> 00:07:28.887
>> Yes, somebody to manage it,
somebody to install it.

126
00:07:28.887 --> 00:07:33.460
>> Yeah, somebody to be there
when something goes wrong, yeah.

127
00:07:33.460 --> 00:07:37.080
They need something else as well though,
something that's really, really important.

128
00:07:37.080 --> 00:07:40.450
Without which I can't send and
receive email and

129
00:07:40.450 --> 00:07:42.720
it's the one thing that we all forget.

130
00:07:42.720 --> 00:07:44.370
>> I've forgotten it too, so.

131
00:07:44.370 --> 00:07:48.400
>> Well,
I've got a cable here right in my hand.

132
00:07:48.400 --> 00:07:50.845
Now, if I didn't have this cable,

133
00:07:50.845 --> 00:07:56.071
how long do you think I would have that
ability to send and receive email for?

134
00:07:56.071 --> 00:08:00.448
As long as, just to your machine?

135
00:08:00.448 --> 00:08:01.318
>> Yeah.
[CROSSTALK]

136
00:08:01.318 --> 00:08:03.144
>> Okay, just to your machine as

137
00:08:03.144 --> 00:08:05.272
long as your battery will hold up.

138
00:08:05.272 --> 00:08:08.993
>> Exactly right, I need power.

139
00:08:08.993 --> 00:08:13.469
So people say to me,
that question, again, which is,

140
00:08:13.469 --> 00:08:17.980
why is facilities management
part of the IT service?

141
00:08:17.980 --> 00:08:23.050
Well because quite simply, if I don't have
power, I can't send and receive an email.

142
00:08:24.170 --> 00:08:27.990
If our servers don't have power,
we can't send and receive emails.

143
00:08:27.990 --> 00:08:32.740
If I don't have a desk to sit at,
then I can't send and receive an email.

144
00:08:32.740 --> 00:08:36.615
Well, I can, all right, technically,
I can go and stand in a parking lot and

145
00:08:36.615 --> 00:08:38.358
I can send as many emails as I like.

146
00:08:38.358 --> 00:08:42.660
[LAUGH] But trust me, I'm gonna get
very tired of that very, very quickly.

147
00:08:42.660 --> 00:08:45.597
And again, my batteries are only
gonna hold out for so long.

148
00:08:45.597 --> 00:08:50.397
So yes, it's really important
that we bring this into IT,

149
00:08:50.397 --> 00:08:55.197
because it's a very important
component of a service, and

150
00:08:55.197 --> 00:08:59.860
without it, we can't send and
receive email.

151
00:08:59.860 --> 00:09:05.803
And if we take that component and
we give it to somebody else to manage,

152
00:09:05.803 --> 00:09:11.948
then we have to have a very,
very good relationship with that supplier,

153
00:09:11.948 --> 00:09:16.204
to ensure that we do get
a consistency in service.

154

380
00:24:43.670 --> 00:24:48.050
So, as it says here, rescheduling
a workload to run at a different time or

381
00:24:48.050 --> 00:24:52.170
moving a service from one
physical component to another, or

382
00:24:52.170 --> 00:24:54.080
maybe even virtualization.

383
00:24:54.080 --> 00:24:59.920
It's all about controlling demand and it's
all about influencing behavior as we say.

384
00:24:59.920 --> 00:25:03.945
So it's one way to meet
capacity requirements.

385
00:25:03.945 --> 00:25:09.780
And our operations guys, they need to
be completely conversant with that.

386
00:25:09.780 --> 00:25:11.470
Completely conversant.

387
00:25:11.470 --> 00:25:14.290
So these are the guys that
are going to be doing this.

388
00:25:15.690 --> 00:25:21.062
Now I promised you that that was going
to be the last slide in this section,

389
00:25:21.062 --> 00:25:22.065
but I lied.

390
00:25:22.065 --> 00:25:26.750
[LAUGH] Because I want to bring
in availability management,

391
00:25:26.750 --> 00:25:28.950
just while we're talking about capacity.

392
00:25:30.120 --> 00:25:34.830
Cuz availability management is another one
of these warranty processes that we find

393
00:25:34.830 --> 00:25:41.190
in service design where we are planning
for the availability of our services.

394
00:25:42.280 --> 00:25:47.660
Here we are identifying potential points
of failure on our infrastructure and

395
00:25:47.660 --> 00:25:48.974
with our service.

396
00:25:48.974 --> 00:25:54.240
And we are performing risk management,
and ascertaining whether we

397
00:25:54.240 --> 00:26:00.435
need to add in mitigation against a risk
or maybe against the impact of a risk.

398
00:26:00.435 --> 00:26:03.714
So this is where we talk about
things like resilience and

399
00:26:03.714 --> 00:26:07.207
adding in redundancy options.

400
00:26:07.207 --> 00:26:11.417
And we perform techniques such as
service failure, impact analysis, or

401
00:26:11.417 --> 00:26:16.117
component failure impact analysis, or
even a technical observation post which I

402
00:26:16.117 --> 00:26:21.938
mentioned in a previous session, which we
use within problem management as well.

403
00:26:21.938 --> 00:26:26.068
And these techniques will just
help us identify failures.

404
00:26:26.068 --> 00:26:30.590
And then utilizing analysis techniques and
looking at the risk and

405
00:26:30.590 --> 00:26:36.001
the vulnerabilities or the likelihood or
probability of that risk happening,

406
00:26:36.001 --> 00:26:40.544
then we'll identify what redundancy,
if any, we need to put in.

407
00:26:40.544 --> 00:26:45.735
And so this is tied hand-in-hand
with capacity because, you see,

408
00:26:45.735 --> 00:26:50.220
we do these modeling exercises
within capacity, what if.

409
00:26:50.220 --> 00:26:52.430
We do this, too,
within availability management.

410
00:26:52.430 --> 00:26:55.060
What if this particular component failed?

411
00:26:55.060 --> 00:27:00.090
What if we run out of space on this
particular server then what would we do?

412
00:27:01.160 --> 00:27:05.880
Could we go to say chi out services for
the remaining space, etc.

413
00:27:07.040 --> 00:27:11.640
So availability management and capacity
management are also tied hand-in-hand and

414
00:27:11.640 --> 00:27:17.280
yet again, we need that technical
experience from our operations guys.

415
00:27:17.280 --> 00:27:20.764
These guys that I've been talking about,
this operations team,

416
00:27:20.764 --> 00:27:23.587
they're absolutely amazing
when you think about it.

417
00:27:23.587 --> 00:27:27.207
There's not one process
within service operation and

418
00:27:27.207 --> 00:27:30.754
within ITIL that they don't
have an involvement in.

419
00:27:30.754 --> 00:27:34.913
You think about it, and the more you think
about it the more you realize just how

420
00:27:34.913 --> 00:27:36.690
many skills they do really have.

421
00:27:36.690 --> 00:27:41.615
>> And Jo, the more that you talk about
this, the more that, at least for

422
00:27:41.615 --> 00:27:44.454
someone new like me to the realm of ITIL,

423
00:27:44.454 --> 00:27:49.148
I begin to see that service operations
in function or its process.

424
00:27:49.148 --> 00:27:52.822
And what it's doing actually does seem to
expand the entirety of the life cycle of

425
00:27:52.822 --> 00:27:54.290
ITIL and what we have.

426
00:27:54.290 --> 00:27:57.740
So it's really neat to see all
these different activities

427
00:27:57.740 --> 00:27:59.570
that we can see and do right here.

428
00:27:59.570 --> 00:28:02.190
So anything else you wanna
add in this episode or

429
00:28:02.190 --> 00:28:04.870
is that what we have for right now?

430
00:28:04.870 --> 00:28:09.268
>> No, I'm going to save that for
another episode.

431
00:28:09.268 --> 00:28:12.202
I think what we do is we just
build up some anticipation there.

432
00:28:12.202 --> 00:28:14.470
>> All right, that sounds great.

433
00:28:14.470 --> 00:28:17.850
Remember that that's what you're taking
a look at here is more different common

434
00:28:17.850 --> 00:28:19.380
service operation activities.

435
00:28:19.380 --> 00:28:23.430
But this time, take a look at it from
across the different processes that we do

436
00:28:23.430 --> 00:28:27.670
see and the entirety of the ITIL life
cycle that is right there for you.

437
00:28:27.670 --> 00:28:31.296
But there is more to come, just like
Jo teased right there at the end.

438
00:28:31.296 --> 00:28:33.140
So, you wanna stick around for
that as well, but for

439
00:28:33.140 --> 00:28:37.760
this episode, signing off for
ITProTV, I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

440
00:28:37.760 --> 00:28:38.618
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

441
00:28:38.618 --> 00:28:43.474
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation shows.

442
00:28:43.474 --> 00:28:49.450
[MUSIC]

443
00:28:49.450 --> 00:28:51.962
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

444

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo dive into some of the remaining activities recommended by ITIL.  Jo mentions the key to keeping good service operations is making sure the communication between teams are effective and efficient as they perform activities that help the service provide value to the business.  She mentions that a great inefficiency that occurs between team is when the communication between them fails when working through a process.  The following processes were also mentioned: knowledge management should result DIKW (data to information to knowledge to wisdom), Financial Management for IT services (capex and opex), IT Service Continuity Management (Proactive) and IT Security Management
episodes.title: Common Service Operation Activities Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

Welcome to IT pro TV.

2
00:00:01.250 --> 00:00:08.252
I'm your host-
>> [CROSSTALK]

00:00:11.549 --> 00:00:15.280
>> Welcome to another great

it's good to be back.

00:00:37.350 --> 00:00:38.460

as we are continuing on with more of these

16

In the previous episode, it was really

21

involvement within those processes.

23
00:01:09.390 --> 00:01:12.410
But as you quite rightly mentioned,
service operation,

24
00:01:12.410 --> 00:01:14.440
these are the people that
are actually doing all the work.

25
00:01:14.440 --> 00:01:16.860
So all of the processes that we have,

26
00:01:16.860 --> 00:01:22.660
the 26 processes that we have within ITIL,
well, these guys perform all of them.

27
00:01:22.660 --> 00:01:27.750
And a process is just a set of activities
that takes a defined input and

28
00:01:27.750 --> 00:01:33.420

29
00:01:33.420 --> 00:01:36.490
So these are the guys that have
got all the technical skills and

30
00:01:36.490 --> 00:01:40.070
the expertise to be able

00:01:40.070 --> 00:01:42.160

32

We are in the service operations.

33
00:01:43.530 --> 00:01:45.260
We are in the business as usual.

34
00:01:45.260 --> 00:01:49.160
So of course all of these processes
are part of business as usual.

35
00:01:49.160 --> 00:01:51.970
You know having a project

36
00:01:51.970 --> 00:01:52.900
>> Right.
>> Managing and

37
00:01:52.900 --> 00:01:55.420

38

The fact that people
are talking to customers and

41
00:02:05.435 --> 00:02:11.318
It's something that happens, business as

42
00:02:11.318 --> 00:02:16.120
>> All right, Jo, so let's go ahead and
take a look at these three processes here.

43
00:02:16.120 --> 00:02:18.090
Help us out,
what are we gonna take a look at first?

44
00:02:18.090 --> 00:02:20.450
>> Okay, well, first of all, we're gonna
take a look at knowledge management.

45
00:02:21.470 --> 00:02:25.710
Now, I've mentioned in previous
sessions that knowledge management

46
00:02:25.710 --> 00:02:28.830
is about insuring that the right
information is available at the right

47
00:02:28.830 --> 00:02:31.000
time to enable informed decision making,
okay?

48
00:02:32.140 --> 00:02:33.490
What does that mean?

49
00:02:33.490 --> 00:02:37.870
I want to bring your attention to the last
bullet point on this slide, actually.

50
00:02:37.870 --> 00:02:42.800
And we have words there, and
we call this our DIKW model, Data,

51
00:02:42.800 --> 00:02:44.480
Information, Knowledge, and Wisdom.

52
00:02:45.560 --> 00:02:50.870
What this actually means is that we start
off with individual data sources and

53
00:02:50.870 --> 00:02:53.250
with individual pieces of data.

54
00:02:53.250 --> 00:02:59.040
But to be fair, individual pieces of
data can only tell us so much, okay?

55
00:02:59.040 --> 00:03:02.790
I know that the component that I

56
00:03:02.790 --> 00:03:06.790
have right in front of me
right now is a Mac Book, okay?

57
00:03:06.790 --> 00:03:11.620
It's a Mac Book, that is the component
that I have in front of me, okay?

58
00:03:11.620 --> 00:03:17.620
But that's all I have is just that piece
of data about that particular component.

59
00:03:17.620 --> 00:03:21.650
But if I add in relationships
between my components, because

60
00:03:21.650 --> 00:03:26.350
another component would be the network
that we're on, that's another component.

61
00:03:26.350 --> 00:03:31.040
Another component would be the software,
the services that I use.

62
00:03:31.040 --> 00:03:34.600
And if I add in relationships
between those data sources,

63
00:03:34.600 --> 00:03:38.340
then that relationship allows
me to have information.

64
00:03:38.340 --> 00:03:42.570
Because the relationships will tell me
that now that this MacBook Pro uses

65
00:03:42.570 --> 00:03:45.890
these services, xyz services,

66
00:03:45.890 --> 00:03:51.800
to which I have these licenses for and
I sit on this portion of the network.

67
00:03:51.800 --> 00:03:54.660
And that gives me information.

68
00:03:54.660 --> 00:03:57.840
Now, I can do a lot with information
because I can analyze information.

69
00:03:57.840 --> 00:03:59.890
And that's what gives me the knowledge.

70
00:03:59.890 --> 00:04:05.980
And we generally display that analysis by
way of a nice, pretty picture or a graph.

71
00:04:05.980 --> 00:04:11.190
But no matter how we display it,
when we display knowledge, when we analyze

72
00:04:11.190 --> 00:04:16.280
that to give us knowledge, it's with
the intent of making an informed decision.

73
00:04:16.280 --> 00:04:20.670
And that's where we get
the wisdom from in that DIKW.

74
00:04:20.670 --> 00:04:23.030
It's with the intent of
making an informed decision.

75
00:04:23.030 --> 00:04:27.670
I mentioned in a previous section
about the fact that in IT,

76
00:04:27.670 --> 00:04:32.540
we have, well, reports just for
the sake of reports.

77
00:04:32.540 --> 00:04:35.815
I mean,
sometimes some organizations I've been in,

78
00:04:35.815 --> 00:04:39.670
I'm just fed up with seeing reports
that nobody ever refers to.

79
00:04:39.670 --> 00:04:46.310
And so we'll tell you that if you
can't make an informed decision, then

80
00:04:46.310 --> 00:04:51.190
that report, you have to really go and
understand the relevance of that report.

81
00:04:51.190 --> 00:04:53.434
Because if it doesn't allow
you make an informed decision,

82
00:04:53.434 --> 00:04:54.844
then what actually is it telling you?

83
00:04:56.295 --> 00:04:56.891
>> Yeah.
>> So

84
00:04:56.891 --> 00:05:00.998
what does service operation have
to do with knowledge management?

85
00:05:00.998 --> 00:05:04.730
Well, service operation,
they maintain the data sources.

86
00:05:04.730 --> 00:05:06.790
Think about database administration.

87
00:05:06.790 --> 00:05:10.350
But it's not just about DBAs,
it's also about all of our

88
00:05:10.350 --> 00:05:14.320
other data sources like our servers,
for instance, our network.

89
00:05:14.320 --> 00:05:18.170
The configuration management
system records all

90
00:05:18.170 --> 00:05:21.540
of the data about our infrastructure and

91
00:05:21.540 --> 00:05:25.020
what is on our infrastructure and
what our components are.

92
00:05:25.020 --> 00:05:28.000
And if you looked at the last
sections that we did,

00:05:28.000 --> 00:05:32.180
you'll notice that we had a reference to

94
00:05:32.180 --> 00:05:36.610
the fact that these service operations
guys have got a responsibility

95
00:05:36.610 --> 00:05:39.660
to keep that accurate and
to keep it up to date.

96
00:05:39.660 --> 00:05:42.170
So, it all ties in.

97
00:05:42.170 --> 00:05:45.870
And I love, and
maybe there's something wrong with me.

98
00:05:45.870 --> 00:05:47.797
I will admit this, okay?

99
00:05:47.797 --> 00:05:53.510
But I really love when I go into
an organization in a consultancy role and

100
00:05:53.510 --> 00:05:56.360
analyze the relationships
between their processes.

101
00:05:57.650 --> 00:06:04.060
Because it's quite often the relationships
between the processes that don't work.

102
00:06:04.060 --> 00:06:07.420
And that is what causes inefficiencies.

103
00:06:07.420 --> 00:06:09.500
It's not the fact that they don't have,
say,

104
00:06:09.500 --> 00:06:11.600
an incident management process in place.

105
00:06:11.600 --> 00:06:14.880
It's that they have an incident
management process in place, but

106
00:06:14.880 --> 00:06:17.700
it is completely separate to
the change management process and

107
00:06:17.700 --> 00:06:20.970
completely separate to
configuration management.

108
00:06:20.970 --> 00:06:24.630
And so that leads to inefficiencies.

109
00:06:26.100 --> 00:06:30.490
And I love when we do these
particular sections in classes,

110
00:06:30.490 --> 00:06:34.570
and we look at the relationships between
those processes, because without

111
00:06:34.570 --> 00:06:38.810
these relationships relationships,
then quite simply we can't be efficient.

112
00:06:38.810 --> 00:06:42.990
And without that understanding
that the service operations guys,

113
00:06:42.990 --> 00:06:47.210
the guys that sit here in our
business as usual environment,

114
00:06:47.210 --> 00:06:50.380
these are the guys that are doing
all of these processes.

115
00:06:50.380 --> 00:06:54.580
You don't just have one
particular process to perform.

116
00:06:54.580 --> 00:06:58.640
Throughout the day I might
perform bits of, say,

117
00:06:58.640 --> 00:07:03.010
15 processes, and I'll perform
different activities within each one.

118
00:07:03.010 --> 00:07:07.940
And sometimes I'm even performing
three processes at the same time.

119
00:07:07.940 --> 00:07:11.450
If I'm updating information in
Configuration Management System,

120
00:07:11.450 --> 00:07:15.380
I am performing configuration or
service asset in Configuration Management,

121
00:07:15.380 --> 00:07:16.900
as we call it in ITIL.

122
00:07:16.900 --> 00:07:19.590
I'm performing that, but
I'm also performing knowledge management,

123
00:07:19.590 --> 00:07:22.550
too, just simply by updating data.

124
00:07:22.550 --> 00:07:26.260
I'm keeping the data up-to-date,
and I'm performing two processes.

125
00:07:26.260 --> 00:07:28.080
And we don't often realize that.

126
00:07:28.080 --> 00:07:33.790
So I, yeah, okay, I'll admit that maybe
it makes me a little bit of a nerd.

127
00:07:33.790 --> 00:07:37.359
But I like analyzing the relationships
between those processes.

128
00:07:38.510 --> 00:07:42.900
And the next process is
one that is despised,

129
00:07:43.910 --> 00:07:48.990
overlooked sometimes, considered
to be a necessary evil within IT.

130
00:07:50.240 --> 00:07:52.006
But it's financial management.

131
00:07:52.006 --> 00:07:55.140
We sometimes see that
abbreviated as FM for IT.

132
00:07:55.140 --> 00:07:58.251
FM for IT, yeah, it makes sense.

133
00:07:58.251 --> 00:08:00.100
That's the title up there.

134
00:08:00.100 --> 00:08:04.152
The financial management deals
with what we call the ABC.

135
00:08:04.152 --> 00:08:09.398
And now, I'm gonna start off with B,
because B stands for budgeting.

136
00:08:09.398 --> 00:08:13.903
And budgeting is how much
money have I got to spend.

137
00:08:13.903 --> 00:08:15.407
So we're looking into the future.

138
00:08:15.407 --> 00:08:17.390
How much I've got to spend?

139
00:08:17.390 --> 00:08:22.580
And accounting stands for how much have
I spent, so we're looking into the past.

140
00:08:22.580 --> 00:08:24.240
How much have I spent?

141
00:08:24.240 --> 00:08:27.550
And the charging, the C,
well, that's optional.

142
00:08:27.550 --> 00:08:32.524
We don't always cross-charge our
organization and cross-charge internal

143
00:08:32.524 --> 00:08:37.356
customers, but of course, we definitely
charge our external customers.

144
00:08:37.356 --> 00:08:41.274
So budgeting tells us how much we've got
to spend, and budgets are generally set.

145
00:08:41.274 --> 00:08:46.728
And I say generally, but they're generally
set based on how much money we spent so

146
00:08:46.728 --> 00:08:49.850
on our accounts for the previous year.

147
00:08:49.850 --> 00:08:52.810
That's usually how it works.

148
00:08:52.810 --> 00:08:57.145
Now, here we are in IT, and like I said,
we despise financial management.

149
00:08:57.145 --> 00:09:02.135
And to be perfectly honest, it wouldn't
be amiss of me to admit that there's

150
00:09:02.135 --> 00:09:06.315
not many of us in IT that are really
good at financial management.

151
00:09:06.315 --> 00:09:08.095
Generally, because we avoid it, I think.

152
00:09:08.095 --> 00:09:11.485
But it still exists.

153
00:09:11.485 --> 00:09:13.449
Yeah, we've still gotta have money.

154
00:09:14.710 --> 00:09:17.350
And whilst service operation,

155
00:09:17.350 --> 00:09:23.100
like everybody in IT,
we don't particular like to get involved.

156
00:09:23.100 --> 00:09:25.570
Of course, it makes sense for
us to do this.

157
00:09:25.570 --> 00:09:30.200
We have to be able to identify and
quantify,

158
00:09:30.200 --> 00:09:34.020
articulate, if you will, how much money
we spend and what we spend it on.

159
00:09:35.080 --> 00:09:40.430
Because you see, it's that, that gives
us then the budget for the next year.

160
00:09:40.430 --> 00:09:45.610
So we divide our expenditure into capital
expenditure and operational expenditure.

161
00:09:45.610 --> 00:09:49.800
Capital expenditure should be in the one
of things that we buy, like a new server,

162
00:09:49.800 --> 00:09:54.430
for instance, piece of hardware,
or even a piece of software.

163
00:09:54.430 --> 00:09:58.230
But then, operational expenditure
is something that's ongoing.

164
00:09:58.230 --> 00:10:02.930
So our utility bills are operational
expenditure, our licenses.

165
00:10:02.930 --> 00:10:06.090
If they're ongoing,
they're an operational expenditure.

166
00:10:06.090 --> 00:10:10.290
And we have to be able to articulate not
only the difference between the two but

167
00:10:10.290 --> 00:10:13.710
exactly what services we're
spending our money on.

168
00:10:13.710 --> 00:10:16.020
So bear in mind, that's not so

169
00:10:16.020 --> 00:10:21.160
easy when you consider that a lot of
the components in our services are shared.

170
00:10:22.300 --> 00:10:27.360
Yet we only have one network, and
that one network provides access and

171
00:10:27.360 --> 00:10:31.500
supporting service and provides as
a component for all of our services.

172
00:10:31.500 --> 00:10:33.705
We don't have a different network for
each service.

173
00:10:33.705 --> 00:10:38.070
So when somebody asks you,
in service strategy,

174
00:10:38.070 --> 00:10:42.410
to come up with a business case for
a new service, and

175
00:10:42.410 --> 00:10:47.020
they want to know how much it's going
to cost and then what return on

176
00:10:47.020 --> 00:10:51.880
investment they're likely to see,
that's not exactly as easy as it sounds.

177
00:10:52.970 --> 00:10:56.455
Because we have to take into
consideration all costs,

178
00:10:56.455 --> 00:11:00.025
including cost of shared
components like the network.

179
00:11:00.025 --> 00:11:02.526
So how do we work that out?

180
00:11:02.526 --> 00:11:03.161
Well, you know what?

181
00:11:03.161 --> 00:11:07.310
Our operations guys are gonna be
the people that are actually going to do

182
00:11:07.310 --> 00:11:08.360
this for us.

183
00:11:08.360 --> 00:11:13.870
Cuz these are the people that are in
at the ground doing the work.

184
00:11:13.870 --> 00:11:16.710
These are the people
that understand exactly

185
00:11:16.710 --> 00:11:19.400
what components are being
used to resolve problems.

186
00:11:19.400 --> 00:11:23.560
Exactly what components are being used
because of preventative maintenance, so

187
00:11:23.560 --> 00:11:25.630
because of scheduled upgrades, etc.

188
00:11:25.630 --> 00:11:33.920
I really like the bottom bullet point
in this particular slide, okay?

189
00:11:33.920 --> 00:11:39.010
Beware of proposed cost cutting, which
can actually increase unit support costs.

190
00:11:41.870 --> 00:11:43.950
You know the routine, right?

191
00:11:43.950 --> 00:11:48.520
We don't wanna spend money on this because
it's been working okay up until now.

192
00:11:48.520 --> 00:11:52.010
And we've had three years worth of
reliability from this particular

193
00:11:52.010 --> 00:11:56.630
component, so we have no reason to think
that it's going to fail in the future.

194
00:11:56.630 --> 00:11:58.150
And then we cut budget to it.

195
00:11:58.150 --> 00:12:01.040
And as soon as we cut the budget to it,
what happens?

196
00:12:01.040 --> 00:12:01.566
It fails.

197
00:12:01.566 --> 00:12:02.830
>> [LAUGH] Yep.

198
00:12:02.830 --> 00:12:07.813
>> And the thing is that if we'd planned
to replace that particular component,

199
00:12:07.813 --> 00:12:12.280
we probably could have
negotiated a good price for it.

200
00:12:12.280 --> 00:12:15.570
But because we waited until it failed,
it's a last minute purchase,

201
00:12:15.570 --> 00:12:17.315
there's no negotiation involved.

202
00:12:17.315 --> 00:12:22.461
So it actually costs us more, which is why
we talk about increased support costs.

203
00:12:22.461 --> 00:12:25.679
The other thing is that
we're going to have to, so

204
00:12:25.679 --> 00:12:29.910
nothing ever fails at ten o'clock
on a Monday morning, does it?

205
00:12:29.910 --> 00:12:33.220
It always fails at two o'clock
on a Sunday morning, right?

206
00:12:33.220 --> 00:12:38.130
So think about the support cost in getting
somebody in two o'clock in the morning and

207
00:12:38.130 --> 00:12:41.530
then trying to get suppliers
in at that time as well in

208
00:12:41.530 --> 00:12:44.248
order to rectify any issue
that you might have.

209
00:12:44.248 --> 00:12:47.410
Yeah, it's expensive.

210
00:12:47.410 --> 00:12:50.232
It's a bit like not getting
your car serviced, really.

211
00:12:50.232 --> 00:12:54.093
We like to try and put it off as long
as we possibly can, but we know that

212
00:12:54.093 --> 00:12:58.303
the longer we put it off, the more
damage it's doing to the engine, okay?

213
00:12:58.303 --> 00:12:59.704
And let's face it.

214
00:12:59.704 --> 00:13:04.816
If we leave it two long before we replace
the brake pads, we very, very soon,

215
00:13:04.816 --> 00:13:08.948
needs replacing the brake pads
because we won't have a car, right?

216
00:13:08.948 --> 00:13:14.271
So we have to understand that
this expenditure is required.

217
00:13:14.271 --> 00:13:19.024
But you see, our financial teams within
our organization won't necessarily

218
00:13:19.024 --> 00:13:22.170
understand that unless
we can articulate it.

219
00:13:22.170 --> 00:13:26.880
And it goes back to what I said in
a previous session about communication.

220
00:13:26.880 --> 00:13:32.626
Sometimes in IT, we're not very good
at articulating things outside of IT.

221
00:13:32.626 --> 00:13:34.650
So financial management is very important.

222
00:13:34.650 --> 00:13:38.013
It tells us how much money we've
got to spend, but in turn,

223
00:13:38.013 --> 00:13:42.952
we've got to tell financial management how
much we realistically have spent as well.

224
00:13:42.952 --> 00:13:46.204
Then I wanna bring us on to
service continuity management.

225
00:13:46.204 --> 00:13:52.518
And service continuity management,
it's not just about disaster recovery.

226
00:13:52.518 --> 00:13:54.798
Ronie, let me ask you a question, then.

227
00:13:54.798 --> 00:13:57.988
What do you think is the difference
between disaster recovery and

228
00:13:57.988 --> 00:13:59.090
service continuity?

229
00:14:00.600 --> 00:14:05.924
>> Service continuity is about
providing the ability for

230
00:14:05.924 --> 00:14:11.606
the organization to continue
even if something happens.

231
00:14:11.606 --> 00:14:14.565
Whereas disaster recovery is
something jas happened, and

232
00:14:14.565 --> 00:14:16.346
now you're recovering from that.

233
00:14:16.346 --> 00:14:18.855
>> Right, okay, yeah, I like that.

234
00:14:18.855 --> 00:14:22.139
I mean, I'd like to think that it
was fairly self-explanatory, but

235
00:14:22.139 --> 00:14:25.490
you wouldn't believe how many people
do get confused between the two.

236
00:14:26.620 --> 00:14:30.320
Disaster recovery is about picking up
the pieces after something is gone wrong,

237
00:14:30.320 --> 00:14:34.780
something major, something that the
organization considers to be a disaster.

238
00:14:34.780 --> 00:14:37.840
It's about recovering from that disaster.

239
00:14:37.840 --> 00:14:41.740
Service continuity is actually
the proactive side to that coin

240
00:14:41.740 --> 00:14:46.750
because disaster recovery is very
reactive whereas service continuity.

241
00:14:46.750 --> 00:14:48.910
Okay, we incorporate disaster recovery,
but

242
00:14:48.910 --> 00:14:51.617
what we're trying to do is keep
everything up and running.

243
00:14:51.617 --> 00:14:56.634
Let's stop it, having an impact to
the business in the first place, okay?

244
00:14:56.634 --> 00:15:01.454
So service continuity and
service operations, well,

245
00:15:01.454 --> 00:15:04.050
the two are really entwined.

246
00:15:04.050 --> 00:15:08.472
Because its these operations guys that
not only tell service continuity whats

247
00:15:08.472 --> 00:15:09.146
possible.

248
00:15:09.146 --> 00:15:12.248
Cuz sometimes, the business asks for
the impossible,

249
00:15:12.248 --> 00:15:15.000
especially given the budget that we have.

250
00:15:15.000 --> 00:15:19.376
So service continuity will ask us in
service operation what's possible.

251
00:15:19.376 --> 00:15:21.080
But these service operation guys,

252
00:15:21.080 --> 00:15:23.991
they are also the people that
carry out the risk assessment.

253
00:15:23.991 --> 00:15:27.663
These are the people with
the experience and the skills, and

254
00:15:27.663 --> 00:15:31.890
they actually write these recovery
plans and continuity plans.

255
00:15:31.890 --> 00:15:36.290
They'll advise on resilience options in
conjunction with availability management.

256
00:15:36.290 --> 00:15:38.360
We looked at that in a previous session.

257
00:15:38.360 --> 00:15:40.329
They'll also do the testing, too.

258
00:15:40.329 --> 00:15:45.400
ITIL recommends that you do a test
of service continuity at least

259
00:15:45.400 --> 00:15:49.780
once a year, and
we don't just mean a run through.

260
00:15:49.780 --> 00:15:52.723
We mean a physical test.

261
00:15:52.723 --> 00:15:57.280
That's not something most organizations
want to do because of the disruption.

262
00:15:57.280 --> 00:16:00.231
But We do need to test
our service continuity.

263
00:16:00.231 --> 00:16:03.662
And one of the things that we forget about
quite often in service continuity, and

264
00:16:03.662 --> 00:16:06.030
we'll look at this in service design.

265
00:16:06.030 --> 00:16:08.610
But one of the things that we
forget about, is actually,

266
00:16:08.610 --> 00:16:13.029
once we move to this DR site, as we
call it, we've got to get back again.

267
00:16:14.310 --> 00:16:20.160
It's not very often that we have
a mirrored server, that we can just

268
00:16:20.160 --> 00:16:25.840
flick the switch between the two, that's
a very, very expensive redundancy option.

269
00:16:25.840 --> 00:16:29.740
And so a lot of organizations don't
have that for all services, so

270
00:16:29.740 --> 00:16:32.480
we still have that concept of the DR site.

271
00:16:32.480 --> 00:16:37.500
Now with cloud technology,
service continuity has become easier.

272
00:16:37.500 --> 00:16:41.400
But really what we're doing is, we're
just transferring that risk to somebody

273
00:16:41.400 --> 00:16:44.030
else and
letting somebody else deal with it.

274
00:16:44.030 --> 00:16:47.900
Sometimes, hoping,
that they will be able to deal with it.

275
00:16:47.900 --> 00:16:50.220
But we need to have that assurance there.

276
00:16:51.820 --> 00:16:54.990
The other thing that our service
operation guys will get involved with in

277
00:16:54.990 --> 00:16:59.940
terms of service continuity is that
communication during a time of disaster.

278
00:16:59.940 --> 00:17:03.160
When something has gone wrong,

279
00:17:03.160 --> 00:17:08.230
it's the service operation guys
that carry service continuity.

280
00:17:08.230 --> 00:17:11.560
These are the people that manage
that movement over to the disaster

281
00:17:11.560 --> 00:17:12.660
recovery site.

282
00:17:12.660 --> 00:17:16.010
And these are the people that will
take over the communication, etc,

283
00:17:16.010 --> 00:17:19.800
with the business,
to tell them what's happening, okay?

284
00:17:19.800 --> 00:17:27.180
So a service continuity should be embedded
into all service operation activities.

285
00:17:28.690 --> 00:17:30.590
So what about security management.

286
00:17:30.590 --> 00:17:33.850
I know that we've addressed
security in some previous sessions.

287
00:17:35.380 --> 00:17:40.440
We also addressed sort of firewalls,
etc., on our servers or on our network.

288
00:17:42.550 --> 00:17:45.150
These are the guys that
are doing event management, so

289
00:17:45.150 --> 00:17:49.470
they're doing that monitoring and
they're doing the control as well, and so

290
00:17:49.470 --> 00:17:52.660
we should be monitoring
security activities.

291
00:17:54.220 --> 00:17:57.020
We don't just monitor people
logging in and people logging out,

292
00:17:57.020 --> 00:17:59.710
we also monitor when people
have forgotten their passwords.

293
00:18:00.710 --> 00:18:04.720
I know we covered in the previous session
when we looked at access management,

294
00:18:04.720 --> 00:18:08.410
the fact that if somebody has forgotten
their password repeatedly over a period of

295
00:18:08.410 --> 00:18:13.550
time, then maybe there is something
there that we need to investigate.

296
00:18:13.550 --> 00:18:16.860
And so, our service operations
guys are involved in this.

297
00:18:16.860 --> 00:18:20.950
They may also be doing sort of screening
and vetting and maybe doing training,

298
00:18:20.950 --> 00:18:22.280
etc., as well.

299
00:18:22.280 --> 00:18:25.540
That depends on the size of the
organization cuz some organizations have

300
00:18:25.540 --> 00:18:29.055
separate training teams within IT, so

301
00:18:29.055 --> 00:18:33.340
sits firmly within operations or
maybe even within the service desk.

302
00:18:33.340 --> 00:18:39.600
Some organizations have security in
vetting outside within the business.

303
00:18:39.600 --> 00:18:42.030
It's not necessarily within IT.

304
00:18:42.030 --> 00:18:43.840
It really depends on the organization.

305
00:18:43.840 --> 00:18:46.200
But the more secure the environment.

306
00:18:46.200 --> 00:18:49.380
So I use, for example,
government departments,

307
00:18:49.380 --> 00:18:54.700
government agencies, our military,
financial institutions.

308
00:18:54.700 --> 00:18:57.540
They are more likely to have security and

309
00:18:57.540 --> 00:19:00.970
vetting as part of the organization
rather than just being as part of IT.

310
00:19:02.330 --> 00:19:06.820
Whatever happens, we have to have
documented procedures for security, and

311
00:19:06.820 --> 00:19:11.800
they have to be adhered to by everybody,
including operations.

312
00:19:11.800 --> 00:19:14.790
Now you could argue that operations, well,

313
00:19:14.790 --> 00:19:17.650
these guys have got access
to absolutely everything.

314
00:19:17.650 --> 00:19:22.660
So therefore we have to ensure that they
have the highest security clearance and

315
00:19:22.660 --> 00:19:24.360
the highest security levels.

316
00:19:24.360 --> 00:19:29.190
Because they've got access to absolutely
everything, and they're also the guys that

317
00:19:29.190 --> 00:19:33.950
are in here at 2 o'clock in the morning
[LAUGH] doing the work as well.

318
00:19:33.950 --> 00:19:39.250
So, we need to make sure that for
their safety,

319
00:19:39.250 --> 00:19:44.030
rather than [LAUGH] anything else,
that people that have

320
00:19:44.030 --> 00:19:48.030
the access into the server, so the people
with the right security clearance.

321
00:19:49.840 --> 00:19:55.160
So that just leads us onto the improvement
of operational activities.

322
00:19:55.160 --> 00:20:00.165
And the last bullet point there is one
that's in big, bold, capital letters.

323
00:20:00.165 --> 00:20:01.795
And it talks about communication.

324
00:20:01.795 --> 00:20:05.255
And it talks there about education and
training, etc., too.

325
00:20:06.465 --> 00:20:09.385
I've mentioned throughout
these last three sessions,

326
00:20:09.385 --> 00:20:12.995
part one, two and three,
the importance of communication.

327
00:20:12.995 --> 00:20:17.275
And about the fact that we in IT
are really good at talking to each other.

328
00:20:17.275 --> 00:20:19.560
We're good at talking amongst ourselves.

329
00:20:19.560 --> 00:20:21.290
But when it comes to
talking to the business,

330
00:20:21.290 --> 00:20:26.610
when it comes to talking to suppliers,
etc, financial management,

331
00:20:26.610 --> 00:20:33.380
we tend to try to maybe
overcompensate sometimes, I would say.

332
00:20:33.380 --> 00:20:37.350
And so, we've got to get our communication
spot on because communication

333
00:20:37.350 --> 00:20:39.370
will cause breaches in security.

334
00:20:39.370 --> 00:20:43.790
Communication or lack thereof,
will cause processes to fail,

335
00:20:43.790 --> 00:20:47.320
will cause changes to fail
when they're implemented.

336
00:20:47.320 --> 00:20:52.250
Communication really is the key
to successful IT operations, and

337
00:20:52.250 --> 00:20:56.730
to successful ITIL processes, okay?

338
00:20:56.730 --> 00:21:00.860
At worst, we might want to look at
improvement in terms of automation,

339
00:21:00.860 --> 00:21:04.980
and improvement in terms of audits,
and making sure we follow processes.

340
00:21:04.980 --> 00:21:08.130
The key to all of this has got
to be effective communication.

341
00:21:09.140 --> 00:21:14.940
>> Now Jo, you had mentioned
the idea of when you go in and

342
00:21:14.940 --> 00:21:20.310
you do some of these where you're auditing
the processes and where they fail and

343
00:21:20.310 --> 00:21:24.260
it's usually because those teams are not
able to communicate with each other.

344
00:21:24.260 --> 00:21:27.200
In ITIL, is there a particular

345
00:21:27.200 --> 00:21:31.810
process that we go through to ensure
that communication happens well or

346
00:21:31.810 --> 00:21:35.590
to better ourselves in that or is this
something outside of the scope of ITIL?

347
00:21:35.590 --> 00:21:39.430
>> We embed communication to
absolutely every process.

348
00:21:39.430 --> 00:21:43.790
And we're going to look at
the service desk in a later session.

349
00:21:43.790 --> 00:21:48.260
And the service desk is responsible for
communication to the users.

350
00:21:48.260 --> 00:21:52.970
We also have a process called business
relationship management in strategy that

351
00:21:52.970 --> 00:21:55.470
is responsible for
communication to our customers.

352
00:21:56.480 --> 00:21:58.950
And we will look at the introduction and

353
00:21:58.950 --> 00:22:01.940
the difference between a user and
a customer.

354
00:22:01.940 --> 00:22:06.870
But we do have teams and
processes that are responsible for

355
00:22:06.870 --> 00:22:09.090
communication to the business.

356
00:22:09.090 --> 00:22:14.480
Communication within IT, I would like to
hope, should be a matter of common sense.

357
00:22:14.480 --> 00:22:17.710
It should be a matter of us
getting on with each other but

358
00:22:17.710 --> 00:22:21.238
it also should be a matter of
us speaking the same language.

359
00:22:21.238 --> 00:22:24.342
And we have a process called
supply management as well,

360
00:22:24.342 --> 00:22:28.770
that is responsible for the communication
between us and our suppliers.

361
00:22:28.770 --> 00:22:32.220
So we do have processes that
take ownership of this.

362
00:22:32.220 --> 00:22:38.130
We look in the ITIL practitioners
guidance a lot more at communication and

363
00:22:38.130 --> 00:22:39.830
communication techniques and

364
00:22:39.830 --> 00:22:43.500
organizational change
management techniques as well.

365
00:22:43.500 --> 00:22:48.167
Because we have to understand that
whatever we want to do in IT,

366
00:22:48.167 --> 00:22:52.305
there may be resistance from
either the organization or

367
00:22:52.305 --> 00:22:55.843
there may be resistance
internally within IT.

368
00:22:55.843 --> 00:22:59.415
So, we do address these concerns.

369
00:22:59.415 --> 00:23:02.711
Now, we don't have,
I know I've said this previously,

370
00:23:02.711 --> 00:23:07.220
we don't have a magic wand that we
can wave over absolutely everybody.

371
00:23:07.220 --> 00:23:13.540
And you can't always deal with
interpersonal issues and conflict, etc.

372
00:23:13.540 --> 00:23:16.940
But nevertheless, there's no reason why
we can't look at conflict management

373
00:23:16.940 --> 00:23:22.445
techniques to try and ensure that we can
communicate the best way that we can.

374
00:23:22.445 --> 00:23:25.075
And I mentioned previously
that communication

375
00:23:25.075 --> 00:23:27.345
has gotta be in the language
of the audience.

376
00:23:27.345 --> 00:23:30.655
And that's the real important
part of communication.

377
00:23:30.655 --> 00:23:33.100
Understand what are your audience values.

378
00:23:33.100 --> 00:23:36.290
Whoever your audience is, whether it's a
colleague or whether it's the business or

379
00:23:36.290 --> 00:23:39.670
whether it's somebody external,
understand what's valuable to them and

380
00:23:39.670 --> 00:23:41.330
then you can communicate
in their language.

381
00:23:42.590 --> 00:23:46.720
>> All right, Jo, well thank you again for
helping us out with these

382
00:23:46.720 --> 00:23:49.660
last few processes that we're
identifying right here.

00:23:49.660 --> 00:23:53.830
And also remember that the key, of course,
making sure that all this works for

384
00:23:53.830 --> 00:23:57.900
your regular service operations and
your day-to-day business, is gonna be

385
00:23:57.900 --> 00:24:01.110
that key that she's emphasized,

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss the functional area of Service Desk.  Jo emphasizes that the service desk is where the perceived value of the service is determined because it normally is the SPOC, single point of contact to the services.  This, she says, means that its important that the people with the right set of qualities should be there.  The service desk personnel must be properly staffed, then properly trained, says Jo.  She also notes that the perception that service desk is a stepping stone means we must be considerate to train and retain individuals to work it properly.

that sit within the business,
