00:26:03.773 --> 00:26:08.569
that act as a liaison point
between the business, and

451
00:26:08.569 --> 00:26:11.564
between the Service Desk and IT.

452
00:26:11.564 --> 00:26:15.540
And so we could use them as the first
level support for instance.

453
00:26:15.540 --> 00:26:19.470
And we sometimes use them
to run training courses or

454
00:26:19.470 --> 00:26:23.550
to actually act as a communication point.

455
00:26:23.550 --> 00:26:27.940
So we may have new developments and
changes and etc, we'll utilize these

456
00:26:27.940 --> 00:26:32.650
super users to deliver that message
out to the business as a whole.

457
00:26:33.780 --> 00:26:35.620
We don't mind the use of super users, and

458
00:26:35.620 --> 00:26:38.510
in fact we'll encourage
the use of super users.

459
00:26:38.510 --> 00:26:43.417
However, what we will advise
with the use of super users is

460
00:26:43.417 --> 00:26:46.532
that all calls still must be logged.

461
00:26:46.532 --> 00:26:50.823
When we talked about incident management
yesterday, we mentioned the fact in

462
00:26:50.823 --> 00:26:54.570
incident management,
that all calls had to be logged.

463
00:26:54.570 --> 00:26:56.929
And that it was really important for

464
00:26:56.929 --> 00:26:59.995
trends analysis that all
calls were logged and

465
00:26:59.995 --> 00:27:05.515
that we ensured that we could understand
training needs for instance of our users.

466
00:27:05.515 --> 00:27:11.500
And business super users will act as
a contact point within IT but if they

467
00:27:11.500 --> 00:27:18.900
don't log the calls then we are not able
to ascertain any training requirements.

468
00:27:18.900 --> 00:27:24.840
So of course our super users have to
part of the IT Service Desk as well and

469
00:27:24.840 --> 00:27:27.130
they have to be a recognized part.

470
00:27:27.130 --> 00:27:29.210
So we're not telling you not to use them,
but

471
00:27:29.210 --> 00:27:34.720
what we're telling you is that ensure
that if you do use super users,

472
00:27:34.720 --> 00:27:37.890
then make sure that they're considered
a part of the team as well.

473
00:27:37.890 --> 00:27:42.200
>> And I think that makes a nice cohesion
or that team unit that really brings

474
00:27:42.200 --> 00:27:48.090
bonding and of course that ability to
work together well is kind of the key.

475
00:27:48.090 --> 00:27:51.440
So, Jo any other considerations
that we need to think about for

476
00:27:51.440 --> 00:27:52.660
this particular section?

477
00:27:52.660 --> 00:27:54.050
>> No for this particular section.

478
00:27:54.050 --> 00:27:56.870
In the next section we're going to
look at measuring the performance of

479
00:27:56.870 --> 00:28:01.150
the Service Desk, and we're also going to
look at Service Desk structures as well.

480
00:28:01.150 --> 00:28:06.110
So, for this particular
section we're just going to

481
00:28:06.110 --> 00:28:08.898
hold everybody with anticipation again.

482
00:28:08.898 --> 00:28:09.669
>> All right.

483
00:28:09.669 --> 00:28:12.860
>> [LAUGH] And
we'll look forward to the next section.

484
00:28:12.860 --> 00:28:13.400
>> All right, so

485
00:28:13.400 --> 00:28:17.335
remember that in this particular
section as we talked about the idea

486
00:28:17.335 --> 00:28:22.525
of the Service Desk, it really is about
the person that we need in that place.

487
00:28:22.525 --> 00:28:26.045
And it's not so much about the technical
skills, but the right person and

488
00:28:26.045 --> 00:28:29.280
that was an emphasis that Jo really
wanted to make sure that we got across.

489
00:28:29.280 --> 00:28:32.543
But there's a lot more to come
on the idea of Service Desk.

490
00:28:32.543 --> 00:28:33.915
So you wanna stick tuned for that.

491
00:28:33.915 --> 00:28:37.940
Stick tuned, stay tuned for
that one as well, but

492
00:28:37.940 --> 00:28:42.914
for this episode signing off for
ITProTV, I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

493
00:28:42.914 --> 00:28:44.145
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

494
00:28:44.145 --> 00:28:49.202
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation shows.

495
00:28:49.202 --> 00:28:55.338
[MUSIC]

496
00:28:55.338 --> 00:28:57.110
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with additional understanding of the service desk by diving into the performance metrics.  Jo provides a small warning when taking a look at the resulting metrics and looking for direct indicators of performance.  They may not match up, according to Jo.  The team looks at several examples of service desk and discusses the pros and cons of each.
episodes.title: Service Desk Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:01.516
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.516 --> 00:00:06.312
I'm your host Don Pezet, [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.312 --> 00:00:08.311
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.311 --> 00:00:12.140
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.140 --> 00:00:15.415
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:15.415 --> 00:00:19.116
You're watching
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation show.

7
00:00:19.116 --> 00:00:20.833
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:20.833 --> 00:00:25.250
And today we're taking
a part two on service desk.

9
00:00:25.250 --> 00:00:30.840
And here to help us out once again is
gonna be our kid wonder, Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:30.840 --> 00:00:32.570
Jo welcome back to the studios.

11
00:00:32.570 --> 00:00:33.792
>> Thank you very much Ronnie.

12
00:00:33.792 --> 00:00:37.360
Every time you describe me Ronnie,
you come up with something different.

13
00:00:37.360 --> 00:00:39.162
I wonder when you're
gonna run out of ideas.

14
00:00:39.162 --> 00:00:40.443
>> Probably in the next five minutes.

15
00:00:40.443 --> 00:00:42.492
>> [LAUGH]
>> Don't count on me as being

16
00:00:42.492 --> 00:00:43.653
an idea generating machine.

17
00:00:43.653 --> 00:00:45.292
>> [LAUGH]
>> That I'm not, but

18
00:00:45.292 --> 00:00:49.308
we've already taken a look at a lot of the
service desk, especially about staffing.

19
00:00:49.308 --> 00:00:52.774
So where are we gonna begin
in this particular segment?

20
00:00:52.774 --> 00:00:54.755
>> Okay, so in this section,

21
00:00:54.755 --> 00:00:58.726
this is the second part of
our look at the service desk.

22
00:00:58.726 --> 00:01:00.537
And in this particular segment,

23
00:01:00.537 --> 00:01:04.230
we're going to be looking at
measuring service desk performance.

24
00:01:04.230 --> 00:01:09.199
And also looking at the structures
within the service desk environment, and

25
00:01:09.199 --> 00:01:11.270
the structures that we may see.

26
00:01:11.270 --> 00:01:15.924
And structures that we may decide
that we want to utilize within IT

27
00:01:15.924 --> 00:01:18.260
service operations.

28
00:01:18.260 --> 00:01:21.920
>> Alright Jo,
it sounds like a very important topic for

29
00:01:21.920 --> 00:01:26.650
us when we start to take a look at all
the service desk has involve so far, so

30
00:01:26.650 --> 00:01:28.010
where we gonna begin right here?

31
00:01:28.010 --> 00:01:33.670
>> Okay, well the first thing I'm gonna
begin with is that the understanding,

32
00:01:33.670 --> 00:01:37.370
the Service Desk actually sets value
perception for the whole of IT.

33
00:01:37.370 --> 00:01:40.101
Now we covered this in part one.

34
00:01:40.101 --> 00:01:44.537
But we need to reiterate again,
right now, just before we get started,

35
00:01:44.537 --> 00:01:49.340
because you see the Service Desk is all
about setting value perception in terms

36
00:01:49.340 --> 00:01:51.689
of delivering value to the business.

37
00:01:51.689 --> 00:01:55.289
And as we've already said, a really
good Service Desk could make up for

38
00:01:55.289 --> 00:01:57.572
a lot of chaos that goes
on in the background.

39
00:01:57.572 --> 00:02:02.031
But a really poor Service Desk will
actually have the opposite effect, and

40
00:02:02.031 --> 00:02:07.056
it doesn't matter how well organized and
how well skilled we are in the background,

41
00:02:07.056 --> 00:02:10.240
if the Service Desk is not
delivering a good service,

42
00:02:10.240 --> 00:02:13.251
then the perception of IT
is not very good, okay?

43
00:02:13.251 --> 00:02:16.982
So the first thing that we're gonna
look then is actually how do we measure

44
00:02:16.982 --> 00:02:18.195
the performance of IT.

45
00:02:18.195 --> 00:02:23.343
And in the last section, we looked at
the fact that the service desk skills

46
00:02:23.343 --> 00:02:28.090
don't necessarily need to be as
technical as we originally think.

47
00:02:28.090 --> 00:02:31.540
And so,
it's all about delivering value, and

48
00:02:31.540 --> 00:02:34.940
it's all about customer perception and
therefore customer satisfaction.

49
00:02:36.150 --> 00:02:39.050
So how do we measure what
goes on in the service desk?

50
00:02:39.050 --> 00:02:44.570
Well the first thing that we've got
to measure is customer satisfaction.

51
00:02:44.570 --> 00:02:48.190
We have to find a way to measure
how happy our end users and

52
00:02:48.190 --> 00:02:51.410
our customers are with the service desk.

53
00:02:51.410 --> 00:02:56.000
Now we can use traditional ways to
measure service desk performance.

54
00:02:56.000 --> 00:02:59.870
And if you look at the examples, we talk
about percentage of first line resolution,

55
00:02:59.870 --> 00:03:05.140
and time to resolve an incident and
time to escalate, etc.

56
00:03:05.140 --> 00:03:06.870
But that's a very traditional look,

57
00:03:06.870 --> 00:03:11.540
assuming that the service desk
are going to be resolving incidents.

58
00:03:11.540 --> 00:03:16.320
Now of course the rate of resolution of
the incidents is determined by the target

59
00:03:16.320 --> 00:03:18.580
in the service level agreement.

60
00:03:18.580 --> 00:03:22.190
So we have to meet or exceed that target.

61
00:03:22.190 --> 00:03:26.260
We're not necessarily aiming
to resolve 100% of incidents.

62
00:03:26.260 --> 00:03:30.680
We're aiming to meet or exceed the target
that's in that service level agreement.

63
00:03:30.680 --> 00:03:33.740
But what we are aiming to do
is to keep our customers and

64
00:03:33.740 --> 00:03:36.090
our users happy 100% of the time.

65
00:03:37.330 --> 00:03:41.530
So it's really important that we can
measure customer satisfaction, and

66
00:03:41.530 --> 00:03:46.670
we will tell you that what
is in your service level

67
00:03:46.670 --> 00:03:51.970
targets is important, but you should also
have a target for customer satisfaction.

68
00:03:51.970 --> 00:03:57.910
I want to see that just as much
importance is placed on that

69
00:03:57.910 --> 00:04:03.460
as it is placed on the actual facts and
figures of incident resolution.

70
00:04:03.460 --> 00:04:06.930
You see when we talk about assessing
health and maturity and efficiency and

71
00:04:06.930 --> 00:04:10.890
effectiveness, we're not just talking
about the incident management process.

72
00:04:10.890 --> 00:04:14.230
We're also talking about
measuring fulfillment process, and

73
00:04:14.230 --> 00:04:15.920
the service desk as a whole.

74
00:04:17.430 --> 00:04:21.800
In a previous section, we look at the
activities of the service operation, and

75
00:04:21.800 --> 00:04:25.660
we looked at the different teams that
we might have in service operation.

76
00:04:26.680 --> 00:04:31.533
But what we didn't really discuss
was the concept that some of those

77
00:04:31.533 --> 00:04:34.864
activities might belong
in the service desk.

78
00:04:34.864 --> 00:04:39.799
Remember we looked at access management,
and we looked at Active Directory, and

79
00:04:39.799 --> 00:04:41.168
giving rights, etc.

80
00:04:41.168 --> 00:04:43.019
And I did mention during that section,

81
00:04:43.019 --> 00:04:45.440
that we might give some of
that to the service desk.

82
00:04:46.490 --> 00:04:48.040
We talked about change management, and

83
00:04:48.040 --> 00:04:52.460
change management's involvement
in service operation.

84
00:04:52.460 --> 00:04:55.990
Well we love the service
that's to raise request for

85
00:04:55.990 --> 00:05:00.260
changes, of course we do, because
a request could come in from a customer.

86
00:05:00.260 --> 00:05:03.370
We also allow the service
test to communicate,

87
00:05:03.370 --> 00:05:07.000
remember there that spark,
that single point of communication.

88
00:05:07.000 --> 00:05:10.320
We allow the service desk to
communicate the changed schedules and

89
00:05:10.320 --> 00:05:15.400
the availability schedules for
the coming week to our end users.

90
00:05:15.400 --> 00:05:19.340
We allow the service desk to update
the configuration management system,

91
00:05:19.340 --> 00:05:21.960
the configuration management databases.

92
00:05:21.960 --> 00:05:25.780
So the service desks are not just
tied to incident request fulfillment.

93
00:05:25.780 --> 00:05:32.140
The service desk actually have input and
involvement into every single process.

94
00:05:32.140 --> 00:05:37.020
Even the strategy processes,
such as service portfolio management and

95
00:05:37.020 --> 00:05:41.240
business relationship management,
as well as financial management too.

96
00:05:41.240 --> 00:05:45.710
These strategy processes come up
with new ideas for new services.

97
00:05:45.710 --> 00:05:50.010
Well those new ideas can come up from
anywhere including service desk analysts.

98
00:05:50.010 --> 00:05:54.710
After all the service desk works
hand in hand with the users, so

99
00:05:54.710 --> 00:05:57.250
who better to understand
how the users work and

100
00:05:57.250 --> 00:06:01.540
what they would appreciate in way of
a new service as the service desk.

101
00:06:03.550 --> 00:06:08.001
So when we think about measurements we
also wanna think about just because

102
00:06:08.001 --> 00:06:12.905
something seems to be one way doesn't
necessarily mean that it is the right way.

103
00:06:12.905 --> 00:06:17.832
And if you look at the movement in the
metrics might not be a result of what we

104
00:06:17.832 --> 00:06:18.398
think.

105
00:06:18.398 --> 00:06:20.734
Well we call that logical fallacy.

106
00:06:20.734 --> 00:06:24.843
And what logical fallacy means is that
just because something appears to be one

107
00:06:24.843 --> 00:06:28.190
way it does not necessarily
mean that is the case.

108
00:06:28.190 --> 00:06:33.440
The example that I was giving early on and
I think it is a great example to this,

109
00:06:33.440 --> 00:06:36.690
is the fact that if we think
about two Incidents here.

110
00:06:36.690 --> 00:06:40.950
Or we don't like to call them incidents,
actually, to events that happen,

111
00:06:40.950 --> 00:06:42.100
something that happens.

112
00:06:42.100 --> 00:06:44.520
So the cat walked across the road, and

113
00:06:44.520 --> 00:06:47.210
then five minutes later
it started raining.

114
00:06:47.210 --> 00:06:50.680
There would be an assumption there, if we
looked at that metrics, that it started

115
00:06:50.680 --> 00:06:54.320
raining because the cat crossed the road,
when in fact, that's not the case.

116
00:06:54.320 --> 00:06:57.950
They were two completely separate events.

117
00:06:57.950 --> 00:07:03.130
And so, we have to be very,
very careful about making assumptions

118
00:07:03.130 --> 00:07:09.490
over the movements in our metrics, because
if incidents decrease by 25% last month,

119
00:07:09.490 --> 00:07:15.380
for example, the assumption might be that
the service desk had better performance.

120
00:07:15.380 --> 00:07:18.660
But actually, what might have happened,
it says there,

121
00:07:18.660 --> 00:07:20.690
200 staff moved to a different company.

122
00:07:20.690 --> 00:07:24.440
Or you might have found, that actually
the schools were all on summer break and

123
00:07:24.440 --> 00:07:28.830
everybody's gone away on vacation or
holiday, depending on what you call it.

124
00:07:28.830 --> 00:07:32.374
And therefore, there's not as many
called into the service desk.

125
00:07:32.374 --> 00:07:35.521
So yes,
the number of incidents have decreased.

126
00:07:35.521 --> 00:07:39.435
And you might see an increase for instance
in the number of incident resolutions at

127
00:07:39.435 --> 00:07:41.149
the front line on the service desk.

128
00:07:41.149 --> 00:07:44.726
And you might assume that,
that is because well we've

129
00:07:44.726 --> 00:07:49.237
given everybody additional training,
but that may not be the case,

130
00:07:49.237 --> 00:07:54.759
we might have actually brought some people
in from second level support to help out,

131
00:07:54.759 --> 00:07:59.736
because we were a little bit short staffed
that day So we can't always assume

132
00:07:59.736 --> 00:08:04.920
that because we see a decrease that
something else has happened to cause that.

133
00:08:04.920 --> 00:08:10.190
We have to ensure that we investigate
the root cause of any trend

134
00:08:10.190 --> 00:08:12.298
in service desk performance.

135
00:08:12.298 --> 00:08:14.430
Ideally, we wanna provide value and

136
00:08:14.430 --> 00:08:19.270
therefore we want our incidents
to decrease over time.

137
00:08:19.270 --> 00:08:22.490
And we'd like our services
to be more reliable.

138
00:08:22.490 --> 00:08:25.700
We'd also like incident
resolution to increase as well.

139
00:08:25.700 --> 00:08:28.530
But be careful of watching those
trends and making assumptions.

140
00:08:30.080 --> 00:08:33.395
So we're gonna look at
the structures in the service desk.

141
00:08:33.395 --> 00:08:37.165
I'd like to sort of engage in some
discussion with you on what you

142
00:08:37.165 --> 00:08:41.955
think the pros and cons of each
particular structure type may be, okay?

143
00:08:43.115 --> 00:08:45.233
So let me take a look first of all, then,

144
00:08:45.233 --> 00:08:48.452
at what we call a local
service desk structure.

145
00:08:48.452 --> 00:08:52.652
And we've got a graphic there to
sort of help try and explain this.

146
00:08:52.652 --> 00:08:58.352
And a local service desk is a service
desk that is local to the business unit.

147
00:08:58.352 --> 00:09:03.350
And the example that we've got here
is it's local to the geography

148
00:09:03.350 --> 00:09:05.680
of that business unit.

149
00:09:05.680 --> 00:09:08.280
What do you think the advantages are of

150
00:09:08.280 --> 00:09:12.250
having a service desk that's
local to the business unit?

151
00:09:12.250 --> 00:09:16.330
>> Timeliness,
I believe would be probably the most

152
00:09:17.770 --> 00:09:22.530
obvious type of damage that we would have.

153
00:09:22.530 --> 00:09:27.527
The person or the help desk people being
right there, easier to get a hold of, but

154
00:09:27.527 --> 00:09:29.840
also quicker to get a hold of.

155
00:09:29.840 --> 00:09:31.350
>> Yeah, it could well be.

156
00:09:31.350 --> 00:09:35.580
Yes, there could definitely be some
timing issues there that you'd say,

157
00:09:35.580 --> 00:09:38.890
well actually, I can get hold of them
quicker because they're right here,

158
00:09:38.890 --> 00:09:43.780
and in fact I can physically get up and
walk to go and see them, yes.

159
00:09:43.780 --> 00:09:47.955
But there are other advantages to
this too, such as the local language.

160
00:09:47.955 --> 00:09:49.745
>> Right.
>> The local culture.

161
00:09:49.745 --> 00:09:50.610
>> Mm-hm.

162
00:09:50.610 --> 00:09:52.470
>> The business culture.

163
00:09:52.470 --> 00:09:57.605
Understanding exactly what
that business area does.

164
00:09:57.605 --> 00:10:00.250
>> Okay, what about disadvantages known.

165
00:10:00.250 --> 00:10:04.080
What do you think would be
a disadvantage of a local service desk?

166
00:10:04.080 --> 00:10:04.970
Could you think of any?

167
00:10:04.970 --> 00:10:07.790
>> I think the disadvantage
is almost the same here.

168
00:10:07.790 --> 00:10:12.926
The very fact that they can get a hold
of someone very quickly might also

169
00:10:12.926 --> 00:10:17.977
become overwhelming to that help desk,
and also the assumption that

170
00:10:17.977 --> 00:10:23.312
they can fix everything without having
to go outside of that local desk.

171
00:10:23.312 --> 00:10:28.293
>> Right, yeah,
there are quite a number of disadvantages

172
00:10:28.293 --> 00:10:31.110
to having a local service desk.

173
00:10:32.200 --> 00:10:38.370
The one is that, well what about
availability of the local service desk?

174
00:10:38.370 --> 00:10:39.690
What happens if it's out of hours?

175
00:10:40.770 --> 00:10:42.800
>> Yeah, they may not be there.

176
00:10:42.800 --> 00:10:45.330
>> Right yeah,
there'll be no one to support them if it's

177
00:10:45.330 --> 00:10:47.140
out of their working hours.

178
00:10:47.140 --> 00:10:49.865
>> Right.
>> And what about when they do get snowed

179
00:10:49.865 --> 00:10:54.160
under, when they get inundated with
people visiting them, then it's very,

180
00:10:54.160 --> 00:10:56.330

00:14:54.378 --> 00:14:55.720

00:15:06.351 --> 00:15:11.480

00:21:40.890 --> 00:21:45.930
If I were to ask you,

00:22:24.300 --> 00:22:26.690

00:22:29.140 --> 00:22:34.130

00:22:35.230 --> 00:22:37.470

00:22:37.470 --> 00:22:41.710

00:22:52.700 --> 00:22:54.460

00:23:29.320 --> 00:23:32.730

00:23:40.710 --> 00:23:43.748

00:24:53.755 --> 00:24:58.575

00:24:58.575 --> 00:25:02.809
And it tells us that not only
do they understand incident and

413
00:25:02.809 --> 00:25:09.173
problem management, but actually that
they have passed an audit for ISO 20,000.

414
00:25:09.173 --> 00:25:14.298
And that they are accredited, in other
words, that their processes are efficient,

415
00:25:14.298 --> 00:25:19.240
and that they're effective, and
that they deliver the required outputs.

416
00:25:19.240 --> 00:25:25.140
So when it mentions about ISO/IEC
20,000 is a critical factor.

417
00:25:25.140 --> 00:25:30.150
It's certainly a measurement that we
would use within the industry to tell us

418
00:25:30.150 --> 00:25:34.520
whether their working practices
would be compatible with ours.

419
00:25:35.790 --> 00:25:40.530
So at this point in time we've done
two sessions on the service desk.

420
00:25:40.530 --> 00:25:46.450
And so now is the time when I need
you to go to your course material.

421
00:25:46.450 --> 00:25:50.690
And I need you to take a look at
the exercises that we have for

422
00:25:50.690 --> 00:25:53.830
service desk as a functional area.

423
00:25:53.830 --> 00:25:57.940
Now those exercises also include
the operational activities

424
00:25:57.940 --> 00:26:02.600
that were in previous sections as well,
that we have covered.

425
00:26:02.600 --> 00:26:05.730
It should take you at least 1 hour and
30 minutes,

426
00:26:05.730 --> 00:26:10.190
at least 90 minutes to
undertake those exercises.

427
00:26:10.190 --> 00:26:13.380
And what I would mention, yet again,

428
00:26:13.380 --> 00:26:18.600
is if you do have any questions then
please contact us via the forum.

429
00:26:18.600 --> 00:26:19.665
Please come back to us,

430
00:26:19.665 --> 00:26:23.300
we're more than happy to answer
any questions that you have.

431
00:26:23.300 --> 00:26:27.630
If there's anything that is not quite
clear to you, then please come back to us

432
00:26:27.630 --> 00:26:30.870
and we'll be more than happy
to explain it again to you.

433
00:26:30.870 --> 00:26:34.837
>> All right, Jo, well, thank you
again for helping us now to understand

434
00:26:34.837 --> 00:26:38.740
the differences as we continue to do
more in and learning about ITIL and

435
00:26:38.740 --> 00:26:40.744
learning about that service desk.

436
00:26:40.744 --> 00:26:45.568
Remember the different aspects that we
took a look at today is really helpful and

437
00:26:45.568 --> 00:26:49.816
taking a look at the pros and cons of
each of the types of service desk and

438
00:26:49.816 --> 00:26:53.240
things we must consider as
we continue forward in ITIL.

439
00:26:53.240 --> 00:26:56.424
Do also the work assignment that
Jo said that you should do,

440
00:26:56.424 --> 00:26:58.150
that will also help you as well.

441
00:26:58.150 --> 00:27:03.428
But for this episode, signing off for
ITProTV, I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

442
00:27:03.428 --> 00:27:04.663
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

443
00:27:04.663 --> 00:27:09.543
>> Stay tuned right here for
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation shows.

444
00:27:09.543 --> 00:27:15.527
[MUSIC]

445
00:27:15.527 --> 00:27:18.165
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo briefly discuss the technical management role.  Jo describes this as not being a formalized role necessarily but more of role as needed.  She also helps to define the purpose of technical management within the infrastructure to maintain a stable infrastructure and reviews some of the many activities that go into managing infrastructure too.
episodes.title: Technical Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.492
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pizet.

2
00:00:02.492 --> 00:00:06.439
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.439 --> 00:00:08.264
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.264 --> 00:00:12.271
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:12.271 --> 00:00:15.480
>> Welcome to another great episode,
right here on ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:15.480 --> 00:00:19.322
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Operation show.

7
00:00:19.322 --> 00:00:20.881
I'm you're host, Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:20.881 --> 00:00:25.570
And today we're jumping into a new
area on technical management.

9
00:00:25.570 --> 00:00:30.430
And here to help us is going
to be our superhero in ITIL,

10
00:00:30.430 --> 00:00:32.610
Wonder Woman herself, Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:32.610 --> 00:00:35.020
Jo, welcome back to these studios.

12
00:00:35.020 --> 00:00:38.584
>> I quite like that, do I get
a nice sword and a cape with this?

13
00:00:38.584 --> 00:00:39.768
>> Sure, why not?

14
00:00:39.768 --> 00:00:44.170
>> Excellent, but
then I'm really pleased to be here.

15
00:00:44.170 --> 00:00:45.440
>> Alright, this sounds good.

16
00:00:45.440 --> 00:00:48.920
Now Jo, We've already dealt
with a lot of different areas.

17
00:00:48.920 --> 00:00:52.250
So if there is technical management,
tell me that there is not a untechnical

18
00:00:52.250 --> 00:00:54.255
management area that we
are going to dive into as well.

19
00:00:54.255 --> 00:00:55.740
[LAUGH]
>> No,

20
00:00:55.740 --> 00:00:59.900
that's okay we are not going into
the untechnical management role, no.

21
00:00:59.900 --> 00:01:03.610
That's how I'm feeling today,
I assure you right now.

22
00:01:03.610 --> 00:01:06.924
Now what we're gonna do over
the next three sections, we actually

23
00:01:06.924 --> 00:01:10.962
looked at the previous two sessions at
the service desk being a functional area.

24
00:01:10.962 --> 00:01:14.077
And over the next three Shorter sections,

25
00:01:14.077 --> 00:01:19.192
we're going to look at the other
three functional areas within ITIL.

26
00:01:19.192 --> 00:01:23.985
Now, I know that I've mentioned in
previous sections that within ITIL,

27
00:01:23.985 --> 00:01:27.840
we cannot tell you how to
organize your IT teams.

28
00:01:27.840 --> 00:01:31.820
And we certainly looked at common
service operation activities.

29
00:01:31.820 --> 00:01:37.340
And if we look at the technical
management role as it is laid out here,

30
00:01:37.340 --> 00:01:42.990
we talk about expertise and
management of the IT Infrastructure.

31
00:01:42.990 --> 00:01:48.740
And it's all of the expertise and skills
required to design, test, manage and

32
00:01:48.740 --> 00:01:54.700
improve these IT services, but
in relation to the infrastructure.

33
00:01:55.820 --> 00:01:59.320
So it's everything to do with our network.

34
00:02:00.430 --> 00:02:03.340
Now, this is not a team so

35
00:02:03.340 --> 00:02:07.050
I'm not going to tell you that this
is a team, an stand alone team.

36
00:02:07.050 --> 00:02:11.140
We refer to a function as being a group of
people and the tools that they use, but

37
00:02:11.140 --> 00:02:13.410
there is not rigid structure here.

38
00:02:13.410 --> 00:02:15.390
I like to refer to this as well,

39
00:02:15.390 --> 00:02:19.588
I like to refer to these functional
areas as hats that we all wear.

40
00:02:19.588 --> 00:02:21.469
And we've all got a different color hat.

41
00:02:21.469 --> 00:02:24.890
And so for this one,
I'm gonna give everybody a blue hat.

42
00:02:24.890 --> 00:02:28.310
And every now and
then we wear our blue hat.

43
00:02:28.310 --> 00:02:29.884
Because every now and then,

44
00:02:29.884 --> 00:02:33.107
we might have something to do
with the IT Infrastructure.

45
00:02:33.107 --> 00:02:34.893
So the guys that manage the network,

46
00:02:34.893 --> 00:02:37.380
they're probably wearing
in their blue hat a lot.

47
00:02:37.380 --> 00:02:41.309
But the guys that manage services and
do database administration and

48
00:02:41.309 --> 00:02:45.510
maybe middleware, maybe they wear
their blue hats 50% of the time that

49
00:02:45.510 --> 00:02:48.580
they're actually performing their roles.

50
00:02:48.580 --> 00:02:50.870
Don't think of these as rigid roles.

51
00:02:50.870 --> 00:02:55.290
Think of these as activities and as,

52
00:02:55.290 --> 00:02:59.980
well I was gonna say activities,
but functions that we have to

53
00:02:59.980 --> 00:03:05.190
perform in order to be able to
leave a value to the organization.

54
00:03:05.190 --> 00:03:08.540
So, we think of this as a blue hat, okay?

55
00:03:08.540 --> 00:03:11.400
Sometimes, we need to
bring in external people

56
00:03:11.400 --> 00:03:14.620
to help us because we
need specialist's skills.

57
00:03:14.620 --> 00:03:19.330
And so
our functional areas are not just rigid.

58
00:03:19.330 --> 00:03:24.070
They are not just these people
that are within our organization.

59
00:03:24.070 --> 00:03:28.280
These are people that we could bring in,
maybe on an ad hoc basis.

60
00:03:28.280 --> 00:03:34.160
Or maybe on a permanent basis,
where we outsource some of these skills.

61
00:03:34.160 --> 00:03:40.040
The idea is that technical people
are people that provide the experience and

62
00:03:40.040 --> 00:03:44.280
the skills to be able to support
the whole of the IT Infrastructure,

63
00:03:44.280 --> 00:03:47.610
in whatever way you decide.

64
00:03:49.080 --> 00:03:54.425
What we'll tell you is, that we're looking
for people that can design, and can build,

65
00:03:54.425 --> 00:03:58.639
and can test, and can implement, and
can manage on a day to day basis.

66
00:03:58.639 --> 00:04:03.564
And then improve, in other words,
improve our alignment to the business.

67
00:04:03.564 --> 00:04:05.800
The Technical Infrastructure.

68
00:04:05.800 --> 00:04:09.940
It's just that ongoing management of
our technology of our infrastructure.

69
00:04:11.438 --> 00:04:15.190
>> Now Jo as I just started
talking about that and

70
00:04:15.190 --> 00:04:17.365
the idea of the whole
infrastructure itself.

71
00:04:17.365 --> 00:04:20.610
So I don't know if this is proper or not.

72
00:04:20.610 --> 00:04:25.120
But are we now also saying that we're
excluding like specialty areas,

73
00:04:25.120 --> 00:04:29.690
such as somebody that might be good and
designing the email service,

74
00:04:29.690 --> 00:04:34.810
or somebody bringing in some
other special technical skills.

75
00:04:34.810 --> 00:04:37.281
Are we including them in this as well?

76
00:04:37.281 --> 00:04:38.221
>> No, we're including anybody
that we want to in this.

77
00:04:38.221 --> 00:04:40.205
>> Okay, alright.

78
00:04:40.205 --> 00:04:42.775
>> Absolutely anybody that we want to.

79
00:04:42.775 --> 00:04:47.745
We are really just giving
people a hat to wear.

80
00:04:47.745 --> 00:04:50.225
It's up to you who you put
in what functional area.

81
00:04:50.225 --> 00:04:53.645
It's up to you what color
hat you give people.

82
00:04:53.645 --> 00:04:54.700
It really is.

83
00:04:54.700 --> 00:04:56.450
Nobody's excluded from this.

84
00:04:56.450 --> 00:04:57.880
This is not a structure.

85
00:04:57.880 --> 00:05:03.510
This is not me saying okay,
you have to have a person in this team and

86
00:05:03.510 --> 00:05:06.990
we have to have this team called x.

87
00:05:06.990 --> 00:05:09.668
That's not what we're trying to do.

88
00:05:09.668 --> 00:05:14.750
The reason that we came across with
the concept of the functional areas, is

89
00:05:14.750 --> 00:05:20.573
that it's very, very difficult for us in
ITIL to look at every single organization.

90
00:05:20.573 --> 00:05:25.432
And say from a generic perspective,
bearing in mind that there are hundreds of

91
00:05:25.432 --> 00:05:29.850
thousands of organizations that have
adopted ITIL and adapted this for

92
00:05:29.850 --> 00:05:32.420
a framework to suit themselves.

93
00:05:32.420 --> 00:05:37.016
It's very difficult for us to say,
that one structure works in all

94
00:05:37.016 --> 00:05:41.873
the hundred thousand and
more organizations, because it doesn't.

95
00:05:41.873 --> 00:05:46.838
So there's no way that we could come up
with a generic structure for everybody.

96
00:05:46.838 --> 00:05:51.607
So what we have said in order to be
able to address these people is we say,

97
00:05:51.607 --> 00:05:57.220
well people with these type of skills,
we're gonna call them this.

98
00:05:57.220 --> 00:06:01.770
And people with different type of skills,
we're gonna call them that.

99
00:06:01.770 --> 00:06:06.001
And it's something that we
reference really for ease, for

100
00:06:06.001 --> 00:06:11.249
when we're trying to explain functions and
when we're trying to explain

101
00:06:11.249 --> 00:06:16.516
what certain people do, and
what activities belong in which processes.

102
00:06:16.516 --> 00:06:22.682
But really, it is just to try and
get you or the reader,

103
00:06:22.682 --> 00:06:29.268
the watcher to understand that
these roles need to exist.

104
00:06:29.268 --> 00:06:33.260
And it doesn't matter whether we
use outsourced contractors, or

105
00:06:33.260 --> 00:06:35.615
whether we use internal people.

106
00:06:35.615 --> 00:06:38.710
We have to have somebody
supporting our network.

107
00:06:38.710 --> 00:06:41.470
Somebody has to build it, and
test it, and implement it.

108
00:06:41.470 --> 00:06:45.890
We have to have people that support
our applications and our software.

109
00:06:45.890 --> 00:06:49.180
And we have to have people that support
the day to day running of our jobs and

110
00:06:49.180 --> 00:06:50.610
our job scheduling.

111
00:06:50.610 --> 00:06:53.100
Now here we are in technical management,
and

112
00:06:53.100 --> 00:06:55.590
we're looking primarily
at the infrastructure.

113
00:06:55.590 --> 00:06:58.360
If you want to bring the server
teams into the infrastructure,

114
00:06:58.360 --> 00:07:00.470
then we'll say hey that's great.

115
00:07:00.470 --> 00:07:04.191
If you want to take the server teams and
put them in application management,

116
00:07:04.191 --> 00:07:07.054
we'll say okay that's fine,
it's not a problem at all.

117
00:07:07.054 --> 00:07:11.593
The structure that you have within your
organization is entirely up to you.

118
00:07:11.593 --> 00:07:13.867
But when we look at a structure,

119
00:07:13.867 --> 00:07:18.670
we will just look at the skills that
people have and we'll say okay,

120
00:07:18.670 --> 00:07:23.490
that's a technical person then or
that's an application person.

121
00:07:23.490 --> 00:07:26.730
We're not saying that you do
something completely different,

122
00:07:26.730 --> 00:07:30.390
we're just saying that's
the category that we'd put them in.

123
00:07:30.390 --> 00:07:32.080
So we just give them a label.

124
00:07:32.080 --> 00:07:32.900
>> Alright.

125
00:07:32.900 --> 00:07:36.300
>> So technical management is all
about the infrastructure, and

126
00:07:36.300 --> 00:07:40.310
is about maintaining
a stable infrastructure.

127
00:07:40.310 --> 00:07:46.054
So we want to provide resilient,
as we say cost-effective technology.

128
00:07:46.054 --> 00:07:48.653
Now, we talk about cost-effective,

129
00:07:48.653 --> 00:07:53.224
because cost-effective means not
spending too much money [LAUGH] but

130
00:07:53.224 --> 00:07:57.811
being efficient with our money,
but still having that resilience.

131
00:07:57.811 --> 00:08:02.546
You see if we don't put any resilience in
place, okay things will be cheaper, but

132
00:08:02.546 --> 00:08:06.950
then there are gonna be failures that
are going to impact the organization.

133
00:08:06.950 --> 00:08:09.438
But if we put too much
resilience in place,

134
00:08:09.438 --> 00:08:13.599
then it's going to cost us a lot more
money and we may never ever need it.

135
00:08:13.599 --> 00:08:18.468
So we have to be able to do the risk
assessment before we implement

136
00:08:18.468 --> 00:08:20.440
any technology.

137
00:08:20.440 --> 00:08:23.490
So it's all about having the right
people with the right skills,

138
00:08:23.490 --> 00:08:25.520
to be able to be able to
maintain that infrastructure.

139
00:08:25.520 --> 00:08:29.610
So they build it, they test it and they
implement it, and then they maintain it.

140
00:08:29.610 --> 00:08:36.620
And it's all of the processes within ITIL
,but in relation to the infrastructure.

141
00:08:36.620 --> 00:08:40.640
So as we've seen in that last bullet
point, we talk about technical failures,

142
00:08:40.640 --> 00:08:42.830
we talk about incident and
problem management.

143
00:08:42.830 --> 00:08:45.230
These guys are the people that
are performing second and

144
00:08:45.230 --> 00:08:47.886
third level support,
for the infrastructure.

145
00:08:47.886 --> 00:08:52.550
So you'll see these are fairly
generic skills, but

146
00:08:52.550 --> 00:08:57.560
just relating to the infrastructure
you see managing, and

147
00:08:57.560 --> 00:09:03.600
documentation, and training,
and defining standards,

148
00:09:03.600 --> 00:09:08.840
and research, and development, but
in relation to the infrastructure.

149
00:09:08.840 --> 00:09:12.570
So these people are designing,
they're building,

150
00:09:12.570 --> 00:09:14.354
they're testing, they're modeling.

151
00:09:15.725 --> 00:09:19.065
So all of those things that we mentioned,
those activities that we talked about with

152
00:09:19.065 --> 00:09:23.085
capacity management and availability
management in previous sections,

153
00:09:23.085 --> 00:09:27.967
that's what these guys are doing but
in relation to the infrastructure.

154
00:09:27.967 --> 00:09:33.117
So people that wear a blue hat,
have got involvement in projects and

155
00:09:33.117 --> 00:09:35.467
in availability and
capacity as we've said.

156
00:09:35.467 --> 00:09:39.467
And in testing, which is part of
Change Management and part of release and

157
00:09:39.467 --> 00:09:40.770
deployment management.

158
00:09:40.770 --> 00:09:44.270
That perform in the risk analysis, for
things like security management and

159
00:09:44.270 --> 00:09:46.360
service continuity manage.

160
00:09:46.360 --> 00:09:51.920
They're actually doing vendor management,
which is part of supplier management.

161
00:09:51.920 --> 00:09:56.860
They're dealing with incidents and
problems, etc, and there are data

162
00:09:56.860 --> 00:10:02.170
in the database because they get that
information from those suppliers.

163
00:10:02.170 --> 00:10:04.560
So they're performing
all of those activities,

164
00:10:04.560 --> 00:10:10.110
all of those processes from previous life
cycle phases and from service operation,

165
00:10:10.110 --> 00:10:13.970
but they're doing that in
relation to the infrastructure.

166
00:10:15.230 --> 00:10:18.430
Now, that's not to say that they just
ignore applications because as I

167
00:10:18.430 --> 00:10:22.870
have said, there's a very fuzzy
gray line in between them.

168
00:10:22.870 --> 00:10:26.760
And you can put people
wherever you want to put them.

169
00:10:26.760 --> 00:10:32.080
But you'll see from these activities, that
there has to be a relationship between

170
00:10:32.080 --> 00:10:34.640
technical people and application people.

171
00:10:35.860 --> 00:10:40.240
And people that manage middleware for
instance, where do you want to put them?

172
00:10:40.240 --> 00:10:42.650
Well we'll put them,
we'll give them that blue hat and

173
00:10:42.650 --> 00:10:44.590
we'll put them here with
the infrastructure.

174
00:10:44.590 --> 00:10:46.910
But you might put them
with the application guys.

175
00:10:46.910 --> 00:10:48.620
And we might give them a green hat, okay?

176
00:10:50.040 --> 00:10:51.650
That's entirely up to you.

177
00:10:53.660 --> 00:10:57.310
If I were to bring any of those
bullet points out specifically,

178
00:10:57.310 --> 00:11:01.710
I would bring the bullet point
out about Financial Management.

179
00:11:01.710 --> 00:11:04.948
Because I've already mentioned
in previous sections,

180
00:11:04.948 --> 00:11:07.730
[LAUGH] we're not great with finances.

181
00:11:07.730 --> 00:11:10.711
Well we've run away from finances,
let's face it.

182
00:11:10.711 --> 00:11:15.431
And we have to I guess get a little bit
more mature in the way that we approach

183
00:11:15.431 --> 00:11:17.040
financial management.

184
00:11:17.040 --> 00:11:21.448
And I accept that things costs money and
support cost money,

185
00:11:21.448 --> 00:11:25.780
and we have to be able to account for
the money that we spent.

186
00:11:25.780 --> 00:11:31.465
Because that helps us achieve budget
reaproval for new projects going forward.

187
00:11:31.465 --> 00:11:35.150
So in a nut shell,
that is technical management.

188
00:11:35.150 --> 00:11:40.720
And what I'd like to do now,
is to just take a moment to just review

189
00:11:40.720 --> 00:11:46.250
the notes that you have on technical
management in your course material.

190
00:11:46.250 --> 00:11:51.040
And then in our next section, we're going
go to look at IT operations management.

191
00:11:51.040 --> 00:11:52.380
And the section after that,

192
00:11:52.380 --> 00:11:55.090
we're going to take a look at
applications management also.

193
00:11:56.130 --> 00:11:57.417
>> Alright, Jo.
Well thank you for

194
00:11:57.417 --> 00:12:00.920
helping us to understand more on
this idea of technical management.

195
00:12:00.920 --> 00:12:05.617
That's not necessarily a role as much as a
hat that someone might wear to be able to

196
00:12:05.617 --> 00:12:10.264
provide assistance, or to actually take
that on to a particular point in time.

197
00:12:10.264 --> 00:12:14.202
Also the purpose of the technical manager
as well as some of these different

198
00:12:14.202 --> 00:12:15.583
activities that we have.

199
00:12:15.583 --> 00:12:20.552
All these are good materials that you do
need to review as you continue on in your

200
00:12:20.552 --> 00:12:23.432
ITIL path, for
what you actually need to do.

201
00:12:23.432 --> 00:12:26.512
So that's a great for us to also sign off,

202
00:12:26.512 --> 00:12:30.910
signing off from IT PRO.TV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

203
00:12:30.910 --> 00:12:32.180
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

204
00:12:32.180 --> 00:12:36.607
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation shows.

205
00:12:36.607 --> 00:12:42.600
[MUSIC]

206
00:12:42.600 --> 00:12:49.459
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo dive into operation management.  Jo reminds us that the key goal in all service operation is in delivering value to the business.  This cannot be achieved if the business cannot operate at the status quo or if it not responsive to the continual changing business environment, says Jo.  She also reviews the activities to be performed to help achieve effective and efficient operation management.
episodes.title: Operations Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.057
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.057 --> 00:00:07.789
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.789 --> 00:00:11.865
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.865 --> 00:00:15.321
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV,

5
00:00:15.321 --> 00:00:19.820
you are watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Operation show.

6
00:00:19.820 --> 00:00:25.160
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and today
we're jumping into operation management.

7
00:00:25.160 --> 00:00:30.750
And here in studios is going to be
the ITIL mastermind herself, Jo Peacock.

8
00:00:30.750 --> 00:00:32.340
Jo, welcome back to studios.

9
00:00:32.340 --> 00:00:34.570
>> Thank you very much Ronnie,
how are you?

10
00:00:34.570 --> 00:00:36.040
>> I am doing fine, and

11
00:00:36.040 --> 00:00:41.180
we are starting to move through
several topics relatively quickly now.

12
00:00:41.180 --> 00:00:44.630
>> We've just talked about
some technical management and

13
00:00:44.630 --> 00:00:47.060
now we're moving into
operations management.

14
00:00:47.060 --> 00:00:47.914
What are we talking about here Jo?

15
00:00:47.914 --> 00:00:52.726
>> Well, you're right that we're moving
very swiftly through these particular

16
00:00:52.726 --> 00:00:57.770
topics because in all honesty, we can't
really cover them in too much depth.

17
00:00:57.770 --> 00:01:00.960
Purely because of the fact
that every single

18
00:01:00.960 --> 00:01:05.420
structure within an organization is
going to be unique to that organization.

19
00:01:05.420 --> 00:01:11.170
So we can tell you what activities need to
be undertaken and we can tell you exactly

20
00:01:11.170 --> 00:01:16.100
what processes need to be undertaken, but
we can't tell you who's going to do that.

21
00:01:16.100 --> 00:01:18.100
And certainly technical abilities and

22
00:01:18.100 --> 00:01:24.140
technical structure is going to depend
entirely on what the organization needs.

23
00:01:24.140 --> 00:01:27.050
>> All right, so Jo,
when we start to take a look down,

24
00:01:27.050 --> 00:01:30.530
since we're ready inside
of service operations.

25
00:01:30.530 --> 00:01:33.585
What do we take a look at under
operations management here?

26
00:01:33.585 --> 00:01:38.610
>> [LAUGH] Okay, the naming of this is
not term is not particularly fortunate,

27
00:01:38.610 --> 00:01:39.742
I don't think.

28
00:01:39.742 --> 00:01:43.163
>> [LAUGH]
>> But in certainly in service operation,

29
00:01:43.163 --> 00:01:45.012
in the life cycle phase-
>> Right.

30
00:01:45.012 --> 00:01:46.557
>> We have this function,

31
00:01:46.557 --> 00:01:50.900
and again, I introduced the concept
of hats a littler earlier on.

32
00:01:50.900 --> 00:01:54.290
Think of these guys as
maybe having a yellow hat.

33
00:01:54.290 --> 00:01:58.920
And what we have are a group
of people that perform

34
00:01:58.920 --> 00:02:02.810
the day to day operational activities.

35
00:02:02.810 --> 00:02:05.040
Now we split this role into two.

36
00:02:05.040 --> 00:02:07.690
Or we split this functional area into two.

37
00:02:07.690 --> 00:02:14.260
Because there are two very, very, clear
sets of activities that need to happen.

38
00:02:14.260 --> 00:02:17.260
In order to be able to just,
keep everything up and running.

39
00:02:17.260 --> 00:02:18.730
And that's what we're doing.

40
00:02:18.730 --> 00:02:23.590
So we have operations control and
then we have facilities management.

41
00:02:23.590 --> 00:02:25.300
Now operations control.

42
00:02:25.300 --> 00:02:29.460
Operations control undertakes
all of the activities that we

43
00:02:29.460 --> 00:02:31.390
looked at in previous sessions.

44
00:02:31.390 --> 00:02:34.990
So we looked at activities
such as console management.

45
00:02:34.990 --> 00:02:40.234
We looked at job scheduling, and backups
and restores, and print management,

46
00:02:40.234 --> 00:02:44.718
and maintenance activities for
the hardware for our servers, etc.

47
00:02:44.718 --> 00:02:49.907
That's undertaken by the people
that perform operations control or

48
00:02:49.907 --> 00:02:52.560
sit in the ops control arena.

49
00:02:52.560 --> 00:02:56.536
Now you might give them the name
of network operations center or

50
00:02:56.536 --> 00:02:58.118
NOC or ops bridge, etc.

51
00:02:58.118 --> 00:03:00.774
So these are the people
that sit in ops control.

52
00:03:00.774 --> 00:03:03.322
And the other sub function under

53
00:03:03.322 --> 00:03:07.910
operations management is
facilities management.

54
00:03:07.910 --> 00:03:11.820
And again, in a previous section we
looked at facilities management and

55
00:03:11.820 --> 00:03:14.400
we looked at the activities
that they perform.

56
00:03:14.400 --> 00:03:17.900
So they have responsibilities for
data centers, for

57
00:03:17.900 --> 00:03:23.120
disaster recovery sites, for
power, and for air conditioning.

58
00:03:23.120 --> 00:03:25.140
And so these guys,

59
00:03:25.140 --> 00:03:29.750
they're equally as important as
anybody else within the whole of IT.

60
00:03:29.750 --> 00:03:34.755
We've already explained in previous
sessions the fact that without power,

61
00:03:34.755 --> 00:03:37.758
without me having this
lead here on my laptop,

62
00:03:37.758 --> 00:03:40.467
I'm not able to send or receive an email.

63
00:03:40.467 --> 00:03:44.791
And if I can't send or
receive an email without power,

64
00:03:44.791 --> 00:03:47.150
then I don't have a service.

65
00:03:48.330 --> 00:03:53.600
And so in IT, we're concerned with
delivering services and delivering value.

66
00:03:53.600 --> 00:03:59.416
And if you take away one single component,
I'm not able to facilitate those outcomes,

67
00:03:59.416 --> 00:04:02.413
I'm not able to send and
receive that email.

68
00:04:02.413 --> 00:04:06.471
So I need to have the power,
I need to have the air conditioner.

69
00:04:06.471 --> 00:04:08.154
Can I ask you a question?

70
00:04:08.154 --> 00:04:13.052
Have you ever sat in a room when the air
conditions failed in the middle of summer?

71
00:04:13.052 --> 00:04:16.380
>> [LAUGH] Not only have I sat in a room.

72
00:04:16.380 --> 00:04:18.935
I have lived in rooms for that.

73
00:04:18.935 --> 00:04:20.760
>> [LAUGH]
>> And it is terrible.

74
00:04:20.760 --> 00:04:24.290
>> Yeah, it's not too good,
it really isn't too good.

75
00:04:24.290 --> 00:04:27.030
Now let me tell you, okay,
I come from England, and so

76
00:04:27.030 --> 00:04:30.369
we have the opposite effect,
[LAUGH] certainly during the winter,

77
00:04:30.369 --> 00:04:32.978
being in a room where there's no heating.

78
00:04:32.978 --> 00:04:38.110
And in fact, we even go so far as to have
minimum operating temperatures for rooms,

79
00:04:38.110 --> 00:04:42.890
which are legal requirements for the
temperature that buildings have to be in.

80
00:04:42.890 --> 00:04:46.830
And our computer equipment is
no different to you and I.

81
00:04:46.830 --> 00:04:50.150
I don't want to be too cold and
I don't want to be too hot.

82
00:04:50.150 --> 00:04:53.010
And that's exactly the same
with our computer equipment.

83
00:04:53.010 --> 00:04:56.340
So of course, we have to maintain
that consistent temperature.

84
00:04:56.340 --> 00:05:00.370
You know, even your cellphone will tell
you if it's too hot or too cold and

85
00:05:00.370 --> 00:05:03.339
it will shut down operations
until you actually restore that.

86
00:05:04.400 --> 00:05:07.670
So IT equipment is quite sensitive.

87
00:05:07.670 --> 00:05:09.500
>> Right.
>> Probably more than I am really,

88
00:05:09.500 --> 00:05:10.979
I'm just a bit thick-skinned.

89
00:05:10.979 --> 00:05:15.430
[LAUGH] So we need to have somebody
that's going to be able to manage

90
00:05:15.430 --> 00:05:20.740
the physical environment
of our IT operations, okay?

91
00:05:20.740 --> 00:05:25.370
So IT operation is about maintaining
balance, it's maintaining the status quo.

92
00:05:26.580 --> 00:05:32.050
I like to refer to it as treading water
because that's what we're doing, okay?

93
00:05:32.050 --> 00:05:35.250
We have to tread water,
we have to make sure that everything is

94
00:05:35.250 --> 00:05:39.410
ticking over nicely,
we don't want interruptions to service.

95
00:05:39.410 --> 00:05:44.520
So we rely on service
design to ensure that they

96
00:05:44.520 --> 00:05:50.470
define operating parameters that will
allow us to maintain that status quo.

97
00:05:50.470 --> 00:05:54.310
And we rely on service
transition to build those

98
00:05:54.310 --> 00:05:59.030
services that will allow for
a stable environment.

99
00:05:59.030 --> 00:06:02.390
Allows us to maintain the status quo.

100
00:06:02.390 --> 00:06:06.358
Now, service or operations management,
they are people and

101
00:06:06.358 --> 00:06:09.190
they're performing various activities.

102
00:06:09.190 --> 00:06:12.220
And they perform in
activities within design and

103
00:06:12.220 --> 00:06:15.625
within service transition and
within operation too.

104
00:06:15.625 --> 00:06:20.485
So the process is where we look at
the design characteristics, and

105
00:06:20.485 --> 00:06:22.435
we look at designing metrics.

106
00:06:22.435 --> 00:06:25.685
And we look at building these services and

107
00:06:25.685 --> 00:06:28.735
building the monitoring
systems that we need.

108
00:06:28.735 --> 00:06:34.465
Well, ops control are actually involved
in that, that's exactly what they do.

109
00:06:34.465 --> 00:06:36.819
Facilities management
are involved in that, too.

110
00:06:38.070 --> 00:06:42.671
Just think about the impact
if we designed a new service,

111
00:06:42.671 --> 00:06:47.320
a new server that had to come
in as part of that new service.

112
00:06:47.320 --> 00:06:52.290
Maybe a complete rack of service were
brought in as part of that new service.

113
00:06:52.290 --> 00:06:56.700
Can you just imagine what would happen if
we got to the implementation stage and

114
00:06:56.700 --> 00:07:01.240
your hardware supplier turned up,
generally with a big truck,

115
00:07:01.240 --> 00:07:05.690
full of servers, etc., only to find
that there is insufficient power

116
00:07:05.690 --> 00:07:08.440
in the computer room to
be able to deal with it.

117
00:07:08.440 --> 00:07:11.670
Or maybe the air conditioning wasn't
powerful enough to be able to deal with

118
00:07:11.670 --> 00:07:12.540
the additional heat.

119
00:07:14.040 --> 00:07:19.300
Or maybe there wasn't even simply enough
space to be able to put that new rack in.

120
00:07:19.300 --> 00:07:23.080
Well this is what happens if facilities
management [LAUGH] aren't involved.

121
00:07:23.080 --> 00:07:25.750
We have to get facilities
management involved.

122
00:07:25.750 --> 00:07:29.120
So all of this falls under
operations management.

123
00:07:29.120 --> 00:07:32.890
And it's not just about the day to
day maintaining the status quo,

124
00:07:32.890 --> 00:07:34.880
it's about planning for this as well.

125
00:07:34.880 --> 00:07:39.390
Which is why we're involved in design and
transition activities too.

126
00:07:40.590 --> 00:07:43.510
But then it talks about balance,
and it talks about treading water,

127
00:07:43.510 --> 00:07:47.925
maintaining the status quo versus
participating in added value.

128
00:07:47.925 --> 00:07:52.490
One of the sessions very, very early on,

129
00:07:52.490 --> 00:07:57.410
we looked at achieving balance within
service operation, and we mentioned

130
00:07:57.410 --> 00:08:02.200
stability versus responsiveness and
that's exactly what this is.

131
00:08:02.200 --> 00:08:04.090
Yes, you've got to maintain stability.

132
00:08:04.090 --> 00:08:08.900
Yes, you've got to keep on treading water,
keep the business running.

133
00:08:08.900 --> 00:08:10.820
That's exactly what you've got to do, but

134
00:08:10.820 --> 00:08:13.930
you've also got to respond to
the changing business needs.

135
00:08:13.930 --> 00:08:17.750
The one thing that we know about
the business above everything

136
00:08:17.750 --> 00:08:21.820
else that we know about our organization,
is that it's going to change.

137
00:08:23.090 --> 00:08:27.920
Nothing stays the same and
especially with the rapid

138
00:08:27.920 --> 00:08:32.850
pace of evolving technology now,
nothing stays the same for very long.

139
00:08:32.850 --> 00:08:37.975
So we have to maintain that
balance between treading water and

140
00:08:37.975 --> 00:08:41.350
keeping everybody happy and
just maintaining the status quo.

141
00:08:41.350 --> 00:08:44.300
And being responsive to
changing business needs.

142
00:08:46.180 --> 00:08:51.890
So we have to understand then, what our
technology does for the organization?

143
00:08:51.890 --> 00:08:54.120
What impact does it have
on the organization?

144
00:08:54.120 --> 00:08:58.180
And I'm not talking about what negative
impact does it have when it fails,

145
00:08:58.180 --> 00:09:00.650
because that's a fairly
easy one to ascertain.

146
00:09:00.650 --> 00:09:03.570
That's something that we
do in change management.

147
00:09:03.570 --> 00:09:07.210
When we bring in a new change,
we, as part of change evaluation,

148
00:09:07.210 --> 00:09:12.700
we ascertain the negative impact of
failure of that particular service,

149
00:09:12.700 --> 00:09:14.860
but what about the positive
impact of that service?

150
00:09:15.900 --> 00:09:18.940
What about what good that service does?

151
00:09:18.940 --> 00:09:23.400
We have to understand that there's always
going to be an impact of any service and

152
00:09:23.400 --> 00:09:28.310
we have to make sure that the positive
impact outweighs the negative impact.

153
00:09:28.310 --> 00:09:30.292
So, all staff needs to understand this.

154
00:09:32.254 --> 00:09:36.518
If you don't feel involved,
Ronnie, in your particular role,

155
00:09:36.518 --> 00:09:38.843
if people don't talk to you [LAUGH] or

156
00:09:38.843 --> 00:09:45.450
if nobody explains to you why you're doing
something, what's your motivation like?

157
00:09:45.450 --> 00:09:48.050
>> It's probably not as high as it could
be if I knew why I was doing what I

158
00:09:48.050 --> 00:09:48.660
was doing.

159
00:09:48.660 --> 00:09:53.075
>> You know, we keep going on about, or
I keep going on about communications.

160
00:09:53.075 --> 00:09:53.820
>> Mm-hm.

161
00:09:53.820 --> 00:09:57.370
>> Communications is really,
really important when it comes to IT or

162
00:09:57.370 --> 00:09:58.960
when it comes to service operation.

163
00:10:00.970 --> 00:10:05.235
What we found, and of course we're
focusing on efficiency and effectiveness.

164
00:10:05.235 --> 00:10:09.445
What we found though is that staff
are obviously more effective and

165
00:10:09.445 --> 00:10:11.505
more efficient if we
communicate with them.

166
00:10:11.505 --> 00:10:13.555
If they understand
the value of their role and

167
00:10:13.555 --> 00:10:18.205
they understand the value of their skills,
then actually they will give more to

168
00:10:18.205 --> 00:10:22.355
the organization because they
see the impact of their input.

169
00:10:23.830 --> 00:10:28.210
So, we like to ensure that
all of our staff understand

170
00:10:28.210 --> 00:10:32.580
the impact of their input and the impact
of their technical skills including

171
00:10:32.580 --> 00:10:34.910
whatever they do with their technology.

172
00:10:36.835 --> 00:10:40.025
We like to ensure that we keep all
of our documentation up to date.

173
00:10:40.025 --> 00:10:41.865
That's part of Knowledge Management.

174
00:10:41.865 --> 00:10:46.305
So we will always encourage our
staff to facilitate that and

175
00:10:46.305 --> 00:10:49.767
encourage our staff to
contribute their experience and

176
00:10:49.767 --> 00:10:53.757
their knowledge and
their skills to operational documentation.

177
00:10:55.097 --> 00:10:58.427
But we also have to remember
that we've gotta manage

178
00:10:58.427 --> 00:11:01.920
whether operations is actually working,
okay?

179
00:11:01.920 --> 00:11:07.280
Which is where these metrics come in,
which is where our strategy comes in,

180
00:11:07.280 --> 00:11:10.950
which is where we talk about
continual service improvement.

181
00:11:10.950 --> 00:11:13.710
We've gotta deliver value to the business.

182
00:11:13.710 --> 00:11:15.745
And, well I think we're doing it.

183
00:11:15.745 --> 00:11:18.010
It's not really a good enough measurement.

184
00:11:18.010 --> 00:11:21.650
It's not just a case of sort of licking
your finger and holding it up and

185
00:11:21.650 --> 00:11:23.780
say, yeah, we're doing good.

186
00:11:23.780 --> 00:11:25.225
No, we can't just say that.

187
00:11:25.225 --> 00:11:29.450
We've gotta have some measurements
to say whether we're achieving

188
00:11:29.450 --> 00:11:31.640
that value delivery or not.

189
00:11:31.640 --> 00:11:34.260
Whether we're achieving that status quo.

190
00:11:34.260 --> 00:11:37.590
Are we delivering that, or
are we not delivering that?

191
00:11:37.590 --> 00:11:42.720
Are we responding to changing needs, or
are we not responding to changing needs?

192
00:11:43.740 --> 00:11:48.490
Everything has to be focused on
delivering value to the organization.

193
00:11:48.490 --> 00:11:49.780
But because I think so,

194
00:11:49.780 --> 00:11:55.890
is not a good enough reason to say
that we delivering that value.

195
00:11:55.890 --> 00:11:57.860
Because I think so, is just not a metric.

196
00:11:57.860 --> 00:11:58.840
We've gotta measure.

197
00:12:00.320 --> 00:12:03.880
So as we've already said then operations
management is about maintaining just

198
00:12:03.880 --> 00:12:09.510
the day to day stability,
maintaining that business as usual,

199
00:12:09.510 --> 00:12:12.330
and ensuring that we
are continually improving,

200
00:12:12.330 --> 00:12:16.160
continually aligning ourselves
to the needs of the business.

201
00:12:16.160 --> 00:12:19.700
And so because we want to maintain
stability, we've got to make sure if

202
00:12:19.700 --> 00:12:27.410
something fails, that we're able to
pick up the pieces as soon as we can.

203
00:12:27.410 --> 00:12:29.370
That ties in with incident management,
yeah,

204
00:12:29.370 --> 00:12:33.260
where we've got to restore normal service
operations as quickly as possible.

205
00:12:33.260 --> 00:12:35.830
It also has ties with
problem management too.

206
00:12:38.040 --> 00:12:42.150
So think about what other activities then,
operations management have.

207
00:12:42.150 --> 00:12:45.195
They are doing event management for
instance.

208
00:12:45.195 --> 00:12:49.020
The event management is a process
is where we monitored and

209
00:12:49.020 --> 00:12:52.590
where we reacted to certain conditions and
parameters

210
00:12:52.590 --> 00:12:57.090
that happened on our servers and on our
infrastructure, on our mainframe, etc.

211
00:12:57.090 --> 00:13:00.548
We're going to be liaising
with application management.

212
00:13:00.548 --> 00:13:05.120
I mentioned during our last session
about that gray area that sits between

213
00:13:05.120 --> 00:13:10.000
our technical teams, our network teams,
and our applications team.

214
00:13:10.000 --> 00:13:11.120
What about this middle ware?

215
00:13:11.120 --> 00:13:12.760
Who does it belong to?

216
00:13:12.760 --> 00:13:16.440
There are gray areas there, we can't
tell you how to be structured, but

217
00:13:16.440 --> 00:13:19.692
we can tell you that there needs
to be relationships in place.

218
00:13:19.692 --> 00:13:24.220
If we've not talked to each other then we
end up in that situation where an incident

219
00:13:24.220 --> 00:13:29.280
occurs and it's passed around to 15
different people before somebody

220
00:13:29.280 --> 00:13:34.420
finally says, yes, that's actually my
responsibility, I can deal with this.

221
00:13:34.420 --> 00:13:37.880
So however we organize
ourselves within IT,

222
00:13:37.880 --> 00:13:41.550
we have to have very clear roles and
responsibilities.

223
00:13:41.550 --> 00:13:46.075
And above all, we have to ensure
that we have a stable environment

224
00:13:46.075 --> 00:13:49.214
that can deliver value
to our organization.

225
00:13:50.629 --> 00:13:53.782
>> All right Jo, thank you again for
helping us out and

226
00:13:53.782 --> 00:13:57.684
understanding more about this
idea of operation management.

227
00:13:57.684 --> 00:14:01.565
Remember that the key here of course
is that for our business to function,

228
00:14:01.565 --> 00:14:05.775
we do have to maintain that idea of the
status quo to ensure that things get done.

229
00:14:05.775 --> 00:14:09.139
But at the same time respond
to the business needs and

230
00:14:09.139 --> 00:14:13.470
what we also need there as
business continues to change too.

231
00:14:13.470 --> 00:14:17.160
So Jo also helped us to review the ideas
some these different activities

232
00:14:17.160 --> 00:14:20.720
that we will go through to be able
to do well, both and maintain and

233
00:14:20.720 --> 00:14:24.930
do deliver, the great value that
we can to our costumers as well.

234
00:14:24.930 --> 00:14:29.450
That's a great place for
us to sign off too, for itpro.tv.

235
00:14:29.450 --> 00:14:32.030
I'm your host Ronnie Wong,
>> And I'm Jo Peacock

236
00:14:32.030 --> 00:14:33.565
>> Stay tuned right here, for

237
00:14:33.565 --> 00:14:36.451
more ITIL intermediate
Service Operation shows.

238
00:14:36.451 --> 00:14:41.009
[MUSIC]

239
00:14:41.009 --> 00:14:42.600
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo change topics into application management.  Jo shows us the value of this area is to provide both utility and warranty.  Along with these goals, application support also provides ability to support and address incidents that may arise.
episodes.title: Application Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.300 --> 00:00:06.848
You're watching ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.848 --> 00:00:08.243
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.243 --> 00:00:12.106
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.106 --> 00:00:15.329
>> Welcome to another great episode,
right here on ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.329 --> 00:00:19.150
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Operation show.

6
00:00:19.150 --> 00:00:24.720
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and today
we're diving into application management.

7
00:00:24.720 --> 00:00:27.370
And here to help us out is gonna be, well,

8
00:00:27.370 --> 00:00:31.240
the ITIL master blaster herself,
Jo Peacock.

9
00:00:31.240 --> 00:00:32.490
Jo, welcome back to the show.

10
00:00:32.490 --> 00:00:35.740
>> [LAUGH] Thanks very much for
having me Ronnie, I'm pleased to be here.

11
00:00:35.740 --> 00:00:38.900
>> Well, Jo, we've already taken a look
at a couple of different topics, and

12
00:00:38.900 --> 00:00:41.760
I've mentioned this before,
relatively quickly.

13
00:00:41.760 --> 00:00:45.230
We are now moving into the realm
of application management.

14
00:00:45.230 --> 00:00:48.694
And I've said this in the plural,
and you corrected me right away.

15
00:00:48.694 --> 00:00:51.710
You're going to have to explain why
that's actually so important, Jo.

16
00:00:51.710 --> 00:00:53.177
So Jo, what are we talking about here?

17
00:00:53.177 --> 00:00:55.215
>> Well, it's important, really, for

18
00:00:55.215 --> 00:00:57.701
the case of its like with
everything with ITIL.

19
00:00:57.701 --> 00:01:01.619
It's important for
the case of accreditation and

20
00:01:01.619 --> 00:01:06.467
this is an accredited class that
anybody can take part in, and

21
00:01:06.467 --> 00:01:09.930
then go and sit an accredited examination.

22
00:01:09.930 --> 00:01:14.520
So, we wanna make sure that we
get all of the terminology right,

23
00:01:14.520 --> 00:01:18.850
exactly as it appears
in publications because

24
00:01:18.850 --> 00:01:23.050
that could be the difference
between some points in a test.

25
00:01:23.050 --> 00:01:27.684
So we wanna give everybody the opportunity
to get everything right and

26
00:01:27.684 --> 00:01:30.601
to get the right answers
in the test as well.

27
00:01:30.601 --> 00:01:31.618
>> All right Joe so

28
00:01:31.618 --> 00:01:36.870
when it comes down to the idea
then of an application management.

29
00:01:36.870 --> 00:01:39.720
We one, of course, make sure that we
cover everything that we need to.

30
00:01:39.720 --> 00:01:41.947
Where is the point that we need to begin?

31
00:01:41.947 --> 00:01:44.950
>> Okay, well application management.

32
00:01:44.950 --> 00:01:46.910
It's another functional area.

33
00:01:46.910 --> 00:01:52.300
So it's another group of people
that we have within ITIL.

34
00:01:52.300 --> 00:01:55.810
That we can not tell you how
to structure your team, so

35
00:01:55.810 --> 00:02:00.240
we can't tell you that you're
going to have SAP support and

36
00:02:00.240 --> 00:02:03.500
you're going to have
Microsoft Office support etc.

37
00:02:03.500 --> 00:02:06.740
Because we really don't know what
you've got in your organization.

38
00:02:06.740 --> 00:02:10.482
So what we do is we'll tell you that
people that support application.

39
00:02:10.482 --> 00:02:13.061
No matter what those applications are and

40
00:02:13.061 --> 00:02:17.040
people that manage applications
throughout their life cycle,

41
00:02:17.040 --> 00:02:21.710
well they are what we consider to
be application management people.

42
00:02:21.710 --> 00:02:25.429
So we give in these guys I think
we gave them a green hand didn't

43
00:02:25.429 --> 00:02:26.939
we in previous section.

44
00:02:26.939 --> 00:02:28.680
>> Right.
>> Yeah, we did.

45
00:02:28.680 --> 00:02:32.035
So, our technical management guys
well we gave them a blue hat and

46
00:02:32.035 --> 00:02:35.268
we said if you are doing anything
if you are working on service,

47
00:02:35.268 --> 00:02:39.530
if you're working on the infrastructure,
then you are wearing a blue hat.

48
00:02:39.530 --> 00:02:43.701
But, then later on that day, you might be
doing so work with some applications for

49
00:02:43.701 --> 00:02:47.450
instance doing some software support or
software development.

50
00:02:47.450 --> 00:02:49.710
So you'll be wearing a green hat.

51
00:02:49.710 --> 00:02:53.350
And so, these people got to perform
into project management and

52
00:02:53.350 --> 00:03:00.670
are doing the design and development
of applications and of services

53
00:03:00.670 --> 00:03:05.540
in their entirety are going to be wearing
two hats, potentially at the same time.

54
00:03:05.540 --> 00:03:09.810
Because if you're designing a service,
you're designing the entire

55
00:03:09.810 --> 00:03:14.270
service includes in all of the components
that that service requires, so

56
00:03:14.270 --> 00:03:16.680
therefore you're going to
be doing some server work.

57
00:03:16.680 --> 00:03:18.530
You're going to be doing
some infrastructure work.

58
00:03:18.530 --> 00:03:20.660
You're going to be doing
some application work.

59
00:03:22.320 --> 00:03:26.761
The first thing that I want to draw
your attention to Is, if you notice,

60
00:03:26.761 --> 00:03:32.096
the technical knowledge and expertise
relating to managing applications, that's

61
00:03:32.096 --> 00:03:37.375
pretty much exactly the same wording as we
had in our technical management section.

62
00:03:37.375 --> 00:03:42.283
The only difference being is that we're
relating this to managing applications,

63
00:03:42.283 --> 00:03:44.620
and not managing the infrastructure.

64
00:03:44.620 --> 00:03:49.200
But as I said,
it's all about the hat that we wear.

65
00:03:49.200 --> 00:03:54.720
And so this particular group of people,
however you want to organize them,

66
00:03:54.720 --> 00:04:00.070
are gonna provide all of the resources
to manage all of the life of a service.

67
00:04:00.070 --> 00:04:06.067
That means the design, the development,
the bills, the test, the implementation,

68
00:04:06.067 --> 00:04:11.593
and the ongoing support, and then the
ongoing continual improvements as well.

69
00:04:11.593 --> 00:04:16.701
So these people support the whole of
the service management life cycle,

70
00:04:16.701 --> 00:04:21.473
the whole of itel as we might call
it including providing guidance to

71
00:04:21.473 --> 00:04:24.506
operations on things like when to back up.

72
00:04:24.506 --> 00:04:26.410
What types of backups are needed?

73
00:04:26.410 --> 00:04:29.950
Do we need incremental backups or
do we need full backups?

74
00:04:29.950 --> 00:04:34.260
These people provide all the training for
the applications as well.

75
00:04:35.390 --> 00:04:38.791
Now before we move on
any further I just want

76
00:04:38.791 --> 00:04:42.863
to draw your attention to
a differentiation here.

77
00:04:42.863 --> 00:04:47.316
Because there is a subset of
application management that we call

78
00:04:47.316 --> 00:04:49.300
application development.

79
00:04:50.860 --> 00:04:54.800
Now when we first start a project and

80
00:04:54.800 --> 00:04:58.369
we come up in service strategy
with the idea for a new service.

81
00:05:00.150 --> 00:05:03.680
And with that idea,
we go off into financial management,

82
00:05:03.680 --> 00:05:06.140
and with business relationship management,
and we create a business case, and

83
00:05:06.140 --> 00:05:09.500
we give that business case to our group.

84
00:05:09.500 --> 00:05:13.249
And our steering group, based on
the details within the business case,

85
00:05:13.249 --> 00:05:16.446
and the desire within the organization
will either approve or

86
00:05:16.446 --> 00:05:17.936
reject that business case.

87
00:05:17.936 --> 00:05:21.330
So let's say that they
approve a business case.

88
00:05:21.330 --> 00:05:23.830
Well, the first thing that's
going to happen then,

89
00:05:23.830 --> 00:05:27.150
is a project manager is
going to be assigned.

90
00:05:27.150 --> 00:05:29.390
Because the service has
now been chartered.

91
00:05:29.390 --> 00:05:33.260
In other words, it's been approved and
it's been given a delivery date.

92
00:05:33.260 --> 00:05:35.050
Although that point in time is estimated.

93
00:05:36.290 --> 00:05:39.230
So the first thing that happens
is that the project manager

94
00:05:39.230 --> 00:05:42.370
will bring in some
application management people

95
00:05:42.370 --> 00:05:46.630
to then design the application
portion of that service.

96
00:05:46.630 --> 00:05:49.240
He's gonna bring in some people with
some technical management skills too.

97
00:05:50.245 --> 00:05:54.055
So he'll have people around him that are
wearing both colored hats, maybe both at

98
00:05:54.055 --> 00:05:57.725
the same time, you never know, and
they're going to design a service.

99
00:05:59.365 --> 00:06:01.035
Once they've designed that service, or

100
00:06:01.035 --> 00:06:04.690
maybe as part of the design,
cuz maybe they already know it.

101
00:06:04.690 --> 00:06:09.150
There's going to be a decision
made as to whether we build or

102
00:06:09.150 --> 00:06:13.326
develop an application in-house or
whether we go out and

103
00:06:13.326 --> 00:06:18.240
we buy what we call a COTS product,
a Commercial Off The Shelf Product.

104
00:06:19.770 --> 00:06:26.430
And so we have a subset to application
management called application development.

105
00:06:26.430 --> 00:06:30.818
An application development
are the group of people

106
00:06:30.818 --> 00:06:33.986
who actually develop new software.

107
00:06:33.986 --> 00:06:39.014
But let's say for instance that we're
in service design at the moment and

108
00:06:39.014 --> 00:06:44.042
we're designing this new service and
the service is to deliver financial

109
00:06:44.042 --> 00:06:49.580
accounting for instance including payroll
and including sales and marketing.

110
00:06:50.600 --> 00:06:54.536
Would it be wise, do you think,
Ronnie, to build something in a house,

111
00:06:54.536 --> 00:06:58.860
or do you think you're more likely to go
outside of the organization to somebody

112
00:06:58.860 --> 00:07:00.622
who has already got the skills?

113
00:07:00.622 --> 00:07:04.296
>> I think it would probably be better
to go outside instead of me trying

114
00:07:04.296 --> 00:07:06.200
to reinvent the wheel.

115
00:07:06.200 --> 00:07:07.610
>> Right, exactly.

116
00:07:07.610 --> 00:07:08.490
And you know what?

117
00:07:08.490 --> 00:07:12.890
I love the way you use that word, because,
and no it wasn't prompted, honest.

118
00:07:12.890 --> 00:07:17.116
I love the way you use that, because
that's exactly how a lot of organization

119
00:07:17.116 --> 00:07:21.547
see this right now, is the fact that
there's no point in reinventing the wheel.

120
00:07:21.547 --> 00:07:24.474
If there's already a product out there, or

121
00:07:24.474 --> 00:07:30.025
there is already a product that meets
what we call 80% of the requirements.

122
00:07:30.025 --> 00:07:35.745
Then, in that case, really,
there's no point in doing it in house.

123
00:07:35.745 --> 00:07:39.000
So application development
is not utilized.

124
00:07:39.000 --> 00:07:42.747
And what we do is we manage,
we leave it within the realms of

125
00:07:42.747 --> 00:07:47.411
application management and we manage
the purchase of that product, and

126
00:07:47.411 --> 00:07:50.020
then the subsequent, how do I put this?

127
00:07:50.020 --> 00:07:54.925
Customization, I guess,
of that product through to Development,

128
00:07:54.925 --> 00:07:58.400
implementation and
then into the live service.

129
00:07:58.400 --> 00:08:03.552
So we utilize a small framework,
a small technique, called MoSCoW or

130
00:08:03.552 --> 00:08:09.156
I think we say it slightly differently
here is it MOSCOW is that how we say it.

131
00:08:09.156 --> 00:08:13.276
Yeah, okay [LAUGH] I what it stands for
really,

132
00:08:13.276 --> 00:08:19.088
when it comes to application purchasing,
we have the must have,

133
00:08:19.088 --> 00:08:24.265
should have, could have and
either wanna have right now,

134
00:08:24.265 --> 00:08:28.620
or would like at some point
in time in the future.

135
00:08:28.620 --> 00:08:34.604
And the general rule that project teams
will employ here is that really a service,

136
00:08:34.604 --> 00:08:41.023
a new application, will need to meet about
80% of the must have functionality within

137
00:08:41.023 --> 00:08:47.480
that list that we have of must haves and
should haves and could haves, etc.

138
00:08:47.480 --> 00:08:52.680
So, it's that, that will help us make
that decision as to whether we design and

139
00:08:52.680 --> 00:08:57.680
build it in-house using application
development or whether we go outside and

140
00:08:57.680 --> 00:08:59.210
we purchase something off the shelf.

141
00:08:59.210 --> 00:09:01.664
Because if somebody's already done it,

142
00:09:01.664 --> 00:09:04.990
there is absolutely no point
in reinventing the wheel.

143
00:09:04.990 --> 00:09:07.550
It's very costly to do that and

144
00:09:07.550 --> 00:09:10.830
if we have the right skills
in-house to do that, that's great.

145
00:09:10.830 --> 00:09:13.999
But, what happens if those skills are no
longer there for whatever reason.

146
00:09:15.540 --> 00:09:20.701
So we find that buying applications
off the shelf can quite often be

147
00:09:20.701 --> 00:09:25.688
the most cost-effective way of
implementing any new service.

148
00:09:25.688 --> 00:09:30.393
So application development is optional,
wherever it's required,

149
00:09:30.393 --> 00:09:35.339
it forms part of the application
management and application development

150
00:09:35.339 --> 00:09:40.160
team will quite often then go
on to support any application.

151
00:09:40.160 --> 00:09:44.330
But let's say for instance,
we're just going to assume that for

152
00:09:44.330 --> 00:09:47.910
