this new service that we talking about,
we're going to buy it off the shelf.

153
00:09:47.910 --> 00:09:51.660
So it's going to need some
customization once we've bought it.

154
00:09:51.660 --> 00:09:54.975
But we're gonna leave it within
the realms of application management.

155
00:09:54.975 --> 00:09:57.561
And application management as a whole,

156
00:09:57.561 --> 00:10:01.143
their role is to support all
of the business processes.

157
00:10:01.143 --> 00:10:03.825
So right at the very start of any project,

158
00:10:03.825 --> 00:10:09.070
we are identifying functional
requirements for an application.

159
00:10:09.070 --> 00:10:13.750
And then we're assisting with the design,
notice not the development.

160
00:10:13.750 --> 00:10:16.970
We're assisting with the design and
the deployment and

161
00:10:16.970 --> 00:10:20.490
the support and
improvement of those applications.

162
00:10:20.490 --> 00:10:24.270
Now what it doesn't mention there and
what we need to add into this,

163
00:10:24.270 --> 00:10:30.180
is that it also assists with
the evaluation of the various products,

164
00:10:30.180 --> 00:10:34.690
because we do have a process that will
allow us to evaluate those products.

165
00:10:34.690 --> 00:10:38.759
And we start off with MoSCoW,
but then we still have to,

166
00:10:38.759 --> 00:10:43.782
once we've evaluated the products
that meet that 80% criteria,

167
00:10:43.782 --> 00:10:48.458
then we want to compare against
all of the products that meet that

168
00:10:48.458 --> 00:10:51.922
80% criteria and
come up with a shortlist and

169
00:10:51.922 --> 00:10:55.943
evaluate based on various
factors such as cost, etc.

170
00:10:55.943 --> 00:11:00.323
You see we need our applications because
they're a component of our service service

171
00:11:00.323 --> 00:11:03.460
too and while there is the network and
hardware, etc.

172
00:11:03.460 --> 00:11:05.300
We need our applications to be resilient.

173
00:11:06.480 --> 00:11:09.908
We need them to be well-designed and
to be cost effective.

174
00:11:09.908 --> 00:11:13.760
In ITEL, and in our introduction section,

175
00:11:13.760 --> 00:11:18.270
we looked at the ability of
a service to facilitate an outcome.

176
00:11:18.270 --> 00:11:22.470
We looked at two aspects of the service,
which were utility and warranty.

177
00:11:23.960 --> 00:11:29.120
Utility is really the ability of
a service to do what it's supposed to do.

178
00:11:30.280 --> 00:11:32.715
So for instance, if we wanted
it to send and receive e-mails.

179
00:11:34.160 --> 00:11:40.420
Well the warranty aspects of the service
look at the warranty factors such as

180
00:11:40.420 --> 00:11:46.280
availability, such as capacity,
continuity, and security.

181
00:11:46.280 --> 00:11:52.542
So warranty looks at
the usability of a service, okay?

182
00:11:52.542 --> 00:11:56.776
So if you think about utility
as being fit for purpose,

183
00:11:56.776 --> 00:12:00.210
does it do what it's supposed to do?

184
00:12:00.210 --> 00:12:02.360
Does it send and receive e-mail?

185
00:12:02.360 --> 00:12:07.760
And then warranty is about it being
fit for use, but can I use it?

186
00:12:07.760 --> 00:12:09.950
So let me give you a real
life example in this one.

187
00:12:09.950 --> 00:12:13.280
Because sometimes it can be a little
bit difficult to get your head around.

188
00:12:13.280 --> 00:12:14.200
And I acknowledge that.

189
00:12:15.230 --> 00:12:17.430
So if we wanted to source
an e-mail solution.

190
00:12:17.430 --> 00:12:19.450
So this what we're doing
as part of our project,

191
00:12:19.450 --> 00:12:21.460
we want to source an email solution.

192
00:12:21.460 --> 00:12:25.050
We've ascertained that we're not going to
use application development because there

193
00:12:25.050 --> 00:12:27.970
are so
many different e-mail products out there.

194
00:12:27.970 --> 00:12:33.393
So what we might do then is, we might
evaluate something like an online product,

195
00:12:33.393 --> 00:12:37.730
something that provides us
with free access to e-mail.

196
00:12:37.730 --> 00:12:38.620
That's great, right?

197
00:12:38.620 --> 00:12:41.050
It's free, so
of course we want to go with that.

198
00:12:41.050 --> 00:12:42.020
Don't we?

199
00:12:42.020 --> 00:12:48.012
Do we really want to go with a free
online e-mail in a business environment?

200
00:12:48.012 --> 00:12:49.510
>> No.
>> Why not?

201
00:12:49.510 --> 00:12:52.774
>> Well,
one you don't have any support for it.

202
00:12:52.774 --> 00:12:53.726
>> Right.

203
00:12:53.726 --> 00:12:57.450
>> If you have a particular business
function that you're saying, hey,

204
00:12:57.450 --> 00:13:00.305
this is not something that
they're going to support,

205
00:13:00.305 --> 00:13:03.260
if it's something specific
to your business.

206
00:13:03.260 --> 00:13:06.780
Two, you don't know who else
can have access to that and

207
00:13:06.780 --> 00:13:10.550
that means they may also gain
unauthorized access to your material.

208
00:13:10.550 --> 00:13:12.000
>> So you're looking at security here.

209
00:13:12.000 --> 00:13:12.560
>> Security.

210
00:13:12.560 --> 00:13:16.737
>> You're looking at supportability,
you're looking at availability, and

211
00:13:16.737 --> 00:13:17.708
capacity, etc.

212
00:13:17.708 --> 00:13:20.901
What you're looking at is
the warranty aspects so

213
00:13:20.901 --> 00:13:24.940
you see that online e-mail
service provides us with utility.

214
00:13:24.940 --> 00:13:25.820
>> Right.

215
00:13:25.820 --> 00:13:27.890
>> Okay?
It does exactly what is supposed to do

216
00:13:27.890 --> 00:13:30.130
with, it does what it says on the can and
that's great.

217
00:13:31.340 --> 00:13:34.000
But it still doesn't mean
what we value that service.

218
00:13:34.000 --> 00:13:34.927
>> Right.

219
00:13:34.927 --> 00:13:39.447
>> Because what you've outlined to me is
that we value the warranty aspects of that

220
00:13:39.447 --> 00:13:40.630
service, too.

221
00:13:40.630 --> 00:13:42.060
We value security.

222
00:13:42.060 --> 00:13:43.010
Yeah, we do.

223
00:13:43.010 --> 00:13:48.710
And we value continuity as well and we
value availability and capacity as well.

224
00:13:48.710 --> 00:13:52.170
So, we need both elements to exist,
in order for

225
00:13:52.170 --> 00:13:56.710
us to perceive value, in order for
the business to perceive value.

226
00:13:56.710 --> 00:14:00.540
So we probably wouldn't go with
the free online e-mail service,

227
00:14:00.540 --> 00:14:05.110
because even though it's free, and
provides with cost-effectiveness,

228
00:14:05.110 --> 00:14:11.790
it's not actually meeting our real needs,
which is for security, etc.

229
00:14:11.790 --> 00:14:15.610
So we would go with something that was
commercially off-the-shelf available

230
00:14:15.610 --> 00:14:20.440
perhaps, but something that allowed
us to configure in-house and

231
00:14:20.440 --> 00:14:25.315
allowed us to determine
the levels of availability, etc.

232
00:14:25.315 --> 00:14:28.710
Dependent on our own infrastructure and
our own network.

233
00:14:28.710 --> 00:14:31.660
So we're utilizing both
application management and

234
00:14:31.660 --> 00:14:35.450
technical management in that
decision as to what product to buy.

235
00:14:35.450 --> 00:14:40.510
You see, we talk about
applications being easily and

236
00:14:40.510 --> 00:14:44.840
well designed and cost effective but
it's not just about cost effectiveness.

237
00:14:44.840 --> 00:14:47.900
It's also about our ability to support,
and

238
00:14:47.900 --> 00:14:51.800
our ability to ensure that we meet
the needs of the organization.

239
00:14:51.800 --> 00:14:54.160
So it's not just about
ensuring functionality,

240
00:14:54.160 --> 00:14:56.700
it's about ensuring all of
the warranty aspects, too.

241
00:14:57.810 --> 00:15:03.055
So here in application management then,
we maintain the skills that allow us not

242
00:15:03.055 --> 00:15:06.485
just to design and develop and

243
00:15:06.485 --> 00:15:11.505
implement those services or customize
rather than develop those services, but

244
00:15:11.505 --> 00:15:14.685
also that allow us to
support those services too.

245
00:15:14.685 --> 00:15:19.419
Hence that last bullet point about
resolving application related issues.

246
00:15:20.450 --> 00:15:24.270
So you'll see that the next slide
really just reinforces that.

247
00:15:24.270 --> 00:15:28.560
We're talking about the expertise
needed to manage these applications

248
00:15:28.560 --> 00:15:29.800
throughout their lifecycle.

249
00:15:29.800 --> 00:15:32.520
From the inception,

250
00:15:32.520 --> 00:15:37.850
right the way through continual service
improvement, and then retirement as well.

251
00:15:37.850 --> 00:15:39.716
So here in application management,

252
00:15:39.716 --> 00:15:43.096
we're actually performing all of
the training for our end users.

253
00:15:43.096 --> 00:15:46.959
And we're performing
on-going support as well for

254
00:15:46.959 --> 00:15:52.577
those applications and for those
services Now in application management,

255
00:15:52.577 --> 00:15:57.668
we will take the new approved business
cases back in service design,

256
00:15:57.668 --> 00:16:01.970
and we will evaluate what
products there are available off

257
00:16:01.970 --> 00:16:05.860
the shelf in order to meet
the needs of the business.

258
00:16:05.860 --> 00:16:08.180
So that includes research and development.

259
00:16:08.180 --> 00:16:10.990
It includes liaising with suppliers.

260
00:16:10.990 --> 00:16:15.920
And it includes negotiating contracts
with suppliers that can meet or

261
00:16:15.920 --> 00:16:18.400
exceed the needs of the business.

262
00:16:18.400 --> 00:16:22.372
So when we say involvement in all
projects, we're talking about involvement

263
00:16:22.372 --> 00:16:25.501
in projects, we're talking
about involvement in support,

264
00:16:25.501 --> 00:16:28.210
involvement in continual
service improvement, and

265
00:16:28.210 --> 00:16:31.830
we're talking about involvement
in the decision making too.

266
00:16:31.830 --> 00:16:34.660
Things like availability and
capacity management.

267
00:16:34.660 --> 00:16:39.740
In planning for requirements, for
our technical management guys.

268
00:16:39.740 --> 00:16:44.680
You see and it's the same people,
they're just wearing two different hats.

269
00:16:44.680 --> 00:16:48.450
They're going to do testing,
they're going to do training, and

270
00:16:48.450 --> 00:16:52.230
there's of course that difference between
customer testing and user testing as well,

271
00:16:52.230 --> 00:16:55.290
and these guys are going
to be involved in that.

272
00:16:55.290 --> 00:16:58.810
They're also going to be involved
in sourcing a product, so

273
00:16:58.810 --> 00:17:01.451
therefore they're gonna be
involved in supplier management.

274
00:17:01.451 --> 00:17:06.225
Okay, they're going to be dealing
with incidents and with problems, and

275
00:17:06.225 --> 00:17:11.377
also with new changes too because you know
our customers, they like to come along

276
00:17:11.377 --> 00:17:16.105
with new ideas for bits of functionality
that they can add into a service.

277
00:17:16.105 --> 00:17:20.137
And so they're going to be evaluating
those new ideas as well so they can help

278
00:17:20.137 --> 00:17:25.470
change management with that, and they're
gonna help with the actual deployment.

279
00:17:25.470 --> 00:17:29.060
And I also like the bit which is the third
bullet point from the bottom there about

280
00:17:29.060 --> 00:17:31.630
supporting the known error database.

281
00:17:32.780 --> 00:17:39.240
When we looked at problem management,
we looked at the fact that sometimes, and

282
00:17:39.240 --> 00:17:44.920
I dare mention the fact that sometimes our
services come to us with known errors.

283
00:17:45.920 --> 00:17:48.670
Sometimes they might call
them a list of features but

284
00:17:48.670 --> 00:17:52.260
sometimes they're known errors and
we say, hey, where do we put them?

285
00:17:52.260 --> 00:17:54.380
Well, we put them in our
known error database.

286
00:17:54.380 --> 00:17:58.100
But application management's role
is to ensure that we validate

287
00:17:58.100 --> 00:17:58.969
those known errors.

288
00:17:59.980 --> 00:18:05.070
So we make sure that whatever we're doing
when we're bringing in new services,

289
00:18:05.070 --> 00:18:09.890
that they are updated in our
configuration management system.

290
00:18:09.890 --> 00:18:14.410
And that we are continually aligned
to the needs of the organization.

291
00:18:14.410 --> 00:18:19.220
And that all project documentation and all
support documentation and even the service

292
00:18:19.220 --> 00:18:24.900
catalog is up to date with
the details of that application.

293
00:18:24.900 --> 00:18:28.330
And that we have the right
service level targets

294
00:18:28.330 --> 00:18:32.050
in our service level agreements too.

295
00:18:32.050 --> 00:18:36.030
Now, I like the fact that we refer
to financial management as well.

296
00:18:36.030 --> 00:18:41.170
And I've liked that in all of
our previous sections too.

297
00:18:41.170 --> 00:18:45.248
Because, as I've said before,
probably ad nauseam,

298
00:18:45.248 --> 00:18:50.300
that quite simply, we need to be
involved in financial management.

299
00:18:50.300 --> 00:18:54.460
We're in IT, and we don't like to be
involved in financial management.

300
00:18:54.460 --> 00:18:57.570
But we need to be involved
in financial management.

301
00:18:57.570 --> 00:19:01.258
And we also need to be involved in
decision making and in policy definition

302
00:19:01.258 --> 00:19:06.120
too, though sometimes in IT documentation
doesn't come easily to us either.

303
00:19:06.120 --> 00:19:08.670
It's not something that we like to do.

304
00:19:08.670 --> 00:19:12.300
But nevertheless, we understand
the need for that consistency and

305
00:19:12.300 --> 00:19:14.300
we understand the need for
that governance.

306
00:19:14.300 --> 00:19:19.130
So that's something here that, yes, is
very important in application management,

307
00:19:19.130 --> 00:19:24.035
because these are the software
support procedures that people like

308
00:19:24.035 --> 00:19:29.060
the service desk and second and third
level support teams are going to be using.

309
00:19:29.060 --> 00:19:33.639
So these user manuals and
these standard operating procedures, well,

310
00:19:33.639 --> 00:19:37.090
not only have they got to be
defined in the first place,

311
00:19:37.090 --> 00:19:40.336
they've actually got to be
kept up to date as well.

312
00:19:40.336 --> 00:19:43.765
So what we really took a look
at over the last three sections,

313
00:19:43.765 --> 00:19:45.850
we looked at technical management,

314
00:19:45.850 --> 00:19:50.290
which is the functional area that
deals with our own infrastructure.

315
00:19:50.290 --> 00:19:55.549
We looked at operations management, which
is the functional area that deals with

316
00:19:55.549 --> 00:20:00.805
the business as usual, where we split that
into two subfunctions of ops control,

317
00:20:00.805 --> 00:20:05.249
that's the console management and
facilities management as well.

318
00:20:05.249 --> 00:20:09.049
Where we looked at the physical
environment, such as power and

319
00:20:09.049 --> 00:20:11.290
air conditioning and data centers.

320
00:20:11.290 --> 00:20:15.200
And then we've looked at application
management, where we support the entire

321
00:20:15.200 --> 00:20:20.920
life cycle in defining the software
component of our services.

322
00:20:20.920 --> 00:20:24.390
And on top of that,
we looked at application development too,

323
00:20:24.390 --> 00:20:28.480
where we actually build and deploy and

324
00:20:28.480 --> 00:20:32.800
test those services that are specific.

325
00:20:32.800 --> 00:20:36.230
Very, very specific and
unique to our organization.

326
00:20:36.230 --> 00:20:40.740
So what I'd like you to do now is I'd
like you to refer back to your notes.

327
00:20:40.740 --> 00:20:46.150
And you will see some, what I would call,
being English, revision exercises or

328
00:20:46.150 --> 00:20:51.170
study exercises that will help
you to understand further and

329
00:20:51.170 --> 00:20:56.170
get a little bit more into depth in the
concept of the three technical areas of

330
00:20:56.170 --> 00:21:01.529
technical management, and operations
management and applications management.

331
00:21:02.620 --> 00:21:04.409
Alright, Jo, well, thank you again for

332
00:21:04.409 --> 00:21:07.230
helping us to understand
this a little bit better.

333
00:21:07.230 --> 00:21:13.190
I've actually got a great little
understanding between utility and

334
00:21:13.190 --> 00:21:17.140
warranty now that really does help me
to understand that a little bit better.

335
00:21:17.140 --> 00:21:20.140
Application management is one of those
key elements that helps us to be able

336
00:21:20.140 --> 00:21:21.440
to provide both.

337
00:21:21.440 --> 00:21:25.520
But, remember that there is more for
you to do than just watch the shows

338
00:21:25.520 --> 00:21:29.100
that you've been watching so make sure you
also do that assignment that Jo is talking

339
00:21:29.100 --> 00:21:32.150
about as well and
review these concepts as you move on.

340
00:21:32.150 --> 00:21:34.720
But, it's a great place for
us to end this episode then.

341
00:21:34.720 --> 00:21:38.520
Signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

342
00:21:38.520 --> 00:21:39.988
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

343
00:21:39.988 --> 00:21:44.877
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation shows.

344
00:21:44.877 --> 00:21:50.793
[MUSIC]

345
00:21:50.793 --> 00:21:54.351
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo review the organization structures.  According to Jo, geography, scale, culture and business environment must be considered when implementing organizational management.  Jo describes these management teams that can be organized along technical specialization, activities, geography; they also have benefits and drawbacks that must be considered too.  She also mentions the possibility of working toward a hybrid approach in which core services can be shared without duplication of services and services that need localization can be provided as needed.
episodes.title: Organizational Structures
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.857
Welcome to IT ProTV I am your
host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:07.857 --> 00:00:12.097
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.097 --> 00:00:15.020
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.020 --> 00:00:19.990
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Operation show.

5
00:00:19.990 --> 00:00:25.685
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today we're
diving into organizational management,

6
00:00:25.685 --> 00:00:29.470
but with a Z instead of an S.

7
00:00:29.470 --> 00:00:36.625
Now, we have with us, of course, then,
our master at ITIL herself, Jo Peacock.

8
00:00:36.625 --> 00:00:39.760
Jo, is it okay that we
actually do this with a Z?

9
00:00:39.760 --> 00:00:42.020
>> Well, you know what?

10
00:00:42.020 --> 00:00:44.214
It's gonna be difficult for me but-
>> [LAUGH]

11
00:00:44.214 --> 00:00:46.268
>> We can manage it just this once.

12
00:00:46.268 --> 00:00:47.850
>> Okay, all right.

13
00:00:47.850 --> 00:00:50.080
So Jo as we, I know it's a joke but

14
00:00:50.080 --> 00:00:53.890
at the same time, we do understand
some of these different things.

15
00:00:53.890 --> 00:00:56.690
Now, when we start talking about
organizational management,

16
00:00:56.690 --> 00:01:01.300
this sounds fairly like an umbrella
type of term that we're covering,

17
00:01:01.300 --> 00:01:02.760
what are we looking at here?

18
00:01:02.760 --> 00:01:06.560
>> Well, we're actually going to be
looking at the organizational structures

19
00:01:06.560 --> 00:01:10.610
that we could have within
any IT service provider.

20
00:01:10.610 --> 00:01:15.560
The last few sections that we did,
the few sessions that we did.

21
00:01:15.560 --> 00:01:17.130
We looked at functional areas.

22
00:01:17.130 --> 00:01:21.060
And a functional area is a group of
people and the skills that they use.

23
00:01:21.060 --> 00:01:25.862
And I have said to you time and
time again, ad nauseam,

24
00:01:25.862 --> 00:01:29.360
that we can't tell you how
to organize your IT teams.

25
00:01:31.570 --> 00:01:33.800
But you know what,
we're gonna give you some ideas.

26
00:01:33.800 --> 00:01:35.660
And that's what this
section's really about.

27
00:01:35.660 --> 00:01:37.810
It's just giving you some ideas.

28
00:01:37.810 --> 00:01:41.920
So this, again, is a very short section
that really is just going to go

29
00:01:41.920 --> 00:01:46.600
over the different types of organizational
structure there are and the pros and

30
00:01:46.600 --> 00:01:50.450
cons of each of those types
of organizational structure.

31
00:01:50.450 --> 00:01:52.750
So if you take a look
at your course notes,

32
00:01:52.750 --> 00:01:58.490
you will see that we have got four
types of organizational structure.

33
00:01:59.580 --> 00:02:02.840
We look at things like,
or rather not four types,

34
00:02:02.840 --> 00:02:08.010
these are the four influences that will
decide what type of structure we have.

35
00:02:08.010 --> 00:02:09.970
So let's look at our geography,

36
00:02:09.970 --> 00:02:15.220
where our offices are located,
where our business is located.

37
00:02:15.220 --> 00:02:19.700
Maybe we have manufacturing plants
that are in one particular state or

38
00:02:19.700 --> 00:02:22.825
maybe our offices could be in
another country, for instance.

39
00:02:22.825 --> 00:02:25.450
Think about the scale of
the organization too.

40
00:02:25.450 --> 00:02:27.520
And think about the culture.

41
00:02:28.530 --> 00:02:32.390
Some people work very,
very well in a collaborative environment.

42
00:02:32.390 --> 00:02:36.570
But some cultures actually require,
and prefer,

43
00:02:36.570 --> 00:02:40.000
as well,
having a hierarchical structure, okay?

44
00:02:40.000 --> 00:02:42.400
And then think about
the business environment itself.

45
00:02:42.400 --> 00:02:45.810
What type of business
organization are you in?

46
00:02:45.810 --> 00:02:49.640
Are you in an organization that
is geared very much towards

47
00:02:49.640 --> 00:02:53.650
technical specialities where
people tend to work in silos?

48
00:02:53.650 --> 00:02:57.020
Or are you in an organization where
collaboration is really important?

49
00:02:58.750 --> 00:03:04.240
So let's take a look, then,
at one of the first structures that

50
00:03:04.240 --> 00:03:09.100
we could employ within service operations,
okay?

51
00:03:09.100 --> 00:03:14.880
So you see here that this is what
we probably all see every day.

52
00:03:14.880 --> 00:03:20.370
This looks to me to be a fairly
typical organizational structure for

53
00:03:20.370 --> 00:03:24.110
most IT teams and
most IT service providers.

54
00:03:24.110 --> 00:03:27.219
And that's organization by
technical specification.

55
00:03:28.996 --> 00:03:33.712
It's easy to set internal performance
objectives because everybody knows

56
00:03:33.712 --> 00:03:36.520
what each individual
team is supposed to do.

57
00:03:38.090 --> 00:03:40.880
So you've got the people with
the right skills that are managing

58
00:03:40.880 --> 00:03:42.880
those specific areas.

59
00:03:42.880 --> 00:03:46.810
We can manage training,
we can manage performance reviews, etc.

60
00:03:48.550 --> 00:03:51.290
But then,
we've got a down side to this too.

61
00:03:51.290 --> 00:03:53.960
Look at that siloed mentality.

62
00:03:55.590 --> 00:03:57.210
I mentioned in previous sections,

63
00:03:57.210 --> 00:04:01.040
and it's one of the big dangers
within incident management.

64
00:04:01.040 --> 00:04:03.490
Not only incidents, on problems as well.

65
00:04:03.490 --> 00:04:06.730
And even requests that get
passed from pillar to post.

66
00:04:06.730 --> 00:04:10.400
They get passed from one team to another,
to another, to another.

67
00:04:10.400 --> 00:04:13.980
So imagine you have an incident, and
you've got an incident that's got a four

68
00:04:13.980 --> 00:04:17.870
hour response on that service
level target for that incident.

69
00:04:19.005 --> 00:04:24.070
And we know that it's something
to do with our infrastructure.

70
00:04:24.070 --> 00:04:28.972
So the incidence is raised by the service
desk and the service desk is trying and

71
00:04:28.972 --> 00:04:32.940
do some determination on
incident investigation diagnosis.

72
00:04:32.940 --> 00:04:37.980
And they then,
they spend 30 minutes on that incident.

73
00:04:37.980 --> 00:04:39.320
Well, now we're down to three and

74
00:04:39.320 --> 00:04:44.210
a half hours left on that
particular service level target.

75
00:04:44.210 --> 00:04:47.080
But they've decided that they need
to escalate it functionally and

76
00:04:47.080 --> 00:04:48.835
they think it's something
to do with the network.

77
00:04:48.835 --> 00:04:51.655
So what they're going
to do is they're going

78
00:04:51.655 --> 00:04:53.875
to escalate it to network operations.

79
00:04:55.015 --> 00:04:58.325
And then our network operations team,
we can see them down there

80
00:04:58.325 --> 00:05:03.540
under infrastructure operations, and
network operations team they look at it.

81
00:05:03.540 --> 00:05:07.160
But it takes them about 15 minutes
to actually pick up the incident and

82
00:05:07.160 --> 00:05:10.390
15 minutes to investigate and
then they decide, well actually,

83
00:05:10.390 --> 00:05:14.350
it's not really anything to do with them,
it's something to do with middleware.

84
00:05:14.350 --> 00:05:16.639
So they're going to pass
it to the server guys.

85
00:05:17.820 --> 00:05:21.840
And the server guys then take a look at
it, server operations, as we call them.

86
00:05:21.840 --> 00:05:25.770
And it's taken them 15 minutes to pick it
up, and it's taken them another 15 minutes

87
00:05:25.770 --> 00:05:28.660
to look at it before they decide
that actually it's got nothing

88
00:05:28.660 --> 00:05:32.040
to do with server it's back to
network again, it's a network problem.

89
00:05:32.040 --> 00:05:36.920
And so
what's happened is we have just wasted,

90
00:05:36.920 --> 00:05:43.450
literally wasted, an hour and
a half of that service level target time.

91
00:05:43.450 --> 00:05:46.250
We only have four hours and
now we've only got two and

92
00:05:46.250 --> 00:05:50.315
a half hours and nobody's started
to resolve that incident yet.

93
00:05:50.315 --> 00:05:54.140
We're still in exactly the same
position as we were when

94
00:05:54.140 --> 00:05:58.210
that incident was first raised and
yet one and half hours has elapsed.

95
00:05:58.210 --> 00:06:01.590
And this is what happens
with that siloed mentality.

96
00:06:01.590 --> 00:06:06.470
And it's very, very easy to get
into that siloed mentality as well.

97
00:06:06.470 --> 00:06:10.270
Let's think about the teams that
don't want to collaborate and

98
00:06:10.270 --> 00:06:15.180
the teams that don't work very well
together, you'll find the, them and

99
00:06:15.180 --> 00:06:20.190
us, sort of mentality there, that says,
well, I don't wanna share information

100
00:06:20.190 --> 00:06:24.430
with that team because you never know
they might trying take over our jobs.

101
00:06:24.430 --> 00:06:25.950
It sounds crazy, doesn't it?

102
00:06:25.950 --> 00:06:27.670
But you know I've heard this before.

103
00:06:27.670 --> 00:06:28.900
I've heard it way too many times.

104
00:06:30.070 --> 00:06:33.985
So you end up with fragmented knowledge
because nobody wants to share knowledge.

105
00:06:33.985 --> 00:06:37.000
And we've got that siloed mentality.

106
00:06:37.000 --> 00:06:41.500
So not only does that create difficulty
for things like incident resolution, but

107
00:06:41.500 --> 00:06:45.290
just look at change management,
change assessments, and change schedules.

108
00:06:45.290 --> 00:06:48.200
And if you're relying on somebody else and

109
00:06:48.200 --> 00:06:51.910
they're in a different team to you,
to do some work.

110
00:06:51.910 --> 00:06:53.410
Think about project management,

111
00:06:53.410 --> 00:06:58.270
a lot of projects actually progressed
through tasks and dependencies.

112
00:06:58.270 --> 00:07:02.680
One action is dependent on
the previous one being completed.

113
00:07:02.680 --> 00:07:05.290
So all you need is one
person to hold that up, and

114
00:07:05.290 --> 00:07:09.150
the whole project is then
held up by one bottleneck.

115
00:07:09.150 --> 00:07:10.850
And it could be just something simple,

116
00:07:10.850 --> 00:07:13.050
like two teams didn't
wanna talk to each other.

117
00:07:14.600 --> 00:07:19.930
So technical specification allows for
technical experience and

118
00:07:19.930 --> 00:07:26.980
technical expertise to be built, but
it can create a siloed mentality.

119
00:07:26.980 --> 00:07:30.820
Now I'm not gonna tell you that any one
of these structures is right or wrong.

120
00:07:30.820 --> 00:07:34.844
What I'm gonna point out are the benefits
to these structures, and also the dangers

121
00:07:34.844 --> 00:07:38.089
as well, the pitfalls that we can
fall into with these structures.

122
00:07:38.089 --> 00:07:44.100
So, in this particular structure,
then, we can organize by activity.

123
00:07:44.100 --> 00:07:47.710
Organizing by activity
means that we've got groups

124
00:07:47.710 --> 00:07:52.010
that have got related activities
that are organized together.

125
00:07:52.010 --> 00:07:54.750
So, for instance, rather than having,

126
00:07:54.750 --> 00:07:59.360
if we look in the previous structure, you
can see that we've got mainframe teams,

127
00:07:59.360 --> 00:08:02.690
and we've got server teams, and
we've got storage teams, and

128
00:08:02.690 --> 00:08:06.560
we've got a network team, and then
we've got different application teams.

129
00:08:06.560 --> 00:08:10.620
Well, at the moment, in that structure
there right in front of you,

130
00:08:10.620 --> 00:08:15.360
financial application, and HR application,
and business application may have

131
00:08:15.360 --> 00:08:19.660
different backup requirements and they
may even be managed by different teams.

132
00:08:19.660 --> 00:08:24.010
But if we go into this particular
structure, then the backups for

133
00:08:24.010 --> 00:08:27.774
all of those applications
will be managed by one team,

134
00:08:27.774 --> 00:08:31.016
which allows for prioritization.

135
00:08:31.016 --> 00:08:34.670
That's great, but
then we still have conflicts, then,

136
00:08:34.670 --> 00:08:38.640
between those applications
as to who is more important?

137
00:08:38.640 --> 00:08:43.730
So the output from each team is
based on a collective output and

138
00:08:43.730 --> 00:08:46.310
collective achievement.

139
00:08:46.310 --> 00:08:50.350
However, it would also
encourage collaboration but

140
00:08:50.350 --> 00:08:54.270
we then might have challenges
with prioritization.

141
00:08:54.270 --> 00:08:57.710
Because, you see, I can do more
than one thing at the same time.

142
00:08:59.180 --> 00:09:03.280
I can only either schedule a backup for

143
00:09:03.280 --> 00:09:07.290
this particular application or I can
perform the backup for this application.

144
00:09:07.290 --> 00:09:10.250
But I can't do both of
them at the same time.

145
00:09:10.250 --> 00:09:15.220
And what about the fact that,
here I am working in mainframe and

146
00:09:15.220 --> 00:09:18.810
the server guys might actually
have a similar skill set to me.

147
00:09:18.810 --> 00:09:24.760
And so they're gonna be duplicating their
work because we're based on activity and

148
00:09:24.760 --> 00:09:26.250
we're based on output.

149
00:09:27.840 --> 00:09:31.850
And look at that bottom bullet point,
the bottom negative point there.

150
00:09:33.210 --> 00:09:37.960
That tells us that we're still not got any
focus on what the customer actually needs.

151
00:09:37.960 --> 00:09:42.680
And actually, that's what we need to have,
so [LAUGH] I jumped on a bit.

152
00:09:42.680 --> 00:09:47.520
We need to have focus on the customer,
or focus on that value delivery.

153
00:09:49.190 --> 00:09:53.420
So we might have organizational
structures that are process-built.

154
00:09:53.420 --> 00:09:57.906
And organizational structures that are
process-built are those structures that

155
00:09:57.906 --> 00:10:04.120
are incident management, and
problem management, and change management,

156
00:10:04.120 --> 00:10:06.600
and releasing deployment management,
and so on and so forth.

157
00:10:06.600 --> 00:10:10.449
And you end up with
potentially 26 different teams.

158
00:10:11.915 --> 00:10:15.835
You won't have that
duplication in activity,

159
00:10:15.835 --> 00:10:21.911
you shouldn't have that reinventing
the wheel that happens sometimes,

160
00:10:21.911 --> 00:10:25.270
but it's still going to promote silos.

161
00:10:25.270 --> 00:10:28.888
We looked, in the previous session,
at incident management and

162
00:10:28.888 --> 00:10:33.561
problem management and we actually did a
separate session looking at the difference

163
00:10:33.561 --> 00:10:38.260
is between them but also the relationships
between incidents and problems.

164
00:10:38.260 --> 00:10:42.090
And can you imagine if there
is a siloed environment

165
00:10:42.090 --> 00:10:45.510
where we organize by incident management,
and problem management.

166
00:10:45.510 --> 00:10:47.290
Can you imagine the conflict between them?

167
00:10:48.910 --> 00:10:53.490
Just think, the incident management
team will want to get out that tape and

168
00:10:53.490 --> 00:10:56.140
will want to restore service
as quickly as possible.

169
00:10:56.140 --> 00:11:00.700
But the problem, management team will be
fighting to actually stop anybody from

170
00:11:00.700 --> 00:11:05.210
using the tape because they want to watch
it happen again to see what's causing it.

171
00:11:06.450 --> 00:11:08.150
There's going to be a huge conflict and

172
00:11:08.150 --> 00:11:12.150
there's going to be a conflict
between a lot of these processes.

173
00:11:12.150 --> 00:11:14.340
I always look at,
when we look at conflict,

174
00:11:14.340 --> 00:11:16.750
I look at configuration management.

175
00:11:16.750 --> 00:11:19.500
And configuration management,
and I've said previously,

176
00:11:20.530 --> 00:11:26.480
the configuration management system
underpins all other processes.

177
00:11:26.480 --> 00:11:28.213
So let's think about the service desk.

178
00:11:28.213 --> 00:11:31.280
And the service desk has a role to

179
00:11:31.280 --> 00:11:35.590
ensure that we can restore normal serve
operation as quickly as possible.

180
00:11:35.590 --> 00:11:40.230
But when they answer the telephone
the first thing that they ask is, well,

181
00:11:40.230 --> 00:11:45.240
I think, in previous session I asked
Ronnie for his name and his user ID, etc.

182
00:11:45.240 --> 00:11:48.995
And by taking his name and his user ID,
they were able to input it into the call

183
00:11:48.995 --> 00:11:52.495
logging system and
it brought up all of the details.

184
00:11:52.495 --> 00:11:56.475
Now one of the things that we've got
to rely on is that service desk having

185
00:11:56.475 --> 00:11:59.845
the ability to be able
to update those details.

186
00:11:59.845 --> 00:12:02.375
So when they ask Ronnie
what PC he's got and

187
00:12:02.375 --> 00:12:04.982
he tells them that he's
got a different PC now.

188
00:12:04.982 --> 00:12:11.582
They need to be able to update the details
in the configuration management system.

189
00:12:11.582 --> 00:12:16.215
Because it's the purpose of configuration
management to maintain accurate and

190
00:12:16.215 --> 00:12:17.652
reliable information.

191
00:12:17.652 --> 00:12:22.578
But can you imagine how efficient we
wouldn't be if configuration management,

192
00:12:22.578 --> 00:12:26.128
as a process, turned around
to the service desk and said,

193
00:12:26.128 --> 00:12:29.619
you are not allowed to update
our database, it's ours.

194
00:12:29.619 --> 00:12:35.270
Yeah, there'd be no efficiencies, and
we'd not have accurate information either.

195
00:12:36.530 --> 00:12:40.140
So that approach,
the process approach, creates silos.

196
00:12:40.140 --> 00:12:41.290
It doesn't break them down.

197
00:12:42.300 --> 00:12:45.520
Now certain processes
need to be kept separate.

198
00:12:45.520 --> 00:12:48.328
Things like financial management and
security management.

199
00:12:48.328 --> 00:12:52.800
Yeah, we wanna keep them separate
because they're very, very specialized.

200
00:12:52.800 --> 00:12:56.080
And, in fact, it's mentioned there that
assets and configuration management,

201
00:12:56.080 --> 00:13:00.210
we have to have
a particular focus on that.

202
00:13:00.210 --> 00:13:03.120
But nevertheless, it shouldn't
be kept completely separate from

203
00:13:03.120 --> 00:13:07.290
the other processes, and even financial
management and security management

204
00:13:07.290 --> 00:13:09.780
shouldn't be completely separate
from all the other processes.

205
00:13:11.740 --> 00:13:16.100
So you'll notice that as we move through
and we get into the geography and

206
00:13:16.100 --> 00:13:19.440
the hybrid,
you'll see that actually these particular

207
00:13:20.920 --> 00:13:23.890
organizational charts are growing.

208
00:13:23.890 --> 00:13:25.530
In other words, it's an evolution.

209
00:13:25.530 --> 00:13:30.040
And as an organization grows,
then it's quite natural for

210
00:13:30.040 --> 00:13:32.170
an organization to evolve.

211
00:13:33.170 --> 00:13:38.373
We can organize by geography, and
organizing by geography means that

212
00:13:38.373 --> 00:13:44.210
we've got processes and we've got
activities in each particular location.

213
00:13:44.210 --> 00:13:46.105
That's great.

214
00:13:46.105 --> 00:13:50.509
But look at that second bullet point
with a minus symbol next to it,

215
00:13:50.509 --> 00:13:54.035
multiple duplication of roles and
activities.

216
00:13:54.035 --> 00:13:58.415
We're not just reinventing the wheel,
we're completing ripping it up and

217
00:13:58.415 --> 00:14:01.895
then we're starting again
in every single location.

218
00:14:01.895 --> 00:14:03.915
We're smashing it to pieces.

219
00:14:03.915 --> 00:14:09.522
And so, we end up with four different
versions of incident management and

220
00:14:09.522 --> 00:14:12.922
four different versions of
problem management, and

221
00:14:12.922 --> 00:14:15.362
four different versions
of change management.

222
00:14:15.362 --> 00:14:17.442
There is no consistency.

223
00:14:17.442 --> 00:14:22.222
And what about services that
are shared right across that geography,

224
00:14:22.222 --> 00:14:24.642
like our network, for instance.

225
00:14:24.642 --> 00:14:25.902
Who takes ownership of that?

226
00:14:27.290 --> 00:14:29.580
And, again,
are we focusing on our customer here and

227
00:14:29.580 --> 00:14:31.640
what's delivering value to our customer?

228
00:14:31.640 --> 00:14:35.420
Or are we focusing on the,
how should we say,

229
00:14:35.420 --> 00:14:39.730
the competition between our
geographical locations?

230
00:14:41.120 --> 00:14:46.090
It looks to me like that particular
structure could lend itself to focus

231
00:14:46.090 --> 00:14:48.639
on the competition between
geographical locations.

232
00:14:50.360 --> 00:14:55.702
Ideally, what we want to
really aim towards is a hybrid

233
00:14:55.702 --> 00:14:59.990
structure, which allows for
combined functions

234
00:14:59.990 --> 00:15:05.205
where the functional areas are defined
to meet the needs of the organization.

235
00:15:05.205 --> 00:15:07.215
So its a mixture of everything.

236
00:15:07.215 --> 00:15:11.255
It could be,
if we look at the basis of that structure,

237
00:15:11.255 --> 00:15:15.480
it seems to be based on
functional structure.

238
00:15:15.480 --> 00:15:20.056
But it's not, because we have functional
and we have a mixture of geographical in

239
00:15:20.056 --> 00:15:23.190
there and we have a mixture
of activity based, as well.

240
00:15:24.470 --> 00:15:29.470
So the idea here is,
that we have dedicated functionality

241
00:15:29.470 --> 00:15:33.630
in the areas that we need
dedicated functionality.

242
00:15:33.630 --> 00:15:36.600
But we don't have a duplication
of activities, and

243
00:15:36.600 --> 00:15:39.430
we don't have a duplication of processes.

244
00:15:39.430 --> 00:15:44.854
So we still have consistency,
we still have structure,

245
00:15:44.854 --> 00:15:49.880
and we still have a focus
on delivery of services.

246
00:15:49.880 --> 00:15:52.680
This allows us to manage shared services,
and

247
00:15:52.680 --> 00:15:58.030
allows us to manage our shared
components such as our infrastructure.

248
00:15:59.570 --> 00:16:05.250
This structure can be hard to manage.

249
00:16:05.250 --> 00:16:07.840
Can be,
if we don't have the right skills, okay?

250
00:16:09.130 --> 00:16:14.720
And so it's very, very important that
the management that are responsible for

251
00:16:14.720 --> 00:16:18.240
this structure have the right skills and

252
00:16:18.240 --> 00:16:22.480
the right experience to be able
to manage in this environment.

253
00:16:22.480 --> 00:16:28.120
Now at this point in time,
you have a case study exercise which

254
00:16:29.460 --> 00:16:34.870
looks at organizational structures
within service operation.

255
00:16:34.870 --> 00:16:39.740
And what we'd like you to do right
now is to spend 30 minutes looking

256
00:16:39.740 --> 00:16:44.840
at that exercise and analyzing,
given the case structure, what you would

257
00:16:44.840 --> 00:16:50.760
consider to be the best structure for
that organization within the case study.

258
00:16:50.760 --> 00:16:54.910
If you have any questions or
any challenges, then please

259
00:16:54.910 --> 00:16:59.306
log on to our forum, let us know and
we'll be only too happy to help you.

260
00:16:59.306 --> 00:17:03.610
>> All right Jo, well,
thank you again for helping us out as we

261
00:17:03.610 --> 00:17:07.280
start to take a look at the idea of
the organization management here.

262
00:17:07.280 --> 00:17:12.440
Very key that we get these concepts
down as our organization grows,

263
00:17:12.440 --> 00:17:17.150
as our organization changes,
to know exactly what we want in place or

264
00:17:17.150 --> 00:17:19.780
at least what we need to have in place,
as well.

265
00:17:19.780 --> 00:17:23.290
That's also a great place for
us to sign off then for this episode.

266
00:17:23.290 --> 00:17:26.270
For ITProTV, I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

267
00:17:26.270 --> 00:17:27.300
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

268
00:17:27.300 --> 00:17:32.125
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation shows.

269
00:17:32.125 --> 00:17:38.043
[MUSIC]

270
00:17:38.043 --> 00:17:41.531
>> Thank you for watching, ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo, take a look at using tools and technology to facilitate all the of the relevant service operation process.  Jo describes the goal is to have all the tools and technology that supports the core functionality so the SLA targets can be met through the process capability.  Obtaining these tools and technology may be based on the MoSCoW (must have, should have, could have and wont have) prioritization for example, says Jo.  She reminds us that all tools must have relevance to the overall value to the organization.
episodes.title: Technology Considerations
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:01.290
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.290 --> 00:00:04.980
I'm your host, Don Pezet coming at you
live from San Francisco, California.

3
00:00:04.980 --> 00:00:07.140
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:07.140 --> 00:00:08.359
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.359 --> 00:00:12.580
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.580 --> 00:00:15.190
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.190 --> 00:00:19.970
You're watching the ITIL
Intermediate Service Operation show.

8
00:00:19.970 --> 00:00:21.570
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and

9
00:00:21.570 --> 00:00:25.380
today, we're taking a look at
technology considerations specifically,

10
00:00:25.380 --> 00:00:29.940
diving into some of the different tools
and technology that we have to understand.

11
00:00:29.940 --> 00:00:34.560
And here to help us, of course, is gonna
be our ITIL virtuoso herself, Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:34.560 --> 00:00:36.220
Jo, Welcome back to the show.

13
00:00:36.220 --> 00:00:37.370
>> Thank you for having me, Ronnie.

14
00:00:37.370 --> 00:00:38.320
How are you?

15
00:00:38.320 --> 00:00:39.320
>> I am doing great.

16
00:00:39.320 --> 00:00:42.910
Now, we're moving into this idea
of technology considerations.

17
00:00:42.910 --> 00:00:47.980
We've talked a lot in just the last few
episodes to make sure that we're kind

18
00:00:47.980 --> 00:00:51.060
of gathering all of our ducks in a row,
making sure we've got everything here.

19
00:00:51.060 --> 00:00:53.825
What are we taking a look at here
in this idea of the technology?

20
00:00:53.825 --> 00:00:58.110
>> So like you say, in a lot of our
previous episodes, we have talked at

21
00:00:58.110 --> 00:01:03.040
great lengths about the processes that
exist within service operation and

22
00:01:03.040 --> 00:01:06.905
we've looked at the activities that
are undertaken as part of those processes.

23
00:01:06.905 --> 00:01:11.025
And we even looked at the people in the
skills that performed those activities.

24
00:01:11.025 --> 00:01:13.965
So now what we're going to do is
we're going to look at the tools that

25
00:01:13.965 --> 00:01:16.645
are going to help us with
all of those activities.

26
00:01:16.645 --> 00:01:20.015
So we're not necessarily looking
at the services themselves,

27
00:01:20.015 --> 00:01:23.215
we're looking at the tools
that we use within IT

28
00:01:23.215 --> 00:01:28.110
to support the activities and
to support the services.

29
00:01:28.110 --> 00:01:31.969
>> All right so Jo again,
taking a look at it from my perspective,

30
00:01:31.969 --> 00:01:35.300
not being in really in depth into ITIL.

31
00:01:36.860 --> 00:01:40.140
As we started talking about service
operation and providing a value to

32
00:01:40.140 --> 00:01:44.815
the customer I'm not seeing the connection
where tools help to provide a value for

33
00:01:44.815 --> 00:01:46.815
the customer, so help me out here.

34
00:01:46.815 --> 00:01:47.315
>> Okay.

35
00:01:47.315 --> 00:01:50.365
Well, let's look at this
from a logical perspective.

36
00:01:50.365 --> 00:01:54.815

against the front end,

268
00:16:12.232 --> 00:16:14.291
however that front end is displayed.

269
00:16:14.291 --> 00:16:19.821
Whether it's on the Internet, whether
it's via text message alerts to the user,

270
00:16:19.821 --> 00:16:22.120
or whether it's via a mobile app.

271
00:16:23.490 --> 00:16:26.610
We definitely need to have integration
into the Known Error Database,

272
00:16:26.610 --> 00:16:29.800
too, because they're gonna
give us our workarounds

273
00:16:29.800 --> 00:16:33.880
that will allow us to identify
how we restore service.

274
00:16:33.880 --> 00:16:36.680
Remember, we're not interested
in resolving problems here.

275
00:16:36.680 --> 00:16:39.562
We're interested in restoring service.

276
00:16:39.562 --> 00:16:43.290
So databases gonna tell
us where to find the tape

277
00:16:43.290 --> 00:16:44.710
to put the piece of paper together.

278
00:16:46.290 --> 00:16:50.160
Now, I expect to see request fulfillment
performed in exactly the same tool as

279
00:16:50.160 --> 00:16:54.220
incident management, because we need to
be able to link requests to events or

280
00:16:54.220 --> 00:16:54.820
to incidents.

281
00:16:54.820 --> 00:16:58.520
And again, we need to have that
integration into the front end,

282
00:16:58.520 --> 00:17:01.010
into that self-help.

283
00:17:01.010 --> 00:17:05.350
We're gonna be doing pretty much the same
type of workflow as incident management

284
00:17:05.350 --> 00:17:10.230
does, so it makes sense to have
it all in exactly the same tool.

285
00:17:10.230 --> 00:17:15.080
And of course, all of these tools,
all of these processes produce reports, so

286
00:17:15.080 --> 00:17:18.410
we need to have the right
level of reporting.

287
00:17:18.410 --> 00:17:22.020
Now, one thing I do wanna say about
reporting, while I mentioned it.

288
00:17:22.020 --> 00:17:26.960
Just because a tool delivers
500 reports out of the box

289
00:17:26.960 --> 00:17:28.775
does not mean that that's
the tool you pick.

290
00:17:28.775 --> 00:17:31.385
>> [LAUGH]
>> I mean, I said previously, Ronnie

291
00:17:31.385 --> 00:17:36.860
laughs because I said previously we're
terrible in IT for reporting just for

292
00:17:36.860 --> 00:17:42.090
the sake of reporting, having a nice,
pretty picture just because it's there.

293
00:17:42.090 --> 00:17:46.190
No, reports have to be relevant, okay?

294
00:17:46.190 --> 00:17:51.640
So we don't do reporting just for
the sake of having reports, okay?

295
00:17:51.640 --> 00:17:53.330
All reports have to be relevant.

296
00:17:53.330 --> 00:17:55.485
If a tool says it's got
500 out of the box,

297
00:17:55.485 --> 00:17:58.395
I'll guarantee that 499 of them,
you won't need.

298
00:17:58.395 --> 00:18:01.485
>> [LAUGH]
>> So problem management.

299
00:18:01.485 --> 00:18:04.830
Pretty much exactly the same
as incident management, okay?

300
00:18:04.830 --> 00:18:07.470
We've gotta have the same relationships.

301
00:18:07.470 --> 00:18:11.080
We've gotta relate to incident records and

302
00:18:11.080 --> 00:18:15.090
to known errors, and
to requests, also to events.

303
00:18:15.090 --> 00:18:19.330
We've got to be able to relate to
configuration items through the CMS.

304
00:18:19.330 --> 00:18:22.520
And we've also got to be
able to raise changes.

305
00:18:22.520 --> 00:18:25.870
Now, the bottom bullet point on this
one is really important because that

306
00:18:25.870 --> 00:18:30.370
bottom bullet point looks at the ability
to integrate with third parties.

307
00:18:30.370 --> 00:18:34.030
Quite often our problems
are sent out to suppliers.

308
00:18:34.030 --> 00:18:39.090
So we have to be able to integrate that
problem record with supplier software.

309
00:18:39.090 --> 00:18:42.960
And we have to be able to get
updates from supplier software.

310
00:18:42.960 --> 00:18:47.150
And don't forget, with problem
management we've also got to escalate

311
00:18:48.310 --> 00:18:52.770
to the suppliers, and
notify our end users at the same time.

312
00:18:52.770 --> 00:18:55.260
So think about that messaging.

313
00:18:55.260 --> 00:18:58.050
How do we do the notification
to our users as well?

314
00:18:59.080 --> 00:19:02.100
And then access management is
a slightly different beast,

315
00:19:02.100 --> 00:19:06.710
although we still gotta log
the requests via request fulfillment.

316
00:19:06.710 --> 00:19:12.690
But we have to have some
integration into our HR databases.

317
00:19:12.690 --> 00:19:17.080
We have to be able to verify,
if you remember when we looked at

318
00:19:17.080 --> 00:19:22.025
the access management process,
we had to be able to verify that that

319
00:19:22.025 --> 00:19:26.950
person is who they say they are, and
that that person should have access to

320
00:19:26.950 --> 00:19:32.200
that particular piece of software or
that particular service.

321
00:19:32.200 --> 00:19:34.270
So we have to have some
integration into HR okay?

322
00:19:34.270 --> 00:19:38.090
We have to have integration into

323
00:19:38.090 --> 00:19:40.990
change management because we have
to be able to raise changes.

324
00:19:40.990 --> 00:19:45.720
And we have to have integration into
request fulfillment because it's a request

325
00:19:45.720 --> 00:19:48.040
that we receive to request access.

326
00:19:48.040 --> 00:19:53.310
And of course,
because we are updating access and we're

327
00:19:53.310 --> 00:19:58.640
updating people's user profiles, then
we've got to have access to that software.

328
00:19:58.640 --> 00:20:02.880
So, something like
Microsoft Active Directory, etc.,

329
00:20:02.880 --> 00:20:05.830
will allow us that integration.

330
00:20:05.830 --> 00:20:10.700
And then, last but no means least
in this particular section here,

331
00:20:10.700 --> 00:20:12.350
we're going to look at
the service desk tools.

332
00:20:13.900 --> 00:20:14.790
Now, the service desk.

333
00:20:14.790 --> 00:20:17.110
We've already talked about
incident management, and

334
00:20:17.110 --> 00:20:20.450
we've talked about requests fulfillment,
etc., and

335
00:20:20.450 --> 00:20:24.780
we know about things like the known-error
database and the self-help interface.

336
00:20:24.780 --> 00:20:29.130
But don't forget the things that the
service desk needs to be able to function.

337
00:20:29.130 --> 00:20:36.100
Like a call queuing system or what we call
an ACD, which is a call queuing system.

338
00:20:36.100 --> 00:20:40.720
Think about tools that provide
us with voice over IP or

339
00:20:40.720 --> 00:20:43.225
an CTI, the customer telephony interface.

340
00:20:43.225 --> 00:20:51.190
Now it's not unusual for us to
receive a telephone call from a user.

341
00:20:51.190 --> 00:20:56.440
And actually, what we'd really like on
a service desk is when we receive it,

342
00:20:56.440 --> 00:21:00.880
our service, our system that we have,
recognizes that phone number and

343
00:21:00.880 --> 00:21:03.670
immediately populates our database and

344
00:21:03.670 --> 00:21:06.610
gives us all of the information
about that person.

345
00:21:06.610 --> 00:21:09.720
And we think to ourselves, well,
that would be fantastical, wouldn't it?

346
00:21:09.720 --> 00:21:10.280
But you know what?

347
00:21:10.280 --> 00:21:13.010
That's a reality for
most service desks nowadays.

348
00:21:14.170 --> 00:21:18.490
But I wanna ask you a question
while we're still on the subject of

349
00:21:18.490 --> 00:21:20.870
service desk technology.

350
00:21:20.870 --> 00:21:26.201
So when you call a service desk, Ronnie,
and you get one of those messages that say

351
00:21:26.201 --> 00:21:31.780
if you'd like help with this, press one,
if you'd like help with this, press two.

352
00:21:31.780 --> 00:21:35.070
The fact that you're laughing,
tells me everything.

353
00:21:35.070 --> 00:21:39.409
How many layers do you go down before
you give up and hang up the phone?

354
00:21:40.700 --> 00:21:42.300
>> Normally I just press one and

355
00:21:42.300 --> 00:21:46.660
if I get a whole list that goes
one through nine, I hang up.

356
00:21:46.660 --> 00:21:47.200
>> Right.
>> Yeah.

357
00:21:47.200 --> 00:21:50.810
>> Okay, so the average is three.

358
00:21:50.810 --> 00:21:51.730
>> Well that's not bad.

359
00:21:51.730 --> 00:21:54.600
>> It's not bad at all is it
because I'm with you on this one.

360
00:21:54.600 --> 00:21:56.440
I have no patience for this.

361
00:21:56.440 --> 00:21:58.390
The average is three.

362
00:21:58.390 --> 00:22:01.625
Most people will hang up
after three of those options.

363
00:22:01.625 --> 00:22:02.420
>> Okay.

364
00:22:02.420 --> 00:22:05.260
>> Either that, or they'll start
shouting operator at the phone, or

365
00:22:05.260 --> 00:22:07.220
keep pressing zero until
they get somewhere.

366
00:22:08.490 --> 00:22:11.390
But we tell people when we're advising and

367
00:22:11.390 --> 00:22:15.890
consulting a service desk,
think about your users.

368
00:22:15.890 --> 00:22:18.100
And you know what,
if you need to survey your users,

369
00:22:18.100 --> 00:22:21.340
then survey them and
ask them how they feel about this.

370
00:22:21.340 --> 00:22:22.790
Because these options are great,

371
00:22:22.790 --> 00:22:25.980
especially when we talk about
specialized service desks.

372
00:22:25.980 --> 00:22:32.290
And so having a routine to specialize the
areas where we've got specialized support

373
00:22:32.290 --> 00:22:36.410
on hand that can resolve their issues
there and then for them, then great.

374
00:22:36.410 --> 00:22:38.315
But if you get more than three layers?

375
00:22:38.315 --> 00:22:41.420
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, we all hang up, right?

376
00:22:41.420 --> 00:22:46.410
The key thing when you remember
technology is to remember relevance.

377
00:22:46.410 --> 00:22:50.830
Your technology and
your tools have to meet your needs.

378
00:22:53.000 --> 00:22:58.190
We don't buy something as a tool just
because it looks good on the box.

379
00:22:58.190 --> 00:23:02.400
We need to give it a try, and
it has to meet our needs.

380
00:23:02.400 --> 00:23:06.840
Most of all, it's got to deliver value
to the service, to the business, sorry.

381
00:23:06.840 --> 00:23:10.020
And like we've already said,
if it's got more than three layers,

382
00:23:10.020 --> 00:23:13.400
it's not gonna deliver value,
it's delivering a hindrance.

383
00:23:13.400 --> 00:23:15.420
And that's certainly how they see it.

384
00:23:15.420 --> 00:23:17.570
So with every tool, think relevance.

385
00:23:17.570 --> 00:23:22.020
And think about whether it'll
make your customers and

386
00:23:22.020 --> 00:23:25.314
your users happy if we employ this tool.

387
00:23:25.314 --> 00:23:27.910
>> All right, Jo, well,
thank you again for

388
00:23:27.910 --> 00:23:32.673
reminding us how valuable the technology
really is throughout the entirety of

389
00:23:32.673 --> 00:23:35.190
every part of the ITIL life cycle.

390
00:23:35.190 --> 00:23:39.300
It really does help us to facilitate and
to provide that effective and

391
00:23:39.300 --> 00:23:41.690
the efficiency that we need
to be able to provide,

392
00:23:41.690 --> 00:23:46.090
of course, the value to our businesses
that we will be serving as well.

393
00:23:46.090 --> 00:23:49.380
Well, that's a great place for
us to end this episode then.

394
00:23:49.380 --> 00:23:53.030
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

395
00:23:53.030 --> 00:23:54.170
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

396
00:23:54.170 --> 00:23:58.860
>> Stay tuned right here for more
ITIL Intermediate Service Operation shows.

397
00:23:58.860 --> 00:24:04.718
[MUSIC]

398
00:24:04.718 --> 00:24:07.990
>> Thank you for watching, IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss the implementation and challenges to service operations. As organizational change is constant, there is a need to implement service operation well, Jo says.  This can be achieved if we do not look at service operation as being another added silo team but as partners in the whole of the IT infrastructure, according to Jo.  She also discusses some of the different challenges and risks that come with implementation.
episodes.title: Implementation and Challenges
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.359
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.359 --> 00:00:06.504
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.504 --> 00:00:08.221
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.221 --> 00:00:11.938
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.938 --> 00:00:15.021
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.021 --> 00:00:19.102
You're watching the ITIL,
Intermediate Service Operation Show.

7
00:00:19.102 --> 00:00:21.669
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today,

8
00:00:21.669 --> 00:00:25.510
we're jumping into implementation and
challenges.

9
00:00:25.510 --> 00:00:28.450
And here to help us once
again is going to be well,

10
00:00:28.450 --> 00:00:32.850
our master blaster herself in ITIL,
Miss Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:32.850 --> 00:00:34.210
Jo, welcome back to the show.

12
00:00:34.210 --> 00:00:35.860
>> Thank you very much for
having me, Ronnie.

13
00:00:35.860 --> 00:00:36.560
How are you today?

14
00:00:36.560 --> 00:00:41.972
>> I am doing great, as we start to take
a look here at the idea of implementation,

15
00:00:41.972 --> 00:00:44.640
and of course, the challenges.

16
00:00:44.640 --> 00:00:47.490
This sounds like a pretty big area for
us to cover.

17
00:00:47.490 --> 00:00:50.245
So, what do we need to do,
and how do we begin?

18
00:00:50.245 --> 00:00:54.432
>> Well, what we're going to be
looking at in this section here is

19
00:00:54.432 --> 00:00:57.665
the implementation of service operation.

20
00:00:57.665 --> 00:01:01.625
And also the challenges we
faced during service operation.

21
00:01:01.625 --> 00:01:07.105
And, we quite often don't think about,
certainly, the challenges that we face.

22
00:01:07.105 --> 00:01:11.610
We tend to go into service operation
believing that everything is going to work

23
00:01:11.610 --> 00:01:14.210
absolutely great ,and
everything's going to be fine.

24
00:01:14.210 --> 00:01:17.470
And not really taking into consideration
the fact that things can happen [LAUGH].

25
00:01:17.470 --> 00:01:18.260
>> Right.

26
00:01:18.260 --> 00:01:19.890
>> And things do go wrong.

27
00:01:19.890 --> 00:01:22.573
I think there's a saying,
something along those lines, but

28
00:01:22.573 --> 00:01:24.337
nothing I could repeat right now [LAUGH].

29
00:01:24.337 --> 00:01:27.297
So, we have to understand that
there are other challenges.

30
00:01:27.297 --> 00:01:32.036
And if we're proactive, and I know
that we've mentioned that word in so

31
00:01:32.036 --> 00:01:33.753
many previous sessions.

32
00:01:33.753 --> 00:01:37.977
But if we're proactive in
identifying challenges, and

33
00:01:37.977 --> 00:01:42.240
then looking for
ways to overcome those challenges.

34
00:01:42.240 --> 00:01:45.195
Then, actually we will be more
efficient and more effective, and

35
00:01:45.195 --> 00:01:46.636
deliver value to the business.

36
00:01:46.636 --> 00:01:52.360
>> All right Jo, sounds like a great
opportunity for us, so let's begin.

37
00:01:52.360 --> 00:01:53.520
How are we gonna start?

38
00:01:53.520 --> 00:01:58.550
>> Well, the first thing that we need to
accept is the fact that change happens.

39
00:01:58.550 --> 00:02:02.170
You hear lots of sayings about
the only thing that's certain in life

40
00:02:02.170 --> 00:02:03.190
are death and taxes.

41
00:02:03.190 --> 00:02:05.421
Well, actually there are three
things that are certain in life.

42
00:02:05.421 --> 00:02:09.031
And the third one is that,
things are never gonna stay the same.

43
00:02:09.031 --> 00:02:15.370
And I know that it sounds so
obvious, but it is so obvious.

44
00:02:15.370 --> 00:02:18.981
Your business is never going
to stay exactly the same.

45
00:02:18.981 --> 00:02:24.697
The organization, even though it may have
the same direction, it will still change.

46
00:02:24.697 --> 00:02:29.237
We have three different types of
strategy that we look at from a very,

47
00:02:29.237 --> 00:02:30.898
very high level in ITIL.

48
00:02:30.898 --> 00:02:36.150
And the first one is the strategy of
just simply run into the business.

49
00:02:36.150 --> 00:02:38.410
Just simply maintaining the status quo.

50
00:02:38.410 --> 00:02:41.780
In some organizations,
like government departments for instance,

51
00:02:41.780 --> 00:02:43.220
are a perfect example.

52
00:02:43.220 --> 00:02:45.721
They don't want to grow,
they don't want to do anything different.

53
00:02:45.721 --> 00:02:49.230
They simply want to
maintain the status quo.

54
00:02:49.230 --> 00:02:54.330
Another strategy used are strategies for
organizations that want to grow.

55
00:02:54.330 --> 00:02:57.440
And organizations that want to grow
are looking to increase their profit.

56
00:02:57.440 --> 00:02:59.650
They're looking to increase market share.

57
00:02:59.650 --> 00:03:04.590
They're looking to increase
perhaps their size, as well.

58
00:03:04.590 --> 00:03:08.490
And so, those organizations obviously,
well, we consider innovational, and

59
00:03:08.490 --> 00:03:11.170
we consider those types of organizations.

60
00:03:11.170 --> 00:03:13.500
Then we've got the complete extreme,

61
00:03:13.500 --> 00:03:16.630
which are the organizations
that want to transform.

62
00:03:16.630 --> 00:03:20.150
And these are organizations
that will completely diversify

63
00:03:20.150 --> 00:03:21.900
outside of their industry sector.

64
00:03:23.190 --> 00:03:26.391
And we've got a lot of organizations in
the world where every time they grow,

65
00:03:26.391 --> 00:03:28.174
they do something completely different.

66
00:03:28.174 --> 00:03:31.539
I think of one organization,
Virgin, for instance,

67
00:03:31.539 --> 00:03:36.180
where every time they grow,
it's something completely different.

68
00:03:36.180 --> 00:03:39.500
From aircraft to aerospace,

69
00:03:39.500 --> 00:03:45.220
to fiber optic communication,
to cell phones, to credit cards.

70
00:03:45.220 --> 00:03:47.270
Every time they expand, and

71
00:03:47.270 --> 00:03:51.940
even though they may do that
by acquisition or by merger.

72
00:03:51.940 --> 00:03:56.190
But every time they expand,
they do something completely different.

73
00:03:56.190 --> 00:03:59.968
But you know, even those organizations
that just want to simply run the business,

74
00:03:59.968 --> 00:04:03.520
the ones who maintain the status quo,
have got to change.

75
00:04:03.520 --> 00:04:07.180
Let's face it, Windows 95 is not
gonna be around forever, nor

76
00:04:07.180 --> 00:04:08.910
is it going to be supported forever.

77
00:04:08.910 --> 00:04:11.490
So, we have to change.

78
00:04:11.490 --> 00:04:14.170
So change is the only constant.

79
00:04:14.170 --> 00:04:15.680
We have to change.

80
00:04:15.680 --> 00:04:20.860
Even when we don't want to, we have to
acknowledge that even if we're not being

81
00:04:20.860 --> 00:04:27.410
proactive and innovative in our support of
the organization, we still have to change.

82
00:04:27.410 --> 00:04:31.370
And for organizations that want to run the
business, then a lot of change triggers,

83
00:04:31.370 --> 00:04:34.570
as we say, come out of service operation.

84
00:04:34.570 --> 00:04:36.620
Because they come as a result of failures.

85
00:04:36.620 --> 00:04:39.534
They come as a result of
you know the problems,

86
00:04:39.534 --> 00:04:42.093
identifying root causes to incidents.

87
00:04:42.093 --> 00:04:47.500
But they also come as a result of supplier
notifications on preventative maintenance.

88
00:04:47.500 --> 00:04:50.590
And as you can see in that
third bullet point down there,

89
00:04:50.590 --> 00:04:53.340
the new upgraded components etc.

90
00:04:53.340 --> 00:04:57.449
And legislative changes,
personnel changes, etc.

91
00:04:57.449 --> 00:05:01.830
So these all trigger changes,
and we're all subject to them.

92
00:05:01.830 --> 00:05:06.680
And it doesn't matter what
the strategy of the organization is,

93
00:05:06.680 --> 00:05:09.835
we all still need to change, okay?

94
00:05:09.835 --> 00:05:13.190
And IT operation staff,
we are conducting that business as usual.

95
00:05:13.190 --> 00:05:14.931
And so we've got to be involved in it.

96
00:05:14.931 --> 00:05:19.499
Right the way through from raising
a change to assessing the change and

97
00:05:19.499 --> 00:05:23.785
evaluating it technically
through to building that change.

98
00:05:23.785 --> 00:05:26.545

00:13:38.460 --> 00:13:42.667
Okay, so then the proctor will come
online, and they will ask you if you're

231
00:13:42.667 --> 00:13:46.899
all ready, and they'll tell you that you
can have a piece of paper and a pen.

232
00:13:46.899 --> 00:13:50.349
And then they will ask to
see around your room, so

233
00:13:50.349 --> 00:13:55.314
you must be in a position where you
can physically pick up your laptop,

234
00:13:55.314 --> 00:13:59.453
and turn it around, so
that the proctor can view the room.

235
00:13:59.453 --> 00:14:02.877
That's to make sure that you don't
have any ITIL books with you,

236
00:14:02.877 --> 00:14:06.114
that you don't have anybody like
me hiding in a corner [LAUGH] or

237
00:14:06.114 --> 00:14:08.247
hiding under your desk helping you out.

238
00:14:08.247 --> 00:14:12.463
And it's also to make sure that
you are completely alone and

239
00:14:12.463 --> 00:14:16.269
can't be interrupted during
that particular test.

240
00:14:16.269 --> 00:14:22.160
At that point in time, the examiner
will ask you to start your test.

241
00:14:22.160 --> 00:14:23.940
You will get 90 minutes.

242
00:14:23.940 --> 00:14:27.470
And to be perfectly honest 90 minutes or
an hour and a half is pretty comfortable.

243
00:14:28.800 --> 00:14:32.890
At the end of your test,
one thing I will tell you,

244
00:14:32.890 --> 00:14:34.160
please don't change your answers.

245
00:14:34.160 --> 00:14:36.780
Go with your gut instinct,
it's generally right.

246
00:14:36.780 --> 00:14:40.160
And to be perfectly honest
in about 75% of cases

247
00:14:40.160 --> 00:14:43.930
the person that changes their answer,
changes it to the wrong one okay.

248
00:14:43.930 --> 00:14:46.371
You wanna weigh in for
about 10 minutes per question.

249
00:14:46.371 --> 00:14:49.426
The average is 11 minutes per question but
aim for ten and

250
00:14:49.426 --> 00:14:53.160
then you feel completely
comfortable with the timings.

251
00:14:53.160 --> 00:14:57.460
At the end of your test,
you will be asked to submit.

252
00:14:57.460 --> 00:15:00.890
And when you finished,
then you click, submit.

253
00:15:00.890 --> 00:15:04.790
At that point in time,
your screen will disappear.

254
00:15:05.810 --> 00:15:09.070
You will be given an intermediate.

255
00:15:09.070 --> 00:15:11.682
I don't like to use that word [LAUGH]
actually when we're talking about ITIL

256
00:15:11.682 --> 00:15:12.510
intermediate.

257
00:15:12.510 --> 00:15:15.010
You'll be given an interim
results there and then.

258
00:15:15.010 --> 00:15:18.910
That interim result will tell you very
simply whether you've passed or failed.

259
00:15:18.910 --> 00:15:21.740
You're not gonna be able to get
anything more than that out of it okay?

260
00:15:21.740 --> 00:15:24.210
That's all you're going to
get is just a pass or fail.

261
00:15:24.210 --> 00:15:28.190
Because it has to be independently audited
before they can release the result

262
00:15:28.190 --> 00:15:29.420
to you okay?

263
00:15:29.420 --> 00:15:32.180
So you'll get your interim
result immediately.

264
00:15:32.180 --> 00:15:37.300
And then you'll get your real result
with your score within a week okay?

265
00:15:38.480 --> 00:15:41.450
I wanna just draw your attention
to that bottom bullet point there,

266
00:15:41.450 --> 00:15:42.620
just before we move on.

267
00:15:42.620 --> 00:15:46.260
If you're struggling with a question,
move on and come back to it.

268
00:15:46.260 --> 00:15:50.140
And just remember, that if you don't
answer a question because you think it's

269
00:15:50.140 --> 00:15:52.110
to difficult,
then you're gonna get zero points.

270
00:15:53.350 --> 00:15:56.657
You've got a 20% chance of
getting a five pointer, and

271
00:15:56.657 --> 00:16:01.960
you've got a 50% chance of either getting
five or three, so please answer it, okay?

272
00:16:01.960 --> 00:16:04.860
Don't just leave it blank,
always answer a question.

273
00:16:06.190 --> 00:16:11.370
Right, I think I've probably given
you enough exam tips for now.

274
00:16:11.370 --> 00:16:13.290
Now it's your turn, okay.

275
00:16:13.290 --> 00:16:16.040
What I want you to do now
is I want you to go, and

276
00:16:16.040 --> 00:16:19.320
I want you to download sample paper one.

277
00:16:19.320 --> 00:16:24.080
And then I want you to do sample paper
one including the scenario booklet and

278
00:16:24.080 --> 00:16:25.620
the question booklet.

279
00:16:25.620 --> 00:16:27.600
I want you to do that now.

280
00:16:28.640 --> 00:16:32.878
And then we're gonna comeback and we're
gonna go through that question booklet.

281
00:16:32.878 --> 00:16:36.790
Now, you notice that with this particular
booklet, with sample paper one.

282
00:16:36.790 --> 00:16:38.992
You've got answers and
you've got rationale,

283
00:16:38.992 --> 00:16:42.009
in other words that's the reason why,
that's the five pointer.

284
00:16:42.009 --> 00:16:45.057
The reason why this one is
the three pointer okay.

285
00:16:45.057 --> 00:16:51.110
But for the moment, what I want us to do,
is I want us to come back.

286
00:16:51.110 --> 00:16:53.780
When you finish that exam,
I want us to come back and

287
00:16:53.780 --> 00:16:57.600
I want us to go through that text, okay.

288
00:16:57.600 --> 00:17:00.790
And then, you'll see how you did.

289
00:17:00.790 --> 00:17:03.650
And don't forget,
we've got a forum available to us and now,

290
00:17:03.650 --> 00:17:07.180
more than anything else, is when you
really want to be using that forum.

291
00:17:07.180 --> 00:17:11.687
Just to answer questions, etc,
as we run through that test.

292
00:17:11.687 --> 00:17:14.340
So good luck.

293
00:17:14.340 --> 00:17:16.240
Have fun with your sample paper.

294
00:17:16.240 --> 00:17:20.750
Remember, read the full question,
read the full scenario.

295
00:17:20.750 --> 00:17:23.640
Every word counts, check for relevance.

296
00:17:23.640 --> 00:17:25.300
And don't make assumptions.

297
00:17:25.300 --> 00:17:27.318
And I'll see you when
you finish your test.

298
00:17:28.661 --> 00:17:30.895
>> All right, Jo, well thank you again for

299
00:17:30.895 --> 00:17:33.680
helping us out in those
different exam tips.

300
00:17:33.680 --> 00:17:36.010
But remember that now is the time for,
of course,

301
00:17:36.010 --> 00:17:40.930
you to download that exam paper and do
exactly as Jo says, and when you get back,

302
00:17:40.930 --> 00:17:44.770
there will be, of course, Jo waiting for
you to review that paper as well.

303
00:17:44.770 --> 00:17:47.000
Well, great place for
us to end this episode then.

304
00:17:47.000 --> 00:17:50.080
For ITProTV, I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

305
00:17:50.080 --> 00:17:51.170
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

306
00:17:51.170 --> 00:17:55.707
>> Come right back for
your exam review with Jo.

307
00:17:55.707 --> 00:18:01.700
[MUSIC]

308
00:18:01.700 --> 00:18:04.637
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Description: The Service Operation intermediate module focuses on the principles, processes, operational activities and functions that enable organizations and individuals to successfully manage how their products and services perform. The SO module focuses on the coordination and execution of activities that enable the ongoing management and operation of the products or services developed or implemented during the service strategy, design and transition phases of the IT Service Lifecycle as well as any technology and support resources that are used to deliver them.

episodes.transcript:

1

three comments at the side of your

00:06:39.530 --> 00:06:42.890
You know what, that's kinda the third

00:07:14.540 --> 00:07:19.700

119
00:07:19.700 --> 00:07:23.440
So let's go back to the question

120
00:07:23.440 --> 00:07:29.340
Which of the following options best

00:07:29.340 --> 00:07:34.740

00:07:34.740 --> 00:07:38.390

00:07:38.390 --> 00:07:43.060

A is your one pointer, so

And D, well D,

Reliance on key personnel
